From an eschatological point of view, the garden of God was to be the seat of the worldwide expansion of God’s dwelling place.”  This movement of gaining that which was lost is reflected in the entire biblical drama and Lister spends the vast majority of his book exploring how the presence of God is revealed in Scripture in relation to salvation history.While this entire book is quite excellent and I truly appreciated the in-depth nature in which Lister digs into the topic of the presence of God, in particular his exegesis and analysis of the Old Testament, the section I found most helpful was his concluding comments on the practical application of the doctrine.  It is one thing to take a look at what God has been up to and quite another to begin to grasp how you as a member of the household of faith are currently playing a part in God’s divine plan to include how His presence works in our lives daily.  Lister correctly notes, “The Spirit – the presence of God in this new act of the redemptive drama – now dwells within us to culminate the objectives of the Lord for his glory and our resultant joy.”  The giving of the Holy Spirit as the first fruits promise of that future eternity in the presence of God is what “makes the Christian life possible.”  Furthermore, Lister rightly avers “The power of the Spirit is the power of redemption and regeneration, for it is by his work of applying Christ’s atonement to us that we are born again and reconciled to the Lord.”Those desiring an excellent biblical and practical theology of the presence of God should make Lister’s book a must read.  Full of sound exegesis and theological insight, this is a book that will provide the reader with a greater understanding of what the presence of God is all about and most importantly, the glorious future that awaits those who are the bride of Christ, the sons of God, those who have been called by God to spend eternity in His holy and wonderful presence.I received this book for free from Crossway Books for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

Dietrich Bonhoeffer is quickly becoming a favorite author of mine.  He was a man who lived in a difficult and pivotal period of the 20th century, dealing first hand with the impact of the Nazi regime in Germany.  Bonhoeffer also saw the acquiescence of the German church to the policies of Hitler.  These and many other events helped to shape Bonhoeffer’s thoughts on the Christian life, specifically on matters of discipleship and what he so rightly labeled as the penchant for many believers to settle for cheap grace.  As part of the excellent Theologians on the Christian Life series, Stephen Nichols examines Bonhoeffer’s life and theology.I have become increasingly interested in the works of Bonhoeffer over the past year.  He was always a figure of church history I felt was a bit neglected.  Given that he was a man who personally dealt with tyranny and its impact on the church, he was of course well suited to speak to what it means to make a stand for matters of truth and to share from his own life thoughts on what being a disciple of Jesus is truly about.Stephen Nichols truly brings to life the underlying importance of Bonhoeffer and the important message he so rightly focused on declaring.  There is a perfect balance in Nichol’s book of exploring Bonhoeffer’s theology as well as digging into the life events that led Bonhoeffer to the positions he so often rooted his works upon.  While reading this book, I felt almost transported back to the period of history Bonhoeffer lived, as Nichols deft ability to draws the reader into both Bonhoeffer the man and Bonhoeffer the theologian.Bonhoeffer loved God first and foremost and closely following that passion for God was a love for the people of God.  Living in Nazi Germany and dealing with the daily choice that existed between succumbing to the will of the state or holding fast to the will of God led Bonhoeffer to coin that marvelous of theological phrases called cheap grace.  For Bonhoeffer, “discipleship means conforming to the image of Christ, which entails suffering.”  Such a concept is far too often lost in today’s search for material blessings.  I appreciated Nichol’s salient note that Bonhoeffer embraced suffering “not because he’s an incurable pessimist or an ascetic, but because suffering drives him to grace.”If you are even remotely interested in the life and theology of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, I highly recommend this book as a valuable entry point into his writings and thoughts.  Nichols does a superb job of capturing who Bonhoeffer was, how his theology was formed in the crucible of suffering, and why we should pay attention to his timeless words on issues such as discipleship, community, and the costliness of grace.I received this book for free from Crossway Books for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

We all communicate each and every day in one form or another. Since we are commanded in Scripture to always be prepared to give an account for the reason we believe, it behooves us to be capable communicators when sharing the hope that is within us, namely the message of the gospel. What better place to study the art of gospel communication that from the words of Jesus. Joe Carter and John Coleman in their helpful book How to Argue Like Jesus: Learning Persuasion from History’s Greatest Communicator, take a look at various methods of communication, reflecting on how Jesus utilized those methods as evidenced in Scripture.There is much to enjoy about this book and the approach taken by the authors. The reader will have to engage a number of concepts and words that could be rather foreign to them initially; however, he authors do a great job of explaining the concepts the present to include examples of what the various elements of communication look like in practice as well as how they are used in Scripture.One thing that is quite noticeable is the authors engage Greek ways of argumentation throughout this book. While it is certainly true that Jesus would have been familiar with the Greek approach to argumentation as evidenced in the Gospel accounts, Jesus also spoke and discussed points using many Jewish and Hebraic ways of thinking as well, an approach that is at times a bit different than how the Greeks would have reasoned through a concept. Given his audience was mainly Jews and while that audience would have been familiar with Greek methodologies of thinking, it would have been good for the authors to engage a bit more with the Hebraic/Jewish way of reasoning, if anything as a point of comparison with Greek thought and to also engage those portions of the Gospels where such an approach occurs.The ability to identify for example syllogisms or logical statements within Scripture is something quite important. Since Scripture is quite logical in how it presents it overall message, following the points God is making in His word in order to get to the underlying point as well as understanding what that underlying point is all about is truly one of the fundamental elements of sound exegesis. Carter and Coleman do a great job of explaining what can be some very difficult philosophical and communication concepts. I also appreciated the repeated caution provided by the authors concerning the use of the various concepts they present. The misuse for example of the reduction ad absurdum can as the authors correctly note can lead to “unreasonable logical jumps, many of which involve so-called psychological continuums” that are highly unlikely.” If we are using Jesus’ words as an example of how to communicate, one must notice how he used these techniques, how far he took them, and why he employed them.One particularly helpful aspect of this book are the case studies included in the final chapter. Case studies are typically helpful as they provide the means to put what one has learned into practice. The authors have selected studies that identify the methodologies they have discussed throughout the book in real life situations. After reading these case studies, the reader will definitely be better prepared to identify the methods of argumentation that Carter and Coleman have presented. Additionally, if the reader takes the time to answer the questions the authors pose at the conclusion of each case study, they will be even more prepared to identify, employ, and correctly utilize for example, pathos, logos, ethos, or the plethora of other techniques discussed in this book as they share the message of the gospel or when they engage others in meaningful conversation, especially conversation related to matters of Scripture.This is a book I highly recommend for all believers. Since we all should be actively engaging those around us with the message of the gospel and the truth of Scripture, understanding and utilizing the methods Jesus himself used is most certainly a good practice to find yourself involved. While the title of this book is how to argue like Jesus, perhaps a better title is how to communicate effectively the truth of Scripture for that is the intent and the message the authors aptly get across to the reader.I received this book for free from Crossway Books for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

Who is Jesus? Seems like such an easy question. He is the Son of God, he came and died on the cross and rose again, and will one day return for His bride. But who is Jesus? Do we really grasp this Messiah, this history altering figure? Are we able to share with the world who Jesus is and why he is far more than just a moral teacher who lived a long time ago? Pastor and author Greg Gilbert in his excellent book aptly titled Who is Jesus explores this simple yet truly profound question.There are some books that while small in length, nevertheless pack a giant punch. Gilbert’s book very much fits into this category. While at first glance and upon the first read the message relayed in this book may seem to be focused on those searching for an answer in relation to this Jesus character so many talk about, I firmly believe this is also a book that even the most seasoned believer needs to read. After all, knowing Jesus is at the crux of what we call the Christian life.Gilbert rightly begins by noting there is “one massive treasure trove of information about Jesus – detailed, personal, eyewitness, blow-by-blow accounts of what he said, what he did, and who he was.” Of course where we find that information is the Bible. For those who might feel like closing this book at the mere mention of the word “Bible”, Gilbert encourages them to stick it out and to continue reading. If nothing else, the accounts of Jesus’ life shared by the biblical authors were written as literal and actual history and thus should be considered along those lines. Gilbert encourages the reader to simply take a look at the claims made in Scripture and to examine them to see if they are true. If they are true, then the reader necessarily has to make an important decision as to what to do with Jesus and to answer that all important question of who is Jesus.Throughout this book, Gilbert makes the claim that Jesus was no ordinary man, that he is the King of Kings, the great “I AM”, was fully human, the last Adam, the Lamb of God who died for our sins, and the resurrected and reigning Lord. These are certainly some bold claims in the mind of some who have not yet fully dealt with that underlying question of who is Jesus. Gilbert recognizes that fact and with a great deal of patience and speaking from the heart of a pastor, he walks the reader through each important claim made in this book, proving along the way that Jesus is who he claimed to be.For instance, Jesus claimed to be the great “I AM”. While such a claim may not seem that big of a deal to our modern ears, making the statement that one was the great “I AM” was in the eyes of the Jewish people stating you are God. When God spoke to Moses way back in the book of Exodus, He told Moses to tell the people of Israel that “I AM” had sent Moses to deliver the people from bondage. So to say you are equal with God was shall we say a rather bold statement. Gilbert aptly comments, “if Jesus just wanted to say that he pre-existed Abraham somehow, he would have said, “Before Abraham was, I was.” But by using the present tense – “I AM” – Jesus was clearly taking for himself, again, the unique and exclusive name of God.” Thus, as God and being the Son of God, in order to know God and to have relationship with our Creator, we must know Jesus and affirm that Jesus is who he said he was – God.Gilbert also does an excellent job of working through the humanity of Jesus, something theologians call the hypostatic union – Jesus as fully God and fully man. This is a rather deep theological concept and Gilbert expertly relates he truth of this issue to the reader devoid of technical terms, instead choosing to engage why this matters. Why did Jesus need to become God incarnate? Simply yet profoundly, Gilbert states “Jesus became human because we needed him to do so. We needed someone to represent us before God and be our substitute. That’s ultimately why Jesus came- to be a loving Warrior King who would save his beloved people.”I highly recommend this book for those searching for the answer to who is Jesus and also for those who are long in the faith who want to refresh themselves on the answer to that question. Jesus made some bold claims that must be dealt with and Gilbert does a great job of doing that very thing. Those who are searching will be challenged and those who have longed affirmed Jesus as Lord will find this book a wonderful reminder of who Jesus is and why they are so in love with him.I received this book for free from Crossway Books for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

There are times when I feel the urge to dig into what can easily be labeled as a “nerdy” book and there are some theological subjects that arguably deserve such an in-depth treatment.  Exploring the wisdom literature of Scripture as well as the extra-biblical writings that impacted Jewish and early Christian thought is one of those topics deserving of such a deep dive.  Ben Witherington, in his book Jesus the Sage: The Pilgrimage of Wisdom, walks the reader through the grand and important history of wisdom literature, how it flows throughout Scripture, and most importantly, why it is necessary for believers to spend time studying this subject matter.Let me first state this is a very scholarly book.  If you are looking for a quick overview of biblical and extra-biblical wisdom literature, you should look elsewhere.  Conversely, if you desire to take the time to work through this topic and are looking for a book that digs very deep into the various elements of wisdom literature, then this book is one you will want to explore.  Those not familiar with all the various aspects of wisdom literature and thought will, again if they take the time to digest the material Witherington presents, will find upon completing this book they have gained a great deal of important knowledge.  Ultimately, this is not a quick read but it is well worth the read.Witherington notes in the Preface that “This book…is not only about the pilgrimage of Wisdom but also about Jesus the sage as one who contributed to the growth and development of Jewish Wisdom and, for the community of his own followers, charted a course that they would follow in further developing Wisdom ideas and forms.”  As such, Witherington efforts to trace for the reader not just wisdom literature itself, but more importantly, how Jesus continued this wisdom tradition.Reading, understanding, and identifying wisdom literature is a pursuit that demands a great deal of effort.  Witherington reminds the reader of that important fact at the outset of this book.  With that said, those who again take the time to grasp what wisdom is all about and what it means to be wise, will find their efforts rewarded.  In an effort to break down this journey through wisdom literature, Witherington divides this book into two parts with the first part examining this genre from the period of Solomon to the time of Jesus and with part two looking at how wisdom literature was shaped from the time of Jesus to the period of the early church.For myself, the most interesting chapter was “Wisdom in Person: Jesus the Sage”.  Of particular interest was Witherington’s engagement of Jesus’ parables and aphorisms.  Jesus used the form of the parable to relay important theological truths to those who listened to his words.  As Witherington notes, this approach is indicative of how a sage would have chosen to instruct his followers.  He also suggests “It is also quite likely that Jesus was perceived to be some sort of sage by the part of his audience that was conversant with the world of Jewish Wisdom traditions.”  Witherington presents some very interesting thoughts on the manner by which Jesus presented his teaching, parables, and speeches, asserting they take the form of Jewish wisdom traditions, thoughts that will certainly require further examination given the sheer volume and specificity of information Witherington provides all throughout this book.Anyone desiring to further their breadth of understanding of Jewish wisdom literature and how it presents itself throughout Scripture to include the words of Jesus, should give this book a read.  As noted earlier, this is a very scholarly book and it will take the reader time and patience to dig into all the information Witherington provides.  I know I will be returning to this book in the future to examine various individual elements discussed throughout as I continue my own studies on wisdom literature.I received this book for free from Fortress Press for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

There have been a number of books written lately about the ordinary Christian life.  Far too many have been pursuing what they perceive to be the extraordinary when in actuality, God has been and is calling His people to something that on the surface may seem ordinary, but in reality is actually more extraordinary than the flouted extraordinary so many are focused upon.  Tony Merida, in his helpful book, Ordinary: How to Turn the World Upside Down, explores from a biblical perspective what the ordinary Christian life is all about.Merida notes in the introduction how he came to realize what this ordinary Christian life is supposed to look like.  He pondered what arguably many others ponder when they read passages that speak of the poor and the widow, namely that of believing that focusing on such things steers one too close to liberal theological pursuits, specifically the social justice movement so often rooted in liberal thought.  The question one must answer is what does Scripture demand of us as God’s people?  Merida rightly proposes that “We need Christians focusing on ordinary Christianity – speaking up for the voiceless, caring for the single mom, restoring the broken, bearing burdens, welcoming the functionally fatherless, and speaking the good news to people on a regular basis in order to change the world.” After all, this is what is described as pure and undefiled religion.Not merely content to make what is certainly an outstanding theological statement, Merida walks the reader through the remainder of this book on the active part of what it means to be ordinary.  It is one thing to nod your head and affirm with your head that we are called to help those in need.  The true proof of our commitment is in our actions.  Merida provides the reader with a number of ways to demonstrate we are on the path towards the ordinary Christian walk.While each chapter is excellent, the point that touched my heart the most was Merida’s discussion of reaching out to the fatherless.  As the father of an adopted child, this issue is quite near and dear to my heart.  The number of children languishing in horrible situations around the world and even in our own country is staggering.  Victims of neglect, abuse, starvation, and even the most basis essentials of life, they are often passed by, pushed to the side by far too many as those who reject their needs pursue the chase for the gold at the end of the rainbow.  Merida aptly comments that the “trio of the vulnerable – the orphan, widow, and sojourner – receive special attention in the Old Testament.”  In that period of history and still today, those individuals were among the most “helpless members of society.”  God commanded, not suggested but commanded His people to take care of those in need.  God became very angry with His people when they neglected those in need.  Merida also correctly notes that the New Testament presents this same theme.  As noted earlier, James wrote that pure and undefiled religion is “to visit orphans and widows in their affliction…”  Merida wonderfully reminds the reader that to visit is to actively and physically care and is not relegated to mailing a check as if that covers our religious duty.This chapter, along with all the others for that matter, is a needed call to action.  It is a call to do the ordinary things that truly must define who we are as the people of God.  While such pursuits may not bring attention to ourselves or seem like they are making an impact in a world so full of problems, if we are doing the ordinary, we are being obedient to God’s Word.  Merida saliently comments that as we long for the day when all things are made new, “we find hope and power to do justice in this present world.”I highly recommend this book for all believers.  Merida shares from a heart of compassion and from the perspective of an individual who is putting his practice what he is preaching in this book.  If you read this book, you will find yourself challenged and your paradigm shifted.  I trust that you will take heart what Merida is sharing for it is biblically sound.  This world is full of people crying out for help.  Will you be God’s hands to those in need?  Will you be the ordinary person God is calling you to be?I received this book for free from B&H Books for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

What is worship?  Is it just the raising of our voices in song during a church service or gathering of believers or is worship far more than just a once or twice a week occurrence?  If worship is more than just singing songs, then what does Scripture say about what praising almighty God is all about, not just from a theological angle, but also as part of our everyday practice?  Timothy Pierce, in his excellent book on worship titled Enthroned on Our Praise: An Old Testament Theology of Worship, takes the reader on an in-depth journey to what God has outlined in the Old Testament regarding what He expects worship to look like in our lives.This book is part of the excellent New American Commentary Studies in Bible & Theology and as such, continues the strong tradition found in this series of salient biblical scholarship and most importantly, the applicability of the subject at hand to the Christian walk.  Pierce aptly notes, “A fundamental thirst has awakened in people to recognize someone who is bigger than they are, to relate to Him in a personal way and to experience community with like-minded individuals in the process.”  This yearning demonstrates that many are realizing what we were created for, namely to glorify God and to have relationship with our Creator.  An integral part of glorifying God and having that needed personal and intimate relationship with God is through the act of worship.One may ask why Pierce does not provide a theology of worship that engages both Old and New Testaments.  He answers this question by aptly commenting, “it can instill, in some small way, a greater appreciation of the OT in the hearts and minds of today’s church leaders.”  Second, Pierce correctly states “the God of the OT is the same God we serve today.  The OT presentation of His story transmits a relational vividness and attitude that fills in the gaps about who He is and what He desires in ways that even the NT writers themselves appreciated and recognized.”  Essentially, Pierce is reminding the reader and the body of Christ at large that to understand worship and to have a cogent and holistic perspective on this aspect of relationship with our Creator, we had best begin with the front of the book and the foundation on worship it presents.Pierce rightly begins his treatise on worship with the act of creation, discussing all the various elements subsumed in that act that relate to our worship and relationship with our Creator.  This is the very foundation of Scripture, namely the reality that “the primary relationship of God to humanity expresses a connectedness that is both patent and unexpected.”  As one journeys through Scripture, they find that which Pierce so expertly states, the fact that “it is this relationship that defines the direction of history and theology.  And it is this relationship that moves the tension of the narratives.”The salient discussion of worship is next directed at the Pentateuch, followed by an examination of worship in the writings of the prophets, both former and later, and finally Pierce engages the beautiful prose of worship found in the writings such as the book of Psalms, a book truly replete with songs extolling the majesty of God and demonstrating this repeated pattern and concept of man’s relationship to his Creator.While many may gravitate towards the section on the Writings and their commentary on worship, I was actually most drawn to Pierce’s analysis of worship within the Pentateuch.  I think far too often the manner in which God expressed and demanded He be worshiped through the various sacrifices and for instance the Sabbath are often overlooked as something completely irrelevant and unrelated to our lives today as believers.  After all, we do not conduct animal sacrifices anymore and who wants to get into that argument over when the Sabbath should be observed.  Much can be learned in relation to the needed element of relationship in regards to worship by examining God’s commands regarding Sabbath rest.  As Pierce so aptly states, “What is so intriguing about sacred times is that not only is God’s activity sanctified and descriptive of a relationship, but so is His rest.  There is nothing about Him that does not call humanity to a recognition of His presence and, therefore, to their need to worship Him.”  Understanding the purpose and focus of the Sabbath, as Pierce again so brilliantly comments is fact that “the Sabbath pulls humanity out of its self-interest and striving.”  Conversely, it focuses the created on the Creator in an attitude of humility, dependence, and worship.Those desiring to understand what the OT has to say about worship and why it is important should most certainly pick up this book and give it a thorough read.  I highly recommend it for all believers who desire to grow closer to their Creator.  Since we should all have that desire, then that means this book is for everyone to consider.  Pierce rightly focuses his attention on the front of the book, building that necessary foundation for those wanting to them explore what the NT has to say on worship.  Those who take the time to examine the many truths Pierce explores in this book will find themselves better focused on worshiping God and understanding why worship is a foundation for relationship with their Creator.I received this book for free from B&H Academic for this review. I was not required to write a positive review. The opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255 : “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”

I  have been using Calmoseptine for venous stasis ulceration, but decided to give this a try given the good reviews it got.  I now use it almost exclusively for my ulceration and any little cuts and nicks.  Very nice orangey smell.  Effective moisturizer as well as healing properties.  It is not as thick as Calmoseptine which I like a lot.  It goes on easily and it is easier to get this off my hands. since it is not so dense.  Washes off quickly with a a pad and some mineral oil.  Because it is not so dense I find a tube lasts longer than with the Calmoseptine.  Actually, I am very happy with the Remedy line.  The moisturizer they make is excellent as well.

These are okay, but have a bulky look that does nothing to flatter my polymer clay embellished bottles.  I did not find the cork adaptable to differ sized necks of containers.  But they are functional.  Maybe I just expect too much.  Next time I will look for metal rather than plastic for a more finished look.

Nice, well organized around the neck pouch.  It has a few  small dividers and one larger space.  Great for hiking and walking if you take a set of keys, some ids and a power bar.  Would also work well for passports and ids as well as some cash and/or credit cars when traveling.  I like having something around the neck rather than a fanny pack or shoulder bag.  At times I come back from a hike and find I forget to take it off given that it is so light and easy to wear.  Washes well too.
This is a sturdy, medium size file that works great for sharpening tools, lawn mower blades, etc.  Should hold up well over time.  The price was good too.  A purchase that I am really happy with.

I read the reviews and was unsure about buying this rug, but in the end I did.  It is a good looking rug that is muted enough color wise to not clash with other carpeting, but at the same time the colors are energetic enough to make a statement in a hallway.  One reviewer felt that colors were not well represented by the Amazon picture, that it was darker than expected.  On the contrary, I found the colors were just a slight bit brighter than the picture.  The size is good for a hallway as it does not overwhelm or dominate but rather pulls things together.  I just put it down on the floor and did not find any strong chemical odors.  The wrinkles will disappear as the rug settles on the floor.  All in all this is a quite nice rug, especially for the price.  It feels comfortable.  It needs a grab pad underneath since it has no texturing on the back, but I am pleased by that as those rubbery backings tend to curdle and come apart over time. I like that it is washable.  All in all a really good buy.

Attractive black organza cord with extender chains at a good price.  They seem well made.  The extender offers flexibility on length.  Most jump rings and pendant bails work with them. I like the fact that I can make simple necklaces using them without spending a lot of money or time.  These were an excellent purchase.

Very nice selection of necklace organza cords that seem pretty well made and include an extender chain. so that there is some flexibility on length.  The colors are good.  .The lobster clasp works fine with most pendants and jump rings.  The price was good as well.  I can make necklaces as gifts or for sale at a very reasonable price.  What a deal!

This is by far the greatest product I have ever bought for the kitchen.  It's not pretty:  in fact, it is rather homely and squat.  The color choices are limited.  But if you have a single tub sink like I do it is a real treasure.  It is neither too large nor too small at 12.2 x 12 x 8 inches.  There is plenty of space beside the tub for rinsing what you wash.  Just set it in the sink, close  its built in drain/stopper, add soap and hot water and you are going to get those dishes done with the least trouble and the most efficiency possible.  No more worry about overflow or poorly rinsed dishes.  No more scraps going down the pipe.  This baby has an ingenious drop in stopper/drain that is trouble-free and will never break or get stuck.  It just sits in place and does its job.  The pan itself is sturdy with grab bars on two sides so it is easy to maneuver.  My husband and I are both in awe of this great dishpan.  Frankly, except for large jobs, our dishwasher is going to get very little use.  Now I'm thinking about getting one for my potting bench.  Whoever Joseph Joseph is we thank him for this remarkable invention.  Its built to last and the price was good too!

This is a nice looking cotton robe.  Attractive pattern.  My husband is a tall, skinny guy so it is difficult to know what size to buy when he normally wears mediums and the ad says the sizing is small/medium and large/xlarge.  I would consider this robe a small.  It fits him, but just barely.  Given that it is a light weight summer robe that is okay, but next time I will go for too big rather than too small.  However, it is well made and probably will last a few seasons.  Hopefully, he won't get larger as time passes.  The price was pretty good.

My husband is pretty rough on knees of pants.  I have finally found a pair of pants that he can't finish off in a season.  He and I are both sold on Carhartt's for durability, good looks and a decent price.  These look good.  The fit seems just what I would expect for the size ordered.  I just bought him two more pair because these work so well for him.  And, he likes them.  I notice that he wears them for many occasions and they always look good.

It works well and the design is clean and simple. I love products with those qualities. The power/dim switch, which is a button flush with the surface of the base, requires a light touch, which fits with the elegant design. The base is heavy enough so that you can extend the light without worry that it might fall over. It has two intensities, both of which are useful.

It's small and more compact than any such multi-outlet device I have seen. That's good because many mine are just too big, but I use them anyway because I don't like to throw stuff out. Each outlet can be blocked by the flick of a plastic cover, and they are very close. You should know that you will only be able to use all outlets if you are not using blocky transformers. Or, if you must use transformers, you will need pigtail cables.I use this to activate related electronic items, such that when one is on, the others are necessary.

Right off the bat, I like the book. It introduces you to all the tools, both necessary and "nice to have". You learn what to get, how to shop wisely, and how to use them (of course). This takes up quite a few chapters. Then you get down to business. You learn about electronic components and what things are likely to go wrong in the devices you are most likely to come across. With this knowledge, electronic devices become comprehensible equipment instead of mystery boxes. That's what I like. I like to learn about things. I like to take the mystery out of things.Now for the bad, which has nothing to do with the book. The bad thing is that acquiring all the necessary, and a good chunk of the "cool" tools, will run into the thousands. You also have to have a dedicated work area, so if you are short on space already... Finally, it takes time to troubleshoot and repair things. If you are retired, no problem. But if you have to make a living, it will be much cheaper and easier to have someone do the repair for you or just buy a whole new item (depending on the problem).If you get satisfaction from learning and tinkering, get this book. If you are curious about this sort of thing, but can't afford the tools, space, or time, you might get the book anyway to learn what you can. If you just want to "save money" by doing your own repair work, I'd say do it the easy way. Pay for repair, or buy new stuff when your old stuff poops out.

This thermally insulated container exceeded my expectations. It feels solid, looks good, has a functional non-slip band. Best of all, it works really well. I set my Keurig machine to dispense the most liquid and dispensed only hot water into the mug. I forgot to check it a few hours later. A full 24 hours later, it was still quite warm. I have an insulated mug that I use at work. I would say that it keeps my coffee warm between 1 and 2 hours. A tell tale sign is that my coffee mug at work, feels warm on the outside when the coffee is inside. With this mug, it doesn't feel warm on the outside at all, which means that it is retaining heat very well.The other great feature, is the open/close button on the top center of the lid. It works really well. When it's closed, and I tilt the mug on its side, nothing comes out. Turn it up-side-down, same thing. Not a drop. Push the button to the open position, and liquid flows freely.This mug is relatively expensive, but to me, well worth it.

The bag is well-padded. The padding is thick and relatively rigid, which means that it will distribute the force generated by an impact. The lime green zipper makes it easy to pick out among my other bags. The inner base is also lime green, which makes it easier to spot small items that you might have in the main compartment.The handle on top of the case is handy, the outer material is tough, and the thick rubberized base protects the contents if you set the bag down roughly. The rubber base allows you to place the bag on wet surfaces without a worry. I have an older Case Logic case with a rubberized base, but this one is better because it's non-skid. I worry less about it slipping off a table or other slightly inclined surface.Provided it is the size you are looking for, this is a quality bag that will not disappoint.

I was very pleased to find out that the author of this book is a Red Hat heavy weight. I'm studying for the entry-level RHEL exam - the RHCSA. I use a book that was created specifically for the exam, but I supplement it with other books. One advantage is when you need something explained another way, usually because you aren't quite getting it. This book serves, as the title suggests, as a comprehensive tutorial resource. The only downside (for me), is that it is not specifically for the RHCSA. I wish that it were, because it is easier to read than my exam prep book. No technobabble, and the coverage of Linux "need to know" material is good.As a reference book, this is the one I am going to reach for. I reach for the most easily understood resource, and consult others only if the info I seek is not in my primary source.In short, if you want to have a solid handle on Linux, make sure this book is on your shelf.

I am a critical thinker by nature, but I have a friend who definitely is not. I've been trying to find a good book or two to help him out. Goodness knows, I've tried to help him. He's not that thick, but a book that gets right to the heart of the problem, just short of being terse, is what he could use. It would "give him the answers" and allow him to review them when needed.This book covers the bases, but it's far too wordy. There are quotes and sidebars galore, which I found to serve mainly as distractions. Every now and then, I'd come across some "basics" of critical thinking. But the journey getting there was long. Much of the information in the book is nice to know, but if you threw it out, the book would be much better.Just so you know what I'm talking about when I say "basics", here are a few which the author covers:Analogy: The ability to draw accurate analogies to the problem at hand is important. Making good analogies and recognizing bad ones is a great tool.Thought experiments: Einstein did this often. It is the ability to visualize a realistic scenario to mentally test things that you are unable to test in the real world, either because you lack the time or the means.Logic and Logical Fallacies: In layman's terms, this is how to think in way that produces correct results while avoiding mental pitfalls.I believe that the book would be much better if the author cut out all the "conversation" and just explained the tools of critical thinking and how and when to use them. He knows what he's talking about but he takes a long time getting to what really matters.

This air cleaner is just what I need for a small space, like my workroom. In addition to a pre-filter and HEPA filter, it has a UV-C light which can be turned on or off independently of the air filter. The UV-C light kills or neutralizes biologicals - airborne germs. However, as you might expect, if the air filter is off, the UV-C is off, as there is no air for it to "process".The unit looks nice, like an audio speaker. The air flow is to one side instead of straight outward.The instructions are simple to understand, and even if you are the type to not read instructions, it is easy to figure out. However, I recommend that you read the instructions so that you know the best way to maintain and service the filters and UV-C bulb.It looks nice, is simple to use and maintain, and it works.

When you need to pound on something, but don't want to dent or damage it, this is what you use. It's good that they included a non-scuffing white side should you need that option. I use rubber mallets to knock things loose when they are stuck, or to position things that require a little forceful tapping. This is a quality tool.

I didn't notice any change in the way things smelled, so I can't say if it was doing a good job of ridding the air of odors. But then, maybe my nose just isn't all that sensitive. Also, if my place smelled bad, I would do something about it way before getting a UV-C device. There are two other factors to consider. One is the sound that the fan makes and is the reason I gave it 4 stars. It's at the threshold, where I don't mind it, but I know that some people who are noise sensitive, might think it was on the loud side. The other thing to consider is if UV-C really does kill or neutralize airborne biological threats. I did my research, and it does.This unit is small and unobtrusive. If you have a room that you suspect could use some atmospheric bio scrubbing, this unit is likely a good bet.

When sprayed on weeds that are growing in an established lawn, does this in fact kill only the weeds and leave the lawn? I can only tell you what happened to the weeds on my lawn. I have just a few varieties of weeds that try to creep into my lawn. I was surprised to find the next day, that in fact, the weeds were well on their way to dying. Their leaves were already brown and dead-looking. The reason for 4 stars is because the grass also was negatively affected, showing the same signs, but to a much lesser degree. However, I am fairly certain that the grass will spring back. It seems that whatever the active ingredient is, it affects grass to a much lesser degree. That's actually what I expected. I would have been really surprised if this product were truly selective, meaning that it had no effect on the grass.Anyway, this makes spot weeding my lawn so much easier and faster.

I didn't know there was such a product. If you have established plants around which you find yourself weeding more than you would like this product is for you. There are certain areas of my yard where I grow ornamental plants. If I don't weed regularly, the weeds will start to take over. This product doesn't kill existing weeds, but it does prevent new ones from sprouting up. I don't know how it inhibits them, but it does. To get things going, clear the soil of weeds, then apply Preen according to the instructions. It will time-release fertilizer for the "good" plants, while preventing weeds from germinating.

The stitching looks fine and the simple pattern is appealing to me. It washes up nicely and dries relatively quickly. The material isn't thick enough for formal use, but for anything less than that, it's fine. I don't know how long it will last when washed regularly, but let me tell you that when I got rid of my dryer and started air drying, everything lasts way longer.

This was easy to test. I used it in my high efficiency washing machine. Sure enough, the amount that is recommended doesn't quite come up to the "normal load" mark where I put my normal detergent. That means that it is indeed, more concentrated. It did a good job of cleaning, is safe (non allergenic and free of harmful chemicals), and doesn't smell bad. It doesn't smell as "sweet' as my normal detergent, but that's not a bad thing. The scent is hard to describe other than to say that it is what you would expect from a baby product.

It's Roundup, which means that it does its job of systemic plant killing the same as it always has. The difference is the delivery. I normally purchase Roundup in a concentrate. I have to put it in a pump sprayer and dilute it properly before I can use it. I also have to wash the vessel that I used to measure it. I also have to estimate exactly how much I need so I don't run out and have to mix more, or don't end up with excess that sits there for a long time.This type of packaging is different. The emphasis is on convenience. It's a strong plastic container with a sturdy handle and the Roundup does not need dilution. It didn't come with any instructions, so I wasn't sure how to connect the pump device to the cap. The only thing I could do was "plug it in". You'll know what that means when you get it. Fortunately, that is the correct way to do it. Tubing that is inside the spray handle comes out and what you have is a spray handle/nozzle attached via tubing, to the cap. It was a simple click and go procedure. The tubing allows you the freedom to maneuver the spray handle any way you wish, and carry the main bottle in your other hand. Ingenius design.Of course, with no instructions, I started spraying right away. Nothing came out, but it took only a second to realize that the end of the spray nozzle has four positions, two of them are "off" positions, one creates a foam, and the other squirts out the product in a stream. When done, I close the nozzle, and "shutoff" the cap valve. You'll know what that means when you see it.So, this method of delivery is very convenient. You snap the nozzle onto the cap, select foam or stream, and close up when done. No measuring or mixing. Very handy and highly recommended for jobs where economy isn't a big concern. The convenience pays for itself.

You want to make sure that when washing your car, you use a cleaner that is made for cars. Such products are designed to clean well and not damage your finish. This product does the job well. It is a concentrate that you dilute and can either use from a bucket or put into say, a gallon milk jug for dispensing a little at a time. This car wash liquid works well and I have to say that I trust the name "Griot's Garage". I use their paste wax product, which is four times the cost of other waxes. I have also had good results with their buffers and other car care products.

I don't mean to be flip, but factual. This is a bent sheet of metal with a handle attached to it. The rubber handle grip is nice. When not in use, the handle can be folded over the metal sheet to conserve space. That's a feature I like because I can store it on my shelves more easily. Also, the loop on the handle allows me to hang it on a hook. There is only one drawback - it's springy rather than rigid. It's not going to break, but the "springiness" makes it trickier to work with. I make cheese-heavy, thick crust pizzas, so I have to be very careful not to apply too much initial lifting force to avoid a "bad hop".I would recommend this for thin to normal crust pizzas, which I do make from time to time.

It takes a little more work and a little more patience than buying ready-made trays or rolls of grass. But the savings is great. You just follow the instructions on the package and watch the grass grow. I didn't know grass could be purchased like this, because where I live no one sells grass in seed form. Another problem is that when I visit garden centers, typically the selection is limited. You can order a large variety of grass seed here at Amazon.

A lot of research must have gone into this book. It is concise and yet complete. Any details you might want to fill in can easily be gleaned from the Internet. However, that is not to say that this book is lacking. As you read about one region to the next, you come across the familiar things like places to eat, and places to bunk for the night. In addition to the basics, it describes places of interest, things to be careful of, etc..I would have been slightly disappointed if it just used the format I was speaking of. But it goes beyond that. It discusses things like climate concerns throughout the year, where you should go if you like to do certain things (mountain biking, going on food safaris, fishing, or what have you), and it even describes California culture(s) that you can expect to come across.If you've had any interest in visiting California and you want to know what there is to see and do, this is an excellent place to start. Reading it casually is almost like taking a mini tour. It presents a broad range of information from different perspectives. Eventually something (or many things) will jump out at you and you'll say, "Now that's what I want to do and see!"

I like this thing. I have a number of bluetooth speakers, and they are all different, but this one is pleasingly unique in that it is meant to withstand shocks and is waterproof. It is rated to withstand being submersed 1 meter deep for 30 minutes. But don't go swimming with it, or show off by using it under water. Using it in an environment where it may get splashed, or might temporarily fall into the water is probably fine. It has grippy rubber feet, which is great, because I intend to put it on my dashboard. Also, the rubberized exterior not only helps with shock resistance, it also keeps other things from being damaged should this speaker make contact with them. In other words, if it falls off my dashboard while I turn the corner, it might bounce off another part of my car, but it should not do any damage in addition to not being damaged itself.I like how it powers up and down. You hold the power button for a while and it generates a low, vibrating tone that sounds like a "boing". It makes a thumping noise when you turn it off. There is no mistaking whether you have turned it on or off.The sound isn't going to measure up to say, a Bose speaker, but to my untrained ear, it sounds great.Don't forget that this speaker has a USB port to charge your electronic devices. That's always handy. You can also use it as a speakerphone. And oh yes, I had no problem at all charging, pairing, or using it.

I treated half my hood with Glanz, and the other half with Griot's carnauba paste wax (one of the best). The proof will come maybe three months down the road when I see how this wax holds up compared to Griot's. If it keeps beading as long or longer, I will probably switch.Glanz is like many waxes, in that you should apply it in shade. You apply it, let it sit for about 5 minutes, and then buff in a good shine. Going on, it was like any other liquid wax product - it went on easily. However, it also buffed more easily than other waxes that I am familiar with. Subjectively, it produced a slightly better glossy shine than Griot's. That's always a plus.Read Amazon's product description for this product. It's correct. No exaggeration.

Goes on easily, fits well, and the buttons, which are covered by the case, are still easy to push. The three backplates would distribute the load from impact with a sharp object (a good thing). If one backplate is damaged or scratched, you can replace it with one of the remaining ones. The corners of the case are thicker, in case you drop the case and the phone lands on one of the corners.It comes complete with a screen protector.

Nice little flask. It loses one star because it has sharp edges. Otherwise, there's nothing for me to complain about. The edge is not sharp enough to cut you "accidentally", but if you intended to cut or scrape something with the edge, you could. The cap is tethered by a piece of rubber that runs down the side and the bottom. This gives it a rubber base should you stand it up or lay it on the rubberized long edge. The cap can easily be removed from the tether should you wish to do so. Small and simple.

I learned a while back, that small tidbit treats are the way to go. With larger treats, you can't give them very many before overdoing it. These are just the right size and they smell tasty. You can use them for dogs of all sizes. I have a Pomeranian and a Rottweiler. They can smell and taste them equally well. Even with the Pomeranian, I can give a reasonable number before having to worry about overdoing it.I carry some with me when I walk them. The sound of the zipper on my treat pouch is enough to get them running. Another thing you can do is teach them a word that they can associate with the snacks. When you say that word, they will come running.

I use this baby for two specific things. They are the only things I tested it for, but I'm glad to report that it does them both well.Before I begin, I really like two "features". The first one is that it is less than half the thickness of my Epson photo scanner. That's probably because it doesn't do as much. It specializes (in my opinion), in document and photo scanning. The other feature is that it gets its power from USB, unlike my Epson, which requires an external power source. That once again, is probably because the Epson is more sophisticated hardware-wise (and software-wise to boot).This is a minimalist device pared down to meet the bulk of my needs 99% of the time.I now archive important documents electronically - things like receipts, confirmations, legal stuff, etc.. For example, when I received a letter confirming that my loan had been paid off, I scanned it to a PDF, and stored in a backed-up electronic form. Then I shredded the original. I did the same for a police collision report when a tourist rear-ended me an intersection. It was very handy to email the PDF to the insurance companies.The scanner is very simple to use. My Epson, while more "powerful", is equally more complicated and confusing when it comes the all the settings you have to choose from. This scanner and its software is pretty much "click and done". If I have to choose between my Epson and this to scan just about any document, it's this one hands down.When it comes to photos, I can't knock it. It's considerably easier to use than the Epson. Just remember that the Epson will allow you to do much more. I really like that you just plop the picture down and push the button. However, this scanner cannot "fix" old or damaged photos nearly as well as the Epson. No contest. Epson wins in the photo restoration category. If I were to scan a photo just for illustration purposes, say to email to someone, I'd reach for this scanner. But almost all of my photo scans are of all the prints I have collected over the years. Many of them are faded, damaged, etc.. The Epson does a good job of correcting damage (scratches, creases, etc.), and restoring faded photos to what looks close to their original colors.If you want to scan documents for archiving or sending via email, this is a great scanner. For photos that don't need correcting, it's just as terrific.Its size and ability to draw power from USB make it very portable compared to my Epson. In fact, to save space on my desk, I keep this scanner on my shelf and pop it down only when I need it - because it's very easy to do. I keep the Epson connected all the time, because it's considerably bigger and fussing with the power supply cable and the USB cable is a headache.

I haven't tried any other brands of fitness bands, so I can't do a relative comparison. I found this one to be reasonably accurate with respect to number of steps taken. That surprised me. This band also supposedly measured the number of hours you sleep, but I can't stand wearing anything on my wrist while sleeping, so I didn't test that feature.I think that monitoring the number of hours I sleep is not useful. I just know that if I am not well-rested, I probably need more. Sometimes, trying to force yourself to sleep in order me meet a sleep goal, is actually counter-productive. I'm just saying that the sleep feature is not useful for me.Except as a motivational tool, I don't think that this band will help you much in reaching your goals. I find that if I exercise more, eat less, and get enough sleep to feel rested, everything falls into place.There is only one thing I did not like about this product. The instructions are far too sparse. I had to learn by trial and error. In fact, if you try to get help through the app via the Support FAQ link, you will be taken to a useless website. You won't find any instructions or FAQ. I couldn't even find this product at that website. There are a few features that I still don't understand and I don't have the time to experiment. How hard is it to make a good set of instructions?This product works (functions properly) and links up via Bluetooth easily. If the things that it counts and tracks would be useful for you, I don't think you could go wrong.

First the good. I think that this type of book is great for getting kids interested in reading "chapter books". The illustrations are funny-looking (that's good), the story is lighthearted, and there are built-in amusements (two frame crude animations, for lack of a better term). So we have a great formula here.But here's where it falls short of its potential:I loved Mad Magazine as a kid. It was zany but easy to understand and follow. This book is zany, but difficult to follow. Also there is a good amount of humor that I would not expect children to understand. For example, the name Miss Anthrope. A kid would think it was just a meaningless zany name. One who understands the "punny" name would probably not find it funny. I found it mildly funny. There is also adult humor (no, not that kind). That is to say, humor that only an adult *might* find funny, simply because they can understand the zaniness. I'm referring specifically to such things as the mention of biological concepts (lipids, RNA, etc.) that would likely be understood only by advanced high school students or college students taking introductory biology classes. As a kid, I could appreciate zaniness only when I understood it. I still don't laugh at quantum mechanics jokes.In addition to things that go over a kid's head, there is the story itself. Now this is a toss up. Some kids might like stories that are just jam packed with off the wall zaniness. I don't. Even as a kid, I would enjoy it much better if the story relied more on funny situations for laughs.This style of book has great potential. I think funny illustrations of funny situations would knock the ball out of the park.While the book in its current form, misses the mark for me, if you are the type of person who likes my general description of the contents of the book, by all means, buy a copy to "test it out". Taste in humor is sometimes like taste in music - unexplainable from one person to the next.

It is very easy to set up. You charge it until the blinking light becomes steady, you adorn it with one of the many stickers that comes with it (you can change them later), and you pop the head on and go. That's it!What makes this for kids, are the brushing modes. There is a high for more "experienced" kids. In high mode, not only is the brushing more vigorous, but it makes a congratulatory sound and shuts off after the 2 minutes recommended brushing time. In the low mode, brushing is finished after one minute. Over time, in low mode, the completion time increases to 2 minutes.Each 1/4 division of the full brushing time is marked by a series of reminder tones. It reminds the child to switch to a different quadrant of the mouth. Finally, there is a default easy-start feature which gradually increases the brushing power over the first 14 brushings. This can be disabled.

I love non-fiction books. I take pride in building a personal library covering useful topics. As for back as I can remember, the Middle East has been in the news. I finally decided to look into what the Middle East is all about. What I wanted was a book that gives the general background of the region without going into hair-splitting detail. I wanted to also learn a little about each country that is considered to be part of the Middle East. This book delivers.The first sections describe the general geography and history of the region. It covers petroleum and the economy, water (an important resource), international boundaries, and transboundary issues.It then gives statistics and current issues of each state in the region, very much like a compact encyclopedia might. Finally, it covers key issues like war, politics, and hot zones.Now when I read or hear about what's happening in the Middle East, I have a good picture of the true dynamics.

I didn't know such devices existed. There is also one for lemons. The lemon tool is larger. The enamel coated metal looks good and feels substantial. I chose the largest lime I could find to test this product. When I got home, I placed the lime into the tool and it didn't seem to fit. However, after cutting it in half, it fit perfectly. Squeezing the lime was simple. No problems.With a background in mechanical engineering, I would like to advise you not to try to squeeze the life out of your limes. Applying a gorilla grip to get one more drop simply isn't worth the strain on yourself or the tool. Also, trying to get that last drop will squeeze some "rind juice" in addition to the pulp juice. Enjoy!

It came well packaged, each component individually wrapped in plastic and surrounded by cardboard. There are four pieces - the wheel, 2 handles, and a cylindrical steel connector for the two handles. Assembly couldn't have been more simple. You just click the connector onto one handle, pass the connector through the wheel, and click on the other connector.It's made of strong materials and the double-width wheel is more stable than a single wheel. The downward slant of the handles makes gripping it noticeably more comfortable. I tried simulating a non-slanting handle and it was less comfortable. Just for kicks, I turned the handles up-side-down and that was REALLY uncomfortable. Ha. The downward slant is not just cosmetic or aesthetic.It didn't roll easily at first, so I disassembled it and lubricated the steel connector, which is what the wheel rotates against. That did the trick.Pay attention to the warning sticker. It basically says this thing, misused, can cause serious injury.How did it work? Just great. I have not done this type of exercise before, so the resistance felt great. You folks who do resistance training know exactly what I mean.

It works like a champ. It measured easily and spraying was a cinch. I suggest you buy a 1 gallon or more sprayer if you don't already have one. If you use this in a sprayer, I highly advise that you use the sprayer for nothing else. I feel guilty when a review is short, but there isn't much more to say about a product that is effective and simple to use. You can hardly go wrong.

Who would have thought such a toy would make me smile so broadly? First let me gripe. It comes in tricky packaging that is not easy to open. There are two plastic parts that fasten the base to the plastic packaging. At first I tried to forcefully remove it from the packaging. When a respectable amount of force did not free the base from the plastic packaging, I knew that I was either going to end up breaking it, or I would have to be patient. I chose patience. I carefully tore away until I exposed instructions (on the fasteners) on how to remove the plastic fasteners. That was an annoying exercise.I read the instructions because it's not obvious how to charge and operate it. Having successfully charged it, I launched it and watched it fly right up to the ceiling. I climbed a step stool and pulled it down by the legs. It flew right back up to the ceiling as I expected. I pulled it back down again and played with it like a basketball. I put my hand on the head to keep it from flying to the ceiling. It didn't take long to learn how to push it down toward the ground and watch it fly back up. I stopped it from rising with my palm and sent it down again - over and over. It was fun.Even more entertaining was watching my dogs react to it. They wanted to play with it but were afraid of it at the same time. They kept their distance but watched it with such intensity. Dogs are really intrigued by flying objects in the house.If the rotors strike anything, the whole thing will come to a crashing stop. I suppose it's designed to do that.I would not let young children play with this. I wouldn't even let my dogs get near this. If the main rotor (used for lift) were to strike an eye, it would certainly do serious damage. Even if I let older children play with it, I would either be there with them, have a great deal of trust in them, or make them wear eye protection. It's not that this thing is so dangerous. It's that eyes are not replaceable.Now that I've scared everyone, I think if you just be careful and prudent, you will have loads of fun until the novelty wears off. It still makes a nice decoration just "parked" in its base. And every now and then, you can let 'er rip as you smile ear to ear.I've got to get this for my nieces.Oh by the way, the instructions clearly say to use indoors only. If you use it outdoors, since there is nothing to stop it, it is very likely to fly away - for good.

When you follow the instructions, take your time, and add a dash of extra care, you will find that this protective tape goes on without any problems. Although I won't test it, you can be sure it will do its job of keeping your paint from chipping should your door edge touch something it shouldn't. Hopefully, that would be a wall or a pole, and not someone else's car.It's a nice protective addition for people who like to take good care of their vehicle's appearance.

This is a good case for my Nikon 70-200mm VRII. I usually don't store my lenses in cases, but that baby is expensive, so I always keep it in a special case that is made for a camera fitted with the lens. When I am using my camera (Nikon D7000) with other lenses, my 70-200 stays in the case built for both. It's not a snug fit.This camera fits my 70-200 perfectly, with the hood on. I will now store my lens in this case and use the other case only when I need to already have it on the camera. This case is sturdy, comes with a strap AND a handle, and is padded on the side that would touch your body when carrying it with the strap. It has two side pockets, one carrying the rain hood. I suspect that Case Logic designed this to carry 70-200 lenses, which are expensive no matter the manufacturer.When you open the case, a special pouch-like compartment opens up. It is part of the lid. From viewing a few pictures, it seems that the compartment is for holding the lens that you are going to swap out for the 70-200. I'm not sure (even now). There was no YouTube video that showed how to use the pouch, and the video that comes with Amazon's product page, is for an entirely different Case Logic case. I can think of no practical use for the pouch, but that's just me (and the way I like to change my lenses, no doubt). Having a seemingly non-functional part is not any reason to downgrade the review. I just consider an extra part that I may use someday.Cases are like tripods. I buy too many and end up only using the ones I should have bought in the first place. This case is in the "should have bought in the first place" category. Buy this one first.

Wow, I wish a book like this existed for all of my interests. It is exactly what the title says: The definitive visual history of photography.It thoroughly covers the subject of photography from its humble beginnings - from the time people observed projected images but were not yet able to capture them, all the way to the modern day (cell phone cameras, etc.). It is full of photographs that illustrate concepts, demonstrate techniques, are iconic, etc.. It covers notable photographers and notable cameras - the ones who or which made their marks on the history of photography. It also covers, among many other things, how photography played a part in various historical events (war, etc.).This is no coffee table book that one picks up for light reading. It is almost 500 pages and jam packed with photos and information. The contents of the book, assuming one could bring together the various items shown throughout, could be used to create an entire museum of the history of photography - one that I could easily spent an entire day wandering through.I usually don't mention price, but at the current selling price, this book is a steal and a must have for anyone who loves photography.

It's simple. You just take it out of the box, pop the optional suction cup in the center of the base, and hang it. You know, I didn't notice that it was designed to accommodate a shower hose. All the caddies I've had in the past were not, so I had to awkwardly drape the hose off to one side or in the front. This feature was an unexpected plus. Unlike the caddy this one replaces, there is no dish for holding soap. This is not a flaw, but it is something that I can easily remedy. I just have to custom cut one of those thin green scouring pads and place it over the bottom "grating".

This is a pair of charging panels that come packaged in an excellent case with ample velcro flaps to keep it closed. The velcro flaps, when opened, can be secured on the so they are out of the way. In other words, the is velcro on both sides of all four flaps. The mesh pockets with elasticized openings can easily carry the battery/flashlight, the USB cable, the adapter cable, and the paper instructions.It works, it's handy, it's well-designed, and couldn't be simpler. I don't use this in my everyday life, but I absolutely keep it close by and give it an occasional workout. It's a great backup system or wilderness/camping item.

How could I not like this? It holds four toothbrushes (if you don't crowd them). The base of each toothbrush is confined to its own space, which prevents the toothbrushes from sliding at steep angles and ending up touching each other (yuck) :-)It is durable and stylish, and very importantly, does not have any sharp edges.

My copy came without the required serial number and product key. They weren't anywhere on the packaging, nor were they on the CD. The only other place to find them would be via an online purchase confirmation. There was no online purchase confirmation.Note: After quite a snafu, things were finally sorted out when Amazon sent me the proper codes to activate the software. Someone dropped the ball, but as long as it was all sorted out, I'm proceeding without bias against the product.I'm coming from the standpoint of a user who wants to learn how to draw. I understand that in the digital art industry, Photoshop reigns supreme. My guess is that it has much to do with the popularity of Photoshop. For now anyway, SB Pro 7 is much easier to learn and use. That's critical for someone who wants to focus on learning to draw, and not getting bogged down learning how to use software. I subscribe to Photoshop CC, so I'm very current. I have used Photoshop to construct a book cover, but that did not involve any drawing.When I gave equal time to using both Photoshop and SBP 7, I found myself learning much more quickly with SB7. It has a much simpler interface, which undoubtedly has to do with it being designed for sketching and painting as opposed to also working with photos and such.In addition to having often-used tools in reasonably handy places, SB7 also has layer functionality that either didn't exist before (I own SBP 6, but did not work with it much), or greatly improved layering ability. This moves it into the company of the biggies, like Photoshop. Although I haven't used them yet, I was pleased to find line construction tools (perspective, etc.). These did not exist in prior versions, and even if you are just planning to draw cartoons, you will find them very handy.The software loads up quickly and there no drawing lag that I can detect.Having learned it much more quickly than Photoshop, I will stick with SB7 until or unless I find that it falls short in a critical area. I don't foresee that happening any time soon, if at all. I must still force myself to learn Photoshop to work with photographs, but as of right now, I can whip out drawings much more quickly with SB7.

My dog Kuchen (pronounced koochen; meaning cupcake in German) loves any sort of toy that squeaks, and she also loves to play fetch. So when I saw this toy I knew it would be a good idea for her. The only thing I was concerned about was the fact that it says it suits small dogs better. However, I have had no issues with my dog chewing the toy up. I would recommend if you do have a chewer though to use your own judgement on purchasing the toy. However, its going to take some serious chewing to tare it up in my opinion.My dog loves the toy and plays with it hours upon hours, until I'm tired out! haha. She loves the squeaking sound and is fascinated by it. It's a little different than regular squeaky toys as it sounds more like a duck, but I rather prefer it and think it is a little less annoying than a regular squeaky toy.My dog hasn't quite figured out how to get the treats out, but I have high hopes that she will figure it out over time once the newness of the toy wears off (so she can smell it better). I also plan to try some more potent treats that I know she will want to get to. Other than that one minor issue overall, I think this is a wonderfully designed toy and will provide hours of entertainment for any dog that loves balls or squeaky toys, or even both like mine!

I really like the NutraFx Energy Xtreme Capsules. It gives me a great amount of energy for whatever I am about to do from working out to just simply cleaning the house. It doesn't give me a high which I love nor does it give me any jitters. It just simply gives me energy, which I have desperately been needing. I have Crohn's Disease so I was a little concerned it would bother my stomach, but it hasn't (for those with digestive problems). I also have anemia and thalassemia, so energy is a constant battle with me. I've taken everything and when I say everything I mean everything. From 5 hour energy shots to energy patches to B-12 shots - nothing gives me a good amount of natural energy like these do. I would highly recommend trying these if you are in the same boat as I was. They also have a 100% money back guarantee, so you also having nothing to loose.

I absolutely love this brush! I have never owned a "badger hair" brush before, but I can tell you I have been missing out! It is super soft, and I haven't had any bristles come out which is a great sign so far. It also creates a great lather while shaving. It is very easy to maintain, and while I would recommend using a sleeve to put over the brush when drying to prolong the use of the brush, it isn't an absolute must as it does well at maintaining its shape. I also like not only the brush itself, but the wood finish of the brush. It gives you that expensive brush feel; without the expensive brush price. I have owned several shaving brushes in the past, however this one has a much higher quality than past ones I have used. I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

I love this heated bag sealer! It took me a few minutes to get the hang of it (simply because I was a little nervous), but once I did it worked wonderfully. It does a great job at heating and sealing any style of bag. I tried several different chip bags and various food items, and never had a problem once with it sealing. My chips or whatever food item I am eating at the time taste so much fresher than just putting a regular clip on it. It really does seal in the freshness and makes food last a lot longer.I also like that when I am done using it, I can just put it on the fridge once I am done (since it has a magnet on the back). I also like that there is a safety you can put on, this is very convenient just in case I am babysitting I don't have to worry about a kid grabbing it and getting burned.My only complaint with the heated bag sealer is that it says on the front of the box that it includes batteries, however I didn't have any batteries in mine. I'm not sure if they are all like this or if it was just mine? Other than that though I would highly recommend the product, and I truly believe it will save me money in the long run.

I have tried an item very similar before, however none as good or that have as many as these for the price. It is an amazing deal, and you get 6 full sheets. I like that these have not only gold and silver tattoos, but some blue/turquoise ones as well. These were new to me so, I wasn't sure how they would do compared to the gold and silver, but are now my favorite ones.These are great for all ages, but I like to say they are temporary tattoos for adults because they have a really high quality. So much so that last time I wore one, my mom thought that it was a real necklace. Another great thing about these is that even if you buy them twice it leaves room for creativity, giving you a different look each time.I also appreciate the fact that they are very easy to remove. I use just a little bit of olive oil directly on the tattoo, and it cleans off completely within a few minutes. If you are worried about possibly having an allergy from them, I will say I have very sensitive skin and they don't bother me at all. When in doubt do an allergy test, before using a whole one.They sell these all over Amazon, so it may be confusing about which ones to buy. They are all pretty much the same, but these in my opinion give you the most bang for your buck and tattoo variety. They are also a terrific company, and shipping was fast!

I love that this shampoo is not only paraben free but sulfate free as well. It does a really great job at getting a nice deep down clean, without stripping my hair. I color my hair as well as use a straightener quite frequently, so I have a lot of factors against me. However, using this shampoo I now don't have to worry nearly as much.
