This shampoo really helps to strengthen my hair.I also like the smell of the shampoo to me it has more of an Argan Oil smell. It is also neutral enough, so that if my husband wanted to use it he could as it is not too "flowery."It is definitely a must-have sort of shampoo for the upcoming summer months.

My dog absolutely is crazy over these, so much so that I am about to order some more after I run out. I'm not quite sure why she likes them so much, but I think its great! Not only that but they look fresh, and I love the resealable bag. I also like that it's not just a bunch of chicken jerky crumbs, but rather big pieces. I have a German Shepard, but little dogs could eat these too as you can break the pieces easily if need be. Each bag also has a good amount in them, instead of just a few pieces like most dog jerky treats I have bought in the past  I also appreciate thee fact they have no fillers and are made in the US. I would love to see some sort of Peanut Butter treats (because this is her favorite flavor) from this company, and would highly recommend these.

I really love this makeup brush combo. It is the perfect foundation brush. The sponge on one side and the brush on the other. It is a lot more convenient than pulling out two brushes, and I can really appreciate the design of it. The quality of the brush is really amazing as well. It has never once lost bristles on me nor has the sponge had any flaws. It also puts and blends makeup with ease. I would highly recommend this brush combo, and in my opinion will be the next hot item for makeup artists like myself.

I have a lot of great things to say about this tent, and then the one reason why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. This tent is roomy and very well made. The fabric is thick and doesn't tear easily. I love the windows so that you can look out, and I especially love the "draw bridge" door that ties up. Someone really put a lot of thought into how it should look, which I love!The reason it gets 4 stars from me though is because of how you put it together. If I wasn't a 5"4 small girl instead of say a 6" 0 man like I am sure some that are buying this, I probably wouldn't have been able to put it together quite as nice. I actually had to get my mother to hold the tent up while I climbed inside to put the poles in that keeps the tent up. You put one end in a tiny hole, tie the pole with ties about half way up, and then it snuggly ends at the top of the tent. The design in this sense was just really off, as well as frustrating.However, once I got the tent up it was beautiful. It hasn't once fell or came apart. I would still recommend it, but the flawed design is something to consider when purchasing. Just know its beautiful, but you have to be very patient with it. I originally bought this at a discount for two underprivileged boys my mom keeps a lot who are 6 and 10. They both really enjoy it, and I would recommend it for all ages.

This tub drain is seriously a life saver! We have such a big problem with hair clogging our drain. I love this, because it prevents hair from going down the drain and instead wraps around the drain strainer. Making for a much easier clean-up, and a lot less hassle trying to unplug our drain. All you have to do is throw it down where you need it at, and its ready to go. I would recommend this product if you are trying to prevent your drain from getting clogged, or have had issues with your drain clogging in the past.

Mariko's Scarf Hangers are beautiful, glamorous, and just an all around great alternative than just throwing your scarfs on the back of the couch like I have shamelessly been doing! In each package you get three beautiful hangers, tied (just like you see above) with a beautiful black ribbon. Ready for you to untie just like it was a present meant for only you. I love the presentation of each box, and the hangers themselves are even more amazing in person. There are literally so many different ways you can use these hangers. You can loop them over like you see above, tie each one to make sections, or tie it around the hanger to show it off. Creativity is in your court, and you have the ball.You can put one on each hanger or you can stack 10 on a hanger (I have done this, and it works!). They are beautiful and timeless. They have a very sturdy chrome frame, don't snag one bit, and are very lightweight. However, not so lightweight that they damage easily. They fit and hang easily in my closet. I also absolutely love the bead work, it makes them look as each one is home made (in a good way!). I would absolutely recommend these beautiful hangers, and plan on purchasing more!

Very cute book! If you like knock knock jokes & yo mamma jokes, then you will enjoy this book. It has two sections with plenty of jokes that will keep you amused and have you thinking about it for hours after you read. I think the author definitely has a passion for writing jokes, and I think that shows through in this book. There were some knock knock jokes I have heard before, but most of them I had never heard of.  I thought for the type of jokes they were, they were clean and classy yet humorous. Then the yo momma jokes was the best part, it included each type from yo mama is so fat - to yo moma is so stupid jokes, and everything in between. I would highly recommend this book if your looking for a nice light read.

When I first received the Niapads, I was like wow, this is a small sample. Little did I realize inside it contains 30 pads. Now that's more like it (guess I should've read that on the back!). Immediately, I noticed the refreshing yet light Lavender smell of the pads. I had a couple of areas that needed clearing up, so I decided to try it on my whole face. Now, if you are using it for just a pimple or a couple of pimples than it's plenty big. However, just me personally I would of preferred a little bigger pad.I then proceeded to put it on my face, and left it on for about 30 seconds. I felt a slight tingling sensation, but nothing that bothered me. It was a good feeling, like it was cleaning my pores out. The next day, I significantly noticed my skin looked a bit clearer, in fact a lot clearer! By the second day the patches of acne were pretty much gone. If I had just let it do it's thing (and used my normal facial cleanser every night), it would of probably took close to a week. I was really impressed with these little pads, and how much power they have behind them. I love that they are made is the US. I also think they are 10X better than any of those facial cleansing pads they have in Walgreen's. Not to mention they are great if you travel, since the pouch is resealable. Overall, I would have to say besides being a little small they are a win win in my book.

I am absolutely in love with these baking cups! Not only are they in amazing bright and festive colors, but they work great! I can finally eat my whole cupcake or muffin, instead of half of it sticking to the paper. You get 24 of these lovely liners; 4 of each color. I love this because I can also customize the color to the event I am baking for. The cupcake liners have saved me sooooooo much money! They are also a lot safer for the environment which I love. No waste or throwing them away, I just pop these in my dishwasher and they are clean. I would highly recommend these if you bake a lot or even bake occasionally. They are well worth the money and then some!

I was really impressed with Oridel's Liquid Gem Face Oil. I have never used a oil that hasn't been heavy or made my face feel greasy, but this stuff is NOTHING like this! It is light, smells wonderful, and easy to blend into makeup.It gave me a really nice glow, as well as moisturized my skin. I have combination skin, so I was a tad worried that it would clog my pores in some spots. However, it didn't clog my pores not once.As you can see in the after picture my skin is glowing and more radiant. At one point I could of sworn it started freaking out because of it being so hydrated...haha! In all seriousness, I was thoroughly impressed. It's truly unlike any other skincare product I have tried in the past, and let me say I have tried a lot!One of the best parts is not only getting a beautiful Citrine gem once I'm done using it, but having amazingly supple and beautiful skin.

When I first saw the bottle, I admit I was a little skeptical. I was like, "How in the WORLD can this little bottle enhance my face?" Don't be fooled though. This little bottle packs a powerful punch! I was really impressed. Just after fifteen minutes of my first use, I noticed my eyes were less puffy and indeed brighter.Now, by no means am I saying its a miracle cream but indeed most of the claims of this cream is indeed dead on. I have yet to see if it will get rid of my wrinkles completely, but so far have noticed a huge improvement - and for the price it's a great deal. My eyes and skin is brighter and tighter. I have only used it on my eyes, but am told you can use it on your whole face as well. I think that is pretty awesome, and will be next on my list of things to try. However, I would highly recommend this product.Below are my before and after pictures after just ONE use....

I absolutely love this wine chiller! I have used a lot of wine aerators and chillers in the past, but none quite like this one. The stick itself stays cold for a really long time, making wine enjoyable glass after glass. My favorite thing about this product is the Aerator. Not only does the aerator do a fast and easy job letting the wine breathe, but it has this little plug attached to it that you can open and close. This is my favorite part because it keeps any air from going in, and keeps the wine at a perfect temperature. If you are looking for an aerator, chiller, pourer, or stopper than this is the way to go. Why have 4 different products, when you can buy this with them all in one. Makes things so much easier, faster, and drinking wine an all around better experience.

If you are looking for an amazing gift for a birthday, Christmas, coworker, or even a housewarming gift, then this is the way to go! When I first received this immediately I noticed the packaging. It was wrapped so gorgeously in a nice pink box with wrapping paper, and also had bow wrapped around the container holding the nuts. The mix itself tasted so wonderful and very fresh. I especially enjoyed the cashews and HUGE mango and banana pieces. It was a huge hit with not only myself, but my family as well. I like how it has something in it for everyone, and had a well mixed variety. My only regret is that I hadn't found this mix sooner when I ordered my dad a gift! I would highly recommend this product, and definitely plan on purchasing in the future.

1:42 Mins I have used a bunch of different face masks before, but none quite like Bellaboo's. Here are my pro's and con's of this sinfully delectable facial treat...Pro's- Free of parabens, artificial colors, fragrances, sulphates, petrochemicals, mineral oils, animal derived ingredients, and harmful chemicals- Created for women by women- Smells just like chocolate!- Does a great job working to cleanse the skin- Makes skin smoother after each use- Has Shea Butter & Witch Hazel in it to moisturize and soothe skin- For combination skin like mineCon's- Made my face slightly red for about 10 minutes after use (would not recommend for sensitive skin)Overall, I was really impressed with Bellaboo's Chocolate Face Mask. Besides the slight redness (which went away after a few minutes) I received from it, it worked wonderfully. It got my skin clean, and even got rid of my blackheads!

This set literally has it ALL! First lets talk about the cup It has a wonderful lift top that doesn't leak. It also has a screen on the inside (picture included) so that if you want you can either filter what you're pouring, keep bugs from getting into it, or put some sort of food on top. This cup also has a cup at the bottom that screws off so if you want to put some sort of snack in the bottom you can, use it for measuring, or I even use it to store a few ice cubes. It also has a strap on the side so you can carry it around your wrist if you choose to.The other part of this set is the bento box. It has amazing security and you always hear it snap it place to know its secure. It also has 2 different places to store food. The top place to store food is divided. Then in the middle is a spoon and fork to eat with. Then finally at the bottom is your biggest place to store food. It does a great job at keeping food warm or cold. I love using this to take my lunch in, and it doesn't take up much space. If your looking for a quality bento box & water bottle, these are made really well. Not to mention the pretty purple & pink color is beautiful on this set. Even though it is pink, my husband loves using it as well. It's just that well made, and stores all his food perfectly.

I have used a lot of different types of Mud masks in the past, but none quite as potent and of quality as this one. The first thing I have to say is I love that right on the label it lists the ingredients. It's not 20 long words no one really understands, but simple words such as sunflower oil and shea butter. The next thing I have to say is unlike a lot of mud masks I have tried this has no awful smell! In fact, to me it has no smell at all....just results. My skin is so unbelievably dry, so I was a little worried to use it at first. However, this mask does a great job at taking any dead skin off, and I have noticed I have had to use a moisturizer a lot less since using the mask. I also have really sensitive skin, and turn red almost after any mask. This doesn't turn my face red at all though, and I like that it has Aloe Vera Juice in it keeping my face cool. I would highly recommend this product if you're looking for a great dead sea mud mask that gives you that little something extra at the same time.

I love this bag! It is not only the cutest darn bag I've ever seen, but works well too. My problem with a lot of wash bags in the past is that the bra will get caught on the bag, but this does NOT do that! It stretches quite a bit, without it staying that way. However, I would say comfortably it would holds 3 bras, but would recommend doing 2 at a time for a better wash. I wondered how you could get as great a clean with it being in the bag, but it does a wonderful job at getting your intimates clean as well as dry. I would highly recommend the Bra Wash Bag for washing your bra's. It will in the long run make your bra's last longer, and smell better!
0:57 Mins Extremely useful, very durable! These hold a ton, and I love the designs. They are also easy to store. I would highly recommend these!

12 Graphite Pencils in Various Grades of Hardness: 5H, 4H, 3H, 2H, HB, B, 2B, 3B, 4B, 5B, 6B, 8B3 Charcoal Pencils in soft, medium, and hard1 soft graphite sketching pencil3 graphite and 3 charcoal sticks in soft, medium, and hard1 pencil sharpener & 1 charcoal sharpener1 (PVC-Free) plastic eraser & 1 kneaded eraserI would have loved to have something to come even close to this when I was in art class. The Indian Healing Clay is what I like to call my little trick in a bottle! It makes not only an amazing face mask, but I love bathing with it too. It makes my skin extremely soft and moisturized. I recently received this product, and never knew the wonderful uses it has! From cooking to massages. It makes an amazing massage oil, and I was really quite impressed with how well it absorbs. I thought that it would make my skin feel oily or unclean, but made it feel quite the opposite. I love it so much that I decided to test to see how it would do as a moisturizer on my legs after I get out of the shower. It not only made me skin softer than your usual lotion, but made shaving better as well. It has also kept me from getting shave bumps as much too. I have been using it everyday for a month, and still have 3/4 a bottle left. If your looking for a great moisturizer or massage oil (among many other things!) I would highly recommend this product.I received a sample of this product (either free or at a discounted price) in exchange for my honest review. All opinions stated are that of my own and have in no way been swayed.

What I love about the Epica 3-Piece Ash Bucket set is that not only is it useful, but it looks great in my home as well. It's a very sleek design, and you can just tell once you take it out the box it's made of quality.The first thing I noticed was how much it holds! It is a 6-gallon bucket, leaving plenty of room for multiple fires. Which is great so I won't have to go outside everyday to empty it, on those weeks I decide to light it everyday.The next thing I noticed was the handle. There is just something about it that gives the bucket set that extra added touch of class. I also like that it has ridges designed for your hand, making it easier to carry.You are also provided a shovel with a 4.5"W scoop and maneuverable 12.5" long handle. It complements the color of the bucket, along with my other fireplace items. Once you're done using it, it easily fits back in place in the storage pocket on the side of the bucket for next time.If you have a fireplace, I think this is a must have item! It's not only useful, but it looks great with any fireplace. Seriously, I'll take one of these over a box any day! ha-ha.

My dog really enjoys these! I like how they are easy enough for her to chew, but at the same time it takes her a little while to completely be done with them (she is a german shepard). Everytime she comes back from outside, she is always scratching at the bag to get more. I also like that they have no odor whatsoever to them, and that they are 100% natural making them safe for my fur baby. There was prolly are 8-10 sticks in the oz pack. I do think the price is a little high, but you do get quality treats. I would recommend these if your looking for low odor, natural, and solid treats.

The first thing I was amazed at was not only the quality of these dish towels, but the size! These are huge! They do a great job at drying dishes and don't fill up with water fast, making it so you can get through a full load of drying dishes and then some. They are also perfect for embroidery. They aren't so thick they you can't stick a needle through, but thick enough to where it has some quality to it. I plan on using one of these for Easter, and love that I can customize these how I want. The towels are also really soft, and great for putting between dishes to layer them. For the price you truly are getting a steal, and I would highly recommend these.

My dog Kuchen (pronounced koochen meaning little cupcake in german) is quite picky when it comes to treats. However, she LOVES these! Everytime she comes inside without barking I will give her a treat, and each time she comes in she nuzzles the bag for more. They don't make her breathe smell bad, they are a great size for her (she's a German Shepard) but can be broken apart for smaller dogs with ease. They aren't rock hard, but aren't soft either. There also a great amount in the bag for the price and size, I think it's a great deal. I would say in my bag there was around 30 of them, and each one was around 7 inches long. I would definitely recommend these if your dog enjoys beef jerky or your looking for good quality treats for your pet.

I normally use a scented liquid detergent on my laundry, but these new packets clean quite well without a scent -- a boon to those who are allergic to perfumes or just don't want their laundry to have an artificial scent. I used one packet in a medium load of towels, washed in hot water, and two packets in a large load of sheets, washed in warm water, and both came out clean and fresh. Since these packets are pre-measured, they are easy to use -- you just put one or two of them in the bottom of the washer tub and then add the laundry on top of them. Of course, like any product of this type, you need to keep the packets away from kids and animals who might eat them, but these clear packets look less like candy than some similar products on the market now.
Cute story about a financially strapped teacher who decides to his, um, assets to make extra money, with a friend acting as pimp.

I like this leave-in conditioner. I have fine, naturally curly hair, and many conditioners weigh it down. This one doesn't. It defines my curls and helps tame the frizz without weighing my hair down. It has a light, fresh scent that might be too much for those allergic to perfumes, but for anyone else I think it would be fine. It's a cream, not a foam, that you spread through your still-damp hair with your fingers. I have short hair so I used a small amount -- a couple of pumps. If you have long hair, you'd need to use more. All in all, I'm pleased with this product.

Almost every American school child read Huckleberry Finn and most likely Tom Sawyer, but what are the real-life underpinnings of these stories? Author Andrew Levy explores the time in which Mark Twain grew up, a time when the nation was moving toward Civil War. But beyond the issues of slavery and race, there also were other fears. One of those was of boys -- teen and pre-teen -- committing vandalism and other crimes. There was a lot of concern about better supervision.This book was an eye-opener for me, not least because some of the issues that faced people more than a century and a half ago are still concerns in the present day. And it brought Mark Twain -- Samuel Clemens -- alive for me. This book is dense with information while also being an accessible read.

I love this shampoo and have been using it for years. It's mild and non-drying, but gets my hair clean without leaving it frizzy. My only complaint is the new bottle they are putting it in. The tab you're supposed to press down on the top to dispense the shampoo doesn't work, at least on the bottle I got, so I have to unscrew the lid to use it. Not a big deal, but if this is a common problem, the makers might want to talk to their bottle manufacturer.

No one I've ever read depicts the South quite like Rick Bragg. In his biographies "All Over But the Shoutin'" and "Ava's Man," he describes his own family history in a way that makes the reader feel the heat of Southern summer days and difficult relationships."My Southern Journey" is a series of essays -- I wouldn't even call them short stories because they aren't long enough -- written by Bragg over the years as he lived in different parts of the South. The book is divided into five sections: Home, Table, Place, Craft and Spirit, and the essays cover everything from college football to crawdads. I laughed out loud on many occasions at his sly wit, but other stories are a poignant view of a South that Bragg believes is gone forever. As people crouch inside their air conditioned homes on hot summer days, he misses the big, shady front porches where people used to sit with a glass of iced tea and chat with whoever stopped by.This isn't a book you can rush through -- the language is there to be savored like biscuits and gravy. Bragg's descriptive powers are prodigious. In just a few words, he can evoke sights, smells and emotions. The people he writes about aren't, for the most part, well-educated or sophisticated, but he portrays them with kindness. After years up North, writing for major publications including the New York Times, it's significant that he has moved back to the South and now is a professor of writing at the University of Alabama.I grew up in North Texas in the 1950s and '60s, and while it wasn't as Southern as what we refer to as the Deep South, these stories prompted memories of big meals at Christmas and Thanksgiving with my mother's extended family, and days of playing outside with neighborhood kids during broiling summers. I think this book has value for anyone who grew up in the South of those years, and also for anyone who loves outstanding writing.

A fun, funky album with a reggae vibe. Stone has a great voice, and the arrangements are upbeat. The only complaint I have is about the mailing box. This little CD arrived in a box designed to ship a pair of shoes. Very wasteful, even if I did recycle it. I guess Amazon uses whatever box is handy.

I have read all of this series and enjoyed it greatly. The writing is excellent and the characters are engaging and believable. The author is at work on another book in the series, but the latest report I heard is that it won't be out until spring 2016. I just wish she wrote faster!

I normally eat muesli or granola as a topper for other cereals like Shredded Wheat or Life, so that's the way I tried this version. The taste is decent -- not too sweet like some products -- with the dried cranberries adding a fruity tang. I'm not sure I would buy it, though, at $13.25 for 11 ounces! I could mix my own, or buy it in bulk at the health food store, for considerably less. I'm not sure why this product is so expensive.

I've long been a fan of Elly Griffiths' Ruth Galloway series, so when I heard she was starting a new series, I had to check it out. Unlike the Galloway series, which is set in the present day, The Zig Zag Girl is set in 1950, as England recovers from the war. The main characters are the former members of a British (semi) military unit called the Magic Men, composed of illusionists and code-breakers with the goal of confusing the Nazis. Head of the unit was the beautiful Charis, who was killed during the war when a model of a battleship went up in flames while she was on it.Now, five years after the war, the men keep loose contact with each other but have gone their separate ways. Edgar Stephens is a detective inspector for the Brighton police force, and Max Mephisto is a magician on the theater circuit, still drawing a crowd but worrying about how the public's taste in entertainment has changed since the war.Max, Edgar and the rest of the Magic Men are brought together again after the body of a beautiful young woman is found sawed into three pieces in a gory re-creation of a magic trick called the zig zag girl. On stage, of course, it's all an illusion, but in this case it's horribly real. And she won't be the last one to die, either.I don't want to give away too much of the plot, but I found this an enjoyable read, even if I didn't like it as much as the Galloway novels. There is plenty of suspense, though unfortunately (because I like to be surprised) I figured out who the killer was about three-quarters of the way through the book. Still, this is a decent opening to a new series, and I will read the next book when it comes out. Since it's set more than half a century before the Galloway books, the tone is a little different, but Griffith's way with words still shines.

Claire Scott is the wife of Paul, a successful architect in Atlanta. She lives the good life -- big house, lots of entertaining, country club tennis. Then Paul is murdered in front of her in a robbery gone very wrong, and suddenly Claire is thrust into a nightmare. Little by little, she learns her husband wasn't who he pretended to be -- that there was a dark side to him she didn't know.Not that she didn't suspect, however. The author leaves little clues that all was not right in the marriage: Claire had an affair with one of Paul's closest friends, and, even though Paul wanted a large family, she pretended infertility when she actually had an IUD and was taking birth control pills.Lydia Delgado is Claire's long-estranged sister, who struggles to get by financially. She and Claire, and their parents, were devastated 20 years ago by the disappearance of Julia, the third sister in the family. Julia has never been found, and there's been no closure for the family.The murder of Paul Scott catapults the two sisters into their own investigation of who he really was. And in the process, they put their own lives in danger, because while Paul may be out of the picture, his associates are not.This is a tightly-written thriller with a complex plot and believable characters. I haven't read any of Slaughter's other novels, but I plan to do that soon. This book is a step or two above the usual murder mystery.

This sponge works well cleaning surfaces in my bathroom, including the shower. Used with spray-on cleaner (generic 409), it gets hard-water stains off the bath tiles. At this point I am using it in my bathrooms instead of the kitchen because I have a stainless steel sink and granite counters, neither of which I want to risk scratching. But this sponge is great for areas where scratches aren't an issue. It fits well in my hand and cleans up easily after a job. It isn't recommended for stainless steel surfaces, and I wouldn't use it on non-stick cookware, but other than that, I think it's great.

This novel takes longtime Seattle detective J.P. Beaumont back to the past as he struggles to resolve unfinished business from decades ago. The first is a very cold case -- the unsolved murder of a young woman more than 30 years ago whose nude body was found in a barrel of grease that had been rolled down a hillside. The second is not a criminal case, but it does involve a death -- that of Beau's squadron leader in Vietnam 40 years ago. A generous act by the officer saved Beau's life in the same firefight that killed the squadron leader, and Beau has always felt guilty that he didn't look up the man's fiancée to offer his condolences.Both of these cases come back to Beau in vivid dreams, the result of the painkillers he's taking after having a double knee replacement. He feels like both the murdered girl and his old squadron leader are speaking to him in these dreams, telling him he has things left to do. So, even though he's still laid up in the hospital or, later, at home, Beau starts looking into them both. The results show that the past doesn't always stay there, and that it can be downright dangerous to dig into old wrongs.I enjoyed this book. It was a good mystery, while also giving a taste of what Beau was like as a young detective still learning his craft. Be sure to read the author's note at the end of the book -- some of what happened in the story is taken from life.

This is a light, scent-free moisturizing cream that I use both in the morning and before going to bed. It's a cream -- not a lotion, which is what I had been using -- but it's not greasy and goes on smoothly. It hydrates my skin overnight, and in the morning it's a good base for my makeup, which goes on smoothly. The scent-free option is a plus for those who are allergic to perfumes. It's not cheap -- $34.20 on Amazon for a 4-ounce jar -- but you have to use so little of it each time that it's bound to last a good while. I'm not using any of the other products in this line, which the manufacturer recommends, but it still works well.
This two-disc set has all their greatest hits, and the sound quality is great. It brought back a lot of memories for me, but anyone who enjoys good rock will probably like this collection.

While this is a novel, it is based on truth -- the story of the two Grimke sisters, Sarah and Angelina, who became famous fighters against slavery in the decades before the Civil War. The sisters grew up in Charleston to a slave-owning family, and over time, as the novel explores, they became rabid foes of "the peculiar institution."The story is told through the alternating views of Sarah, from the age of 12 to her 30s, and Hetty (nicknamed Handful), the slave given to her as a 12th birthday present. Since Hetty is only a year or two younger than her mistress, the two grow up together. Their voices tell the story of slavery from both sides, including brutal punishments and small acts of rebellion.I loved Kidd's earlier book, The Secret Life of Bees, which also centered on black/white relationships, but much later, around the time of the Civil Rights Act. The books have a different feel, but the main issue is the same.I recommend this novel to anyone who likes Kidd's work or wants to read a good story about the struggle to end slavery.

I really enjoyed this book. It's a look into life in Cambodia for both natives and foreigners, focusing on the corruption and want in daily life for those who live there -- as opposed to those who come to work there. The book is atmospheric, giving the reader a real idea of what it's like to live in a country that still is recovering from the Khmer Rouge atrocities of the previous century. The story was absorbing, with lots of twists and turns. I had to guess who the good guys and bad guys were. This is an excellent effort for a first novel, and I look forward to future books by this author.

I love Celtic jewelry, and these earrings go with other pieces I have. They are lightweight but well made, with long ear wires. They are smaller than the photo makes them appear -- the decorated part is 1 inch long -- and it's best to use some kind of plastic "stop" on the back to keep them from slipping out. But they are light enough not to pull at my earlobes, which is great. If you like Celtic designs in jewelry, check these out.

Despite its title, this book is about much more than just one year. It follows the U.S. through a period of isolationism until Pearl Harbor brings the nation into the war. It follows FDR, wily and determined, who promises that America will stay out of the war until he can no longer do so. Once America comes into the war, the tide begins to turn against Germany, but slowly.Much of this book focuses on the Nazi death camps and the horrifying details that started to trickle out about what went on there. Why did it take more than a year for Roosevelt to approve a refugee board? As always, politics were involved.Balanced against all of this was Roosevelt's failing health, which was an open secret among leaders in the U.S. and elsewhere. In all, it was a very tricky time for an attempt to both end a war and rescue Jewish prisoners.This is a long book -- more than 500 pages -- and I think it could have been condensed somewhat, focusing more on the year in the title and less on the run-up to it. But Winik is a good writer who brings dry facts to life through his depiction of the interesting personalities involved. Like his earlier book, 1865 -- one of my favorite Civil War histories -- it focuses on the waning days of a massive conflict. For those who enjoy detailed, well-written history, this is a good read.

This is an entertaining, just-scary-enough book for older kids, featuring a witch, a creepy doll, and a cabin in the woods that looks derelict in the daytime but comes alive at midnight.When his father loses his job in posh Fairfield, Connecticut, Daniel and his younger sister, Erica, find themselves moving to Woodville, West Virginia, an economically depressed area where the siblings are reviled as snobs at the local school. The family moves into a dilapidated farmhouse where the paint is peeling and the roof leaks. Both kids want to go back to their old life, but it isn't possible. And then they start to hear the strange stories about a girl who lived in their house 50 years ago -- until she disappeared and was never heard from again. And then Erica disappears ...Mary Downing Hahn has plenty of experience in writing spooky stories for kids, and it shows in this book, which will give readers the chills but hopefully not nightmares. It flows well and kept my interest until the end. The characters are likable (except for the evil ones), and within the supernatural boundaries of the story, the situations and relationships are realistic. It's a fun read.

I first tried this product on a rainy day. Humidity always makes my naturally wavy hair frizz, but this crème kept that at a minimum. I have fine hair that tends to be dry, and it's also color-treated. This product conditioned it while not weighing it down, which has been a problem with other conditioners. The directions also say to leave it on only two minutes, so I can use it while taking a shower instead of having to rinse it out later. It has a nice, floral scent. I used it with my regular shampoo, not the recommended Pantene product, but it still worked well. The tube isn't large, but since I have short hair it should last me for awhile. All in all, I recommend this product.

After tackling the subject of the ancient Jews who fought at Masada in The Dovekeepers, Alice Hoffman now moves forward in time to the 1800s on a Caribbean island for The Marriage of Opposites. Rachel Pomie is the daughter of Jewish immigrants to the tropical island of St. Thomas, controlled at that time by Denmark. She rebels against her overbearing mother and dreams of going to Paris.That dream is dashed when she's married off to a fellow immigrant, a widower twice her age with several children who can help save her family's struggling business. Although Rachel never falls in love with her husband, he is a good man who treats her well. They have four four children together, including one who is born after Rachel's husband dies when Rachel is in her late 20s.All of this is a rather slow-moving prelude to the real crux of the story -- Rachel's torrid love affair with Frederic Pizzarro, her husband's nephew, whom the family send over from Paris to take over the business. The pair are passionately attracted to each other from their first meeting, with joy and scandal the inevitable result because Jewish law prohibits marriage between two members of the same family. Although Rachel and Frederic are not related by blood, the fact that they are related by marriage is sufficient. Their relationship causes them to be ostracized by their fellow immigrants.Hoffman's writing style is both lush -- in describing the beauty of St. Thomas -- and deliberate -- in the slow buildup to the crux of the story. The writing elevates this story above a simple romance.The story is based on truth, because Rachel and Frederic were the parents of Camille Pissarro, one of the greatest artists of the Impressionist school. He changed his name to a more French spelling after moving to France.This is a fascinating story, but it moves at a slow pace. Still, it made me care about the characters and their troubles and triumphs.

Pallavi Aiyar, a native of India, was working as a journalist in China when she learned that she and her Spanish husband would be moving to Brussels, Belgium. It sounded like a great change -- from the crowds, inconveniences and pollution of Beijing to a more developed, cleaner environment for them and their two young sons. And some things did improve. But this was 2009, the year the European economy took a nosedive. Added to that was the increasing disruption caused in Europe by the millions of immigrants coming from Asia, Africa and the Middle East, with their own customs and religions.As Aiyar relates in this book, the gravy train of social programs and benefits that most Europeans have been enjoying for the past half-century is starting to rumble to a stop in the face of more residents in need and increasing competition from countries like China and India where labor is much cheaper than in Europe. One thing she noticed immediately upon moving to Brussels was the frequency of labor strikes by people working in conditions that workers in developing countries could only dream about.Aiyar details the diamond industry in Antwerp, Belgium, which for many years was dominated by powerful Jewish families. Now, Indians have taken over that trade by using cheap labor in India to cut the stones -- and, some say, by being willing to work harder than the less-desperate Europeans.Aiyar discusses the effect of massive immigration on both the Europeans and the immigrants themselves. Despite images to the contrary, she writes, the vast majority of immigrants are poor. Climate control also comes under Aiyar's microscope, with a glimpse into the frustrating bureaucratic maze that greets those trying to hammer out a climate agreement.Aiyar is clear-eyed about the problems in developing countries. Her elder son suffered from respiratory illness while they were living in China. Once they moved to Brussels, the problems quickly cleared up. And she describes life even for the wealthy in India as being fraught with challenges. I recently returned from a visit to India, and I found her observations of the way most people live there to be right on target.This is an exceptionally well-written book that lays out the inevitable clash between Old World (European) culture and developing world culture. Writing from the perspective of an Indian, Aiyar brings a new voice to the discussion. I enjoyed this book and recommend it to anyone who is interested in the changes in today's world.

It's been 10 years since Juliet Townsend graduated from high school, but she still remembers how it feels to be second-rate in almost everything -- looks, running speed, self-confidence -- to beautiful track star Maddy Bell. A decade on, Juliet is still living in that same small town in the middle of nowhere, working as a cleaning lady at the Mid-Night Inn, a rundown motel, and barely making ends meet. Maddy headed off to college and hasn't been heard from since. Juliet, ashamed of her lack of accomplishments, has no plans to attend the high school's 10-year reunion.Then, out of the blue, Maddy breezes into town with a huge rock on her left hand and talk of her glamorous life in Chicago. Surprisingly, she decides to spend the night at the Mid-Night Inn, and she and Juliet meet at the bar, where Juliet lets her long-simmering resentments show. Hours later, Maddy is dead, an apparent suicide that turns out to be murder. But who did it? There are a host of people who knew Maddy in high school and didn't much like her.Juliet, who finds herself the chief suspect, starts looking into the mystery to clear her own name, and perhaps lay to rest the ghosts of her high school years. She's helped and hindered by people who could be suspects themselves, and she begins to ask herself why she has settled for a second-best life for the past decade.This book is so full of twists and turns that it kept me guessing until the author wanted me to figure out who the murderer was. Along the way, the reader learns that Maddy's life wasn't as perfect as it seemed, and that even the most benign-seeming people can have a dark side.I enjoyed Rader-Day's first novel, The Black Hour, and this one (which is not a sequel) is an absorbing read. The characters are well-developed and believable, even if you don't like some of them very much. It also made me glad I did not grow up in a small town, where people know too much about each other and don't shrink from using it to their own advantage.

This gentle product with a light, pleasant scent does a decent job cleaning such things as metal garage doors and patio furniture. I don't have mold or mildew, so I can't say how well it works on that. The main advantage I see to this product is convenience -- the spray bottle is way easier to use than hauling around a bucket of soapy water and a brush. But the solution isn't that strong, so you still will have to scrub some stains. It is more environmentally friendly than many similar products. I sprayed it on my metal garage doors and then wiped them with a rag. The dirt came off well. Then I hosed them down to remove the residue. I tried this product on bricks that have hard-water lime stains from my sprinkler system. Some of the stain came off, but not all of it. I understand there are stronger products to use on lime stains, though. All in all, I probably wouldn't go out of my way to buy this product, but it does have convenience in its favor, and it probably won't damage what it's cleaning.

Fleas are a big problem where I live, so anything that promises to make keeping them off my dog easier gets my attention. This one includes an applicator that parts the dog's fur so the insecticide will reach the dog's skin.Unfortunately, at least for me, this product was more trouble than it was worth. Instead of an easy squeeze down my dog's spine, I had to load an applicator -- during which process I accidentally sprayed a small amount of product in my eye. I immediately flushed it out with water and all is well, but I think this device makes the whole process more difficult than it needs to be. That being said, I have a short-haired dog, so someone with a thick- or curly-coated dog might find it more useful. I plan to stick to my traditional product in the future.

Paula McLain, whose last novel The Paris Wife told the story of Ernest Hemingway's first wife, Hadley, turns to another historical figure in this book: Beryl Markham, whose adventures growing up in Kenya and as an aviator in the 1920s and '30s were profiled in her autobiography, West With the Night. McLain draws heavily on that memoir, and a number of other sources, to tell the story of a woman who lived life on her own terms, regardless of what others said about her.Beryl was raised and spent most of her life in Africa, near Kenya's Rift Valley, where her father farmed and raised horses after moving from England in the early 1900s. Beryl's mother soon got enough of the primitive lifestyle and moved back to England when Beryl was four years old. Beryl didn't see her again until she was well into adulthood, and that abandonment played a part in making her the woman she became.Beryl married young, to a nearby farmer, but the marriage didn't work out. It was the first of her three marriages, and she also had many affairs. Her father let her run wild as a young girl, picking her playmates from the local tribes and riding her horse far and wide. Perhaps it was that childhood freedom that kept her from really settling down as an adult. She became a successful racehorse trainer and eventually a pilot. In the '30s, she flew her plane across the Atlantic, becoming the first woman to fly across the ocean from east to west.Beryl was a complex character, with a good deal of charm but also a disregard for the feelings of others. She became friends with Karen Blixen, who under the pen name Isak Dinesen wrote the memoir Out of Africa. Beryl wound up having an affair with Denys Finch Hatton, who was also Blixen's lover.  Beryl never seemed to worry much about scandal, which followed her throughout much of her adult life.This book is told first-person in Beryl's voice, and as such it manages to paint her as a more sympathetic character than many biographers might have done. While I couldn't admire some of her actions, I found Beryl's story engrossing -- a window into an Africa that is long gone.

I like this lotion. It is scent-free and goes on smoothly, with no greasy feel. It's not heavy or sticky. The cold weather is pretty much gone now, and that's when I suffer from dry skin. But this product forms a good barrier to hold moisture in, so I think it would work well in the winter. It definitely softens my skin.

It's not human bones that cause most of the excitement in Craig Johnson's latest Longmire mystery -- it's dinosaur bones. A young paleontologist working on a spread owned by a Native American family stumbles across what may be the largest and most complete Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton ever found.Coincidentally -- or perhaps not -- the patriarch of the landowners is found dead in a turtle pond on his property not long after the dinosaur bones, estimated to be worth millions of dollars, are found. The dead man's family claims ownership of the bones, and their tribe and the federal government soon make their own claims.It's a rich stew for Sheriff Walt Longmire and his undersheriff Victoria Moretti to handle. Author Johnson does a great job in weaving the strands together and following Walt and his crew as they tease out the facts. Added to the mix is a visit by Walt's daughter, Cady, and her 4-month-old daughter, Lola, from Philadelphia. Cady is married to Vic's brother, Michael, who's a Philly cop.There are several twists to this story that I don't want to reveal, but suffice it to say that Dry Bones continues Johnson's solid series of Longmire mysteries.  For those familiar only with the TV series -- which thankfully was picked up by Netflix for a fourth season -- this book is much farther along the path and may contain some spoilers. It can be read as a stand-alone, but some familiarity with the story, either through previous books or the TV series, is helpful. It's an enjoyable read that leaves a few threads hanging for the next book.

This is a novel about two women, separated by more than 150 years, who have a common issue -- the inability to have children -- and also are connected by a house with a secret cellar where runaway slaves were held as a station on the Underground Railroad. The story jumps back and forth between the two stories, one set in the present day and one set mainly in the years just before the Civil War.One woman actually existed -- Sarah Brown, daughter of abolitionist John Brown, who led the ill-fated raid on Harper's Ferry, W. Va., in 1859. The other is Eden Anderson, a woman living with her husband Jack in present-day New Charlestown, W. Va., in a house the couple would like to rehab and sell. The main drama in Eden's life is her failure to carry a baby to term despite a series of infertility treatments. Her bitterness over this failure is straining her marriage. In Sarah's life, the Harper's Ferry raid and its aftereffects are the main drama, as family and friends are killed during the fighting and her father is soon executed. A near-fatal illness has left her unable to conceive a child.I finished this book glad that I had stuck with the story to the end, which was moving and uplifting. But the pace is somewhat slow, and the continual jumping from past to present and back again was distracting. I'm not sure the modern-day plot line was needed -- the saga of Sarah Brown, her family and her fellow abolitionists would have been engrossing enough.

Originally posted at fantasyliterature.comDetectives Dan Carter and Charlie Hammond have finally tracked down and cornered the perverse serial killer known as The Child-Catcher. Found in his own home, the detectives move in, focused on a speedy capture, before the Child-Catcher performs his bizarre version of open-brain surgery.Charlie takes the lead, turns up a flight of stairs and Carter hears a shot ring out. He follows, and sees the Child-Catcher sitting against a wall, a pool of blood in his lap, and a seemingly serene smile on his lips. “Suicide by cop”. On the wall: a string-connected ‘psycho wall’.Further down the hall, Carter’s partner is crying and laughing, Charlie put his S&W Model 5946 between his teeth, squeezed the trigger, and excused himself from life.Jonathan L. Howard is no stranger to the authorial weird. His resume, after all, includes the Johannes Cabal series — some genetic hybrid of horror, humor, gothic and, well, weird. Carter & Lovecraft contains elements of all of those, but is decidedly dark and heavy. And he writes a powerful opening. The child killer is seemingly caught by Hammond and Carter. He's shot and while dying, the senior officer places a pistol in his mouth and pulls the trigger. No reason why.Carter leaves the police and ventures off into the world of private investigation. While chasing cheating husbands, a lawyer appears in his office (rather mysteriously and… quietly), informing him that he’s been named the sole in inheritor of a home in Providence, Rhode Island. He’s never heard of his benefactor, one Alfred Hill, gone missing seven years ago.Howard writes wonderful prose. He’s noir without being clichéd or overdone. The narrative flows without seeming wordy, and is imbued with a subtle sense of humor:"I'm sorry," said Carter. "I didn't hear you come in.""I came in," said the man, as if to reassure him.Carter didn't need the reassurance on that point, but it was kind of the man to offer it, all the same.Hill’s ‘home’ is actually a bookstore: "Hill's Books -- Antiquarian & Secondhand”. Emily Lovecraft is Hill’s niece and has been managing the store since Hill’s disappearance. It will surprise no one that Emily is related to the Lovecraft of Providence fame, ol H.P. And yes, she’s the last in the Lovecraft lineage.More weird happenings orbit Carter and Lovecraft, and they find themselves pulled by the gravity of a series of deadly events. A mathematician magician has an uncanny ability to ‘influence chance’, and while taking advantage of casinos also seems to defy physics in several apparent murders.It’s clear that the events in and around Providence are not mere magic, nor are they of the natural world. This is, after all, the home turf of H.P. Lovecraft and his dramatically interwoven tales of cosmic horror. Emily is a reluctant expert of her ancestor’s writings and history and is able to tease out from the clues of the recent murders to connect the dots with her own family history. Providence isn’t normal… nor has it ever been."Everything… is kind of f**** up. And by ‘everything,’ I mean everything. Nothing is right, nothing is as it appears. I don’t just mean in some nihilistic, conspiratorial, paranoid kind of way. I mean fundamentally. And the joke is, it used to be worse. Then, back in the twenties, a group of guys figured out what was wrong, and how they could fix it."The world seems to becoming UN-fixed. And it’s no accident that former Det. Carter is involved.I’ll stay away from any further plot description/spoilers, but suffice it to say, there’s a whole lot of Lovecraftian weirdness, including disjointed cities, immortal creatures of the sea, and horrors that cause insanity with just a mere glimpse.My biggest frustration with the pantheon of Lovecraftian writing is the lack of high quality long-form fiction. The space is awash with short stories, novellas and anthologies (I recently reviewed a Cthulhu-Roman Empire mash up anthology on FanLit). Howard’s entrant is a terrific mystery, wrapped up in a detective tale, enveloped in the cosmic weird of Lovecraft. And it succeeds.Carter & Lovecraft concludes with a terrific plot twist. And while Howard has written a solid and definitive ending in its own right, there’s a plethora of potential for a sequel. Additionally, Warner Brothers has acquired the television rights for the series.

My 50-lb Greyhound LOVES these treats. I usually brush her teeth 3-4 times/week, but decided to hold off during the week I fed her these bones. And sure enough, her breath, while never smelling like a rose, did not get worse and I noticed a slight improvement in the discoloring of her teeth. Now keep in mind, I only used one package of Nutri Dent over the course of maybe three days.And my dog could not get enough of them. I gave her an entire piece at first and then doled them out segment by segment afterwards. I'm absolutely planning on purchasing more.

For the full review, please go to fantasyliterature.com"She shivers. She is cold, and she shivers, despite the blanket that wraps her, despite her mother’s enfolding arms.It is not the fever, but the place.A place that feels… old.Old when Rome was young. Old when the she-wolf gave suckle to Romulus and Remus. Old… beyond old. Ancient, and wrong."-from Fecunditati Augustae by Christine MorganTales of Cthulhu Invictus adds nine new stories to the large anthology subgenre of the Cthulhu mythos built upon the cosmic horror foundations laid by H.P. Lovecraft. This collection, edited by the accomplished Brian M. Sammons, has several very good stories by a collection of experienced writers. All fit well within the Cthulhu and Lovecraftian themes, though only a few effectively utilize the Roman place-and-time as an embedded enhancement rather than mere historical window dressing.Below you’ll find very brief summaries and quotes from each of the stories. These aren’t in their exact order from the anthology, but are loosely ranked in order of my favorites."Fecunditati Augustae" by Christine MorganEmpress Faustina is tormented by her inability to give Emperor Marcus Aurelias male heirs. She turns to dark magic to ensure her fertility, though not her children’s health. Morgan has a beautiful turn of phrase and does the best job of building Lovecraftian tension while providing effective hints of the otherworldly horrors. The characters have depth and dimension and, at only 15 pages long, the plot thoroughly embeds itself in its roman historical connections. I really love Morgan’s language and look forward to reading more from her."Seized and held. Roughly turned. Upended over a bony, knobby knee. The world tips as if it will spill out, sloshing like a rocked jar or amphora. The tough, callused heel of a hard hand strikes her a firm blow to the back. She utters a bleat of her own, a hideous glottal expulsion. Her throat opens and now she is the sloshing jar, the rocked amphora, contents emptying in a liquid splatter.""Vulcan’s Forge" by William MeikleThis story explores the idea that the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. may have been more than a simple issue of geophysical forces, but perhaps purposefully triggered to protect the world from a long ancient evil, primed to unleash its fury on the human race. Ancient explorers discover a mechanism deep within the volcano and find clues to its history."One thing is certain — it was designed and built by a race long since lost to man — a race of giant intellect so far above ours that we would be mere insects under their boots should they return."Plague of Wounds by Konstantine Paradias"I sleep in a corner in one of the back rooms of the Synagogue, miraculously left unscathed by the fire. The wound itches and breaks out into a stream of words, its lips flapping together like gums, its tongue lolling. In Greek and Aramaic and Latin and its own nonsense language, it foretells of the terrible doom that will befall the world."This terrific story is of rabbi wrought by an unholy plague, that manifests itself within his own body. He sells out his fellow man to protect his family, but when faced with selling out humanity, he has his soul’s redemption at stake."Lines in the Sand" by Tom LynchAn attempted murder and a cursed dagger drags former Legionary Caius out of his comfortable retirement and into battle with The King in Yellow – a character upon whom Lovecraft built components of his stories."As a Roman cohort stood against an army of unidentifiable creates, they saw: Towers taller than the grandest in Rome floated into view behind the opposing army. Through a haze, over a distant lake, lofty towers pulled the entire cohort’s focus. Everyone watched as the ethereal edifices board towards the sky, until something… changed. Faces feel as the beauty began to fade. Columns cracked, facades crumbled, and friezes fell.The figure in the lead had turned away, gazing back at this domain, and as it began to fade, fall, and decay, his shoulders dropped and his head fell forward. Caius could feel the torment flowing from the enemy. The anguish twisted into anger, then raging fury. The leader brought his head up.""The Temple of Iald-T’quthoth" by Lee Clark ZumpeAnother strong story that’s much more lurid and sanguine than the others, and effectively blends the historical place and time with the Lovecraftian themes.A killer, crucified outside the walls of Jerusalem dies horribly as the cross settles into its base:"… the crown of Jaddus’ skull burst wide open, its gory content spurting through the air. The think, viscid substance — a repugnant mix of brain, blood and gore — rained down on those soldiers ill-starred enough to be in close proximity. From the oozing, shattered husk of Jaddus’ head, a black swarm of small winged things, unseated from their next, took flight with much commotion, congregating briefly in burgeoning shadowy cloud that resembled and impossibly gargantuan monster."Over the next decade, each infected Legionary dies. Quintus knows he’s the last and leads the investigators to a cult leader… who’s a surprise to the characters, though much less so to the readers.

Originally posted at UNRV.comSteven Saylor has built his authorial reputation on modern historical fiction, particularly in the genre of historical mysteries. His “Roma Sub Rosa” series has seen 14 books published beginning in 1991 and continuing through 2015 with his 15th entrant in the series, “Wrath of the Furies: A Novel of the Ancient World”. This story is written primarily from the perspective of a young Gordianus, who grows up to become Gordianus the Finder, the Roman sleuth whose mysteries are set across the Roman Empire in Saylor’s Roma series. "Wrath of the Furies" is the third book of a trio of prequels to the Roma Sub Rosa series, this one set in Alexandria and Ephesus.And who are these Furies and why do they have wrath? Antipater explains to Mithridates:  " The winged sisters are three in number: Alecto, Megaera, and Tisiphone. They are older than Zeus and the other Olympian gods, having been born from the blood of Uranus when his son Kronos castrated him. They dwell among the dead in Tartarus, but are sometimes drawn to eat and to punish certain kinds of wickedness. Once they find the mortal culprit, they hound him relentlessly, circling him and shrieking, sting him with brass-studded scourges…They have snouts like dogs, bulging, bloodshot eyes, and snakes for hair. Their bodies are as black as coal, and they flit through the air on batlike wings."Mithridates has the Roman Empire shuddering due to the destructive force of his moving army. He has vowed to kill every Roman he can, but needs to ensure that he has raised the support, rather than ire, of the Furies. All good ancient commanders must heed their mighty gods. Gordianus has accidentally found himself smack in the middle of this Mithridates plot to pay obeisance to the Furies through human sacrifice.Saylor's narrative style is clean and straightforward. Like his character Antipater, he's not poetic, but the story is entertaining and, I suspect, will be of greatest interest to readers familiar with his characters and the Roma Sub Rosa storylines. Saylor continuously updates the reader as to the Roma Sub Rosa context of returning characters and plot elements. You can absolutely read “Wrath” independently from the rest of the series, but the experience will not be as satisfying. “Wrath of the Furies” is an enjoyable historical mystery and contains 320 pages.A second narrative perspective comes from Gordianus’ mentor, Antipater of Sidon, Greek poet of great renown who has been acting (mostly) as unwitting undercover spy working for Mithridates, scourge of the Roman empire and hero of Greeks across the Mediterranean. Antipater’s contribution to the story comes in the form of fragments from his diary. He reflects on his current status, and provides a view into the goings on of Mithridates who’s systematically bulldozing his way across the Empire destroying towns and cities and claiming the role of eastern avenger against the Roman Empire.The story circles a number of mysteries, plots and subplots that run concurrently throughout the narrative:1) A portion of the aforementioned diary arrives mysteriously at the home where Gordianus is staying in Alexandria. Gordianus travels east, into the thicket of Mithridates violence and hatred, to find his old mentor Antipater who seems to be in a desperate and dire situation in Ephesus.2) Gordianus is cooling his heels in Alexandria which, for the moment, is not a target for Mithridates and so is a relative safe haven for Romans in the outskirts of the Empire. Gordianus must uncover, and perhaps eliminate, the plot of the great Mithradites to destroy all Romans residing in the outer territories of the Empire.3) Pushed into a role of spy himself, Gordianus must also determine the fate and location of several secondary characters of varying levels of interest.Antipater provides the more interesting elements of the plot as he writes in his diary from within Mithridates coterie. At times, he’s relegated to dining tables with the jugglers and entertainers who are available at the King’s beck and call, and sometimes called into consultation with the great king.Antipater describes in great detail the environment of life from the edges of the King’s court, including the horrifically grim death of a Roman general bound with his mouth forced open and fed molten gold. And yes, this is all too familiar for fans of “Game of Thrones” who read (or saw) Khal Drogo kill the despicable Viserys Targaryen in a very similar manner, however Saylor’s retelling is completely based in fact.What’s less factual is the storytelling tone and language. Everyone speaks in a fairly modern manner, replete with terms that were clearly originated well after the time frame in which this story is placed. Antipater describes himself acting like an ‘automaton’, using a term that wasn’t first spoken until the early 17th century (so sayeth Websters, at least). Considering Saylor’s reputation for historical authenticity, I was disappointed in the contemporary stylings of dialogue and narration; though do acknowledge that it may be purposeful as he targets his appropriate reading audience.Considering that Antipater reminds us (every few pages) that he’s a poet of only the highest caliber, his diary fragments are rather less than poetic. They move the story well, and provide the most interesting elements of the narrative, but the language used is merely descriptive and mundane. I would’ve preferred to see Antipater's character and personality developed through the language within the diary. His profession is certainly not apparent outside of his own braggadocio.

Overall, these Lonovo headphones are a good inexpensive product. I'm most impressed with the sound quality at all volume levels, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend this, but......but there are two issues:1 - I've tried wearing the headphones with all three size ear cushions. And the things just don't fit correctly. I think it has to do with the unique angled earpiece mechanism over which the cushions rest. They're intended to angle towards the eardrum. For me, it just doesn't fit properly.2. The plastic shell that covers the sound-carrying wire came off without much trouble. And it shouldn't come off at all. It fits back on, but it's now loose and generally insecure.

This is an awesome mug. The vacuum element comes from the flip-top opening which closes in such a way to create suction/vacuum within the mug. When closed, it won't leak or spill. When closed, it keeps the hot hot and the cold cold.I've tested with hot coffee and I've tested with cold drinks. It's truly amazing and works as advertised. The hot lasted for well over an hour during an early morning drive to the airport about 25 miles from my home.The no-spill aspect works as well. The top screws on firmly and the tight-fitting vacuum flip top seals the beverage well. It won't spill...assuming you have the mug closed.I highly recommend this product.​

New York Review Books Classics has just packaged two novels by renowned author, editor and teacher William Sloane into a single offering, The Rim of the Morning: Two Tales of Cosmic Horror. Sloane is not an author I’d previously known, probably due to the fact that these stories are two of only three novels that he ever published. Stephen King contributes a short but impeccable introduction, providing a tight analysis of the stories and windows into Sloane’s background and style. Sloane wrote and edited primarily supernatural mystery/scifi, but is known in literary worlds as a writing teacher.The first of these novels, To Walk the Night, is a Lovecraftian tale of the investigation into an apparent murder and suicide. This is the much stronger of these two stories. It’s a heavy, moody, genre-bending mystery that drips with molasses-dread and alone is worth the full price of the book. The second is The Edge of Running Water, also mystery-based — the tale of an obsessed professor determined to find a way to communicate with his recently departed wife. Each story is about 200 pages long. I’ve reviewed them separately below.To Walk the NightA thing of beauty is a joy for ever:Its loveliness increases; it will neverPass into nothingness; but still will keep– From Endymion (A Thing of Beauty) by John KeatsThe first story is a weighty and serious scifi/mystery, with Greek tragedy in its tone from the outset. Sloane borrows generously from the myth of Selene, goddess of the moon, who asks Zeus to keep her beautiful human lover, Prince Endymion, forever young. To Walk the Night is suggestive of this myth, though, and not too literal, but it’s fun to catch Sloane’s references to the ancient story sprinkled liberally throughout this novel.The story opens as our primary narrator, Berkeley (called Bark), journeys to bring his best friend’s ashes home following his suicide. Jerry Lister’s death weighs heavily on Bark, and forms the narrative momentum for the initiation of the story. In many ways, this is a 1930s CSI, as Bark must work back through recent events, piece by piece, to uncover all the details and identify what’s pertinent and relevant to Jerry’s suicide.Through Bark, Sloane dramatically builds the density and importance of the full backstory and makes clear the dread and imperative nature of the need to find the true reason why Jerry shot himself. Bark reflects on the complexity of events leading up to the suicide and remembers an “atmosphere of strangeness, even of terror, which was so much a part of my life while these events were in progress.”To Walk the Night feels very gothic: there is a dark and deep polished walnut-tone vibe to Bark’s narration and exposition. The mythological themes are set early, though I only caught the first Selene clue in retrospect, upon reviewing my notes. Not all references are directly related to the story of Selena and Endymion, but the suggestion is always there… sometimes a little deeper under the surface than other times.Bark dissects his recent trauma as part of a late-night discussion with his informally-adoptive father, Dr. Lister – also Jerry’s father. Bark ponders:Nothing in life, I think, ordinarily happens in great, thunderous episodes of obvious and romantic force. Life is a series of small things, and most of them mean much or little depending on how the observer thinks of them.It’s these small things, combined with some larger clues, that feed the narrative and drive the plot.Bark tells of a visit that he and Jerry made to a former professor — a misunderstood, antisocial, introverted and clearly obsessed scientist (Sloane seems to have been enamored with this character-type). The young men found Professor LeNormand, who had been working late and alone at the campus observatory, on fire and apparently murdered. This is the core mystery around which the remaining narrative revolves.And it’s at this point that we meet our goddess of the moon: Selena. Selena LeNormand is the professor’s widow and she’s just downright bizarre. In no way does she behave like a normal human, let alone someone who just lost the love of her life. She’s tall, lithe but strong, and thought by many to be the most beautiful woman in the world. Selena’s repeatedly thought of as more than statuesque, but statue-like. Her age is indeterminate, but she’s compared to the “Greek girls in the frieze of the Parthenon.”Sloane’s writing weeps with loaded language. Language that’s very purposeful in its dramatic flair, while implying things beyond the range of normal human activity:In the silences that lay between us I heard the bumbling of an insect against the glass of the lamp and the faint slither of water moving on the beach below us.Instead of doors, he refers to ‘portals’.There are suggestions of ghosts and that something horrible laying just out of sight. A shooting star “plummets down like a tear of light and vanished in the dark above the Sound.”Tables are described as altars.Likewise, the vocabulary reeks of symbolism and weighted meaning. The names, for example: Bark is the strength of the story, and like his namesake, his role is uber-protector of his friend and of that which is normal and sane. Jerry’s actual name is Jeremiah… and like his namesake, the prophet, his role is as a revealer, working to expose the truth of his former mentor. LeNormand was a French tarot reader famous during the reign of Napoleon, and like their namesake, both the professor and Selena are, in their own respects, seers beyond normal human perception.This is a dark any enjoyable read, with enough literary and narrative weight to stick with the reader days after its completion.For the full review, please visit fantasyliterature.com

I was a big fan of Dungeons & Dragons as an early teen. For a brief period I was a bit obsessed and saved my most nerdly of memories which Are still somewhere in my basement.This game falls into that general category of gaming. It's highly complex, intricate and will appeal to those with patience and who don't mind giving in to their inner Star Wars nerd.You can't play without a decent understanding and reading of the rules. Though there is a simple version to allow quick play.The gist is that one player is the x-wing fighter and the other is the two tie fighters. You maneuver and position to accomplish a specific goal as laid out in the rules.The game allows one player to choose their best strategic move while blind from your opponents counter move. And then you can battle. Maybe.The main set comes with three quality detailed models. One x-wing and two tie fighters. And a bunch of heavy stock cardboard pieces and plastic dice.I'm not judging, but you have to be of a certain mindset to play and enjoy this game. It's pretty cool to be honest. Just not for me.In the context for what it is and its target demographic, I highly recommend it.

This is a gorgeous three-piece set of jewelry and absolutely worth the price.1. All three are based in a rose-tinted gold tone. Each is light weight but feels sturdy and well-built.2. The crystals won't feel anyone looking for diamonds, but they sparkle and seem consistent with no obvious flaws.3. Each has the same style clasp with a subtle but attractive Anne Klein lion logo burned into the face. I think it's something innovative and attractive without being over designed.4. The watch face is simple and extremely easy to read. There's no date and it should be extremely easy to set.5. Each piece has one or two extra links to size down the item.Summary: I highly recommend this jewelry set. It's cost effective for three matching pieces, from a strong and reliable brand.Don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

My son and I performed a taste test between Nutro and another food that rhymes with Fancy Beast. In the taste test, Nutro performed extremely well. The cats 'seemed' to favor the Nutro, but honestly, it's a little hard to tell. They liked it...one of the cats appeared to go to this food first, but in the end both bowls in our blind taste test were empty by the end of the morning.The bad news is that Nutro is a bit more expensive than their competitor and I'm not sure if it's worth it. Do you trust the packaging and marketing materials? If so, it may be worth the additional cost.

This is a beautifully-made, thick office/desk chair.It's built solidly, and it's modern look is attractive and should appeal to many people.It's simply comfortable and has easily accessible adjustments, although there aren't many ways to adjust - just up and down.I had trouble putting it together. I would recommend having someone available to help. I couldn't get all of the screws to tighten 100% which either means they're an imperfect fit, or I should've had help putting the thing together. Give yourself a solid 30 minutes.All in all - this is recommended.

I got this for my two boys - 1 is a sophomore in high school and the other 7th grade middle schooler. They were both VERY excited about getting this drone. The packaging is solid, and the drone feels well-made.I asked them each for their lists of positives and negatives...Positives:Very Small: The drone is TINY. This will not be able to carry any kind of a phone/camera...its made to fit in the palm of your hand. And while it's pretty well made, it's still small and you'll have to take care of the props.It Can Do Cool TricksIt's FunNegatives:It's Very Hard to Trim - which means you'll have trouble creating a base stability of the drone. It'll almost always drift a little rather than stay perfectly still.It's Hard to Drive - this is from the middle schooler. I thought it wasn't that difficult and easier than others we've had.It Cam With Foreign Language Instructions - not sure if I just got an Asian version of what. But the English instructions are on the website. #oddandannoying

AmazonBasics Apple products are terrific. They're inexpensive and very high quality. I've purchased several AB products and actually prefer to use them over their comparable products shipped with my device.This cable is very short...primarily for us when you want to plug your lightning compatible device directly to your computer. There are no random extra loops of cord to to clutter up your workspace.I've had 100% success in this product working instantly and every single time I use it. I have a longer AmazonBasics lightning cable also and I will only buy AmazonBasics for my future needs.I can't recommend these products more strongly.

I'm finding this a difficult item to review. The snacks come in a high quality package and the food itself seems high quality. My dog snatch and gobbled up the first few I fed her but has stayed away after the initial feedings. I'm not 100% sure why, but to be fair, I'm going to edit and update this review after another week or so.I have no reason to think these aren't worth purchasing aside from my own dog's unpredictable vagaries in eating habits.

I assume that the primary role of these dishtowels is to help dry things. In that, they fail. Miserably. They're large and they're attractive, and they're serviceable for wiping one's hands, but they're terrible at wiping counters and kitchenware. I'm better off using my hands.I gave them a fair shot. I washed them multiple times, hoping that the absorbency "issue" was due to their newness. But after three washings, they're no better.I'm not sure under what conditions I would recommend these. Perhaps if one just needs hand-wiping towels for the kitchen. But that's it. Or maybe as single-use diapers.

I've given these headphones to my son who lives and dies by his iPad. He's gone through numerous headphones and I feel he's pretty well qualified to provide feedback.1. He loves them.2. They're noise canceling. I was sitting 10 feet from him and talking to him in an above average raised voice and he said he couldn't hear anything, only see my mouth moving.3. The padded ear phones are extremely comfortable.4. He likes the color combo of blue and purple, though the graphics on the ear pieces are a little goofy. He's 12, so it's possible they're just targeted towards a little younger.5. He liked the sound.6. They seem sturdy, but we'll need to give them a little more time to see how long they last.

This beautiful 2016 calendar offers spectacular images with informative captions and highlights of each location represented.
