I don’t want to say more as I don’t want to ruin any of the mystery for a reader, but it is a page turner and makes the reader take note of everything or he will miss important clues.I received a complimentary copy of this book for an honest review.

I think this is a book for readers who simply like this type of genre, an opinion I reached after reading the reviews before mine.  I also think it appeals to the masculine humor more perhaps than the female.Pros:  It has an interesting plot.  The author handles the back flashes well also.  Where the author elaborates that the protagonist is speaking to the reader, in essence this is called a first person point of view.Cons:  The beginning third of the book was so full of analogies, instead of good “show rather than tell” writing, that it loses the reader’s interest.  Also if the reader does not know the people in the analogies, it leaves him not understanding the meaning of the sentence.The author does have a sense of humor, but perhaps more for a comedian than a book.I was given a complimentary copy for an honest review.
Thewsizard setup works but the images disk doesn't load

I was in high school during WWII and I remember the news footage when General Eisenhower first visited Auschwitz, and even in these times there are people who claim that Auschwitz and the other death camps never existed.Although this story is written as fiction, the conditions and treatment of the Jews as related by Jack Fisher are true.  Jack was originally a Jew and imprisoned in the ghetto in Poland by the Nazis.  Jack and other small boys would make a hole in the wall and sneak out to steal food to eat, for the Nazis never let enough food be allowed into the ghetto to feed everyone sufficiently. At this time, Jack had a Jewish name as Jacob, so he spoke Polish, and then had to learn German, which the Germans demanded.  Jack was rather blond with blue eyes, so he didn’t look Jewish, but more Polish.  One time when Jack was out stealing, he entered a Catholic Church.  The priest gave him food and told him to come back weekly and he would have food for him.  The priest also recognized the fact that Jack looking Polish might save his life, so he dye Jack’s hair more blond and told Jack to use the Polish version of Jacob and he also taught him some Catholic prayers.  Thus Jack was able to save his life and as the years passed, he said he was Catholic.  Eventually the priest was taken away by the Gestapo.  Jack was four and five years old during these times.Then the Nazis began to move the Jews out of the ghetto, over-loaded them on freight train cars and sent them to Auschwitz.  Eventually all of Jack’s family was killed and the only reason why Jack wasn’t was because the Nazis thought him Polish and Dr. Mengele never got around to experimenting on him like he did the other children.  Through this story Jack tells about the atrocities that occurred.The slant in this story against other tales of Nazis and the Jews is that the story takes place in 2039, the Holocaust of the murder of six million Jews took place from 1939 to end of WWII and in the meantime in 2019 there was a slaughter of twenty-thousand Christians by Muslims, which was considered the Great Holocaust.Jack is now one hundred years old and there were only four or five other Jews that old who were Holocaust victims.  One by one they suffered mysterious deaths.  The officials of Austria, Germany and several European countries claimed Jack and the others lied.  That they did have camps where they simply held people who were considered anti-German.Jack spoke up about his experiences when he had a chance and his great grand-daughter, Christine, was able to get documented proof of these camps and the names and numbers who were killed, as they were original Nazi records.This put Jack and Christine’s lives in danger.  And the story continues with what they went through to prove what Jack said.  This is a fantastic plot, a page turner, but a true historical story based on facts.  I received a complimentary copy for an honest review.

In 1840, Captain Eli Gaspar was in charge of a whaling ship off the coast of Puerto Rico.  He left a wife, Sarah, and a small daughter, Charlotte.  Eli and Sarah were very much in love,  but she was a weak woman and she worried always about Eli when he was away at sea, and she had problems coping with life when he was away.  He wouldn’t change occupations because whaling paid best.  In his last trip, they harpooned the biggest bull whale he had ever seen, and after hours of struggling to wear the whale out, it suddenly energized and smashed the whale boats, including the main ship that Eli was on.  There was a young boy, Henry, on the ship and Eli told him to go to the after house because that is where the men went when there was danger.  Eli finally drowned after three days floating on the roof of the after house, which was all that remained of the original ship.In Eli’s home town of Cold Springs Harbor, Long Island, a painter was renting this 300 year old house and he continuously painted pictures of ships and whaling and especially one portraying the last hours of Eli’s life.  It was always a mystery how this painter, who had never been to sea, was so accurate, but he made a fortune. After he died, a young divorcee, Remy, and her young daughter, Olivia, rented the house.  This didn’t set well with Eli, but Olivia was extra sensitive.  The rest of the story is composed of the trials and errors that continued in this house until a solution was finally reachedThis is an entertaining quick read and contains no ghostly horrors, but instead is amusing.  I enjoyed it.  I was given a complimentary copy for an honest review.

I haven't been able to use my Step-by-Step book yet because I can't download the practice files.  When I use the website set forth in the book it is no longer there.  It has been removed and I can't find a phone number for Microsoft Press nor any manner to conact Joan Lambert to find out where I can get these now.  As it is, I can't even start to study the book.  I hope Joan answers this and I would appreciate a direct answer to j.adamak@yahoo.com as it will be faster for me.Joan Adamak

The protagonist, Billy Redmond, has been hiding out in the mountains of Montana for twelve years ever since his wife, Jane, and daughter, Aspen were killed in a fire.  His former home was  Spokane, Washington but none of his family knew where he was except that he had left word with the director of an assisted living institution where his father and mother lived.  This was in case anything happened to either.  The director contacted him because his father, suffering from dementia, had passed.  He drove his old pickup to Spokane and stood back during the funeral, intending to leave immediately thereafter.  But as life so often does to us, he was not allowed to return to his former life. A few months prior, his brother, Trevor, and wife had been murdered while on a trip in Europe, leaving a six year old girl, Gracie, and a teenager, Kendall.  His mother, who was a very bossy and caustic person, spotted him and told him he had to show up for the reading of the will the next day.Trevor and wife had left the guardianship of their girls to Billy and Trevor’s sister, April, but Billy’s mother got a court order vacating April as guardian because she was a drug addict and could never be found, and appointing Billy.  Billy hadn’t been around children for so long, Kendall proved difficult, Gracie loveable, Billy’s mother impossible and then a stranger claimed that Billy’s daughter, Aspen, was alive but in jail in Spokane, going by the name of Libby and that he should go help her.From then on Billy is on a fast track trying to catch up and learn the truth of a multitude of lies, raise Trevor’s daughters, develop a kinship with his now nineteen year old daughter, Libby, and learn the truth of Jane’s death.  The author has a wit about him that shows throughout this story and although the plot is very convoluted, it is entertaining as Billy attempts to untangle everyone’s lives and find a new romance for himself.I enjoyed this book and would recommend it to anyone for a few hours of light reading.  I received a complimentary copy for an honest review.

This is one of the best books I have read lately.  It immerses one in the Muslim and Western worlds.  Muslims, Jews and Christians created a culture of tolerance in medieval Spain before Spain existed.  The area dominating this story was called Andalus by the Arabs and Berbers, Iberra by the Greeks and Hispania by the Romans.  The author did extensive research to be able to present to the readers the various characters who carried the tale forth, including all of the religious and social mores of these times.  The Arabs controlled this area for over seven hundred years.Noor was the daughter of King Tarik and is the protagonist who carries this story forward.  During these times, Islam was not so aggressive and actually considered itself an offshoot of Judism because Abraham was the reputed father of both races/religions.  Christianity was tolerated as long as it didn’t try to interfere with the other religions.  It is a shame that the world can’t continue along these line.In this story, Noor, as the surviving queen of Andalus continually faces wars as races fight for land.  There are too many colorful characters who demonstrate the times to attempt to describe in this review.  For any reader who loves historical novel and is intrigued by that part of the world and those times (remember the movie “El Cid”), you will be thoroughly educated and intrigued by this story.I was given a complimentary copy for an honest review.

This is a short, entertaining and rather intriguing mystery.  Cleo Cooper is quite knowledgeable about ferreting out good mineral or rock deposits and she believes that there is a large run of granite in NE North Carolina.  She has a little dog Tulip, who slips in and out of the story, and she has made a deal with the owner of the land covering this possible granite deposit, it turns out to be so, that Gladys Walton, the owner will deal with her.The story wraps itself around Cleo having a drilling crew out on the property drilling core samples near a house in which Gladys’ best friend Irene lives.  Cleo goes to the well on Irene’s property, and seems to fall in, although she feels more like she was uplifted quickly into it.  At the bottom of the well is Irene’s body.  Now include Gladys’ two adult children who have discovered their mother’s deal with Cleo and attempt to thwart it, having their mother sign over the rights to them.  Then mix in a lover of Cleo’s, her ex-husband, the sheriff, unexpected accidents and run-for-your life chases.This is a simple story, but good for a fast read and reasonably written.  The author may not have included any depth of character  on any of her actors, but lets the reader decide that since Cleo and the rest certainly have some good and bad traits.I was given a complimentary copy of this book for an honest review.

This novel contains many metaphysical teachings and beliefs and so may be a little difficult to understand for some readers.  The narrator of the story is John Burns, a clairvoyant therapist who has been working with Sophia Deming, a middle-aged, married Canadian woman residing in southern Florida with her second husband, Nigel Deming. She is the youngest of three sisters, Louise the eldest and financially secure, and Cynthia, the middle girl who is talented and a writer.  The parents of these girls were George and Amelia Kelly, both deceased by the end of this story, but Amelia was very talented as a painter and writer.Sophia is working with John because she is so miserable at this stage in her life.  When young, she was only interested in getting married, which she did and Nigel is her second marriage and then she became a nurse.  Because of such a talented mother and sisters, she feels she has failed in life and now she works as an administrator in a hospital to support herself and Nigel, plus she is taking college courses to improve her standing.John, in his therapy, recognizes her as a Libran and she is extremely talented, if she would only let herself go. She has a beautiful voice but won’t sing and whenever a new facet of life is suggested to her, she refuses even thinking about it by saying “but.”  Through the years Sophia has studied Jung, different religious thoughts and books of psychology.  She hates it in Florida because of the heat and she can’t grow the flowers she loves.  Finally in desperation, she returns to Canada to be with her sisters and her father is dying.  While she is gone, John can keep track of her actions and thoughts through remote viewing and often sends her mental messages to help her.Sophia always thought her mother didn’t love her, which often occurs with children, but it seemed to be mostly caused by her intense awareness of her mother’s talent as a painter.  When her father dies and she is going through his household effects, she comes across a story entitled “The Antiquity” written by her mother during the two week before her death.  Sophia feels that her mother is trying to tell her something since she left a note saying it was for Sophia.  The story is included in this novel and then Cynthia convinces Sophia to let her do a play of it, which she does and the entire play is also included in this story and it is difficult to determine if both of these are saying the same things because they are not verbatim.The story is well written but it will present a difficulty for some readers because John off and on goes through pages of dialogue expounding on his philosophy, which is most difficult to understand and then the original “The Antiquity” and the play do the same and the reader is at  a loss as to what the author is attempting to project.  Much of it made no sense to me, but the last chapter is narrated by Sophia and she explains what was meant because she finally has reached that pinnacle.I was given a complimentary copy of this book for an honest review.

The author has done it again and come forth with another brilliant “who done it?” mystery.  Take Jack and Melody Dickinson married for twenty years, throw in two pairs of pink underpants owned by Serena Rowland discovered by Melody causing her to become aware of her husband’s infidelity with Serena, and then add various characters from Melody’s best friends, to her employer, Roger, and police investigators, a double to look like Jack, and hidden motives, and you will be buried reading a page-turner.  The author is expert at describing her characters so that the reader absolutely is involved with them and she is also expert at throwing in cliff hangers off and on throughout the story.I was totally immersed in this tale and recommend it to all readers who enjoy this genre.  Although there are many dark actions, there is also a tremendous offering of religious thoughts, which demonstrate how human suffering can be alleviated and understood when using this particular philosophy.This book was given to me as a complimentary copy for an honest review.

I bought Smokey Joe 18 years ago as a teenager (when it had the wood handle). I saved up my own money, $44 (a lot for a 13 year old) to get it. I always wanted one so I could barbecue on my own. I was so excited to try it for the first time! It wasn't easy to master charcoal grilling, but I eventually got it down. I don't barbecue much anymore, so I haven't used Smokey Joe in a few years. I did take it out of the plastic trash bag I had it stored in and it was as good as it was when I left it. No rust, no corrosion.Smokey Joe is a great little charcoal "kettle" grill. It's much better than the other offerings and cooks really well, as good as the other Weber kettles due to the design. The heat from the charcoal is radiated and conducted around the inside. Some exits the vent, but the majority stays inside. It stands about 18" tall from the bottom of the stand to the too of the lid (not including the handle). It's probably 14" in diameter at the grate, and has two air control vents- one on the bottom in the center, and one on the lid. The bottom vent has nice wide tabs for adjustment. The grill itself is made from stamped sheet steel, probably about 22 gauge or 20 gauge, that's been enameled with a nice rich polished black finish inside and out. For those unaware, this isn't powder-coat. It's a special paint containing glass fibers that is sprayed on, allowed to dry, and then fired at high temperatures like glaze on a piece of pottery or the enamel coating on your camp cookware. It's a very durable finish that will last for decades if cared for. I've never had any issues with chipping, peeling, or pitting with the finish. It cleans up well too.The cooking grate and fire grate are both steel. The fire grate is probably 10 inches across and a little heavier-duty and isn't chrome-plated like the cooking grate. The legs are actually bent aluminum bars that are fastened with bolts and wing nuts to the lower half of the kettle. The nuts are on the inside and also help support the fire grate. They join in the middle with a bolt and wing nut, which also holds the ash pan.  Overall the legs are the only weak link with Smokey Joe as they bend pretty easily and are a pain to bend back. The lid fits snugly to the lower half of the kettle to help control airflow.As far as function goes, it's great! I like it as much as a propane table top grill. Not as easy to use, but I like charcoal and how it adds flavor to the food when you use lump charcoal (all I use) with a charcoal chimney. The fire grate will hold a full chimney of charcoal, about 4 lbs and that will last a long time. I've fired up Smokey Joe, grilled, set it aside, and it was still hot enough to cook with an hour later. The grate isn't big. I could only fit 4 large burgers (6" uncooked), but could fit a full dozen hot dogs at a time. It would easily roast a whole chicken or a couple of cornish hens. I could fit 2 big T-Bones on it as well, and 6 kebabs with room to spare. There are instructions for smoking as well, but I never used it for that. If you're cooking for a crowd, you will run out of room, but for a family or 3 or 4, it's just fine, especially if you don't have room for a big grill or want something portable for tailgating or camping.The only gripes I can think of is the legs are flimsy, the ash pan is a little too small for my liking, and the bottom vent can get jammed up with ash and be hard to adjust. It also gets hot so you can't do it bare handed. The airflow in the firebox area is a little uneven. There seemed to be a hot spot right in the middle of the charcoal. Not ideal.Some tips for cooking with charcoal...Use lump charcoal. Not briquettes. Lump charcoal is all natural, made from whole pieces of wood with no fillers. Briquettes are made from a mixture of charred wood chips, coal dust, calcium carbonate, and a binder like dextrin. I think lump charcoal starts easier, burns more evenly, and gives off better heat. Use a charcoal chimney with firelighters, not lighter fluid. I don't care how odorless they make it, I can always taste it on my food. A chimney also starts the charcoal more quickly and evenly. Try to lift the lid as little as possible while cooking. Unlike a propane grill where the heat is constant, it disrupts the airflow inside and can change the charcoal fire's heat output. It's okay to keep the bottom vent cranked wide open, but only when grilling burgers and hot dogs and some steak. Chicken and pork needs lower heat. Be patient! Charcoal doesn't cook like propane does, and the temperature doesn't respond as quickly.ProsAffordableWeber qualityWill last longer than youCompact and lightweightEasy to cleanPortableConsLegs are a little weakAsh pan is on the small sideBottom vent gets clogged with ash and is hard to adjustOverall, I recommend this over any of the other hibachi-type tabletop grills. It's not as easy as propane or as forgiving, but it cooks like nothing else. It's Weber, so it will last a very long time! (Mine was made is USA).

One of the best Christian movies I've ever seen! I am a Christian, and don't normally watch many Christian movies. I've seen the popular ones (Fireproof, Courageous, Facing the Giants) by these directors, and they were good, but this one took the show. It's about an embattled family (the Jordans)-Elizabeth (wife) and Tony (husband) whose marriage is in serious trouble. Tony is a pharmaceutical salesman and is very successful and on top of the (his) world. Elizabeth is a real estate agent. They are both at odds with each other and don't know what to do, how to communicate, love, and give little attention to each other, all with their daughter in the middle. He is also flirtatious and gives into temptation. Things are bad, but Elizabeth meets a new client, Miss Clara, who soon bonds with her and starts to minister to Elizabeth. Eventually, Miss Clara gets Elizabeth back into a prayer life, teaches her to pray the right way for her family and Tony where the real fight is against the Devil, not her husband. Elizabeth gets into the groove of prayer, Bible reading, and growing into the wife and mother God intended. Soon, some things change and Tony gets fired from his job due to his own issues. That's when it gets interesting and we see how prayer works to do things and enable us to work in ways and love in ways we never thought possible in the midst of tragedy and trials, all by grace. I won't ruin the ending, but let's say that the Lord does a great work in all the Jordan's and the family is reunited under their prayer and God's grace and power working through it. Not by their own strength, but by God's intervention through prayer and God's presence. I love the Scripture at the end of the movie...2 Chronicles 7:14. See it. Even if you aren't a Christian, you will really like it and it will change you. I know it really encouraged me and motivated me to pray more, and pray the right way! Also, pay attention for surprise cameos throughout the movie.

I got this as a Christmas present from my brother back in 2000 (I think). I've had it for 15 years, and I can say it's one of the better lighters I've used. It's super-simple only one moving part, no electronics, no electric igniters, no pressurized butane, and it's just about bulletproof. You can stomp it, run it over, drop it, dunk it in water, or leave it outside for weeks. It's wind-resistant and will burn just about any flammable liquid you can put in it, but I don't recommend anything other than Zippo or Ronson fuel, which is mostly naphthaline and some other hydrocarbons.I really do love the Zippos. They've been around forever and haven't changed a bit aside from some simple updates. It's made from formed sheet brass, I'd say about 28 gauge-it's pretty thin, that's gone through an extruder. The fuel reservoir, chimney, wick, and flint wheel are housed in the insert that slides into the body. It's made from sheet steel, bent and formed. The fuel reservoir is stuffed with cotton to hold the fuel, and the wick threads up through it. It's caped off by a dense piece of cotton held in place by a spring-loaded brass screw that houses the flint holder. To fill, you lift the cotton and squirt in the fuel until the cotton is saturated. Put the insert in the lighter body, and you're good to go! The lid is spring-loaded and snaps shut to extinguish the flame and keep out dust and dirt. It's not water proof, so it's not a water-tight seal, but it still resist water and would light when wet.To light it, flip the top and spark the wheel and that's it! Super simple. The wick is cotton with metal inserts to keep it standing up straight. It will last forever, and the only thing I had to replace was the flints, which also last a long time.As far as durability, this is one of the most durable lighters I've ever owned. It will last forever if you take care of it. The only things that would wear out is the wick and possibly the spring mechanism that holds the lid closed. It's wind-resistant. I've got it to keep lit in pretty windy conditions. The flame is bigger than most all lighters as well, as much as a butane lighter turned all the way up or more. The fuel lasts a long time if you don't keep it lit for long periods, otherwise it won't last nearly as long as a butane lighter. It's easy to fill, and it's important not to over fill it as it will leak out of the wick and all over the place. When you light it, poof! You'll have a lighter on fire. It uses the standard "Zippo" type fuels. I recommend only Zippo brand or Ronson. You could use gasoline, paint thinner, Coleman fuel, jet fuel, or diesel in a pinch, but I don't recommend it. I love this lighter. I don't use it much anymore since I don't smoke, but it is always on standby!Highly recommended for any survival kit, camp gear, or around the house.

I am not a gamer, but I have played around with these some, and I know a little bit about headsets and headphones so I figured I'd give my input. First, these are designed for the X-Box 360 console. They have a microphone for chatting (like a headset I used to use as a customer support rep) and two earphones for sound. I had never heard of Turtle Beach before my stepson got these so this was my first exposure to this brand.The design is fairly standard. They are "over the ear" type headphones, which fit around your ears, with two earphones connected by a nice wide padded headband. The headset is made pretty much entirely of plastic, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, as it keeps it lightweight (and the price down). They are able to swivel maybe 10 degrees to the right and left, and the band is somewhat adjustable, but I found it hard to adjust. It's interesting that the earphones are screwed to the headband as opposed to a traditional sliding band design. There's a nice, flexible microphone with a dampener on the end to minimize pops and noise from breathing (yes, it works). The earphones are nice and padded with a fabric like material that I didn't think was all that comfortable, not like some other brands that have a soft, faux leather material that really conforms to your ears and blocks out ambient noise and helps with bass response.Speaking of sound, the X12 has an inline amplifier that runs off a 5 volt USB port on the X-Box. Turtle Beach says it pushes a measly 35mW per channel, which is reasonable considering the sound output I got. The speakers themselves are 50mm drivers with neodymium magnets. There's a control module on the main cable (it's a full 16'-that's feet) long. It has controls for volume, bass, and chat volume, which you can adjust to be able to hear it in the headphones along with the game/movie audio, a useful feature.It's a little tricky to set it up. I am pretty good with electronics and audio stuff, and ended up consulting YouTube to get it to work. It will work with a PC as well as the X-Box, but it's a little different to set it up on a PC.For performance. In a word it was good, but not great in movies and games. I didn't use the microphone so I can't comment on that. I've listened to some really cheap $5 earbuds all the way up to $500 headphones, and these fall somewhere in the bottom half. There's no noise-cancellation option with these, so I think the $60 price point we paid is a little high. I will say it's a million times better than your TV's speakers, but I wasn't impressed. Nothing to write home about. The bass was mediocre with the bass boost turned all the way up, so I can substantiate the 35mW rating. I think they could have benefitted from some different padding on the earphones to seal them better to your ears. They are comfortable to wear, but I found that extended sessions with them did hurt my ears. They are nice and breathable, so my ears didn't sweat.The most annoying thing about these is the durability. They broke after a month when one of the earphones decided to break off from the headband below the screw mounts at the swivel. During the autopsy, I found that the swivel itself is only about 1/4" wide. Obviously it wasn't an easy fix, but some JB Weld later and it was back up and running. Only a few weeks later it was broken again, so I ended up drilling down through the screw mount block, driving some 1/16" steel rods through the holes to stabilize it and keep it from flexing, and JB Welding it all together again. So far no issues. It's uglier than before, but hey it works.ProsGood value (on Amazon)Decent performanceInline amplifierChat volumeLong cordConsBroke easilyNo noise-cancellingSound output could be betterUncomfortable during prolonged useInstructions were vague and confusingFor the price, there are better headsets out there. Turtle Beach has a big selection, and although I like the X12, I think there are better options.

This is my first experience with a Husky mower. You might know them for their saws, weed trimmers, blowers, and hedge clippers, and their professional mowers, and they make good products. They make 2 models of this, one with a Honda engine, and this one with the Briggs engine. It has all wheel drive, meaning it is propelled by all 4 wheels as opposed to the rear or front. It has smaller 8" wheels in front, and 12" wheels in back which is good for rough lawns or going up hills. It has a 22" deck with an attachment for a hose for cleaning, and is a 3 in 1, meaning it bags, mulches, or can do side discharge. I am not sure how big the bag is, but it holds about the same amount of grass as the Honda I use from time to time. It's big enough to hold the grass from a 10,000 square foot yard, provided the grass isn't taller than 3," and keeps the dust down. All the wheels are ball bearing supported, and it's adjustable from about 2" all the way up to 5." Just like other mowers, adjusting the height isn't easy, but it's made easier by some WD-40 on the wheel pivots.I really liked the 4-wheel drive system although I can't really see any read advantages over a rear wheel drive system on other machines (I like it better than front drive). It's activated by a clutch drive system sort of like the hydrostatic drive on a riding mower. There's 2 handles on the handle that you squeeze to make it go faster. Squeeze harder, it goes faster. Simple. It works well and was easy to control when mowing around water handlers, trees, and edges. It goes from a very slow crawl to about 3 mph very quickly. The 163 cc 7.25 hp Briggs motor is more than powerful enough to get the mower going and up steep hills without bogging down. It cuts great as well. Grass leaves were cut very small and that's good. I was pretty impressed. It's relatively quiet, but not as quiet as the Honda 6.5 hp overhead cam motors. Like most all of the new engines, there's no primer or choke on the carb and no throttle control (which I didn't like). It started on the 2nd pull after sitting for a week. Impressive. It takes the Honda 5 or 6 pulls sometimes to get going. It's good on gas too. I mowed a 10,000 sq ft. yard and barely used 1/4 tank. The grass catcher is easy to remove and replace, although one of the mounting bars always gets caught on the pull start string.The only things I don't like about it is that there's no throttle control and I thought it's noisy. Also it's difficult to back it up if you need to because the groomer gets pulled too far under the deck. It's also heavy and I'm a pretty strong guy, but I found it a little hard to push when freewheeling. Husky gives you a 3-year warranty which is nice, but not as good as the Honda mowers.ProsAll wheel drive works goodInfinitely adjustable speed controlPowerful engineBall bearing wheelsNo chokeStarts on the 2nd pull when coldConsNo throttle controlA little noisyHeavyVery hard to back outDifficult to push when freewheelingBottom line: This is a very capable mower. Powerful, easy to use, and has Husqvarna quality. Would I buy this over the Honda? In short, personally no because for the same price Honda makes better motors with overhead cams (the Briggs is overhead valve), they have honest to goodness throttle controls, composite decks so they'll never rust, and they have the quadra-cut system with 2 blades, which cuts better, although I have no complaints about the Husky's performance! They have a better warranty as well.

This is a great story. I was skeptical at first, thinking it's another sports-theemed inspirational movie, but after watching it, I was surprised and inspired. "23 Blast" is based on the real-life story of Travis Freeman (played by Mark Hapka-you might remember him from a short stint in Days of our Lives). Travis is a small-town boy from Kentucky with a love for football. He grew up around the game, and at age 9 was water boy for the local high school football team, the Corbin Redhounds, which he aspired to be part of one day. However, at age 12, Travis was stricken with a serious and rare case of bacterial meningitis in his sinuses that nearly killed him. Although he survived, unfortunately, it left him completely blind in the span of 2 days. However, that didn't get Travis down and out for long. With some help from his parents, a tenacious mobility coach, and his childhood friend, Jerry Baker, Travis is able to live a normal life. He attends Corbin high school, and even goes on to play football for the Redhounds, fulfilling his dream despite his handicap.However in the movie, Travis Freeman is a junior at Corbin high school playing football for the Redhounds when he gets ill and is blinded. Also unlike real life, before the incident, Travis was a star player, exemplary student, and all around popular guy. Just as in real life, he is accompanied by his childhood friend, Jerry Baker, who plays as second string backup quarterback for the team. Jerry struggles with his own trials and tribulations, but serves as a great inspiration and encourager to Travis throughout his ordeal. Travis eventually gets well enough (with some help from the State appointed mobility coach, Patty) to get out and live more independently, and eventually get back to high school. With Jerry's help, Travis is able to fit in as a normal student. After a while, Travis is approached by the team's head coach, Coach Ferris (played by Stephen Lang), and asked if he wanted to play football again. Travis accepts, and is tasked with playing the center position. It wasn't an easy transition, and after a lot of practice, trial, error, and some humiliation, Travis gets the position down. The movie concludes with the final game of the Redhound's season with playoff implications. With everything on the line and seconds left in the game, after their running back and quarterback are injured, Jerry and Travis are called to the field by coach Ferris. I won't ruin the ending, but what ensued was really surprising and a really cool ending to the movie.I really enjoyed the credits because it showed real life pictures of the actual people involved in the movie, some of which stood in during filming (on site in Corbin, KY at Corbin HS, no less). These included Travis' mom and dad, his mobility coach, coach Ferris, and others from the film. As far as content, I really liked it. The acting wasn't cheesy (unlike some other Christian-ish movies out there), and it's well choreographed and produced. This movie is rated appropriately as well, with a minimum amount of cursing (occasional mild language), alcohol use (Jerry Baker struggles with alcoholism-as he did in real life), and no trace of sexual content to be found, other than a nice wet kiss from Travis' love interest, Ashley. I wouldn't recommend this as a child-friendly movie, but it would be appropriate for a young adult/teen.Some have said this is a Christian movie, and there are undertones to it, but it's nothing like movies like Fireproof, Courageous, or God's not Dead. Don't expect to see prayers, the gospel message, or evangelizing in 23 Blast. I thought it's kind of disappointing because the real-life Travis Freeman actually went on to become a pastor. He even makes an appearance in the movie when Travis and his family are in church. The pastor (Freeman) gives a message that I actually felt was inspiring, and I think it touched Travis (movie Travis) in a way that helped motivate him to press forward in life.So this was a good movie. I wished it were closer to real-life, but I'll take it. Not so much a Christian movie, but it's a great story that I am sure will inspire you. It spoke to me as I have a disability due to a brain tumor surgery I had 11 years ago. The message is that nothing is impossible if you believe and keep pressing on.

I love Krazy Glue! I've been using it for years and years and it's been just about the go-to adhesive when things need fixing. Why do I like it so much? It works fast-usually only 30 seconds is all you need for a bond. It's strong-if you prep your surfaces being bonded. You only need a little-or you can use a lot. It bonds just about anything-wood, metal, glass, stone, plastics, ceramics, stoneware, pottery, rubber. I've repaired things that would have otherwise been tossed out and used it for tough jobs where JB-Weld or other glues wouldn't have worked like on small items, toys, electronics, and tools. I also follow an old mechanic's trick where if you cut yourself, you can use super glue to glue the wound shut. It's really amazing and I don't need a band-aid. Yes, it works! For the record, surgeons use a type of this glue to close incisions.I love it. The only time I don't use it is when I need a real strong bond or the bonding surface is too small or under shearing loads-then I reach for JB-Weld. I really like the design of the glue bottle and applicator and the protective tube. The glue container itself is small and holds about .14 oz of glue, but that's really all you need as a little goes a long ways. It has a green cap with a needle in the end to seal the tube after using it. This works very well. Better than some others I've tried from Loctite and Super Glue. The bottle dispenses a small drop at a time, which is good to avoid over-applying it and making a mess and having bonded skin. The tip is small, which I like, as it helps getting glue where I want it.Krazy Glue is really a chemical called cyanoacrylate-ester with proprietary fillers to speed bonding (usually powered glass) and cling. Cyanoacrylate has been used for a long time in the model airplane and boating hobbies to bond wood and plastic as a 2-part deal of the glue and the hardener/catalyst. This doesn't need the catalyst owing to the unique fillers in it. All it needs is pressure, or more specifically, the absence of air, which makes it great for quick bonds where you can't wait around holding the workpiece together. The bonded pieces are pretty strong, but surface prep is really important. The surfaces have to be clean of old glue or paint, and as flat and tight-fitting as possible. The better the parts fit, the stronger the bond will be.For all it's merits though, it has limits. It doesn't do well bonding small items together that will be under load. It doesn't have good shear resistance in those cases. Also, it doesn't work well on irregularly-shaped workpieces or porous surfaces or really shiny surfaces. To address those, you need to put glue on both sides being bonded. On some items like plastics, if you add too much, the excess glue seeps out and discolors the workpiece, especially on shiny plastics. It can also cause clouding near the joint on clear plastic like polycarbonates or clear polystyrenes.Other than that, yes, it bonds your skin in seconds. To release bonded skin, pull it slowly and gently  in little increments while applying rubbing alcohol to the affected area.  Mineral oil or vegetable oil can also help. Other than that, it really is a "wonder product." I can't imagine not having a tube or two around my house.

I've had this for about a month so I can give my professional opinion. I worked in IT, and did a lot of work on printers-configuration, setup, maintenance, troubleshooting and repair-on all kinds of printers, from $100 Brother monochromes, Xerox Phasers, HP, Epson, and Canon ink jets, to $20,000 Konica-Minolta BizHubs. I've seen a lot of good printers, some terrible ones, but I haven't come across any great ones. The 3460 is an exception. I've had experience with the WorkForce units and some of my customers really liked them. When I was asked which inkjet printer to buy, I told them get a WorkForce. This was on sale at C*stCo for cheap.In the box I got the printer, a set of inks that seemed to be full (standard capacity), not the reduced "trial" sizes some companies include), the power supply, and installation CD. The courage of printers was painfully evident: Epson still doesn't include any USB or ethernet cables. This is a commonality with all the printers I've worked with. It's not hard to pack a $5 ethernet cable or USB cable in the box. It was nicely packaged as well, but not an eternal struggle to remove it from the box. The 3460 is an update to the previous gen. WorkForce ink jets, which were really great. Ultra reliable, good output speeds and page counts, and pretty economical to run for an ink jet. Like the 3640, they all have print, scan, copy, and fax capabilities, and ran a multi cartridge setup (black, cyan, magenta, and yellow), which was nice because you could keep printing (limited to monochrome) when one color was very low or empty. My Epson NX625 couldn't muster that as well as the WorkForce for some reason.For those unaware, the WorkForce line is the business-oriented model of ink jet printers from Epson. They typically feature options for higher output and page count duty cycles (not unlike the HP OfficeJets), larger paper capacity with dual feeder trays, duplexing, ADF, automatic 2-sided printing (also scanning fax, and copying), and support for 14"x11" stock and everything in between. The 3640 is no exception. It has all that and adds WiFi connectivity, Ethernet, and a USB option as well. Up front, you get a multi-card reader that reads SD, Memory Sticks, CF, and has USB input for connecting flash drives, cameras, or other external devices that you can directly print from without a PC. There's a nice 3.5" LCD touchscreen as well, and a well laid-out control pad for the fax, copy, return button, and menu functions. Everything else is mirrored on the screen. Very nice. The screen itself is bright (you can adjust it), the UI is also nice and it's not hard to learn where all the menus, functions, and controls are located. It has an auto document feeder for the fax and copier, a scanner bed that will take books or stock, and 3 paper trays (2 up front, 1 in back) for different types of stock. Epson says room for 500 sheets and I believe it. The document feeder can hold 35 pages, which isn't bad!It has WiFi, ethernet, and the standard USB. It's not a small printer. I estimate it to be 17" wide, 14" tall, and 17" deep, so make sure you have room on or under your desk. It's not heavy, under 30 lbs, so much lighter than a comparable laser. Setup was easy, and I'd say it would be easy for anyone. You can use the CD, or download the newest drivers from Epson, which I recommend because they are the newest releases with bug fixes and firmware. Install the inks, power it on, run the install program, follow the connection instructions (for WiFi or ethernet-USB is simpler), wait for it to finish (or update if using the disk), and print your test page. Voila! It's a quick process as well, something Epson has been good about in the past. For the fax it runs from the install program, but you can opt to do it later, which I did. Fax setup is simple enough, just make sure you use a filter if you're on DSL. If you use a PBX, make sure you select that from the settings and you should be good to go. Run a fax test of course-I fax HP's automated fax system for that.Performance is very good. Epson says 19ppm, and I agree. It's not as fast as my (expired) Stylus 625, but fast enough. Just as fast as a laser if not faster. First page out took about 6 seconds over ethernet, which is pretty good. Not as good as my retired HP LaserJet 2xxx series, but still good. I don't know the max resolution, but text and graphics came out very crisp and sharp. Photos were also good on standard ink jet paper and would be a lot better on photo paper. You can set the print quality that ranges from fast draft, draft, normal, and photo (very high) quality. Scans were completed quickly from both the ADF and glass, and the scan utility was easy to use. Copies were fast too from both the ADF and on the glass. The fax is a fax. It's about as fast as any other fax machine I've used. There are tons of parameters you can adjust from the touch interface. The screen is responsive and sensitive, but not overly sensitive, and the icons and graphics looked good and were totally legible. A really neat feature this has is the ability to print from your mobile (iOS or Android) device and tablet. Follow the directions to set up the link, and you can print web pages, documents, pictures, or graphics from your device over the air.Now as far as this being economical. Typically in the long run, lasers are more economical than ink jets, especially if you print a lot (10,000 images a month). A large toner can pump out 2000 pages. This will barely get out 200 with standard inks, and probably another 100-150 with the XL's. Obviously, printing text and graphics will stretch that, but using it for photos and graphic intensive tasks will quickly drain them. Also cleaning the print head and power-on's drain the ink, as the print head is cleaned during power on. Cartridges for this typically run about $35-$40 for the colors (they come individually packed or as a 3-pack-the 3-pack is cheaper to buy) and a black runs $16 or $17. That's for the standard capacity. For the XL's plan on spending $20 to $40 more for the color and blacks. If you run them all dry and have to buy 4, plan on dumping out about $100 for the XL's and $50-55 for the standards. Cheaper than toner (OEM), but not by much. You can get remanufactured toners for much cheaper. On a side note: Unlike laser toners, which you can get away with, do NOT use refills in these printers! They either don't work or will work a little, and when they do, the print quality is not as good as the OEM's, and they don't last as long. More lines, less coverage, and dead spots even after cleaning and aligning the heads. The refills aren't much more than the OEMs. It's better to keep it on. It has an eco-mode that puts the machine into a suspended animation until you wake it up (tap the screen) so it doesn't use a lot of power. I say under 10 watts at idle, maybe less. A lot less than a laser printer, even at idle.Sending faxes is a good experience. Provided the fax is correctly configured and working, it's a breeze. You can program commonly-used numbers into the speed dial memory. You can schedule a fax, pause it, set it for auto pickup, program the number of rings, set templates, assign signatures, etc. Lots of features for all 4 functions. The scan interface is the standard Epson-style. Same as my Stylus. Not the most feature-rich or easy to use (my HP utilities are my favorite), but still functional. This machine requires very little finagling and it's easy to set up.Final thoughts: This is my favorite ink jet printer. No, it's not HP, and I really like HP (my OfficeJet 6310 is almost 10 years old and works fine), but I prefer the Epson. The new HP Envy units are impressive, but for price and performance and features, it's hard to beat the 3640. I highly recommend this printer. If you own a small home-based business, or want a quality, high-output ink jet, go for the WorkForce. If not this one, the step down is perfect for just about any print job. However, this isn't a laser and isn't meant to do continuous jobs, so if you do over 300 images a month, go for a small laser. Otherwise, I recommend this over any other.Pros:EconomicalVersatilePrints fastHigh quality printsFast first page outUser interface is easy to useComes with 4 inks that seem to be fullReliable3.5" touch screen interfaceCan print wirelessly from mobile devices and tabletsCons:Ink is still expensive for relatively low page outputsDoesn't include any cables (USB or ethernet)

I got this for my stepson for Christmas in 2014. We got it at a local retail store on a holiday sale for $25*. It came bundled with a wireless controller, 2 games, a cheap headset with mic, the power supply, power cord, and all the cables needed to get it going on your TV. There was also a free month of Xbox Live, which you needed in order to play games. They had one with the optional Kinect, but it was almost $100 more.For those who aren't familiar, the Xbox 360 is Microsoft Corp's venture into the console gaming arena back in 2005, joining the already wildly successful Sony Playstation 3 console that otherwise owned the market. Like Sony's online community, Microsoft's Xbox Live paid subscription online community linking Xbox owners together where they can buy apps and games, receive Microsoft software updates and patches, and do multiplayer. All you needed was an Internet connection and pay Microsoft $60 a year for "Xbox Live." The original was buggy, and later versions suffered from a hardware flaw that caused the console to overheat (Red ring of death) and in some cases completely lock up. Unless you did some major surgery to fix it, your Xbox became a paperweight. The later versions fixed that problem. This is the newest 360, the "E" model, following the 2010 "S" model. The 360 "E" brought about some welcomed changes. One was a change in hardware. Mircosoft offered the 360 with or without a hard drive. Ones without the hard drive had 4 GB of user storage for user profiles and whatever games could fit. It's better to pay the extra $100 to get the 250 GB model.The original Xbox had a processor based largely on Intel's "Coppermine" Pentium III CPU's. The new "E" iteration has a 3-core CPU made by IBM based on  PowerPC, codenamed Xenon with a separate graphics processor. The "E" 360 has a SoC, with the GPU and CPU integrated on a single PCB. The CPU runs at 3.2 GHz, and can run 2 threads per processor core, so it's a lot like Intel's Hyperthreading tech. The first Xbox had a Nvidia graphics processor. The 360's graphics processor is made by ATi (now AMD). The power supply is external, and the power brick is big and heavy. It has to be to run the 180 watt Xbox.It runs "silver" disks (not compatible with Bluray) from the optical drive that will read DVD's of all kinds (DVD-R/RW), CD's of all types (R-R/W+/- MP3, etc.) and the game disks, so you can watch movies or listen to music on it. For connectivity, on the back you get a full-size HDMI and a component video out (yellow, red, white) that's set up as a 3.5mm jack terminating in the composite plugs that go to the TV, a lot like a video out for an older digital camcorder. For the record, you're going to want to toss those out because it works best with the HDMI. The max video resolution for the 3 plug output is only 480i and both signals are analog, not digital. HDMI funs full HD at 1080p with digital audio that's a lot better. It's odd that Microsoft didn't include an HDMI cable...why wouldn't you include a $5 cable in a $275 console bundle? It's like the $600 printers that don't include ethernet cables or USB cables. Sheesh. For the audio, it comes with support for 5.1 Dolby Surround. There is no digital audio, just the standard 2-channel from the composite. For digital audio you need to run the HDMI.The bundle comes with one wireless controller. It runs on the 2.4 GHz band, and you get good connection up to 30 feet. It runs on 2 AA batteries and boy does it use batteries! If you use it a lot, a set of batteries will only last you maybe 3 weeks. I use high capacity rechargeable and still only get that much. The battery back detaches from the back, and it's not very durable. Mine is held together with duct tape and super glue at the moment. Older Xbox controllers work just fine...plug them into the USB in front.The 360 has both a RJ-45 fast ethernet (10/100) or WiFi 2.4 GHz. There's also 4 USB 2.0 ports. 2 on the front for controllers or other devices, and 2 on the back. The software features are endless. Microsoft transferred a lot of it's Windows genius to the Xbox. When you sign up with Xbox Live, you  go to the Xbox Live user interface, which took some getting used to, but is overall a nice layout. It's arranged a little like Windows 8. You have access to Microsoft's Xbox Live app store where you can get access to online game marketplace to buy games and DLC's, apps for Netflix, Hulu, Nickelodeon, YouTube, and others. There is also a weird rendition of Internet Explorer built in that lets you (somewhat) browse the web. It's nothing like the desktop PC equivalent though, but good enough to do basic stuff. The sad part is you need to subscribe to Xbox Live Gold to use it all for $60 a year. Sony's Playstation Network has been free since inception, but I hear that's changing soon...Gameplay is good. Audio is good, and graphics are good too in HD. Now for the record, for those folks throwing down the argument that PC's game better than consoles...well you're right for the most part. Yes, you can game in 4k on a PC with multiple monitors and have amazing frame rates and audio quality, but you're going to pay for it. The Xbox One costs around $400. A PC that can game in 4k, or even 1080p will run you twice to three times that much, not including the monitors. So if you want to game, but don't want to spend $1200 on a gaming PC, get the Xbox One. It's amazing.  Even the 360 is good on games in HD. I have no issues with the video quality or audio quality. The 360 will play the older previous-gen Xbox games, but for the older games, some won't run in HD. My Star Wars Battlefront 2 only runs 480i even with the HDMI cable. You won't get HD until you get into games launched around 2007. Watching YouTube and Netflix is nice too. HD videos play well, and on a nice HDTV it's a great experience! I have noticed that it does get hot when playing games like Minecraft. Nothing real bad, but it was alarming at first.As far as the game selection...there are tons. If you can think of it, it's probably an Xbox game or been ported to Xbox. There are games on disk and games for download. The bundle came with Halo 4 and Tomb Raider. As a side note, the most profitable game franchise in history, Halo, debuted on the Xbox. The rest is history.So now that the Xbox One is alive and well, is it worth getting the now year-old "E" 360? I think it depends. If you haven't got the extra $150 or so to spend, then get the 360 with the 250 or 320 Gb hard drive. If it were me, I'd keep saving and get the One. It adds all of the stuff missing from the "E" 360 and competes well with the PS4. The bummer is you can't play older Xbox games on it, but Microsoft has a fix for that in the works I hear...Pros:Versatile: plays all Xbox games (except One)Great gaming performancePlays CD's and DVD'sFull size HDMI output4 USB 2.0 portsWiFiLots of options for apps, Internet, and social mediaCame with Halo 4 and Tomb RaiderNice user interfaceConsNo digital audio (optical) optionNo Bluray driveGot real warm during gamesDidn't come with HDMI cableExternal power supply is bulkyNeed to sign up for Xbox Live Gold to use games and appsSo that's the Xbox 360's newest (and last) iteration. Microsoft says it will stay on the books until 2016, so if you've got one, enjoy it white it lasts. Would I get one? It depends on how much money you've got. For $280...no, because soon the One will come down enough in price and with Microsoft unlocking it soon so it will play all Xbox games, I see no point in getting one at that price point. Otherwise, it's a great box that will keep you entertained until the cows come home.

I've been using this monitor since early 2005 and it has been a great monitor for the last 10 years. No dead pixels, no ghosting, no fading, and no burn-in. It's just a good as it was when it was new. The Syncmaster is an LCD display with a 17" (measured from top corner to bottom corner) viewing area. It's not a widescreen, so expect the standard 4:3 format for videos and multimedia. It has a fluorescent backlight and a matte screen to prevent glare. It has both VGA D-Sub and DVI inputs for digital and analog. It has an internal power supply, so it takes a standard 3-prong PC ATX power cable, so there's no power supply to mess with.It has some pretty nice features too. It has an auto adjustment that actually works as it should. You can adjust just about every display parameter possible, way more than I ever had a use for since the auto adjust worked so good. It's not the thinnest thing out there, but this is 2005 vintage display tech at a time when CRT monitors were still in use. It's not too heavy as it's mostly made of plastic and ultra thin sheet steel and aluminum. Unlike some of the Dell monitors in this class (17 and 19") it's pretty light. I'd say it's under 6 lbs. I think it's about 2.75" thick.  at the thickest part (the part where the stand attaches on the back.It comes with a stand that raises it up to a good height for viewing. It's not adjustable for height and it doesn't pivot like the Dell monitors of the same period, but it's the right height for most people. It's nice and bright, but there were times when viewing some multimedia that I had to turn the brightness up. Not a huge deal though. Because it's an LCD, don't expect the high contrast and color saturations of an IPS or LED backlit panel you see today. It's got nice viewing angles too. The response time (between frames) is .8 ms, which is pretty good, only a couple tenths off some of the newer monitors out there. Contrast ratio isn't the greatest at 600:1, but this isn't an ultra-high resolution display. It maxes out (natively) at 1280x1024, which is the best you can get with VGA, forget DVI, but then again this screen is so small you really wouldn't get much benefit from DVI over VGA anyways. There's no speakers and no USB plugs with this one either, but that's just fine. It keeps the weight down and the power consumption and heat. Because this uses a CFL for illumination, it does get pretty warm with prolonged use. Not real hot, but it doesn't stay cool to the touch.Overall this is a nice (even today) monitor. It's cheap, simple, and will last forever. It has decent viewing angles (for an LCD PC monitor), is bright, and has good contrast and color accuracy. I wished the native resolution was higher and the contrast ratio was better, but hey, for a 10-year old display, I can't complain. It's outlasted 2 printers and one PC!

This is the 2nd installment of the Star Wars franchise- Attack of the Clones. It continues where the 1st installment, The Phantom Menace, concludes.  Anakin, now a young man (probably 17 or 18), is progressing rapidly in his Jedi training, and although he is brilliant with his lightsaber and as a pilot, is very much an arrogant, headstrong, and often argumentative pupil, much to the chagrin of Obi-Wan. Padme Amidala has grown up into a gorgeous young woman, and the former Queen of Naboo now occupies a seat in the galactic senate. All is not well in the galaxy though, as a dark shroud that is the dark side of the Force has clouded and obscured the Jedi Master's insight into the mysterious inner workings within the Republic, and the strengthening of the Separatists droid army and Trade Federation has plunged the galaxy into economic and political strife, with many star systems dissenting to join the Trade Federation. In like fashion, Anakin and Obi-Wan are tasked with protecting Senator Amidala after an assassination attempt. In a unique turn of events, Anakin is given the responsibility of protecting Padme after Obi-Wan is send on a Knight's errand by the Jedi Order to trace the suspected assassin back to Kamino, where Obi-Wan discovers a decades-old secret plan by the Republic and Jedi Order to build an army of clones to protect themselves from the Separatists.This movie is a lot different than the first. There's more lightsaber and epic battle scene action, more drama (as in an unfolding romance between Anakin and Padme), a somewhat jumbled-up story line with Hayden Christensen (Anakin) slowly but surely coming under the influence of the dark side with his inability to control his feelings (and his preoccupation with Padme). The acting is a little stale at times, and there's a cheese-factor sometimes, but it's somewhat classic Star Wars. Overall, it's a good movie. I don't give it 5 stars simple because it didn't feel like a great movie. It's still Star Wars though! Love it.

Revenge of the Sith is the 3rd installment of the Star Wars series. Although Episodes 1-3 are totally different than 4-6, I think Lucas did a great job of following the canon between the sequels/prequels. I thought it would be a total mess, but the story lines actually follow each pretty well. The acting on Anakin's part is better. The dialogue isn't as cheesy and stale, and it's more suspenseful with better CGI.Here's my overview without spoiling it if you haven't seen it...It's critical to have watched the other 2 movies to get what's happening in this one as they all play together. Episode 3 sees Anakin progressing as a Jedi apprentice (he moved up from Padawan), Obi-Wan's increasing frustration with his Anakin's lack of discipline and inability to control his feelings (as he comes under the increasing influence of the dark side), and the Jedi council's increasing suspicion that something's awry with the Galactic Senate and the shadow of the dark side looming over it. We learn of Padme's wonderful revelation as well, and we see the appearance of General Grievous (the droid army's commander in chief) for the first time. It's full of epic battle scenes from the Clone War with the droid separatist forces in space and on land. Not like the 2nd film where it's basically Geonosis. These battles take place on Utapau, in space, and other worlds. The CGI is better (I think), and the storyline is more developed. Ewan MacGregor (Obi-Wan) is brilliant (again) and it's nice to see some emotion and expression in Hayden Christensen (Anakin) as well, something lacking in the 2nd installment.It was absolutely heart-wrenching when Anakin befriended (against the Jedi Council's order) Chancellor Palpatine (the mysterious Sith lord), who manipulated him and told him he could prevent Padme from dying if he embraced a new facet of the Force, as foretold in Anakin's recurring nightmares. As their relationship progressed, he became more disenfranchised, aloof to the true force and his role as a Jedi (he never became a Jedi Master), and eventually melted like butter in Palpatine's hand. It was nice to see it make sense- Anakin's strange behavior in the 2nd movie, arrogant, unpredictably violent tendencies, and totally un-Jedi like demeanor, turn to the dark side in tragic fashion and morph into the Sith Lord's new apprentice- whom any Star Wars fan knows is the completely heartless and evil Darth Vader. We finally get to see why Vader has to wear the iconic and infamous black cybernetic suit as well (thank Obi-Wan for that).Other hallmarks critical to the latter 3 installments includes the breakup of the Galactic Republic and the formation of the Galactic Empire, the birth of Luke and Leah and their journeys, and the demise of the Jedi order with Obi-Wan and Yoda's exile. Good stuff.If you've seen the 1st and 2nd installments, get this one and watch it. It's almost a no-brainer  anyways.

The #10 (formerly A5) is a cold plug with a thicker element, designed for higher nitro content fuels, high-compression engines, and warmer temperatures. I used this when it was the A5 plug in my .15 CV with a high compression head. It didn't like the A3's and the #8's were finicky when I tried 25% nitro, so I tried the A5 and was pleased with it. The summer weather made the motor run hot on 25% with the #8 plug, so I switched to the A5 for a while and the tuning was a little easier. Once I switched back to 20%, I started using the #8 again because I couldn't make power with the A5 installed, so you'd want to use this on a motor with higher compression or when using high nitro content fuels (above 20%). Any higher nitro and probably best to go to the R5. It didn't last as long as the #8 did, and it was more expensive, but for a high performance plug, you can't go wrong.

I got this for Christmas last year along with some AAA and AA high capacity Powerex rechargeable batteries. For the record, although this is branded Tenergy, I got mine from Batteries Pl*s, and it was the same charger, but it was rebranded as a one-hung lo brand "Nuon." Outside it's the same case, and inside it's the same electronic systems, just a different branding.This is supposed to be a "smart" charger, and in some ways it is, but I guess that depend s on your definition of "smart." Like most all battery chargers, it has built-in microprocessor controls that monitor the cell condition, temperature, and voltage,  and adjusts the charging current to give the best possible charge delta. It accommodates only four batteries at a time (two 9 volts), but will charge rechargeable NiCad and NiMH battery chemistries. It's compatible with AAA, AA, C, D, and 9 volt cells. Sadly, it won't do Li-Ion cells. There are two charging modes that you select with a switch. "A" mode is for lower capacity batteries (under 1000 MAh and the "B" mode is for batteries 1000-2700 MAh. When the switch is in the A position, it charges the batteries for 4 hours, but when it's set for high-capacity batteries, it takes 8 hours, and they aren't exaggerating. Interestingly, you have to plug it in after you load the batteries or it won't work right according to the directions. I charged 4 AAA 1000 MAh Powerex batteries, and 4 AA 2700 MAh Powerex cells, and it took a full 8 hours. Even when they were out of the package and had a slight charge to them, so this isn't a "quick" charger. It does have a row of 4 red LED's that turn off when charging has completed. To differentiate them from the rest of the batteries, the LED's for the 9 volts are green. My gripes besides the long charge cycle was that it felt cheap, smelled bad when charging, and didn't have adequate ventilation. It did get quite warm during charging, so I am not sure how that will affect the batteries longevity.Pros:CheapSimple set-and-forget auto shut off and trickle chargeCharges NiCad and NiMH high and low-capcityCharges all of the popular battery types AAA, AA, C, D, 9 voltLED indicators let you know when charging has completedConsNo real-time monitoringNo conditioning or break-in modesNo display for charging statusFeels cheapSmelled bad during chargingSeemed to have inadequate ventilation for coolingFor all it doesn't do, it will still charge your batteries better than an analog charger, won't overheat them or overcharge them, and shuts off it it gets too hot. It's a simple, low-cost charger that's pretty versatile. It doesn't have the bells and whistles of the $50+ chargers, but it's compelling that a $30 charger does lots more, and you get real-time monitoring. Spend the extra $15 and get the NiteCore 2014.

I got these for Christmas last year in a pack of 8 batteries from Batteries Pl*s. They cost about the same here as there, so no qualms about going Amazon for them if you're curious. They came in a transparent plastic clamshell container that snaps together and it's really handy for keeping them together. This isn't my first set of NiMH rechargeable batteries. The last set I had was way back in 2003 when NiMH cells were just getting affordable and practical. This is my first experience with "Maha" branded batteries though.For the record, these are the highest mAh capacity AA's out there that I know of. The package says 2700 mAh, but I have heard of them coming in slightly less than that even after being conditioned, which I think would be a good idea with these if your charger has that function. The "can" of the batteries seem to be well-made, and the negative side of the can has a dimpled surface which is nice for keeping the batteries snug against contacts and makes it harder for them to fall out. They are NiMH chemistry, nickel metal hydride electrolyte, and as such only produces 95% of the voltage an alkaline cell does. A far cry from the 1.2 volts the first NiMH cells managed. I put 8 of these on my multimeter with a 3200 ohm 2-3 watt load, and got:1.42v1.42v1.43v1.44v1.43v1.42v1.42v1.42vThis is compared to the 1.5-1.7v for alkaline, so expect a drop in performance from items powered by electric motors or lamps. I put them primarily in an X-Box controller and RC car (takes 6 of them) and noticed a definite difference in the car's speed compared to alkaline cells. As far as run time, I did notice a difference between these and a name brand cell in the RC car. I'd say at least 30% more run time before being too drained for the car to move. I ran these in a wireless X-Box controller and got a good 2 weeks worth out of them with several hours use each day. I can't comment on how they would work in other devices, but I could reckon that it you put these in something like a TV or stereo remote, they'd last forever, probably years before needing to be charged. In something like a flashlight, digital camera, flash, or low-draw toy, these would give excellent run times. The downside of all that capacity is charge time. In my Nuon "smart" charger (it's not that smart), takes forever. They needed the full 7-8 hours for the lights on the charger to come off. Lame. I am not sure how they'd do in a different charger. On another note, the plastic film label on on of the cells has started to peel off. Not sure why as I haven't abused or roughed these up at all.ProsAffordableVery high capacityConsistent voltage output under loadHandy storage caseSeems to be a quality productConsNeed to be slow chargedReally need to be conditioned for maximum performanceLabel is already peeling off one batterySo that's the Maha Powerex AA batteries. I like them so far, and they seem to have gotten better with age. I have no reservations recommending them. If you need long run times or standby, then these would be perfect.

These are rechargeable AAA batteries. I got them for Christmas from Batteries Pl*s for about $5 more than on here. I also got the Nuon "smart" charger. I've had no experience with the high capacity NiMH batteries, just the standard capacity (like 600 mAh), so I was excited to get to try them out. Being rechargeable, the chemistry limits them to about 1.4 volts, not the 1.5-1.7 (both measured by my multimeter) of alkaline batteries. So you can expect a drop in performance from devices like lights, lamps, and items with electric motors. These are listed at 1000 mAh, which is a lot. The highest I've seen for AAA rechargeables. My main application for them was in my electric shaver/trimmer, which is an absolute battery hog. I had been buying batteries from the Dollar Store (4 batteries for $1). Two alkaline batteries lasted for maybe 3 uses of 10-15 minutes each time.After trying the Powerex batteries, I was less than thrilled. The drop in output voltage is noticeable. The motor doesn't spin as fast, and for cutting hair, that's not good as you don't get clean cuts and it pulls the hair. On the plus side, I did notice slightly longer run times, but strangely, the margin wasn't impressive, maybe an extra 30 minutes of run time overall, so the extra time was welcomed. It was kind of offset because the slower motor speed meant it took longer to knock down my beard. I put them (3) in my high powered LED flashlight, and I could tell a sight drop in light output, but the run times was a better. I didn't measure it, but I'd say it was about an hour, probably more added run time. Use these in something like a TV remote and it will probably be good for a couple years of use before needing a recharge. For the record, all that capacity means they took forever to charge. When they had run down to 1.24v, four batteries needed a full 8 hours to fully recharge in my Nuon, AKA Tenergy charger. I would say that like all high-capacity rechargeables, these would benefit from conditioning to keep them operating at maximum efficiency. The battery "can" itself seems to be sturdy and well-made, but the negative contact is missing any kind of dimple or ridges to help keep the battery seated on the contacts. The AA version of these has a roughened negative side. Not sure why these don't.ProsHigh capacitySturdy constructionSeem to be good qualityConsNegative contact was flat and smoothTakes forever to chargeNeed to be conditioned for maximum outputI'd have no reservation recommending these. Be sure to invest in a good quality digital charger so you can run them through a conditioning cycle. I am sure they will get better with age, but conditioning would be helpful. Otherwise, great batteries.

My stepson has head this for years and years. It sat in the closet until I found it. I thought it was a gimmick, until I started digging in the toy box and found the controller. After more digging, I found the eye glasses. I love RC cars, and my son told me it had a video camera in the car that you can see through the glasses.Naturally, I couldn't resist giving it a try. I put in some fresh batteries and gave it a spin. It works! At first I was a little disappointed because it seemed cheesy, but after a while, it grew on me.The car itself has a camera built into a pod in the front that can tilt up to about 75 degrees. It has 3 lenses on the pod. One is the actual camera lens, and it's flanked by two others. I am not sure what purpose they serve, but one seems to be an infrared illuminator and the other is a receiver. The glasses have a TV projector that projects to the right eye. It has a soft rubber eye cup that helps if you have glasses, but it doesn't work the greatest. The controller has a single on/off switch, and the glasses plug into the bottom with a 3.5mm jack. You get forward/reverse and left/right controls for the car. Pretty standard RC car stuff.How does it work? I thought it worked pretty good. Please note this is 2006-era tech when POV and FPV technology was in its infancy for the consumer market, so I didn't expect much, and that's what I got. It works, and that's enough for me. The camera only does monochrome, and the resolution less one of those portable black and while televisions. The screen itself is tiny, about 1" square, smaller than the viewfinder on an old video camera from my high school video production class. It's bright enough, but don't expect ultra-clear pictures. In the dark, even dim light, the picture is so dark you can't see. That's not surprising as the camera lens is so tiny, a hair bigger than a cell phone camera.The car takes 12 (yes, 12) AA batteries, 6 for the controller and 6 for the car. That's a lot of batteries, more than any RC car I've ever seen, and more than any toy I've ever seen. It's good to use alkaline and not rechargeable batteries because they have more voltage (1.5 versus 1.2). It might not be a big difference, but it adds up and that extra voltage helps with the car's speed and maneuverability. I used it with rechargeable batteries and I could tell a difference. The batteries don't last very long either. I have 2700 mAh capacity AA rechargeable batteries and I only got a few days of occasional (10-15 minutes) of use before the car was sluggish and barely moved. With alkaline cells it's even less.It's easy to control. It's a single speed and isn't variable, so you get full forward and full reverse speed, which with fresh batteries (alkaline) is about 4 mph. The steering is instantaneous- snapping left to right very quickly. It was fast enough to be useful. I think if it went any faster it would be hard to get a clear picture on the camera and control it. This was designed for kids, and it's probably not a good idea to have an RC car going 10 mph in the house crashing into things because it takes a little while to get used to controlling something from the car's point of view. The turning circle isn't very good because of the wide tires and weak motor, so it got stuck easily. Not a huge deal, but annoying. The range is terrible indoors. I could only get maybe 20 feet before the picture in the viewfinder was so garbled and scrambled it was illegible. A far cry from the miles of range from the new FPV machines.The glasses leave a lot to be desired as they aren't very eyeglass friendly. I wear glasses and they didn't fit over my face close enough to my eyes to get a good view of the viewfinder. Thankfully, the viewfinder can tilt up and down, so I was able to position it downward enough to get a good look.As far as durability is concerned, I was impressed. This is a rugged toy. It's heavy, sturdy, and the plastics are strong polystyrene. The axles would be the only weak link and there's no suspension, but that makes it stronger, and the axles are steel and imbedded into the wheels so unless it was stepped on by an average-sized man, they wouldn't bend. The same for the glasses and controller. The cable for the glasses will disconnect from the controller before it breaks. Both were sturdy and seem indestructible.Pros:Sturdy and durableReally funWorks goodAhead of it's time (for 2006)Easy to useCons:Range is really shortGlasses didn't work well with eyeglassesCamera viewfinder could be bigger and brighterLow resolution pictureUses lots of batteriesPoor battery life with standard capacity batteriesSo that's the Wild Planet Spy Gear video car. For its time it was amazing. There weren't many practical toys that worked this well 9 years ago, and even today I think it's still useable, especially if you don't have a smart phone or a lot of money to spend on a new one. It's good for kids and big kids alike.

I never got mine because it got lost in the mail, twice. It ships from China, so expect to wait a month before getting it (if you get it).That said, I know enough about it to write a review. This is a capture card that lets you record video from a TV onto a PC (desktop or laptop) via USB. It plugs into the component output (red, white, yellow) jacks on the TV, and runs into the actual card, where it's decoded to the PC in a readable format, I forget which, but it's easily uploaded to YouTube.For those of you looking for good video quality, you will be sorely disappointed. There's no HD, not even 720p. The max render is TV out, which is 720x480, that's the most you get from the component outputs. Yes, it works, but barely.

This is a nice basic stand. It's not super fancy, but good enough. It came in 2 pieces, the legs were folded up and the bottom piece that cradles the guitar was separate. The top of the stand telescopes up or down to fit different sizes of guitars, so you could put a banjo, a lute, or something like a ukulele on it. The legs fold down and have rubber feet on the ends, the neck cradle is also padded with foam, as well as the bottom part. There was a warning sticker on it about not using it with nitrocellulose finishes, so I think the foam has something in it that hurts that finish. The stand is pretty sturdy and solid. Holds the guitar (a larger bodied acoustic Fender) just fine. No issues. The bottom is a little wobbly and isn't held in by anything- it just sits inside the upright tube.
