That's the only issue I can think of. Other than that, it's great, worth every bit of the $10 I paid for it!

This is a good, cheap, and functional capo. No issues whatsoever after a month. Holds the neck tight and no rattle and hasn't damaged or marred the guitar. It's sturdy and has a good thick spring that's unlikely to break, and the frame seems to be nice and strong as well. Not sure what it's made from, but seems to be cast aluminum. No complaints!

This is a slip-on TPU case. TPU stands for thermoplastic polyurethane, a semi-rigid quasi-rubber material that's impact resistant and pretty tough. I've had good luck with TPU cases and silicone cases over the years so I thought I'd get this one. The case works, the only issue is that it didn't fit on the phone very well. The bottom left corner kept slipping off and the edge of the phone was exposed. Not good. Empire Cases was amazing though and I was able to exchange it for another flip wallet style case. Quality issue aside, TPU cases are good, simple, cheap insurance for your phone.

I've had my trusty Optimus L9 for 2 years, and it's been a good phone. It was a mid-tier smartphone, and I got it on a good deal from T-Mobile (paid $224 for it). It was a massive upgrade from my old, but great Exhibit 4G and I initially like the big 4.5" 540x960 qHD screen, big battery with removable back and expandable storage, dual-core processor and dedicated Cortex GPU, thin profile, sturdy build, Android Jellybean, and LG's nice Optimus interface. Now, after 2 years, it's beginning to show it's age. 4.5" screens have become the bog standard, dual-core processors have gone the way of the dinosaurs, even in mid-tier phones. As much as I wanted to keep loving the L9, it's now becoming a 3rd wheel.Enter the L90. It's a mid-tier smartphone. Mid-tier means it won't have an 8 MP or higher camera, a 5+" 1080 (even 720) screen, 2 GB of RAM, 16 GB storage (although the Samsung Galaxy Avant, the L90's rival, does), the latest quad-core processor and GPU, LTE (again, the Avant does), or ultra-thin and light construction.The L90 is a T-Mobile only device (for the US anyway) and the bigger, more mature brother to the L9. Although it still has "L" and "9" in the title, the L90 isn't the same phone. There are similarities, but hardware/software-wise there are some significant differences. First off, it's bigger, measuring 5.18" tall x 2.60" wide x 0.38" thick. A little thicker than the L9's .36," but I found it's still easily to hold and rides nice in the pocket for a biggish phone. It's a little heavier at 126 grams (4.4 ounces). Other differences include a quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon Cortex-A7 400 processor running at 1.2 GHz, compared to the L9's 1.1 GHz Texas Instruments OMAP chip. You get an Adreno 305 GPU and there's 8 GB of ROM inside compared to 4 GB on the L9, but like the L9, half of it is consumed by the operating system and user interface, along with T-Mobile's bloatware. All told you get to use a little under 4 GB. Not much, but better than the L9. You still get the same 1 GB of RAM, and it retains the expandable storage with a MicroSD card slot up to 32 GB. The back is removable (thank you, LG) along with the slightly-bigger battery. In the L9 you got a 2150 mAh cell. In the L90 it's up to 2460 mAh. There are still 3 sensors on the front (not including the IR for the QuickRemote): accelerometer, proximity, and compass.For connectivity/network, this is a GSM device, so it runs on the same networks as ATT, MetroPCS, T-Mobile, and Cricket, but it's only a tri-band phone, so it runs on the 850, 1900, and 1700 MHz bands, and (sadly) is WCDMA, which means it's radio only gets up to HSPA+ 21 "4G" 3G, or EDGE. There's no LTE support (also sad). That said, there is an international version (GSM) that adds the European 900 and 1800 MHz bands. So, if you take this one overseas anywhere outside Brazil, Oceania, or Israel, chances are it might leave you hanging.The display has also grown from 4.5" to 4.7." That might not seem like much, but holding the phone it's easy to tell. It's covered in the same Gorilla Glass 2, and same multitouch capability. The extra screen is a welcome addition. The resolution hasn't changed from the L9 at 540x960 at qHD. It's still an IPS display with 16m colors as well. The ppi hasn't changed. Last I remember it was 236 on the L9. Not bad, but not great and you can see the pixels if you look close. It's still really responsive and sensitive, so that's good, and has good contrast and is pretty bright. The other difference is in the construction. LG borrowed the self-healing material from the Flex to use on the L90's battery door. It's an attractive finish, but I like the L9's back better as it's easier to hold, won't collect fingerprints, and has a textured soft touch rubber coating. The rest of the device is pretty blasé. Whereas the L9 had nice wide chrome trim, the L90 only has a thin strip. Although the L90 isn't bad looking, I like the L9 better. It' thinner, easier to hold, and looks better without all the curves. There are only 3 physical buttons, volume rocker, power/lock, and the home button/task manager button. It's flanked by two capacitive keys for back and menu. Same as L9.Other features that are the same includes the camera. It's still a 5 megapixel unit with a single LED flash, and is GPS-enabled, geotagging, autofocus, has a voice-triggered shutter (don't have to press the on-screen button), face-tracking, and preset shooting modes like panorama, etc. The white balance and exposure meter are adjustable, but that's about it. The front camera is the same as well, 1.3 megapixels and records VGA video only. Like the L9, it shoots 1080p video at 30 fps, and you can pause in the middle of recording or take snapshots. It can keep the flash on to act as a video light as well.For software, it runs Android 4.4.2 KitKat, which I like more than Jellybean. It looks better, is smoother, and works better with the Optimus 3 interface. It adds some good features like the QuickRemote feature that lets you use the phone to control your TV, Blu-ray player, cable box, or other devices needing a remote, but most of the apps are the same from T-Mobile, which I never used. You get the Google search, Facebook, Google+, Gmail, Amazon, T-Mobile TV, etc. There's also Quick Memo that you can draw on the screen to take quick notes. I really like the Optimus 3 UI as well. A nice refresh from the L9. There's some similarities, but thanks to KitKat, it's pleasantly different. There's also knock unlock, which you just knock on the screen to unlock it. It's nice, but more of a novelty I think. There's the obligatory live wallpapers, customizable color themes, etc as well.The other miscellaneous features include b/g/n WiFi, A2DP v.4 Bluetooth, micro USB 2.0 (no 3.0 here), full HTML and Flash enabled browsing, Java MiDP, mobile hotspot, WiFi calling (on T-Mobile only), MTP USB sync, 3.5mm headphone jack, predictive text input, LG's rebranded Swype, A-GPS, NFC, FM RDS radio, text-to-speech, voice commands (Google's version of Cortana and Siri).So, how does this all work? First, it's a lot faster than the L9, which doesn't surprise me because of the hotter chipset, but in normal use you can't really tell. It's only when you ask it to pat it's belly and say the ABC's and jump on one foot that you can tell a difference. Where the L9 would choke and sometimes crash, there's very little lag in multitasking and games on the L90. The screen is actually nice! Nice and bright, vibrant  colors, and good resolution. It's a little nicer and brighter than the L9, and I'm not sure why because they are the same display. Still sensitive and very responsive. The camera leaves something to be desired though. The same issues that I had with the L9 are carried over to the L90. Shooting performance is similar, but faster to focus and snap on the L90. Image quality is also similar. Outdoor photos in bright sunlight look surprisingly good. It's only when you go indoors that the quality drops off considerably. There's no HDR (helps when things are backlit and shadowed), and images suffer in low light. Pictures were noisy and grainy, almost out of focus. With the flash on, it tended to either over expose or turn everything blue, but you can help that by changing the white balance. In anything other than a nearly pitch-black room it was only good for about 5 feet.Videos looked good for a midrange camera. They were in focus and smooth at 1080. No complaints there, I was pretty impressed. You can also shoot 720, and 640x480 for MMS. I liked the image galleries, video, and music player apps as well.For call quality and data on T-Mobile, I had no issues. WiFi calling was uneventful, calls were loud and clear and I couldn't really notice any robotic voices or stuttering on the other end when someone called me from the L90. Data speeds on 4G where I live are respectable. Full bars give about 4 mbps down, and about 1.5-2 mbps upload. Not bad. Obviously LTE would improve on those quite a bit. Battery life? It was so-so. If you used it a lot, it would need to be refilled with electricity at the end of the day, not dissimilar from the L9. Despite the bigger cell, the battery life between the two is similar, probably due to the L90's bigger screen and faster processor. Figure on about 10-12 hours talk endurance (maybe more) and 2-3 days standby. FYI, you can improve the battery life quite a bit by turning down the screen brightness to 40 percent, disabling all unused apps running in the background, and disabling WiFi.So...Pros:Larger 4.7" screen with good colors and brightnessLarger 2460 mAh batteryRetains expandable storageRemovable back and batteryKitKat 4.4.2Respectable camera8 GB ROMQuad-core 1.2 GHz Snapdragon 400 chipsetShoots nice 1080p videoQuickRemote works goodOptimus 3 UI is easy to useSeems to be well-builtDecent battery lifeGreat valueCons:Not as pretty as the L9A little heavy/chunkyNo LTETri-band onlyOnly 4 GB user accessible ROMReally needs 16 GB ROMCamera photo quality is hit or missPoor indoor and low-light photosThe Galaxy Avant is a better phoneSo, that's my take on the L90. I still like my L9, but it will be put to pasture soon. Will I replace it with the L90? Probably not as the Samsung Galaxy Avant beats it in important areas. It has LTE, 16 GB ROM, better battery life, and a more consistent camera. I have always had better luck with Samsung's camera over LG's. If I had to, I'd take the Avant with the smaller screen simply because it has LTE. All points aside, now that you can get a near-new Galaxy S3 for the same price as the L90, it's a no-brainer. Still, the L90 is impressive. You can get one for $100 at T-Mobile, and that represents a fantastic value.

I worked for a whitewater rafting equipment supplier and we used 303 to wipe down and protect our urethane and PVC boats after being cleaned. It works fantastically. There are some other products out there from Armor All, Meguairs, and Mother's, but this one works the best.303 is a spray on/wipe on protectant for plastic, rubber, urethane, fake leather, PVC, and Hypalon. You could put it on bonded leather, but I wouldn't recommend it on expensive leather. Use a good quality leather cleaner/protector for that. I don't know what's in it, but it's similar to other protectants of this type. You can spray it on the surface, or spray it on a rag and use it that way. It works good either way. Use it on your tires, the weatherstripping, plastic bumper covers, headlight lenses, tail lights, vinyl roof (for a convertible), the vinyl upholstery in your car or boat, interior trim, dash, interior light lenses, or sunroof seals. Also use it on your PVC or urethane-coated raft, paddle board, or your poly/composite kayak. It will also do glazed fiberglass.It has an additive that helps protect the surface from ultraviolet rays so it won't degrade or fade under prolonged sun or weather exposure as well. It also acts as a cleaner, but don't expect it to remove the mud stains or dried-on dirt from your bumper covers, rubber, or plastic trim.How does it work? Comparing it to something like Armor All Ultra Shine, I say it works just as good, but with one difference, and that is the longevity of the shine and how well it shines with a single application. I put this on the headlight lenses of my wife's car that were starting to "craze" (get cloudy), and it took away about 80% of it right away. After buffing with a buffer, I added more 303, let it sit, and then wiped it off. The lenses are still as good as the day I cleaned them! I get good results on trim too, especially on my back bumper which has a black matte plastic on the top that was oxidizing. It cleaned it up and it's been good ever since. Armor All did a good job, but the shine didn't last as long.I also I compared this to a commercial interior and exterior trim shine/protector I had access to that a lot of body shops and detail shops swear by, and although 303 didn't do as good a job, it sure came close, and the commercial product was a lot more expensive. I am pretty happy with it. I highly recommend it, and especially for items that will be exposed to the elements and direct sunlight for long periods (outdoor upholstery, inflatables rafts RIF's, convertible tops or vinyl roofs, trim, etc.), but it works great for any plastic or rubber. It costs more than Armor All, but for what you get, it's worth it.ProsWorks on all rubber, plastic, or synthetic materialsContains high concentration of UV protectantsShine lasts a long timeProtects from the sun, rain, andHelps prevent oxidizationWorks nearly as good as the professional stuffConsA little expensiveSo that's 303. It's a great product and I give it my high recommendation. We used it on $6000+ urethane finish rafts before long trips and it worked great, better than Armor All or Meguiars. It's worth the extra cost to protect your investment.

First off, for those who think these are indestructible because it says "tungsten carbide" need to be aware that they are fragile and will break if you use them improperly. I bought a set of 20 of these (each size had an additional bit, which was really, really nice) from a local retailer Ha**r F***ght T**ls that repackaged and put their name on them. I had been looking for some of these for quite awhile and finally found them on Amazon, and was going to buy them until I found a set of 20 for a few dollars more and snatched them up.As stated these are micro "drills." The actual tungsten carbide part is the drill itself. The rest of the bit is made from high speed steel, and the carbide tip is welded on. They are right hand twist micro fluted bits and range from 1.2 mm down to the smallest .3 mm. They come in a nice opaque plastic holder that opens like a clamshell. The middle holds the bits and lifts up so you can easily take them out.The sizes are perfect for just about any project. I had to look real close to see the finest bit's cutting surface. The actual drilling part measures about 1/4" for the largest bit (1.2mm) down to about 3/16" for the smaller 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5 bits. This is long enough for about all of the projects you'll be using these for as they aren't heavy-duty. The shank is 1/8" which is the size of rotary tools (Dremel and the like) and pneumatic high-speed micro die grinders. You could also chuck them in your lathe or milling machine. They had the plastic donuts that help you set the depth on the mill without changing the settings on the machine. I wouldn't even think about using them on a regular drill as they are so fragile. You can use them for more than drilling as well. They make good spiral cutters on thin and soft materials.They are best used on thin and soft materials like copper or brass, fiberglass, plastic composites, carbon fiber and graphite composite, plastics, aluminum. They don't work on steel as I tried drilling a small broken knife tang from a handle. The largest bit only put a nice divot in the metal before snapping. I tried a smaller bit and it was the same effect. I did try them with my Dremel on some thin plastic and some thin posterboard to see how  they work and they worked great! I did manage to break one of the .3 mm bits though when I tried to use it as a spiral cutter on the poster board, but there was another one to take it's place. I think there's a reason why I got doubles of each one. Also be careful when handling them as they are sharp, and the small ones are sharp like needles. I managed to stab my thumb on one when getting another one from the plastic holder.Pros:Wide selection of sizesSeem to be well-madeTungsten carbide cutting tipsHandy plastic holderGood valueCons? Not really a con, but worth mentioning: They are incredibly fragile. Use with care!Overall, I'm really happy with them. I know they will get a lot of use! Time will tell as to how long they'll last or how long they stay functional, but they should last a while. be warned: It's not if you break one, it's when!

"Super Glue" as it's know is actually a mixture of cyanoacrylates and some additives that help with adhesion and drying. Unlike traditional "CA" type adhesives, this one doesn't require a catalyst for it to harden and set. This glue is unique in that it cures in the absence of oxygen unlike some other glues that react with the moisture in the air (wood glue, Elmer's school glue, polyurethane glue), or solvent-based adhesives that rely on aerosol effect to set up (rubber cement, contact cement, PVC or urethane adhesives).This stuff works great on just about anything. I've glued metal, rubber, plastic, wood (somewhat), ceramics, glass, and china. The only things I had trouble bonding were fabric, stone, and wood. It doesn't work that good on porous materials as it needs something to stick to. You have to apply the glue to both pieces you're bonding to for the best results on porous stuff.It works especially good on polystyrene plastics as it liquefies and softens the plastic a bit. If you put some on a piece of styrofoam, it will actually dissolve it. To make Super Glue work correctly, you have to squeeze the two items being bonded together tightly for a strong bond. The more surface area you have to adhere, the better. It's better to apply the glue to both pieces before bonding them together.A little bit goes a long way, and because it's runny, if you add too much it goes everywhere. Get it on your skin and it will bond instantly to anything you touch. The best way to "unstick" your skin is to use something like lotion or mineral oil, let it soak a little bit, and gently pull it off.Loctite did a good job of designing the dispenser and bottle. Usually the glue will make a real mess of the applicator, and if you don't wipe off the excess glue from the tip before putting the cap back on, it will glue the cap to the applicator. I've had this happen to me a lot, but it took longer for it to happen with the Loctite bottle. The 10 grams will last a long time. I've had mine for almost a year, and I use it frequently. My only gripe is that the applicator still sticks to the cap after a while and gets crusty with hardened glue. CA also has a very acrid smell to it that burns your eyes and nose if you get a good whiff of it.Overall, a great product. Highly recommend it. Every home needs a bottle of Super Glue.

I bought the "old" style Gorilla Glue a while back and had it for about 2 years. I used it a lot, and generally was happy with it. However, this is not a miracle adhesive and does have some limitations, which I'll go into later.This is a polyurethane-based glue, the active ingredients are diphenylmethane diisocyanate and some other reactants, and are very similar to those in expanding polyurethane foam, or 2-part polyurethane used to make molds or rigid polyurethane foam for insulation. Like wood glue, it reacts with moisture in the air, and just like poly foam, it expands when curing. It doesn't contain any aromatic hydrocarbons or suspended solvents like toluene, heptane, or acetone, or alcohols, so it's non-flammable and relatively safe as it doesn't produce strong and dangerous fumes. It does have a funk to it though, but not obnoxious.It works pretty good, but that largely depends on a couple factors. One is the surface it's being applied to, and the other is the type of application. Gorilla Glue by nature doesn't have good tensile strength and isn't very strong in shearing-type loads. When it cures, it gets frothy and expands to 3x's it's original volume, so that can cause problems with joints that shift when it dries. The surface prep is important, like any adhesive. It doesn't work good on bright, shiny surfaces like steel or plastic, and works best on porous things like wood, concrete, fabric or unglazed ceramics. If using it on steel or plastic, you need to sand the surface to rough it up to get the best bond.I used this to secure the little nobbles that go on the bottom of the toilet seat, and they came off within a couple weeks. I used it to glue the stock back on my stepson's wood and metal replica rifle, and it broke in a month. So I was pretty disappointed with it. It worked great on wood and some pottery, but didn't work when I glued the handle back on a mug that broke off. The trick is to firmly clamp the bonded items together or the glue will expand and compromise the joint. The frothy glue isn't resistant to shearing loads, unlike something like a hard epoxy (JB Weld, etc.), but works good when used to bond items with good surface area contact. The less surface area bonded, the weaker the bond. If you have a small surface to bond to, it's better to get hard epoxy.It's pretty easy to use, just apply a small amount of glue (a little goes a long ways) and clamp or compress the surfaces being bonded together. It helps to moisten the surfaces being bonded.You need to be cautious and clamps are important as the glue will expand and try to push the pieces apart. When the glue dries, it expands and will leak out everywhere if you use too much of it, so be cautious and not liberal in applying it. There may be some extrusion from the joints, but that's normal. You can scrape it off with a knife blade or sand it off. It is messy, sticky, and won't clean off with soap and water. Acetone, paint thinner, or alcohol are the only cleaners that will work.ProsStrong bonds when used correctlyDoesn't contain toxic chemicalsNon flammableWaterproofConsNeeds meticulous surface prep on nonporous mediumsLow tensile strengthExpands when curingRequires solvents for clean upSo Gorilla Glue is a good product. Perfect for wood and pottery and stone, but requires extra attention on steel and plastic. Overall, I'd prefer a 2-part epoxy over this just because it doesn't expand and makes a stronger bond and resists lateral loads better.

UPDATE: I returned the first defective digitizer, and they sent out a replacement quickly. The replacement worked just fine! 2nd time's the charm I guess. Now after a month, the screen has one hairline crack and some  micro fracturing under the camera (see the pictures). It hasn't been dropped or abused or anything. I originally gave it 3 stars, but now down to 2. Obviously, this isn't an OEM replacement or equivalent as the glass is much thinner and flimsier.I ordered this to repair a very badly damaged iPad 2. It had been dropped on two separate occasions and the screen was completely demolished. It was so bad that my stepson was cutting his fingers on the glass shards. I got a quote of over $90 at a local electronics shop to replace the screen, and was considering it until I found out that a replacement digitizer was less than $30 and wasn't terribly difficult to install if you know what you're doing and are careful. After weighing the options, I went for the replacement digitizer. I considered a couple others, but settled on this one because it got the best reviews and came with a full set of the required tools for a great price. I got it in the mail in a week, and it arrived well protected in a box cocooned with bubble wrap. The glass was protected with two clear peel off plastic sheets as well. No issues there. It came with the home button and camera holder installed too. I also bought the plastic bezel frame that fits between the digitizer and the iPad chassis. You'll want to get one as you'll most likely ruin the original. It only cost $4.Quality-wise, it seems to be as good as the original. The glass seems relatively thick and smooth with no visible defects, but I don't think it's the same quality as the OEM. The home button has a good clicking action and feel to it, so no complaint there. I did notice it's a little snappier than the original, but it doesn't effect function. The camera holder was a little crooked though, not a huge deal.The toolkit was great! I didn't get the Torx driver, but they sent me the phillips free. The SlyPry tool worked good, and there was a straight plastic pick with a point and a pryer on one side, a blue plastic pry tool, a metal spudger, a T4 Torx driver, and a 000 philips driver. The 2 included suction cups were useless (at least to me). The drivers were okay, but I could tell they weren't quality items as the shafts weren't centered to the handle. Not a huge deal though, what can I expect for $25 plus shipping?For those curious, this is the digitizer, not the actual "screen." I won't go into how it works in detail, but it translates the touch from your fingers to the LCD screen underneath to interact with the iOS of the iPad. All touch screen devices have one, and it functions independently of the LCD, which is good because in most cases, you can replace it as it is the thing that's usually broken, and the iPad screens, especially the later iPad 2, 3, 4, Air's that are more fragile than the first gen. iPad, which had the digitizer integrated to the LCD.Installation was pretty straightforward, but a nightmare! The screen was so shattered it took over 2 hours just to get it off. I am pretty good and comfortable with delicate electronics repair, and I will say this was one that really tried my patience to the max. Some helpful pointers for those thinking of DIY digitizer replacement:Get a heat gun. A hair dryer doesn't get hot enough to fully loosen the adhesive, and Apple does a good job of liberally using adhesive! Apply heat with the gun on the low setting, holding the gun about 1" above the digitizer. Move it back and forth so as not to heat one spot too long. Get it hot enough so you can only touch it for a second. Don't overheat it as you might damage delicate parts underneath. Heat along the lower left hand corner of the iPad to loosen the adhesive and slip you spudger in under the glass. I used the SlyPry tool and it worked really good. Pry it up a little, enough to get the spudger in. Guitar picks would be helpful here. Applying more heat if necessary, work up the left hand side of the glass with your spudger, being careful to keep it as flush to the glass as possible so you don't push down inside the iPad and damage the LCD screen. There aren't any cables on this side to break, aside from the digitizer flex, which you can cut with scissors.Keep working it up the side until you get to the camera. Don't heat the camera up as you can melt it. Heat around it and pry up the screen on the top. STOP and keep away from the upper right side where the power/volume keys are as you'll most likely ruin their ribbon cables if you do as they are stuck to the digitizer glass and super-delicate. Once you get the glass unstuck, stick in a guitar pick to keep it off the frame and go back down to the bottom and heat to the right of the home button. DO NOT go prying under the home button because that's where the WiFi module is and it's extremely fragile, and could be stuck to the digitizer as well. Now that the left side, and part of the top and bottom are free, apply heat to the right of the home button and up the right side to loosen the adhesive.Once it's hot, lift up on the left side of the digitizer, and fold it over to the right hamburger-style, making sure that the ribbon flexes for the power/volume and WiFi aren't sticking to the digitizer (You'll have to cut the digitizer cable on the left side, don't worry as you won't need it). Add more heat it necessary, and be really careful. You should be able to fold the screen and lift it off without breaking any cables. This won't work well if your screen is really shattered though, as it will break apart like it did for me. I had to go back and lift the screen from the broken sides to get it off, but it worked for me. I recommend buying the plastic trim piece because it's possible it will get damaged in the process. Just replace it so the screen will fit flush without any gaps or high spots. It's a $4 part. I did, and it was a bit of a pain to get in. I ended up super gluing it down because it was fractionally too large.Once the screen is off, remove any glass pieces left behind. Make sure to get them all or the screen won't lie flat. Be careful not to jam razor/needle sharp pieces of glass into your fingers like I did 8( I cleaned the edges with a Q-tip soaked in 99% isopropyl alcohol to get up any left behind adhesive. Optional, but I recommend it. You need to use the included philips screwdriver in the kit to take out the screws holding down the LCD so you can remove it and get to the digitizer cable. Take out the screws and lift it from the right side, as the connector is on the bottom left. Flip up the metal retaining handle and GENTLY pry off the LCD cable and lift off the LCD. The digitizer cable is held in with w flip-up plastic clips. Be VERY careful flipping them up (use a fine plastic pick, toothpick, or dental pick-don't break them as they are real fragile). Once they're up, slide out the digitizer cable.Now you can put the new digitizer in. Insert the digitizer cable into the ZIF connector, making sure to fully seat it in the connector. Use a tool to press it in as it needs to be seated all the way or parts of the screen won't work. Lower the plastic clips carefully. If they break, the cable won't seat correctly and the screen won't work. Set the LCD on it's left edge and plug in the LCD cable, flipping down the metal clip. Replace the screws and wipe off the LCD with a lint-free cloth to get off any fingerprints or dust. Take the digitizer and fold it over the LCD and set it in the frame. Now you can power on the iPad and test the digitizer functionality.If everything works, you can remove the adhesive backings, remove the plastic protector on the bottom, and set the digitizer in the frame, pressing firmly on the edges until it sits flat and flush. I don't recommend putting books or heavy things on the digitizer to get the glass to set flat. If it doesn't, then it's possible the frame is warped from being dropped (like mine was...I had to grind 3 of the corners flat with my Dremel tool to get the plastic frame to lay flat because it was so buckled) or the plastic frame is damaged.That's pretty much it! Hopefully you didn't break anything during the process. The usual victims are the WiFi module and power/volume assemblies. They're cheap to buy but a bear to replace (You might consider buying them as a precaution and send them back if you don't need them), so being careful is paramount.If you have problems with the screen not working, or parts of it not working, before you glue down the screen, check the digitizer connector. Make sure the cable is pushed all the way down so the white dots are flush with the connectors. If you still have issues, it could be a faulty digitizer, or some other part on the iPad. If it was working fine before the digitizer replacement and you didn't damage anything, then it's more than likely the digitizer being faulty or damage to the connector. If the replacement digitizer doesn't fix it, then it's a bigger problem.ProsCheapIncluded tools are very helpful (guitar picks would have been nice)Seems to be the same as OEMConsDigitizer was faultyStarted cracking after a monthAdhesive didn't fully hold down the digitizerCamera holder was installed crookedSo if you need to replace the digitizer and would rather DIY, this is a "cheap" fix. Buyer beware though. It's tempting to save so much money, but it's a crap-shoot with quality and I recommend investing in another adhesive kit in case the digitizer starts to peel off the iPad body.

I got this to replace a white iPad frame that was destroyed and falling apart after the iPad was dropped on the edges. I replaced the screen and the bezel at the same time, and I recommend doing this as you'll probably damage it when replacing the digitizer. The frame arrived in perfect condition in a sturdy cardboard sleeve. It's made from fragile semi-rigid plastic, and I couldn't tell much difference between the OEM Apple frame and this one, other than the Apple frame had extra keyways so it fit more securely in the iPad chassis. I found out later that this created a pain when installing it, which wasn't easy. The problem occurred when setting it in the frame as it was fractionally too large, so it bowed upwards on the sides and didn't fit flush. I thought it was due to the buckled corners of the iPad from it being dropped, but the frame bowed at least 1/8 inch on one side. I ended up breaking a corner to get it to fit flush. Also, it didn't set down securely, so I added some super glue to hold it in place, which was like wrestling an grizzly bear for a steak. To be fair, the Apple frame was also secured with glue (like rubber cement), but it had extra keyways that set in cutouts on the iPad chassis corners.Once I got it in though, it looked almost exactly like the original, aside from the raised corners where it didn't fit flush. Not a fault of the frame, but from the iPad's damaged corners.Pros:CheapWorks just fineCons:Didn't fit rightMissing some key alignment marksFragileSo if you are replacing the digitizer in your iPad, make sure to get a frame, especially if the original is cracked or broken as the new glass won't fit right. Overall I'm satisfied as it works as intended. Not as good as the original, but close enough!

This the best laundry stain remover I have ever used. Out of the others I've tried (bleach, Shout! is the most common), this works better, faster. I've had no issues cleaning blood, coffee, fruit stains, grass, dirt, or stains from "body fluids." It does better than bleach and doesn't contain chemicals like bleach (sodium hypochorate) that will ruin your clothes if you're not careful with it on colors. I've used it on clothes, carpet, upholstery in my car and couch. For whites, it's fantastic. It will even remove dried, set-in stains that bleach won't touch. It works fast too. I could see the stain being removed before my eyes when the stain is fresh!For those interested, it contains hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 for the chemists) as the active ingredient, which is an oxidizer, and in low concentrations is safe to use on organic and inorganic materials as a cleaner and disinfectant. It doesn't work like a surfactant, which lifts stains, but dissolves them. H2O2 is also a weak acid that helps with disinfecting and stain removal. The laundry cleaner adds some suspended chemicals, a thickener, and maybe some surfactants to boost the cleaning action, but it's mostly H2O2 and water. It is safe for your skin too unlike bleach, and doesn't leave a strong smell if you are sensitive to those products. Yes, there are reports of it bleaching colors, but if you use it properly, it won't. Make sure not to let it sit on the garment too long, and rinse it with plenty of water before throwing it in the washer. I've never had an issue with it, other than when I've been careless with it and bleached a spot of my carpet 8(Pros:Fantastic stain removerSafe to use on hands and clothesOdorlessDoesn't contain caustic chemicals like bleachWorks fastCons:Will bleach clothes or carpet if not used properlySo if you want an environmentally-friendly, but powerful stain remover that won't eat the skin off your fingers or make your nose burn, get some of this.

I've been using Oxiclean for the last 5 years, and have never been disappointed with it. In a word, there isn't much properly applied Oxiclean CAN'T clean or remove. I don't know what it's made of, but probably a mix of suspended hydrogen peroxide as sodium percarbonate or sodium perborate which provides the stain removal action through oxidization and dissolving stain compounds. In a pure form, it's used in rocket fuel as an oxidizer.In addition, H2O2 is also a weak acid, which also helps to remove stains. As another plus, it's a fantastic disinfectant, used extensively in various forms to sterilize medical devices and prevent infections (this is the foaming action that happens when you pour over the counter hydrogen peroxide in a cut).It works best on organic stains (fruit juice, blood, dirt, grass stains, pit stains, urine, poo, vomit, etc.) because the H2O2 is good at removing organic things (it's used in hair bleach products and teeth whitening, and bleaching flour and paper). Oxiclean is also environmentally friendly, unlike some detergent or chemical cleaners. It's also odorless and doesn't contain strong irritating chemicals, good for those who are sensitive to those things. I noticed it doesn't dry my hands out real bad like bleach or other cleaners (Comet, Soft Scrub, Pinesol).I've used it on some of the toughest stains to remove, that bleach wouldn't touch. Here are a few: Set-in orange juice, blackberry, and raspberry juice stains. The yellow underarm "pit stains," stains from chocolate (chocolate milk), blood (after it's dried, on white shirts), cooking oil stains (vegetable, canola, and olive), poo and pee stains from people and pets, grass stain (a bear to remove), water stains in the back of my station wagon, too. Those were particularly hard to remove. Strong carpet cleaner, highly concentrated Simple Green, laundry soap, dishwashing liquid didn't work as good as this! I've also used it to remove hydrocarbon stains from lubricating oil. It didn't work great, but it did work a little. I usually end up using something like brake parts cleaner on those.I like to dissolve it in warm water and put it in a spray bottle. A little goes a long ways. I put 2 tablespoons in a 24 oz. sprayer and it worked great! Make sure to shake it up occasionally and keep the spray orifice clean or it will build up. I also use it in the laundry when washing whites. I put a scoop into a large load while it's washing and I did notice the whites (especially dirty socks) were brighter.A word of caution though. Oxiclean in high concentrations can bleach things. I sprayed it on my carpet to clean a big hot chocolate spill, let it sit overnight until I could get a carpet cleaner, and when I vacuumed it, there was a spot that had lightened quite a bit. I also had this happen in the back of my car, so be careful. If you spray it on in a solution, don't let it sit too long before laundering clothes or before cleaning carpets.Pros:Environmentally friendlyDoesn't contain noxious smells or chemicalsDoesn't bleach clothes when used properlyRemoves just about any organic stain when used properlyA little goes a long wayVersatile disinfectantCons:None, other than be careful when applying in high concentrations as it will bleach fabric or carpetSo overall, this is the unequivocal cleanser and stain remover. It's outdone some of the most popular cleaners and stain removers I've used, and it's environmentally friendly, safe to get on your skin, and doesn't smell bad. Use it on carpet, clothes, couches, mattresses, cushions, drapes, etc. You won't be dissatisfied.

Got these to replace the original T-Mobile brand screen protector, which was one of the best I've used. Seem to be of good quality and didn't affect the operation or sensitivity of the screen at all. Fitment was good and came with a microfiber cleaning cloth. Instructions were just fine as well. Only had it a little while so I can't comment on durability, but they seem to be good quality so shouldn't have any issues.Application was just fine and they went on without too much bubbles under the film. The fitment was really good with no big gaps between the components in the cutouts.

I bought this for my wife's 1999 Ford Escort ZX2. After reading some favorable (and unfavorable) reviews, I decided put it in at I think 134,000 miles in an attempt to smooth a rough idle. It only cost $7, so I figured it was worth a try. If it worked, great. If not, then I only lose $7 and it was a good learning experience.For those who don't know, Seafoam itself is an oil-based solvent. You can use it on gas, diesel, 2-stroke, 4-stroke engines. It dissolves and removes carbon buildup and deposits. It contains stuff like naphtha and pale oil, which serve as dual-purpose cleaner and lubricant. It was originally developed as an additive for use in 2-stroke outboard motors (hence the name, Seafoam) to remove carbon buildup on the top of the piston and spark plug, exhaust and intake ports, and inside the crankcase. 2-stroke motors use oil in the gasoline for lubricating the internal engine parts, and over time carbon and gunk builds up and causes power loss and hard starting and accelerated engine wear.You put it in the gas tank, crankcase, or you can pour it down a vacuum line (the brake booster line on most cars) when the engine is running (I think 2000-2500 rpm) so it goes down the intake manifold into the combustion chambers. The directions say 1/3 of the can that way, the other 1/3 in the engine oil, or you dump the whole can in the gas tank. Doing it down the intake makes lots (or a little) white smoke out the exhaust. You're supposed to put it down the vacuum line until the motor stumbles and stalls. Let it sit for 10 minutes or so, start it up (this is where it smokes), and drive it hard for a few miles to burn off the dissolved carbon. If you go the oil route, you run the engine for 250 to 500 miles max, then change the oil. In the oil, it's supposed to remove sludge and deposits. In the gas tank, it stabilizes the fuel and removes varnish buildup, removes carbon from the valves and piston crown, and cleans the injectors (carburetor jets, fuel bowls, and venturi) in the carburetor.When I used it, I did the 1/3 deal and put 1/3 down the vacuum line and 1/3 in the gas tank. I didn't put it in the engine oil since it wasn't due for an oil change for a while. I put it down the vacuum line for the brake/clutch booster and kept the engine at 2500 rpms until it drank all the Seafoam. Some smoke came out, but nothing major. Let it sit 15 min, then drove it hard.After a while, I couldn't notice any discernible change. Even after the tank of gas was gone, no change. So, 7 bucks down, no biggie. Your results may vary. I've heard some got great results from it, and others not so much. Even though the idle didn't change, I am sure it did some good fuel system cleaning.Personally, I would use caution when using this on a car, because there are potential hazards, such as carbon being blown down the exhaust and lodging in the catalytic converter. There are too many other good fuel system cleaners (like Chevron Techron, Berryman B-12, Gumout FST, Lucas Oil Fuel System Treatment and Upper Cylinder Lubricant) that actually work well and are designed for modern engines. I've used Techron and Lucas Upper Cylinder Lubricant and they work great. Smoothed the idle out quite a bit in the car I used the Sea Foam on.

As described. A honest-to-goodness 14' ethernet cable at a good price! I've paid $20 for the same length cable at a computer supply store for IT projects before.Yes, it's Cat6 (not the more common Cat5 or Cat5e, "e" for enhanced), which means it's higher quality, than Cat5 and Cat5e, more resistant to "crosstalk" and able to handle more data efficiently. Cat6 is a must for a high throughput network (up to 10 gigabit). The price difference isn't much, but it's worth it if you need to manage a lot of data through a lot of cables like a big switch from a DC to many routers or access points, or amplifiers. The cable itself seems to be of high quality, though I'd like to see the clip protected a little better, but it's pretty snag-resistant as it is. Fit snugly into the ethernet port and haven't had any issues with it. A 14' Cat6 cable for under $10? Can't go wrong.

Love this book! I never heard of the author, but his message is right-on, and he mixes it with the word of God, which is the hallmark of his life experience of his journey through unemployment. It's so encouraging to me because I've been on and off of work for over three years and have had a very hard time finding work in my field.His message is inspiring and really speaks to me. He mixes his practical experiences with Biblical foundations that really help put a deep perspective on the many struggles that accompany unemployment. The author is a success story, despite going through many storms: a once highly successful company executive, family man, ready to collect a large bonus, and close on his dream home, only to have his world turned upside-down by a pink slip and endure a year-long unemployment journey.I am a Bible-believing, Spirit-filled Christian man, husband, and father, and know that God is hard at work during my personal journey with job-seeking and has a bigger purpose behind it, but it's so nice to read the account of someone who has "been there and experienced it." Even if you aren't a Christian, I think you will find this insightful, inspiring, and instill some hope in the struggles, the testing, and storms that come with career transition and unemployment.Whether you've been out of work for a week, or a year, I think you'll find this an inspirational, enlightening, and encouraging message from someone who has survived and is thriving even in difficult circumstances. A must-read for anyone struggling with unemployment!

I got this for my stepson for Christmas. It's as the description describes it. This is a "training" device meant to mimic the real thing, just like a "blue gun" used for firearms training drills. It mimics the real thing pretty accurately, with similar heft (some butterfly knives are lighter), balance, and functionality. The only thing that's missing is the quality, which isn't good. The description says it's "black powder" and I assume it means it's powder coated, but it seems more like thick black paint than powder coat. The faux blade is about 1/8" thick steel and has holes drilled in it for lightening and identification purposes. The handles are about 5" long and coated with the same black material. Functionally, it's indistinguishable from the real thing. It opens pretty smoothly and easily and the pivots aren't tight or bind up. The screws are torx type, so they don't come loose, and I assume it's also to keep people from taking it apart.It has a locking latch at the butt, but I had to force the knife closed to get it to latch to the other handle, and it didn't fit flush like it should. I found it funny that on the blade there's a Benchmade-like butterfly with the word "Balisong" running through it, which lets you know this is a knock-off of the real Benchmade Balisong butterfly trainer. Funny.So, that's it in a nutshell. A good knock-off that's pretty much as described and you get what you pay for. I give it 3 stars to be fair because it's low-quality, but does what it's supposed to.

I got this for free with a purchase from a local tool and hardware retailer. It's a digital multimeter with seven functions. Pretty simple. No auto ranging, buzzer for continuity, just the basics.It came with a tiny instruction manual and the two test probes. It includes the 9v battery. I wasn't expecting much, and that's what I got so no surprises. It does everything the box says it does.You can measure all the basic functions (except AC current): AC volts, DC volts, DC current, Ohms, Continuity, diode/transistor, and a battery test mode. It works pretty well for being so cheap. It does only go to 750 volts on AC or DC, and doesn't measure AC current, but everything else is there. The LCD display only has a 3.5 resolution, so you're limited to that. Not a huge deal, but a larger display would be nice.I had no trouble getting the functions to work. The instruction booklet did a reasonable job explaining things, so a novice can pick it up and learn how to use it. It doesn't have auto-ranging so you have to choose it yourself. I always start on the middle setting when probing unless I know the correct setting for the test I am doing. I was able to measure volts, DC current, resistance, and continuity. The battery test function was useless to me (maybe I didn't do it right). The best way to test whether a battery is "good" is to hook some leads to the test probe (alligator or test clips), and hook it to a resistor (anything around 100 ohms and 5 watts), then probe the terminals. You get great readings that way.As far as accuracy, I'd say it's good enough. 1.5v batteries read around 1.6v and the 9v batteries read 9.7v. The bother for me is that the resistance readings dance all over the place and never really settled in, even with good connections. The thing it's missing is microamp setting. Milliamps are the bog standard, but it would be nice to be able to measure something smaller.The test probe wires are reasonably long, but the test probes themselves seem pretty flimsy and the wires wiggle inside the hand pieces. I had trouble with the banana plugs coming loose and unplugging themselves from the meter. Having to keep plugging them back in gets annoying. The only other gripe I had was it acted wonky a couple times, where I'd turn it on and it wouldn't give me a measurement. It would eventually sort itself out after a while, so that's annoying too. The battery might need changing soon I guess. Not sure if this has a fuse on the 10A circuit...hope it does.ProsCheapReasonably accurateIncludes a batteryDoes the basic functionsSmall and compactConsCheapNo AC currentNo microamp settingReadings took a while to settle downCheap test probesBanana plugs wiggle out of the meterSo that's the Cen Tech multimeter. For what it is you can't beat it. This isn't a Fluke, so don't expect that. Expect it to be a cheap, somewhat reliable, and basic test tool.

I got this on special at Ha***r Frei**t Tools for cheaper than on here. I'd been in the market for one for quite a long time, and finally bought one a few weeks ago for an electronics project (fixing my wife's hair flat iron) that required some delicate soldering. This would also be good for something like beading or jewelry repair.Because humans don't have 4 arms and there are some tasks that would benefit from it, this thing is great. It came in a blister package, and my first impression was: Cheap!It's made from chrome plated steel and seems pretty sturdy. The base is weighted and has a soft pad on the bottom to protect whatever you set it on and to keep it from slipping. It's painted in an attractive black crinkle paint. It's pretty simple design. There's a main bar that has two arms at the ends with alligator clips. Attached to the bar is the magnifying glass that's mounted to a similar mechanism as the alligator clips, which is basically 2 plates with wing nuts on either side that squeeze together. In the middle of the plates are holes that mount to ball ends on the bar so the arms and magnifying glass can articulate.The bar itself is rigid except for where it mounts to the base, which can move left and right and rotate. The magnifying glass is mounted in a flimsy steel compression ring. It's interference fit so there's no glue or anything holding it in. Surprisingly, the magnifying lens is actually glass! It resists scratches and dings better than polycarbonate or other plastics.As far as how well it works, well, it works and does what it says it does. It helps you hold things so you can have 2 hands free to work. I use it mainly for soldering wires together, but I'm sure you could use it for other tasks. I am not impressed with the design on the mechanisms that allow the arms and magnifier to articulate though, as the nuts can get loose, and to move the arms you have to loosen them and re tighten them. The base kept it steady, but you'd want to limit how much weight you put on it or it will topple. The magnifier didn't magnify that much, I'd guess maybe 2.5 to 3x at the most. It would be nice to have a secondary lens inside the bigger one for small up-close work.Pros:HandyReasonably pricedSturdyGlass magnifying lensFull lange of motion for the "hands"Cons:Joints are clunkyBase could be bigger/heavierMagnifying lens isn't secured to the mounting ring very wellSo overall this is a handy tool for people needing another set of hands. It works, and aesthetics aside, that's good enough for me.

JB Weld has been around for a long time and I have used it for a lot of different projects/repairs.It's a standard 2-part epoxy, containing the resin and a hardener (catalyst). The two won't work without being mixed together, and require equal part of each tube to harden properly. The thing that sets JB Weld apart is that it is reinforced with tiny steel filaments, a lot like polyurethane resin reinforced with fiberglass or body filler. This adds stability and rigidity so it creates a very strong bond. They say it has a tensile strength of 4,000 psi, which is pretty strong. Not the strongest, but pretty good!It's super easy to use, just mix equal parts from each tube together and mix until it turns a nice grey color. Once it turns grey, you'll have about 30 minutes to make the repair before it sets up and becomes unusable. I've found it works better if you mix slightly more than you feel you'll need because it seems to mix better in larger quantities, and mixing it in a container (like a mix cup or inside of a sports drink bottle cap).It's water proof, resists chemicals and petroleum products like oil, gasoline, diesel, grease, brake, hydraulic, and transmission fluid, and even solvents. I used it to repair a carburetor on my weed trimmer (an internal part that's submerged in gasoline), a knob on my Bowflex, a fitting on my RC car's exhaust (which gets bathed in highly corrosive nitro fuel constantly), and some other things I can't remember, and it's fantastic. Never had a problem unless it was my fault. I was able to grind it like steel, you can drill holes in it, run a tap in it, sand it, and cut it with a cutoff wheel no problem.Unless you need to fix a cracked engine block, the two 1 oz tubes will last for a while. They do make a jumbo-size tube though.Overall it's a great tool every home should have. Pro's have been using it for a long time in industry.ProsSuper strongContains steel fibersResists petroleum products and solventsCan be sanded, drilled, tapped, or machined like steelEasy to use

I got this to repair a Dell Inspiron that wouldn't charge or run off the AC adaptor. I suspected the charger board had gone bad so I bought another one.This isn't an OEM Dell part. It's not even a name brand, but a one-hung-lo Chinese clone. It appeared to be relatively well-made, but I could tell it had lots of hand-soldering that wasn't done very well. There was flux all over the joints for the ethernet jack and solder mask. The joints were sound, but sloppy. I compared it to the genuine Dell and I could tell the quality wasn't up to par.But looks aren't everything. It cost under $10 and I am sure it worked, just it didn't work in my situation as it turned out to be another problem (motherboard).3 stars for the part, 5 stars for the customer service. I got a full refund the same day I filed my claim! Great customer service from DoRight! Buy it from them.

I got this years ago (I forget how many, probably over 10) and I will say it's the perfect addition to the Dremel rotary tool! This is a flex shaft that attaches to the motor drive shaft of the rotary tool. There's a special drive adapter that you screw onto the roto tool's motor shaft (after removing the chuck and collet) so it mates with the flexible drive shaft inside the tool. The end of the shaft has a collet that screws onto the front of the rotary tool to secure it. It's super-simple to install (Yes, a caveman can do it). I got it as part of a kit and it is a very welcome addition.I love this thing. It's been as indispensable as the Dremel itself! I've used it for drilling, grinding, carving, cutting, polishing, and sanding and it works great. Never had an issue except for me using it incorrectly and breaking my micro bits. I don't know if it has an RPM limit, but I never used it past 25,000.As far as the shaft itself, it has a hand piece that houses the shaft lock (for locking the shaft inside to install bits). It has a rubberized coating all around and feels great in the hand. I had no trouble controlling the tool even in awkward positions. The tip houses the same quick-change collet system as the rotary tool. Use the wrench to loosen the drive nut, unscrew it, and remove the collet. Simple. There's a collar on the tip of the hand piece that unscrews so you can attach Dremel accessories to it (the router/spiral cut attachment, sharpener). I am not sure if you can mount the planer. I haven't tried it.The shaft is made from high-density elastomeric rubber that is very tough, but flexible enough to be useful. It's about 5/16 or 3/8" in diameter and about 3 ft long (give or take). Inside the rubber jacket is a flexible metal drive shaft that flexes very easily to reduce friction when bending during use. There are spring coils at either end of the shaft to reduce stress on the hand piece and the mounting nut that screws to the Dremel tool. I had no issues with it binding up at all even when bent at nearly 70 degrees. Dremel says a 5" radius, and I can substantiate that.I forget if there are needle bearings in the hand piece (I'd say there are), but Dremel applies generous amounts of what looks like silicone grease to the drive shaft, which you can remove easily for servicing or cleaning if needed, like adding more grease. I don't think that's necessary as more grease just adds drag and it spins pretty freely as it is. I would say this is a very low maintenance tool, just like the Dremel itself.I did apply some M7 Pro CLP to the shaft and I can tell it spins more freely and with less noise and vibration.I have no gripes with this at all. It's comfortable to hold, and even after awkward positions I had very little hand fatigue. You can use it with a fist grip (be careful not to push the shaft lock) or fingertips. It's capable of some very precision work. It's very easy to maneuver into tight spots the rotary tool won't fit. Any of the 1/8" bits will fit this, and you can of course swap the collets to fit micro drills too.It's versatile as well, and fits most of the modern Dremel rotary tools. I love it. If you have a Dremel and use it a lot for precision work, get one of these. Great investment.Pros:Dremel qualityEasy to useComfortableLong shaftLow maintenanceVersatile, works with some Dremel add-on'sCons:Only one, that it won't fit every Dremel. Otherwise perfection.

These were a Christmas gift to my wife. I am an avid cooker (so's my wife) and know the mark of a good pan/skillet. I have some experience with Calphalon with their flat bottom griddle,. and wasn't pleased as it warped after the third use and didn't heat or cook food evenly.These are the Contemporary line, which I know has a good reputation for quality vs. value, and I can say I am pleased with them. This comes as a 2-piece set and you get a 10 inch and 12 inch skillet/omelet pan (you can use them for both, tradition pans are a little deeper and come with lids) made of hard anodized heavy-gauge aluminum (not sure of the type of aluminum, there are lots), but I can say it's of high quality. We have an 8 and 10 inch tri-ply (aluminum/copper/stainless) that have been the best pans I've ever used, so these have some tough competition!Aside from being heavy-gauge aluminum, It has a heavy bottom as well, which is good for even heat distribution so foods cook evenly (I hate hot spots). I can report that these do heat evenly and I haven't had any problems with hot spots. I'd say these cook as good as my tri-ply cookware even though they don't hold the heat as well. The sides are shaped in a fashion that helps food to slide off, and it does pretty well. It's non-stick inside as well, which works great and has been durable (make sure to use plastic or wood spatulas, spoons or turners) even with some abuse with metal forks and spoons. It's not as smooth inside as some other pans, but does the job and cleans up very well. You don't have to use a lot of butter or oil to keep food from sticking, which is good for your health too.The handles are aluminum as well (forged this time) and fastened to the pans with heavy rivets (they are cylinders of soft aluminum pressed on with a hydraulic press) which is the norm for cookware these days. Aluminum handles stand up to heat very well, but these are only good for 450 degrees, so a bit less than stainless or ply pans. Not a huge deal, but some buyers might want ones rated for higher temps.My ONLY gripe is that the handle on one pan has come loose and is wiggling. I think from heating and cooling cycles, but they aren't warped so I don't really mind much. I will keep an eye on it and report back if it gets worse, but you really can't argue with a ton of happy reviewers!Pros:Heavy gauge hard anodized aluminumHeavy bottoms heat evenlyForged aluminum handlesNon-stick coating has held up wellGreat value for what you getCons:Handle on one pan has come loose and is wiggling a bitOnly rated to 450 degreesSo you get some great pans for a great value. You'd expect to pay at least $50-$60 for each one of these separately, but for $75 shipped, you can't beat it.

This was a Christmas present we got a few years ago. I think we've had it for about 4 years? I don't know, but it sat unused for quite a while. I think the extent of its use was a couple (botched) haircuts and me using it to trim my beard (lots faster than my little Panasonic trimmer), which I've been doing for probably the last year.So it's a kit that includes lots of stuff and you should be able to start cutting hair with it after some practice. The kit includes six cutting guides in various lengths from around 1/2 inches down to 3/16 or 1/8 inches (I forget), two hair clips, some barber's style scissors and guide comb, a tiny bottle of oil for the trimmer blades, blade cover, and a tiny brush for cleaning off the cutter assembly. It comes in a plastic container to hold all the contents.Now, the picture on the listing is different than what I had. The clippers are a shiny chrome and the on-off switch is on the side not the top. The clipper itself looks different as well (maybe Conair redesigned it?).The clippers did their job and worked as I expected to. There's an adjusting lever on the side that adjusts the top blade's depth, push it forward and the top cutters move forward. Pull it back and they retract. I liked that feature quite a bit, and the lever was pretty sturdy and held their position.  I kept it on the smallest setting to trim my beard to the length I like it and it worked fine. They trimmed my thick beard (beard hairs are much tougher than actual hair) like it wasn't there and cut hair with no issues whatsoever. The blades are self-sharpening as well, and it isn't noisy. The motor inside doesn't spin too terribly fast so the cutter head doesn't go very fast. The guides snapped onto the clippers just fine and stayed on pretty securely.The scissors were junk. You could tell they're cheap, made from cheap steel, not very sharp, and marginally cut hair. The comb worked fine, and the clips worked good like they should. No complaints there. The oil bottle is small and won't last a long time, but you don't have to go crazy with the oil. Just a couple drops on the cutters to keep them lubed between uses. The brush is pitiful and only good for cleaning the hair residue out of the cutter head.Now, the reason for two stars...The clippers are complete junk. True, they work good, but they broke after maybe 12 hours of use. I was trimming my beard and then the clippers started making a terrible racket. The top cutter seemed to detach from the rest of the cutter head and was flopping around. I took the clippers apart to investigate to see if it was just something that came loose, but on further inspection, one of the return springs for the cutters had snapped completely in two. That is due to metal fatigue and over time, the spring got stressed and finally broke at the fatigue point. It's basically unfixable unless you buy the whole spring assembly, which might cost more than the entire trimmer kit.The design of the cutter head is also questionable. It's based on the eccentric reciprocating design, where an eccentric plastic hub with a metal shaft that fits into a slot in the cutter head. As the motor spins, the shaft moves the top cutter side to side. A torsion spring acts to return the cutters and provide some stability to the top cutter. This isn't the ideal setup for clippers. Good clippers have an electromagnetic reciprocating system that's much more reliable and provides a more positive cutting motion.Pros:Clippers performed goodCuts thick hair greatAdjustable cutter depthIncludes six cutter guides, hair clips and comb and scissorsInstruction manual and how-to for haircutsCons:Cheap clippersCheap scissorsClippers broke after 12 hours of useSo it's not a professional-grade clipper set, but unless you're a barber or stylist, you probably don't need anything better unless you're brand-specific. They do what you want them to do, cut hair, and they just work. Conair doesn't make bad products, and I don't know if they've been redesigned to address the issue, but breakage after 12 hours of use in a hair clipper is ridiculous. Go buy some Wahl's and you won't be disappointed!

My 2002 Subaru started to experience transmission quirks about 8 months after I bought it back in 2010. It would slightly jitter (tough to notice, but it's there) when cold from 1-2 gear, and abrupt downshifts from 3-2 2h3n you put your foot down. I did a full service (trans fluid, both filters replaced), and it didn't help. It started getting worse, so I bought some of this after reading favorable reviews.You add the whole bottle to the existing fluid, but be careful because if it's already full, you need to drain some. This is a full 24 oz of fluid you're adding, almost 1 quart and a half. I added it and my transmission was overfilled. You add it when the motor is warm and running and should notice a difference right away, but I didn't. No discernible difference in shifting. In fact, it has gotten slightly worse in the last 2 years.I paid $12 for it and it was hit-or-miss, but not a big deal. I think I will drain 48 ozs of trans fluid and replace it with 2 bottles of this for yucks soon. Not terrible optimistic about it.The upside is that it does other stuff like clean the fluid, condition it, and helps stabilize it. That's good, even if I can't tell it's working. So, give it a try. It's better than dropping thousands on a rebuild or new trans. You never know. This won't repair a problem and it's not a permanent solution. If your transmission is damaged, it might help temporarily, but the issue will come back.

I am skeptical when it comes to "engine additives."  I have tried some and they didn't work so never again. I am familiar with Lucas Oil products...I've used their Transmission Fix/Stop Leak with mixed results. I wasn't apt to try more. My dad's a mechanic of 31 years and knows other mechanics of 30+ years, and some love and swear by additives and some think they're a waste of money. I was in a conversation with a long-time mechanic and he mentioned the Lucas Upper Cylinder Lube and Injector Cleaner and how he got a lot better mileage in his 2005 Buick. I had seen this stuff in the parts store and never thought much of it until I heard the words "I got better mileage" and "it's less than $12 for up to 10 tanks of gas."So I borrowed some and what do you know, I got about 60 miles farther on 1/2 tank of gas. Normally my 2002 Subaru Legacy wagon gets maybe 18-19 city and 25 highway (not too good...gas here is $4.00/gallon) so that's 110-120 miles for 1/2 tank. I was lucky to get 260 miles on a full tank with mixed driving (that's 15 gallons of gas if I run it almost dry). I added a squirt of the Lucas and I got 180 miles for 1/2 tank! I drove it last week on 3/4 tank from here in Vancouver, WA to Olympia, WA and back and then another 40 miles of driving before the light came on for gas...that's 340 miles to a tank. Amazing. I was stunned.The 32 oz. bottle will treat 100 gallons of gas or diesel. You can add more or less if you want to. You can add it every fill-up or every other, doesn't matter. I noticed that if I didn't use it then things went back to the way they were.It's best to use it right before you fill up. They say use 3 ounces per 10 gallons. I take the bottle with me in my trunk and add it right before I pump to mix it up. I didn't notice any change in how the engine performed, no change in power, idling, acceleration, etc, but who knows how it's helped the insides. It's got lubricants in it that stick to the "upper" part of your engine, the parts that gas touches like the injectors, intake valves, piston crown, valve seats and guides, fuel pump and adheres to them. I am sure it's good for cleaning (although I don't know how good it does as this isn't a solvent-type cleaner) and lubing the injectors, and I'm sure my fuel pump is happier and the fuel system's happy (ethanol in fuel is corrosive to rubber parts and over time it makes them brittle). It didn't make my pinging go away, but hey, for $12 it's paid for itself in the first 4 tanks of gas!It's made me a believer in Lucas Oil and I will definitely try their other products again. Amazing. Definitely worth it.

I use two of these at work for a dual-monitor setup, and I am really pleased! I used to use one of these with a Viewsonic 19" widescreen and could immediately tell a difference between the two. The Viewsonic's colors were duller and were darker than the Dell's, and even on max contrast they still weren't as good. Although the resolutions were the same, the colors and detail were nowhere near as good, which is why I "traded" for another one of these from another co-worker's setup!It's a 19" widescreen format monitor with anti glare coating on the screen, the 19" being measured diagonally, it's actually 17.5" wide and 14.4" tall including the stand, and 5.7" thick. It operates at a 60 Hz refresh rate, 1000:1 contrast ratio, and a dot pitch around 0.2 mm. You get 16.7 million color support, and it's pretty bright too at 300 cd/m2. It's energy efficient, EPEAT rated silver, and only uses 38 watts when on, and 2 watts in standby. Obviously the LED monitors are much more efficient than the old fluorescent lamp backlights.I really like the monitor. The E198WFP isn't a newer monitor and doesn't have LED backlighting, but it does do HD and has inputs for both DVI and VGA/D-sub. Obviously, the DVI will give much better picture quality, but on VGA it's not bad at all. There's no HDMI. The maximum resolution (native) is 1440x900 HDCP and a 160 degree top/bottom viewing angle, which is pretty good for a lamp-type display.The base is nice a sturdy, and it's adjustable for height. It locks into place securely as well. The monitor is heavy though at 11 lbs (no doubt due to the internal power supply) and not as thin as newer ones, but for what it is, it's great. There are only 4 buttons on the front, power/standby, menu, and two function keys (1, 2).Pros:Dell quality19" anti-glare screenNative 1440x900 dpi HDCPEasy to set upIncluded adjustable stand1000:1 C/RGood contrast and excellent color reproductionBright, even on low brightnessCons:HeavyThickI have no problems using this all day. It's a great display for a good price. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a high quality monitor with very respectable performance.

I have two Buzz Bee dart guns; this one and the Hawk bolt action blaster. I really like the Hawk, and despite it's shortcomings it's a really cool gun. From my understanding, the Double Shot was originally a side-by-side "double" rifle, but they reconfigured it into an over-under shotgun design. It's made of the same polystyrene plastic as Nerf's (I own a lot of them), and is colored as such. What's very un-Nerf is how it fires. The darts load into hard plastic cartridges that look like shotgun shells. Inside the shell is a post and some kind of spring (like on Nerfs) to limit the amount of air that propels the dart. The cartridges are loaded into the open breach of the gun, which you break open from a tang-mounted release. As you break open the barrel, a cord cocks a spring mechanism and piston, sets the trigger, and the gun is ready to fire. It has a single trigger to fire both barrels either individually, or all at once. After firing, break open the gun and when it's fully open, the shells are ejected just like in an ejector-style shotgun or rifle. Really cool.Range isn't stupendous. Maybe 20 feet. Sometimes I only got 1 foot, the dart just fell out of the barrel, other times, one dart would come out with some authority. This isn't a slow-loading dart gun. If you keep spare loaded shells on you (there's a storage area in the stock covered by a flip-open cover) it can be re-loaded pretty quickly. If you're using this as a primary weapon in a war, then you are in trouble as even though it's not slow to reload, you only get two shots, while someone else might have 18, ready to go. So this would be best as a last-ditch gun. Fire and throw it away. I didn't find it too difficult to operate, but I'm an adult. Kids under age 8 would have some difficulty getting the gun cocked. The shells are critical to firing it, and losing them renders the gun useless (unless you use it as a club). Durability is a major issue. We had this for a little under a year and it's broken. The string that cocks the mechanism snapped (or one of its mounts), so it's useless which is kind of a shame because I like the Double Shot, just like the Hawk. The plastic isn't as thick as on Nerfs either, so I'd hesitate to say this is "kid-proof" and even less adult proof. Even though I like the blaster, there's a reason I'm a Nerf aficionado. Also, the dart/cartridge refills aren't cheap. For $10 you get 6 of them. I can get 30 Nerf darts for that price.Pros:Works like a real shotgunCan fire both barrels at once or individuallyStorage area in the stockLightweightShoots far (when it wants to)Con's:Isn't durableDoesn't shoot far (when it does)Breaks easilyOnly fires two shotsCartridge/dart refills are spendy

I own a lot of Nerf guns (a few Recon CS6, the Recon Deploy, Stampede ECS, Swarmfire, ultra-modified Airtech 2000, some modified N-Strilke single shot pistols, and some Nite Finders). I have used lots of Nerf guns as well and modified a lot of Nerf guns.My first experience with Buzz Bee's guns was at a church event because they were using them in a kid's game I was working on (shoot through the circle on a whiteboard, get some candy). There were the break open over-under shotgun and the Hawk. I think I hated it at first because it wasn't working at all, kept jamming, and didn't shoot far, but I fell in love with the coolness. It uses plastic "cartridges" that look somewhat like a shotgun shell. They hold the darts (plain suction darts a little wider than Nerf's) in the shell, which you load into the blaster. The Hawk is a bolt action dart blaster, and it works basically like a bolt-action rifle! It has a clip that holds 5 (if I remember right) cartridges that load in like the real thing. Load it open bolt or closed. Insert the clip, cycle the bolt, and fire. To reload, move the bolt handle up 90 degrees, the bolt cocks the spring, ejects the "spent" cartridge, and loads another dart. Awesome! You can load them individually too, just like a single-shot rifle. The action actually works really good most of the time. I was pretty impressed. They don't go real far. I had trouble getting them past 20 feet or so, but it shoots accurately. Probably more so than my long-barrel CS6. The stock has a built in storage area that holds extra shells and darts.Compared to a Nerf, the Nerf blasters are better-built, stronger and more durable than the Hawk. Not to say Buzz Bee has quality-control issues, but they could build their stuff better. I could tell you had to be careful with the Hawk. It's not really flimsy, but could benefit from some thicker plastic. It's made from the same polystyrene as Nerfs. The clip is hard to load too as you have to hold the first cartridge down with your finger while you insert the second one or else it will fall out. Annoying. Loading is slow. You have to put the darts into the shells or you can't fire them. For any kind of rapid-fire, you'd need extra clips pre-loaded.Sometimes the darts wouldn't leave the barrel, so you would reload and fire only to have two darts come out, one might go 10 feet, the other will fall out. The other downside is the cost of the thing. It's $30 to buy it. It comes with only 3 shells and 4 darts. To buy more shells and darts, I think it's almost $10 for a pack of 6. You can get 30 Nerf darts for that much, and you can't really use the Buzz Bee darts in a Nerf gun. I had mixed results, either they're too big or too short. They work fantastically in my Nite Finders and my Airtech though. They also worked well in my N-Strike pistols.So, that's the Hawk. It's super-cool on one hand, not-so-cool on the other. Questionable quality, unreliable operation, mediocre firing range, hit-and-miss functionality. The cool factor outweighs the other things though. I was going to rate it lower, but because this dart gun is in a class by itself, I gave it accolades.Pros:Super-cool and realistic functionalityLightweightDecent firing rangeAccurateCons:Unreliable firing mechanismSeems to be flimsyClips hard to reloadSlow to reloadExtra ammo and cartridges can get spend and the more the better

This came in an ASUS Essentio desktop from BestBuy that I set up and configured for a customer. It's my first experience with an i7 Ivy Bridge quad, so I was excited to see how it worked. I am familiar with the Sandy and Ivy-Bridge i5's, and they are already overkill for 90% of what you'd use a PC for (even gaming), so I was expecting more of the same. I was happily rewarded with the exact same (I couldn't tell a huge difference) performance as the i5 3470 (another screaming CPU). I have built 4 machines with that CPU and have 4 very happy customers.The i7-3770 is the locked-multiplier version of the i7-3370. Intel also makes an unlocked "K" code of this processor that can be over clocked for better performance, and it's really easy to OC the i7 K same as the i5 K. It's built on the 3rd-gen Ivy Bridge 22nm process, which is an excellent package. It doesn't consume a lot of power and is rated at just 77 W TDP (same as the i5-3470). For a comparison, a comparable AMD is rated at 125 W TDP and gets completely smoked by the i7. (I love AMD, but they are still way behind Intel in their architecture and efficiency/speed). It's a quad-core with hyper threading, which effectually doubles the base core count, so Windows (or Mac) sees 8 processing cores in Device Manager. The base clock is 3.4 GHz with Turbo-Boost to 3.9 GHz. There's 8 MB L3 smart cache, 5 GT/s DMI, and 25 GB/s memory bandwidth.
