I have every blues play along by Hal Leonard, as well as many other play along collections, and this one is easily at the top.**On a scale of 1-10 in difficulty playing note for note along with the book, this is about an 8, lots of slide work, string skipping, chord work and, what gets me, the frustratingly "simpleness" to the songs.A MUST for any blues lover!

This is another fine collection of TAB plus backing track books from Hal Leonard. I got this mostly to practice my right hand picking technique and work on my speed, and wow yeah this is a good one for that! Whats cool about this one is alot of the intros and melodies are somewhat "easy" to get under your fingers with a lot of practice, but then when it comes to the guitar solo parts, thats where it gets pretty insane. Do-able and nice to have one reliable sourse if you're a big time Dime fan, but those solos are going to take a LOT of repetition!!  ;-) Great backing tracks. Minus the one star for some of the guitar work was a little oddly off from the originals, making it somewhat difficult to process. Still, a great Play Along book for Pantera fans or those wanting to rock out.**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 9.3 Pretty extreme in quite a few areas. Melodies are easier to learn than the Dime solos. Really good backing tracks.

I buy a ton of guitar instruction books, learning materials, play along books, videos, all sorts of items to expedite my proficency at playing guitar.I play mostly blues. The reason I got this book was mainly because I didn't really understand what it means when they say to "play the A minor(or whatever) pentatonic over the I, IV, V" in a progression. Do I just use form 1 of the 5? Where and when should I use the other 4 forms? I'm assuming that it would be too easy to just use the first form for all the chord progressions so I'm not sure when I would use the other ones and where exactly. I didn't and still don't fully understand that concept and how that works. I'm going on my second year of playing. I practice 2-3 hours a day minimum, 7 days a week and read a TON to learn the concepts behind what exactly I'm doing.This book says it will get you playing all over the neck. Yeah, it does. But so does the $5.99 "Ultimate Scale Book." The best thing about that book was it gave you the BIG PICTURE first of the all five scale patterns, then you practice each one until you put them together. This book goes thru one at a time for an entire chapter. Me I like/have to visualize the ENTIRE picture and know what I'm ultimately working towards. What I was looking for exactly, was WHY, HOW, and WHEN to apply one of the five pentatonic scales.Well, basically what this book is is an expensive lick book. There are hundreds of lick examples, mainly in a rock or blues style. Upon first opening the book you see tons of licks in tab, and tons of words, so your first impression would be "wow theres a ton of info in here! Yay!"  Well, the words usually aren't actually helpful, they're simply describing the lick you're about to play. Lots of filler.Before purcasing this book, I already knew and understood how all 5 patterns fit together and how to transpose them. I guess what I was after was some clarification on how to mingle different keys together, what the "rules" are for that, and basically a definitive source for that. Well, after looking through this book, I found only partial answers without really any clarification. I found sort of what I was looking for on page 68.What this book is: tons of licks with description of each as well as audio samples, and "Quick Theory Tips" one or two per chapter which usually ARE actually helpful, but since they're "quick," they don't really expand on some of the ideas. This book would be good for those that would like to practice each form of the pentatonic scale for an entire chapter, which includes dozens of licks. I think if you were going thru this book chapter by chapter, sure by the end you'd know how the scales fit together, but I feel if you did that, you'd be bored by the time you got to the end.If you're just looking for a book on how to practice and fit the pentatonic scale together, the book that worked for me that costs $5.99 is Troy Stetina's"Ultimate Scale Book." which has pretty much ALL the scales, major, minor, blues, etc. I have 4 of Troys books, and I consider his books to be EXCELLENT resources for the beginning to advanced guitarist. That book mainly has pictures and I just practiced it day in and day out until I got it.This book mainly failed for me in the writing; boring textbook style, whereas Troy's books are written in a conversational fashion and also CONTAIN INFORMATION CONSISELY. Not a bunch of filler words to sound smart. Maybe the info I need is in here, but if it is, it is NOT easy to find, isn't in a logical place, or is hidden among the hundreds of lick example "explanations."3.5 Stars. One thing I really liked about it was it does have some really cool sounding licks that aren't so easy and not so hard. Good licks.  Not a complete waste of $ for me, but wouldn't buy again.

I have about 30 of these Play Along books, and I play mostly blues. One my favorite guys is Magic Sam, so I was super excited to see this Play Along out!! I played the heck out of "Easy Baby," one of my all time favorite songs. Side note: I use a VOX Valvetronix VT20 amp and I am able to get that "slapback" Magic Sam sound.) All the tracks are great, the backing tracks as well as the guitar parts. Every song and every artist on this one are legendary!! It's like playing with the Blues All Star Team!!(obviously these are NOT the original tracks played by the original artists. There are two tracks, each complete songs, one with guitar and one without guitar) What I personally like about this book is, I can play acoustic guitar to most of them, or electric, they sound good either way! Most of these songs have been covered hundreds of times by other blues artists along the way, so if you're trying to get the "vibe" of a song and you cant find the TAB anywhere else or the backing track, give this a shot! A lot of my favorite artists are represented on this collection, and I found it fun to play along to! I mainly use these play along books for the backing tracks. I learn the melody or the theme of the song and then improvise the rest.**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 7  Not too difficult for an intermediate guitar player. Not easy by any means, but fun and challenging.****Upadate**** This has easily become my most favorite Blues play along. I have every other blues play along book, but this one stands out, for me, as every song is good, fun to play, and the just the right ammount of difficulty for me to still find challenging. This is a great one.

Fun book! Great collection of songs. I've been able to do only two of the 8 songs, most of all of "Dueling Banjos" which is REALLY fun, and another easy one "Wildwood Flower." The rest of the collection tho, I would say are very difficult as they are very very fast! But fun none the less!**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty:  9  I found only two songs to be pretty "easy," the rest are quick and fairly complex.

This is a really diverse collection of popular 90's songs. I found most of the backing tracks to be really great, and a few had really stellar guitar parts recorded, noteably "Alive." This would be a good pick for an intermediate/advanced guitar player. The songs are pretty difficult to pin down for a beginner. Thought the tab/sound for "Santeria" and "Been Caught Stealing" sounded odd/off, like an odd added note was thrown in there throwing off the whole familiar vibe. Otherwise all good!!**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty:  8  Most of the songs are technically difficult for a moderate guitar player.

Being as I'm super into playing blues, I'm always on the lookout for books/dvds to make me better and expand my musical horizons. The three star rating is in no way a knock on Dave Martone's playing ability. If you don't know who he is, wow, he is pretty amazing at guitar to say the least! There are a ton of instruction materials out there, and I've bought enough to realize about 50% are worthless, 30% are misguided jumbled messes, and the other 20% are actually helpful. This one is somewhere around the 30% misguided mess. The book has several lick examples. The DVD is high quality, Dave is well spoken and knowledable, however, the course just seemed like it wasn't following any sort of plan and I kept wondering where it was going. I felt the video was mostly a showcase of Dave going, "Ok watch this!" and then ripping thru some crazy lick example at lightning speed then saying "ok now you try." The book is pretty useless unless you're following along simultaniously with the DVD. The lick examples are pretty boring to play. Three stars for the excellent quality video, and the couple of pointers I learned. Not sure who exactly this is aimed at, definitely NOT for beginners or intermediate guitar players.

This is another excellent selection of "rockin' country" songs and backing tracks from Hal Leonard. I bought it to learn "Guitars Cadillacs" by Dwight Yoakam, and that is a FUN one and overall rather "easy" to pin down for a moderately good guitarist. I also found "Drivin' My Life Away" to be fun too and it gave me a chance to play my acoustic. Most of the songs on this one are fun to play. Worth checking out!**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty:  6.5  Not too bad! Fun!

This is another quality fun Play Along book and CD from Hal Leonard. Some really fun songs on this one, most of them have a "rockin" vibe to them. My favorite and the main reason I bought it was Robert Cray's "Phone Booth." Awesome song!!! So FUN to play to! I play mainly blues, and use these Play Along books for the backing tracks. I learn the first couple measures and then improvise over the backing tracks. This is a good one for those who like fast paced "rockin' blues."  And bonus for having a Susan Tedeschi track on here!**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 7.5  Moderately difficult. Fun!

I have about 30 of these guitar play along books, and I play mostly blues. I have almost all the blues related ones, and there isn't a bad one in the bunch. This one is no exception. I've noticed the "slower" sounding the beat of blues songs, the faster the guitar part is. That is true for this case. Some pretty quick guitar going on here. I mostly use the backing tracks to improvise. What I normally do is learn the first few measures, the melody, and then just improvise the rest which is fun for me hence me buying a bunch of these books!:-)**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 8.5  Note for note, about 70% of the songs are "difficult" for an average guitarist.

I have about 30 of these play along books, and I generally play blues. This Gary Moore book is FUN to jam along with. Gary Moore was a super talented guy, and played a variety of genres. This book has a little of his blues and a little of his rock side. The songs are pretty technical, but what I usually do is learn the melody to the songs and practice improvising to the rest. If you like to play blues AND rock, this is a great pick! Excellent backing tracks as well as recorded guitar parts. Probably my favorite part about this particular Play Along book is, almost all the songs on here, the main riff or intros are fairly easy to master, leaving me open to improvise the rest of the song while keeping the "feel" of the song intact to the original.**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 9 Most songs are pretty technical at some parts. However, fairly "Easy" to learn the melody/intros and go from there improvising.

I have a ton of these guitar play along books, and they all very with difficulty. This one seems to be right about good for a beginner, as most of the songs are technically fairly easy to catch on to and have the bonus of being an actual song you can play to your friends. And who doesn't like Steve Miller?! Excellent backing tracks and tab! Suggested for the beginner! Fun!**I started a rating system based solely on how technically difficult the songs are to play fully and exactly as transcribed; 10 being extremely difficult. I buy these play along books not usually so much to play exactly along note for note, but if that's what you do then the rating is based on those who would do that: note for note, no improvising.Difficulty: 5 Most songs are fairly easy for a moderate guitar player.

I bought this DVD as a supplement to my other guitar lessons I'm doing. I have a few of Troy's books, and really like them and find them pretty concise and helpful, although they are really challenging. This isn't really an instructional video per say, or just an interview video, it's somewhere in between. Basically what this dvd is, is it is like you get to sit down and talk to Troy about his philosophy and how he approaches playing guitar, what techniques he uses and likes and recommends, and some of his favorite  exercises for speed and control. It's filmed interview style and its him talking directly to you. Some "instructional" videos I have are basically some meathead showing off for 55 minutes and then telling you, "so, like, now do that." Well, this isn't quite as bad, as Troy RIPS through plenty of examples without very much set up, but the thing I like about this video is, yeah, he's ripping through them, BUT, he's explaining WHY he's doing it and his logic behind it. So, even though I am an "intermediate" guitar player, the few tips I picked up, the knowledge about kinda how and why to do a few things, made this video worth purchasing. I really appreciate an INSTRUCTION video that actually has someone smarter than me on it, who is actually TEACHING me something or inspiring me in some way to figure something out on my own. That's where this video shines. Troy really comes off as being sincere and wants me to learn something from him. He's very well spoken and a natural teacher. His style is loose and candid. The setting and camera work are top notch. This isn't one of those gimmicky cash grab "Learn everything about playing in a band as lead guitar in an Hour" dvd's where you're just copying what some horrible host is showing you and talking to you as you're a dork and he's the cool kid. Most of the video was way over my head, as there is a LOT of assuming you have some knowledge of music theory, but the way it's presented didn't make me irritated, it only made me want to learn more so what was presented could really connect with me.  It comes with a TAB lesson book, which has all the examples he plays, so you can practice them on your own.I would say, if you're hungry for all types of guitar instruction, this video is a great insight to a really super talented guitarist! It's basically like sitting down with Troy for a couple hours and him trying to convey to you his 30 years of experience and ideas. There's a ton of knowledge here, you just have to be able to properly receive it, or be prepared and ready to do some work to make those ideas "click" for you.**UPDATE:OCT.2014***** Well as I've progressed at guitar and my knowledge of music theory, I went back and rewatched some of the tips. It was cool because now I can better grasp some of the concepts and was able to pick up some valuable tips! I would say to any and every new guitarist, don't blame the material at first if you don't understand it yet, just be patient and keep studying and soon things will just make sense to you. Good luck! Great video!!!!!!! Also, fun to watch some of the shredders on this video. MAB was my favorite. Sweet guitar too!**UPDATE: NOV.2014**** I watched this video AGAIN the other night. I pretty much learn something new each time I watch it. The more you learn, the more you are able to learn. This DVD is a great resource if you can extract the tips that Troy presents. Also, its fun to watch.

I'm somewhat new to playing guitar, and this is the second amp I've owned. I debated a while on why I should pick this amp compared to some of the other ones on amazon. Ultimately the reason I bought it was all the helpful reviews. Well, here is my positive hopefully helpful review!If you're new to guitar, this amp is a great logical choice. It is plenty loud, and it has hundreds of sound settings for you to find your own sound or a sound you're trying to mimic, such as BB King, which I have found, which is really cool, considering this is more of an "entry" level amp. I'm claiming this is great for beginners and parents of beginners for several reasons: Brand recognition, affordable, VERY well made(solid), loud, and FUN to play with, thus keeping you interested and having fun with your new guitar. It's also fairly compact, looks "cool," portable, and has customizable sounds to play around with via the Fender software. Another reason if you're looking at this as a parent, well, for me (an adult), who plays every single day for hours and hours and can afford much more expensive amps, I really can't justify buying another amp right now. This one meets all my needs, which is great because it just happened to be so affordable! So, unless your kid is the next John Mayer, this amp should meet the needs of most kids and teens through their entire time playing. And if they stop playing after a couple months, you can easily sell this amp and get some of the modest ammount you paid full for it.If you're an adult like me, and are somewhat new to guitar, this amp is really a bargain, and you can get a TON of sounds, it's plenty loud, and you can always upgrade if you need more loud, as the other Fender amps pretty much have the same exact settings and sound fields as this one, they're just louder and have a couple more options.So far, I feel I really scored with this amp!

Hi, I am 34 year old regular guy intermediate guitar player. I'm definitely not a guitar snob. Funny how almost every "low priced" guitar on Amazon have "reviews" by those super cool guys who already "own" Gibsons and Fenders and Martins, but for some reason buy these "cheap" guitars and then trash them on a review. Anyway, I actually took a chance and bought this guitar used from Amazon warehouse deals as "like new." I'll share that experience as well, in case you're wondering about how that works too and hopefully you can find a good as deal as I did! Well, the guitar came in a plain outer box, and inside was the Epiphone guitar box. The guitar had all the plastic on it and was wrapped still perfectly inside and looked to be unused. There were also stickers on the pickups and a sticker on the guitar itself. It had the user manual and even came with a bumper sticker too! It was NOT stamped "USED" on the backside of the neck. I'm assuming it was unused. I'm not exactly how that works with Epiphones lifetime warranty, as they generally only warranty items bought new. There was only ONE pretty "major" "flaw" with it, and that was one of the pickups as way loose and rattling around. I tried screwing it back down but it seems that whatever it screws into is stripped out. This to me was NOT a big deal as I will find time to fix it myself.  For the amount I saved buying it "used," I cut my losses. It still works just fine, and actually doesn't present that much of a sound issue or anything. Able to play just fine.There were quite a few reasons why I picked this guitar, mainly for me, I really loved the trapezoid inlays. They are mother of pearl and look great. The color, Wine Red with the Flame Top, is so amazing looking! It has just a great color scheme with the white pick guard, the muddy orange knobs, and the chrome hardware. A stunning guitar!!! Aesthetics alone, this guitar is magnificent!!!!!!!!One really awesome thing you can't see from the picture, the "Epiphone" logo on the headstock is also mother of pearl!!! Which adds just an extra touch of class to an already beautiful guitar.To me, this guitar seems built like a tank. It's quite a bit heavier than my other guitars, but it doesn't seem "heavy." It's balanced perfectly. The tuners hold their tune just fine. I can see like others have stated about the push/pull coil tapping knobs being somewhat difficult to push/pull. To me it's not an issue as I don't switch around mid song or anything. This guitar is my best sounding guitar, and I can produce quite a few different sounds with the coil tapping feature and the tone control. I actually got a BB King play along dvd to play with, and I can replicate a LOT of his sounds and tones using this specific guitar combined with a Fender Mustang1v.2 amp.($129) I reach for this guitar the most now, as for me, it just seems like I can honestly get the sounds I want and maybe it's just in my head I don't know, but it feels like I can just grab those notes and chords easier. Everything about this guitar I love. Looks, sounds, build quality. Everything. There is absolutely nothing wrong with buying an Epiphone product.I was also on the fence and wondered about what the difference was between this $499 model and the $399 LP Standard model and why the price difference. Well, I went on Epiphones website to find out.-This, the PlusTop PRO has the coil tapping controls-PlusTop PRO has Probucker pickups, Standard has Alnico Classic Humbuckers-PlusTop PRO has the flame topI believe everything else is exactly the same, and you can get more color options with the PRO model. So the extra hundred bucks may or not be worth it to you.Is this guitar worth $500? To me, yes, Definitely! If you're lucky enough to be able to get one, you should! And even better, if you can pick one up on Amazon Warehouse deals "used-like new," for a considerable discount, I highly suggest you do! If you buy it from Amazon Warehouse, you can return it, free, if it's not up to your standards. Hope this encourages you if you're on the fence like I was before dropping five bills on a guitar! :-)**Update Sept.2015***I still use this guitar qutie often. I play it about 50% of the time between my Fender Stratocaster. What I like about this particular guitar is that I can always count on it to get a very distinct  sound that works well for what I play, which is mainly Blues. It's hard to decribe a sound, but I'll say "rich, warm, complex, slightly 'dirty',low, authoritative."  I use it for real slow blues, Peter Green type sound.I can definitely tell the weight difference after using this one for the day! It is quite a bit heavier. But, sounds great still!Also, I never did get around to fixing that loose pickup. It NEVER makes a difference in sound  and I've been quite lazy about fixing it. :-)

I got this as sort of supplement to my Learn & Master Guitar dvds I own. I was looking for a way to practice actual songs and have some fun playing guitar rather than just drills and chords. The song selection on this dvd is pretty good. There are a few I haven't even heard before. I would say this dvd is "aimed" at a more advanced player, as there is NO slow speed or hand holding. There are however introductions to each of the songs explaining the music theory part of it and which scale boxes the notes are in. The song you pick out has 3 ways to view, pick hand close up, players view with TAB, and front view with TAB. The first song I started out with was "Thrill is Gone." It took me about an hour at JUST the intro part rewinding and rewinding and rewinding several dozen times to get it, but it was fun as I was actually playing something recognizable. The other song I am working on is "Gamblers Blues." I broke out a pencil and paper and actually wrote out the TAB as watching on the tv it goes by way faster then I can coordinate and play and decide which notes to pick. Very well produced program and the camera angles are clear and the sound quality is fantastic.Basically, if you REALLY want to learn, you can. One of my favorite features is you can turn the guitar part "off" during playback and then YOU are the guitar lead! Its GREAT for improvising and plugging in notes you figure out sound good by yourself. That was an added bonus for me, the "discovering" how certain notes sound really well together and jamming with the backbeat. This was also a great way for me to work on my skills on the entire neck of the guitar, not just open position. The backing tracks are studio good, NOT karaoke bad. All in all, being a intermediate guitar player, this can be a fun supplement to your progression. The teacher even plays a Gibson BB King guitar, adding to the authentic sound.  I'll most likely order more of these dvds. The only one thing I think could wish for, would be for the notes to light up like lyrics do in karaoke so you could see and hear exactly what and when to play it if you're stuck on something. Other than that, a great tool!Pretty much like with any new skill, you get out what you put in. I'd say give it a shot if you're wanting to branch out and learn some very recognizable songs!

I bought this set thinking that it would enhance and add variety to my already rigorous guitar practicing of the very very EXCELLENT "Learn and Master Guitar" course. I have tons of praise for that course and the instructor, Steve Krenz, who also teaches this course. It teaches you in a logical, methodical way so you so can really grasp what you're learning as you progress. Right now I am on Lesson 8, barre chords on the 5th string which is really frustrating so I needed a break and put this in. Well! This course is almost ENTIRELY different than the regular L&M course, in that he just jumps right in to things and kinda leaves you to figure some things out on your own time. There's no hand holding in this course, which there is gently in the regular course to lead you into the waters of playing guitar. I even went to the next lesson to see if maybe I was just being grouchy, but it was the same.That being said, if you already have a pretty good grasp of guitar and all the chord forms and are able to find and execute chords, notes and barres pretty rapidly, I would think this dvd set is great. Great production value, excellent online resources, and a great instructor. However, if you're like me, a "beginner," then this may be a little too fast paced and frustrating.I'm thinking after a few more L&M lessons, I should be ready for this set.*****UPDATE:Oct.2014:Well, I've progressed to the "Blues" lesson on the Original L&M Course so I thought I'd give this another shot. I found it really irritating and frustrating. The concepts in Lesson 1 are basic, simple concepts. The I,IV,V chords, and then it's off to going into soloing using notes from chords and then into a Call and Response section. This would be fine if there was on screen TAB and or it was CLEAR on the screen what notes exactly he is playing. I would say if you're thinking about buying this as a stand alone to learn the blues, I would not recommend it unless you already have a really through understanding of music theory, know all 5 pentatonic scale forms, and already have a pretty good understanding of guitar and the fretboard. I wouldn't really recommend this for an absolute beginner, which is sad because the regular L&M guitar course is amazing. I would say if you're a beginner, go with the regular L&M course, as it offers FAR better instruction and covers a wide variety of genres, including blues! :-)***UPDATE:Nov.2014*** I skipped ahead and watched disc two and disc three. I'm so frustrated with this set!! It seems so jumbled and misguided. Its hard to follow. I'm not sure exactly who this set is aimed at. I'm a fairly advanced beginner, and the concepts in the dvd to me are all over the place with skill levels. Steve will display a complex chord progression or advanced figering and demonstrate at a fast pace, then in the next scene it will be a lesson about "This is the key of A on the sixth string." Then he'll slowly walk you thru the names of the notes on the sixth string. I'm thinking if someone could easily play the previous example, surely they would already know the names of the notes on the sixth string! I just am not getting as much out of this as I was hoping, considering the COLOSSAL help I gained with the original L&M course. Maybe the fact that it's titled "Learn and Master Blues" is what's bothering me. I'm not really learning or mastering. Not worth $90****UPDATE: DEC.2014***** Well, I've been doing a ton of music studying and decided to give this set another shot. I rewatched discs one thru three, lessons and workshops. Now that I have a better understanding of music theory, the course is a little more accessable. There are still some things I just don't understand why Steve is presenting and I'm not getting the logic behind them, such as "while you're doing an E7 chord, your pinky is free to hit these other notes." I understand the concept, but not the logic. I wouldn't know how to apply this example. And watching it again, disc one where he's demonstrating the basics, he DOES do some convoluted example with a hammer on and some other flair added in. This totally confused me the first several times I've watched it, as he just says "this is an E7" and then does this weird example and never really explains it. I'm going to leave my rating at 3 stars, as you CAN learn some things, but it's definitely not up to par with the original L&M course.***********OCT 2015*************I know a LOT more now than I did before so I decided to give this another shot, starting with Disc 3. Well, disc three actually turned out to be fine and I learned some things. BUT, this is after two years of constant studying and playing. I still have no idea who exactly this set is aimed at. So after the sucess of disc three I put on disc 4. Disc 4 is an absolute Sh**t show! I have no idea what is going on or the thought process involved in this. It is SO disjointed and unorginized. It's as if it was made on a weekend and rushed out after the sucess of the regular L&M course. I'd advise skipping this set. Lowered one star to two stars total, as lessons are jumbled, follow no real recognizeable plan, and just irritating in their sloppiness.Random Fun Fact: The Nashville session muscian drummer Steve uses in this video is now the drummer for Lady Antebellum.

Lets start with a light rant and a little about me. Skip to paragraph three for guitar review.I'm fairly new to playing guitar, 34 years old, and I am finding myself really interested in all things guitar now. Needless to say, I read a LOT of reviews on Amazon and other guitar sites. I find that the majority of reviews for these "low end" guitars are unhelpful, i.e. ("not as good as my '54 Fender Made in USA Strat") arrogant, ("decent for for a cheap guitar") or just plain dumb, ("changed strings and now it sounds like a $2500 Fender.") Well, me, being a smart person and also now a real passionate about guitar person, I get books and read things and take those reviews with a grain of salt. I read a "review" about a Squire guitar on Fender's site today; the guy touted himself as a "Semi Professional." and then went on to say he had this Squire guitar for "two or three years" and then mentions not ever once changing the strings.!? I doubt most "semi professionals" play a $179 guitar and don't change their strings regularly. Likely story...So rather than trust these people who throw out a lot of common words that sound fancy and mysterious to the beginning guitarist, i.e. "truss rod," "intonation," "proper set up," (which could mean anything) I tought myself about guitars; how they're made, what to look for, what produces what type of sound, importance of wood type, history of guitars, the makers, brands, types, body styles, all sorts of stuff. So MOST of the reviews I read about guitars make me really irritated. If you're looking at this guitar and you already own a real life Gibson Les Paul (not an Epiphone) or a real Fender Strat (not a Squier) and you write a review about how this $179 is a piece of "crap," well, I compare that to those snooty wine snobs who think they can detect the difference between a $90 bottle of wine and a $14 bottle of wine. People buy what they can afford or what is the best value. This guitar is a great VALUE.Guitar review:I got the Lake Placid Blue, and it is very very beautiful. The prettiest, most "Play me!!" guitar in my small, humble collection. The chrome hardware and white pickguard just set it off!  The body is made from Alder wood and the neck is made from Maple wood.(This is important; remember this as I'll be discussing it later) It has a polyurathane finish. The pickups are "Vintage-Style Single-Coil Tele."  It has a 3-Position Blade switch. Position 1= Bridge Pickup, Position 2.=Bridge and Neck Pickups, Position 3.=Neck Pickup. It has two control knobs, one for tone and one for volume. It comes with Fender 9-42 strings. It was easy for me to change strings too. It has a slightly smaller headstock as is customary on a Telecaster. The tuners I've not ever had a problem with. The knobs all work perfectly, no scratchyness to them. I find it balanced well, not too heavy or light. Just right. The sound I like very much, as it's distinctivley different than my Fender Squier Delux Strat "Hot Rails" guitar. I have a Mustang 1v.2 amp. I think a lot of people are confused about guitars and amps and give guitars a lot more credit for sound then the amp. I find amps are really what makes guitars sound good or bad or different. But, yes, this does have differnt pickups then my other guitar so it sounds different. I suppose it has that "twang" that people talk about from a Telecaster. To me, I find this Telecaster the most "easiest" and fun to play. I don't know about it being "fast" on the neck or the radius or whatever mumbo jumbo some dork wannabe talks about to sound like he's in band. All I know is how it feels to me. And I pretty much LOVE this guitar! Proud to have this Fender Squire Tele!If you happen to be looking at those Fender Squire Bullet Strats for $129 like me, I've done a lot of research on Fenders website to compare the difference between that "cheap" model and their one step up $179 "Affinity" models. The only difference that I found is the Bullet is made from Basswood and the Affinity is made from Alder. The headstock is a little bit bigger on the Affinity model, as Fender touts it as "Large 60's Style." Their site also says about the inlays, the Bullet having "White Dot" and the Affinity being just "Dot." Everything else is excatly the same. The pickups are the same. Neck radius same. So the extra $40 may or may not be worth it to you I guess if you're a wood expert.Another reason to buy if you're on the fence; Fender American Standard Telecaster, $1729.99. Specs.ALDER BODY,MAPLE NECK. Same AS THIS $179!!!!! The reason for the $1600 difference? Maybe because the Fender has a "urathane" finish and not a polyurathane finish..??.....just sayin'. The Fender has different pickups as well. Oh, and it has the name "Fender" written on it. So save a thousand bucks and buy this and have fun playing and don't let anyone tell you its a "crappy" guitar. They're dumb. Enjoy!Hope this review helps you save $1500 bucks and you have as much fun playing it as I do!!!Shane

I bought this guitar here on Amazon for $59. It's been $59 for a while, and now I notice it's up over a hundred! I would NOT pay over $89 retail for this guitar. Here's why. First, I'm by no means one of those unhelpful guitar snobs who write reviews for a $400 guitar telling you "its ok for a cheap guitar." Well, to most people, $400 is a lot of money, and if it's just ok, why did you buy it? Must be nice to be so cavalier... On to the review.I purchased this as a guitar to bring up to work with me and since it was only $59, I wouldn't be too hurt if it got ruined in transit or damaged at work. I have other more expensive guitars, (none over $300), and after receiving it, I thought WOW this looks almost identical to my Fender Squier guitar! Very very similar in weight and finish, nobs, etc. I was very happy with it. If you're new to guitar, you've probably read a ton of reviews by guitar snobs who write about how "crappy" a guitar was "until" they did a "proper set up" on it, and the good ol' "fixed the intonation" or "filed the frets," blah blah wow you play guitar, who cares. I didn't do anything to it, nor have I done anything to any of my other guitars, which sound just fine to me. My most expensive one was set up by the shop I bought it at, but my other ones were from Amazon.This Silvertone guitar looks great and is built well. Silvertone has been around for quite awhile and used to make guitars and such for Sears. I did put my own strings on it after a few days, not because the other ones were bad, just I like a certain brand. The only issue I would like to tell you about is that playing it without an amp, it's great, however, when I plugged mine in, it sounded quite a bit different then my other guitars, but in a bad way. "Scratchy" when turning the nobs, just didn't sound as good as my other ones. These issues may very well be fixed if you do in fact know how to "adjust the truss rod" or "lower the nut" or work on guitars. I don't yet, and I don't see spending money to get it set up on a $60 guitar. Mine did come with a cable that you plug into an amp, so that was cool!Another great thing about this guitar; I play for about two and a half hours a night, seven days a week, and I'm just learning chords and I really go at it. Well, this guitar stays in tune VERY well. Tuners are GREAT!I would highly recommend this guitar for beginners, people who need a fairly inexpensive guitar for whatever reason, people who want to modify this guitar, people who know how to work on guitars, or those of you who just need an inexpensive guitar to play "Rocksmith."I wouldn't pay over a hundred bucks for this guitar. I would recommend looking at one of the Fender Squier models for a low budget entry guitar priced over $100.Hope this review helps!

Last year I was lucky enough to see Christina Perri live as she was the opening act for Jason Mraz. I didn't really know who she was at the time, but after seeing her and hearing her, I was a fan! She is GREAT! This album is a fantastic and beautiful album from the talented Christina Perri. Well worth buying, just as good if not better than her first album. Every song on the cd has melody, structure and they all seem to flow together beautifuly. They are all very well written, too, and they each have a story to tell. There's not a bad song on the whole cd! Probably my favorite song so far is "burning gold." The cd has a really pleasant, natural melodic flow to it, and Christiana's beautiful voice always conveys just the emotion she's looking for. All in all, if you liked her first cd, this one is a must have as well! Great!

This guitar set is the PERFECT set up for the beginner. The guitar itself costs $169 on Amazon. This set comes with a small practice amp, cable to attach guitar to amp, nylon guitar strap, a few pics, a guitar tuner, and a gig bag, which by itself sells for $19. The great thing about this is it is specificlly aimed at the beginner, and comes with everything you need to start playing right away, without having to do homework and figure out the accessories you want/need when as a beginner you don't really know and aren't that interested in, you just want to start playing! Well not only is the guitar in this set a really good quality guitar, you get the periphery items that will definitely work for you as you're just starting out, that you will very much most likely upgrade after you figure out what you want. The amp is a really nice amp. It is small and louder than you'd imagine. It has bass and treble settings, a headphone out jack, and an input that you can plug a standard ipod headphone cable into so you can play your ipod out the amp speaker and "jam" along. The cable that attaches to the guitar and to the amp is about ten feet long, one end is right angled. The amp runs off regular US 120V power. The guitar is much more beautiful in person than you can tell from the picture. It is very well made. Mine had a couple of very very small cosmetic blemishes that are hardly noticible. The sound of the guitar  is good as well. It does indeed sound different than my Fender Squire Stratocaster, but not in a bad way at all. It has a "warm" tone to it. It has some heft to it, but is not what I would consider "heavy." Epiphone is owned by Gibson, and the Epiphone line is much like the Squire line of Fender products; a beginner and cost friendly alternitive while having similar apperance to their much much more expensive brethern. The included tuner didn't have instructions, and took me messing with it for quite some time to figure out what it wanted, and is quite finnicky. It includes battery. It works fine. The nylon strap that connects to the guitar that you wear over your shoulder is highly adjustable, and could probably be adjusted down or up to fit a small child or a very large adult. The "gig bag" guitar case has a big pocket that you can use to store a couple song books or whatever. It too has a sling strap you can tote over your shoulder, or you can use its handle. The pics it comes with are just as good as any other pics. Mine was shipped in the box shown with a plain brown box with padding surrounding it, so you can order this as a gift and not worry about it being not wrapped.So why order this set for $30 more than just the guitar? Well, as a beginner you don't really know what you want yet. It's better to start out with decent, cheaper items and go up from there. Here you have a base to build upon. Since purchasing this set, I've upgraded the case to a hard case for travel, bought some new pics, and bought a Snark tuner,(<$15) and bought a nicer, stylish and  more comfortable guitar strap. So for $30, I figured out what works and what doesn't. The amp and cable and guitar are great, and in no way are needing upgrades for the beginner. The bag, guitar strap, and tuner work, and are fine, but I quickly grew out of them. All in all, this is very much worth $199!!!-As a side note for any future players interested in self paced guitar instruction, the set I chose after hours of research and is VERY highly reguarded as being excellent for beginners, is called "Learn and Master Guitar." by Gibson. They have a website and the more complete set which I got is right around $200. They also have it here on Amazon, but I'm not sure if you get all the extra "bonus dics." Anyway, the instruction is terrific and I never thought I'd be able to play guitar!-As far as the included online instruction that is included with this set, I never used it so I can't comment on that.Have a great time learning guitar!! :-)-Shane****-UPDATE-**** July 29, 2014Well, since purchasing this as my first guitar, I've since bought a few other guitars, most recently a Epiphone Les Paul Plustop PRO, $499. Well, build wise, the Plustop PRO is much fancier and stylish, heavier, and just way nicer to look at. Aesthetically terrific. HOWEVER, even tho the Plustop PRO has different pickups, different tone selectors, has a glued on neck, better workmanship, quite honestly the sound of this budget Epiphone LP guitar is really not worth the extra $330. For the looks, yes, but actual SOUND, not too much of a discernible difference. I wish it were a huge difference in sound, but in all reality, not so much. I get a few more sounds from the Plustop due to the coil tapping feature and the slightly better pickups, but, again, not a crazy noticeable difference. I notice after messing around for a bit with the Plustop, I grab this one,(its WAY lighter) and rip on it. Just as easy to play. I contend this Epiphone is still a GREAT buy! Also, if you want a little bit more fancier looking guitar, the next step up from this one is the Epiphone LP-100,($249), which has a some better color options and also has second set of tone and volume knobs, and is a bit beefier physically than this model. The pickups however are EXACTLY the same, so most likely you'll get the same sound as this one. So spending the extra $80 may be worth it to you if you want a bit better looking guitar.***UPDATE FEB.2015*** Well, I've since progressed quite a bit in my playing, and I've acquired many more guitars. This one has now been assigned duty as my primary Slide Guitar, as I use an open tuning on it. So, if you're thinking about buying this and wondering about progressing, you can still find a use for it! Still sounds great, and I think this is one outstanding purchase for a first guitar!*********UPDATE SEPTEMBER 2015***********I recently took a break from playin' the blues and picked up my AC/DC guitar play along book. "Dirty Deeds" looked fairly "easy" to learn the first few measures, so I went about trying to get the sound of Angus Young on my Fender Stratocaster and Mustang III amp. I just could NOT get that thick, whole, bass'y sound I was looking for, no matter how much I messed about with the knobs. This Epiphone Les Paul Special II, my first 'baby',  was sitting right in my closet, and I remembered how nice and full she sounded, so I plugged her in and found a good setting on my amp and bingo, PERFECT MATCH!! This guitar, while kinda plain looking, produces a  really full, thick sound. Great guitar. Still!

I ordered this snow thrower primarily to clear my two car plus RV parking driveway that had around 13'' of snow buildup. The snow has been frozen, thawed, rained on and frozen again. It's about the consistency of pea gravel. A real pain to shovel.  The instruction manual has a guide for the correct cord size they recommend as well as the gauge and length. You can use a 16G cord on this. I bought a 50' 14G outdoor cord for around $35. Its a good idea to make sure your outdoor receptacle is GFCI protected. You can check your service panel, too, as it might be protected there, which you can see if it has a "Push to Test" button on the breaker.I ordered this model after reviewing the SnowJoe and seeing it had a mixed bag of reviews and only a two year warranty and a 18'' clearing base. Snow throwers at Home Depot and Lowes are a LOT more expensive. The gas ones can be up to $1500! This seemed like an economical chance I could take. It is a lot easier than shoveling, that's for sure. It was moderately difficult and took about two or three passes to knock down the hard snow, and quite a bit of heavy pushing to work it through. It was NOT "easy," but the alternative would have taken hours and I would have been miserable. When I got to an area of fresh snow that was only about 4" deep, it was about as easy as pushing a reel mower, very nice. But for the thick frozen snow, it requires a fair amount of work.  I was able to clear my driveway in about 2.5 hours. The wheels don't travel too nicely over bumps, so you'll have to do a fair amount of adjusting as you go.Overall, I am VERY happy with this purchase. Well worth $160. If you're considering this, it's a GREAT investment. But think about it like a lawnmower; if you go out there and do it right after a snowfall, it will be EASY. If you wait until it gets a foot deep and freezes and thaws and freezes again, it will be difficult and take a lot longer, but it will still work. So, like anything, if you're diligent about using it right away, it is an EXCELLENT product. About as loud as a vacuum. Also, once the handle is released to stop, the auger stops instantly. A great safety feature. All in all, works as hard as you do. I'm happy about this purchase. Recommend it to any homeowner that is doing a regular street driveway.UPDATE:2013 Dec.I've used this snowthrower three other times since the first time using it. I used it within 24 hours of some pretty heavy snowfall, total accumilation between 3-4". It is SO much easier to use on fresh snow! Plows right on through it! Nice!! VERY happy with this little guy!UPDATE:2014 Winter:This thing is still doing great! Way easier than shoveling, great price, effective, and doesn't take up a ton of room in the garage. Good choice.

The item was received sealed in a plastic bag, smudged and filthy black all around the outside edges. The elasticized center area that slips over a lens does nothing to support the rest of the diffuser, so if you lean forward, the diffuser falls forward and if you lean back it is propped up by the camera's flash or prism. I'll go back to what I used before, a piece of white card stock with a hole cut out for the lens.

This is a nicely fabricated, very sturdy and well finished riser mount. Assembly is a snap and it is supplied with necessary hardware. The wide stance makes for a very stable platform and the height puts both die and shell holder end of the reloading process in clear view. Extra top plates to accommodate different reloading presses cost only $16.  My Redding T7 press is now on an Ultramount and it is much easier to operate and there is plenty of handle and linkage clearance.

Mechanically, the unit is nicely assembled and packaged. The flash head moves to position, vertical or swivel, and stays put, the wide angle light diffuser and bounce light reflector work cleanly and effectively, the flash works fine from a hot shoe. The snap on diffuser fits poorly and light leaks from the back side. The exposure and time adjustment range is good and these settings are easy to make once the instruction book is decoded.The instruction book is terrible. The front half of the manual is in Chinese, the second half is supposed to be in English, however, whoever wrote this section was only vaguely familiar with the language. The manufacturer might want to invest a few dollars to provide a proper manuals for markets they service. The menu structure is awkward and in no way intuitive. The frequency setting feature used to integrate into an existing command setting is arranged in odd increments and not compatible with other popular systems. The slave sensor does not trigger to other electronic flash units, even with all room lights and modeling lights off and the Neewer unit's sensor pointing directly at another flash.

This style of machete is much easier to use and needs less room to maneuver. The balance and heft are good, which reduces fatigue when clearing paths through brush. It arrived sharp, cut brush and made hacking through small tree limbs easy. It washes off for cleaning and has a purpose shaped handle that doesn't slip even from sweaty hands.

This was purchased as a replacement for a small gas powered trimmer. Battery life is good, but power is not. The effective cutting radius is very small and it did not trim, even at full power, unless tipped at a steep angle that cut into roots. It was returned.
Inexpensive and enough pieces to make this kits highly adaptive in use. For the home shop it is more than sufficient in quality.
A one piece shield rather than a three section adjustable type. The produce material and quality is good, however, it rarely fits any pies correctly.

Good sights; very bright, good contrast with red and green and small enough diameter fiber optic element to permit precise shot placement. The sights are easy to install and adjust with a basic punch or Nylon 66 block and hammer, however, Springfield XD sights are exceptionally difficult to remove without doing damage. I removed the original sights with a sight pusher which simplified the tasl.

Excellent soft leather case. Good construction and good fit. Easy to operated keys through protective plastic and all cutouts for external buttons and camera are correctly located. Unlike most other cases, the clip rotates for comfortable positioning on a belt.

Worked great for six months. Direct drain and filter cleaned weekly, kept basement at 30% humidity over the winter. Progressively less effective in the Spring and currently has no effect on humidity at all.

Either Weatherby has made minor changes to the Mark V action since moving production to California from Minnesota, or Warne has changed their hardware. The last three set we used for scope installations on new Weatherby Magnum rifles did not fit. The rear base hardware was too long by a couple of threads and it contacted the each rifle's bolt.

I needed a small speaker that would be out of the way, produce good sound and not cost very much. The Logitech speaker accomplished those objectives. It has plenty of volume, no noticeable bass distortion and it has held up well in use.

Over time, my weaken eyesight made it impossible to use the camera's adjustment range to get a sharp image in the viewfinder. The correction eyepiece  bumped the range enough to correct for my vision and provide room for future adjustment.

While it would seem the magnets would allow for very flexible placement, they do not. The magnets are week and there are just not enough placement points to precisely direct a beam. The light is very dim when it can be aligned. The battery life is very short. They are fun to play with for a few minutes and then reality sets in.

I had a Microsoft keyboard that would not lay flat and it shed its key cap legends after a couple of months. I picked up this keyboard as a replacement and it is terrific. It has some weight so it lays flat and stays put, same when using the elevating feet. The wireless response is instantaneous and the keyboard is USB rechargeable.The key caps are double shot so the legends are molded all the way through and won't wear off. They are also back lit so they are always clearly visible. The keyboard senses ambient light levels and adjusts accordingly. The key resistance is perfect, not to hard or too light for touch typing.  Excellent keyboard.Revised - Went back to order another within three days and the price went from $68, when sold and shipped by Amazon Prime, to $30 more from an Amazon reseller and fulfilled by Amazon. Great keyboard as I reviewed the first time, but not at a 50% higher price. I'm finding that resellers listed as Prime do not honor in spirit the free shipping benefit that comes with Prime membership. They just grossly pad their selling prices and negate the benefit.

Normally when I pay $5 for a book and it is substandard in quality, I toss it on a pile or toss it out. This time, the product is so bad I am returning it because I feel I am being scammed. The printing is horrible, the black & white "photographs" are generations old and reprinted to the extent you can't tell what they are. The line drawings are so rough in detail they are useless and none of the specific information takes into consideration that major revisions to this firearm. Pile of public domain junk repackaged and sold. There are many credible sources of the same information that are free.

This is almost a terrific product. The USB cable is long, the probe reach is long, the image quality is actually very good. I had no software problems with Windows 7 32 or 64 bit compatibility and it is easy to use as long as the borescope is plugged into a USB port before the software is opened.The three angle mirrors do not fit the end threads of the camera so they only slip on and easily fall off and I was not able to find anyway to contact the seller other than public feedback. Wish they made a 5mm version.Update - After attempting to work with the product and being unsuccessfully in resolving the incorrect mirrors, I decided the product wasn't worth the price and it was returned. Bit being able to have an angle view minimized the usefulness of the tool.

I shoot subjects with lenses that emphasis perspective issues. After working with perspective correcting features of popular photo editing software, Viewpoint makes it easy. Most of the time the fix is as simple as dragging a single control point into parallel with other elements of the photo. I can also change aspect ratio, rotate point view, crop and alter horizon with the same simple control.Even after modification, sharpness is not lost, nor does distortion appear in other areas of an image. Good product.

It took a while for me to get my brain unplugged from Photoshop type photo editing to understand that his product brings back all of the capabilities of the dark room with software tools with control over paper type, grain of film, easel angle correction of perspective and distortion, color tone, color temperature, cropping. This on top of DxO's lens aberration auto correction for specific camera body sensor and lens combination.I use the product with FX and DX format Nikon bodies and a large variety of Nikkor lenses. The software recognizes all and adjusts accordingly. If the software detects a combination that is new, it will prompt for approval and then download the news configuration module.Excellent tech support. Responsive and thorough from people who know their product inside and out.

Inexpensive, sharp focusing and good contrast make this a useful DX lens. The only problem I've had is with the incredibly short dept of field any time the lens is not parallel to the subject. Working within that limitation, the lens is actually a very good performer even in comparison to Nikkor lenses 5 to 8 times the cost.

Horrible reproduction of a monumental book. The print in the book is so bad it looks like 3rd or 4th generation photo copy and the black and white picture are mostly not even discernible. Unbelievable. It appears as though the machine was running dry when this book was being printed.

A nice, cast light duty vise that works well with the locator bar on the Proxxon drill for xy location control. Some of the condemnation reviews on this page are almost comedic. It is a $22 small vise with dual parallel guide bars and plated hardware. No, it is not comparable to a $400 precision machinist vise, but it is does precisely hold material within the capabilities of the Proxxon drill. I must have received a special model because it closes square, a jaw does not ride upward when closed and it does not loosen in use. I do have a heavier, steel, small drill press vise, a  Wilton 11681 1-3/4-Inch Drill Press Vise. It cost $72 and it offers more mass, not greater precision than the Proxxon Vise.

We operate a commercial shop. We often drill small diameter holes in various types of steel and aluminum that accept close fit solid and roll pins to hold stressed assemblies together. Rather than tie up a large drill press or mill on routine small hole drilling, we purchased the Proxxon for the purpose. In this application it has been excellent. It is quiet, vibration free and with sufficient speed range to handle anything withing the range it is operating. The unit we received was made by Proxxon Luxembourg.When we received the drill, like all new machines received, it had some rust preventive coating that came off with a quick blast of spray solvent. The supplied collets fit properly, the optional German Rohm chuck installed easily and worked properly. Motor speed remains constant with more than enough power when the proper speed range was selected. Used as intended, there were no high temperatures, rattling or belts that did not track and drive properly. We saw no need to invent ways to "test" the drill, we just used it per the instructions and good machine use practices. We were not surprised by how small the drill is as the published specs with the listing indicate it is 14 x 9.3 x 4.8 inches and weighs 8 lbs.We did not initially purchase the optional Proxxon 28132 Machine Vise, we went with a heavier Wilton 11681 1-3/4-Inch Drill Press Vise instead. However, we were so pleased with the drill we went back and ordered the Proxxon vise for use with the sliding guide bar. Very nice little machine offered by its manufacturer, under its manufacture's brand.

I am hooked on these stainless tables. This is the third, all different sizes and configurations. It is being used to hold a small combo bench sander that gets moved around the shop. The cart is sturdy and stable, the basket is sturdy and the ball bearing wheels, if anything are an overkill. The stainless top is smooth and well supported, doesn't scratch easily and wipes clean with little effort. Assembly time was approximately 10 minutes.

I buy and use a lot of bench top tools, most expensive and precision made. The Rikon was purchased because I needed a small 1" belt sander to do some quick rough out work on fabricated parts and I wanted to be able to move it to different locations within the shop, putting it on a shelf while not in use.The Rikon is nicely finished for a unit of this price. Yes, the belt platen was off 1/4" to the left, but took ten minutes to correct. The belt is not centered to the platen, it is centered to the rollars, which should align it with the platen. The opening in the belt sanding table is a little rough, but both tables align correctly and provide good support. There is plenty of power for the size of material appropriate for this size sander. The belt tracked correctly as received, however, I did try adjustment and it drifted right and left just fine and stayed where set.I do have another more robust 1" belt bench sander that has much heavier cast iron tables with lots of adjustment options. It has all steel enclosures, the same horse power rating and a power take off for a flex shaft. A JET J-4002 1-Inch by 42-Inch Bench Belt and Disc Sander which sells for over $400.

Tried this for three days to raise humidity in a dry, winter heated room. With a hygrometer in place to measure, the humidifier could not elevate humidity by even one percent. It did, however, make a damp spot on the carpet immediately around the table it was placed on.  Varying water vapor dispersal rate made no difference.

As a person with a good deal of experience with the film types they claim to emulate, they are not even close. The muted Agfa films are over saturated and way too contrasting. Bright, colorful Fuji is reduced to some low contrast, orange or green cast images. The color and saturation isn't true for film or slide types and black and white grain looks like someone push processed ISO 6400 surveillance film rather than the listed Tri-X Pan or Ilford films.Sorry I bought it.

The diameter is as large as the original slinky, but not the length. It does not have enough mass to store enough energy to make a trip down a flight of stairs. Unless you want to spend time shuffling this thing from one hand to another, and frustrating children with its inability to do much of anything, not a good pick.

Best of the inflatables we had this season. Stayed fully inflated and upright. Hand waved as designed. Tie downs are properly located and it ran even on the coldest -20F degree days. The grand-kids really liked it.

Had this guy up for weeks. Remained fully inflated and was well lit. Had to play with locating ties downs as they are located only at the sides, but other than that, it worked fine. No problems running down to -20F degrees.

This "racing" game involves manipulating the character's movements by simultaneously tilting your device to control side to side motion while swiping up, down, or to the side to control other functions, such as jumping, in order to collect strings of objects scattered throughout the racetrack.There is no tutorial or slow-paced introduction to acquaint the user with how to play the game.  Occasionally, a "tip" pops up, such as "don't hit your head!" But these are not helpful.  The entire game, including the math section, is backed by frantic music that makes you feel as if you are racing against death or something.If your character hits a wall or other object, the game is paused while the user is presented with anywhere from three to five math questions in the format of "N - x = N2", for example, "5-___=1".  These are multiple choice questions with three alternatives, and the "test" is timed - anywhere from 10 - 20 seconds (I did not notice any rhyme or reason to the number or type of questions presented and how much time is given).  If you get one wrong, "Game Over" unless you have collected enough of the coins that are scattered through the racetrack, and then you can pay with them to keep going.As far as I can tell, all features of this game (including changing the type of question offered, adding "power ups" such as helmets to your character, or changing the character and setting), cost actual money. You are prompted to pay this actual money after EVERY "GAME OVER" even if you select the "No" button when it asks if you'd like to see how you can get access to the other characters and features (i.e. selecting "no" brings you to a lovely splash screen displaying a different character & setting, where for one click of a button that says $1.99, you can unlock said features).  So even opting OUT of wanting to see how you can unlock the full game does not work.So, essentially, a player is trapped in an infinite loop of running through a short maze, answering a few arithmetic questions, and then being asked for real money.  Even when you try to select only addition or only subtraction (all that was available for free, from what I could tell), you get what you get - which isn't what you requested, but a mix of the two, or one and not the other.What's more, these are essentially first grade math facts, but there is no possible way a six year old could either operate/play this game with any success OR answer these math facts in the time allotted, so any way you look at it you lose.  Even my eight year old, who is okay at apps and better at math, couldn't do anything with this game.  AND she said the music was AWFUL (a sentiment I share).If you are a game developer AND know something about cognitive psychology AND elementary education, then by all means, make an app that is fun to play and helps kids learn. If you are a game developer only, and think that because you passed second grade you can teach second grade, PLEASE just stick to making games and forget the so-called "edutainment" angle.I don't know about the permissions or adware/spyware so perhaps someone else can comment on this aspect, but for my part, this "game" will not just be deleted from the Kindle; it's getting deleted from my CLOUD.Note to parents: don't waste your time or RAM  on this one. I know there are not a lot of math games for elementary age kids, so it's tempting to jump on whatever you can get, but this Math Run is not only NOT helpful, it could even be HARMFUL to a child who already has some anxiety about math, because of its frenetic action and panic-attack-provoking soundtrack.As with any review, these are my own opinions, expressed after playing this with my eight year old for twenty minutes, and your mileage may vary.(Final note:  you are prompted to rate the app after the first few times you play and lose - about a 2-minute cycle for us.  Clicking "remind me later" lets the app know that you want to be asked to rate the app after EVERY time you play and lose, so, if you like being pestered half to death to rate an app you've only used for about 8 minutes, this is the one for you. Personally, I prefer to have a good hour of experience with something before I rate it, but then again, I don't think I could have stood to play this app any longer than I did, so maybe the dev was anticipating that.)

First, please don't be fooled (as I was) by the "8.5-Inch" in the name of this device.  This is probably one of the reasons I give it four starts instead of five.  I believed that I was getting the version of this device that is roughly the size of an 8.5x11 piece of paper, which I had seen in a nationwide consumer electronics store that once-upon-a-time catered to people who liked to build their own radios and electronic devices, back when a ham "wireless" setup was referred to as a "shack" - I am sure you can guess which place I mean.I saw the larger size version of this device there for the same price I paid for the smaller version from this seller (E&B Electronics, fulfilled through Amazon).  I almost returned it for this reason, but the birthday girl's birthday was too close, so I decided to just buck up and keep it, even though the price was higher than expected for the size being smaller than expected.  (FYI, for those of you who, like me, don't already know, the device is measured diagonally, like a TV, so if you want the larger one, you should look for the 10.5".)Otherwise, the product is nifty.  Its, as others may have said, just a fancy electronic version of that old waxed-board-and-cellophane thing that anyone over the age of forty probably had as a child, where you draw on the cellophane with a little stylus, which makes the cellophane stick to the waxed board, making darker lines where you have drawn, and to erase you lift the cellophane up, peeling the two layers apart.  Well, this is like that.  That's all.  Except you press a button to "reset" the image.There is no computer connection (although they DO make one that can hook up to the computer and transfer your valuable notes and sketches, for about four or five times the cost.)But for kids - why bother?  Did we complain back in the day that we couldn't "save" our drawings on the wax-board-and-cellophane-thingy?  No.  We just played tic-tac-toe and drew silly pictures and were amused on long car rides.  And the 8-year-old girl for whom this was purchased was THRILLED.  She has been using it to draw, write us notes, compose odes to her stuffed animals (never done this before!), and we can play dots, hangman, etc, in restaurants now without me having to drag my Kindle everywhere I go (hee hee!).The only way this device could have been better as far as my 8-year-old is concerned is if it somehow could convert into a stuffed animal, ha ha!  Highly recommend, but be forewarned about the size, triple check the price**, and understand that what you are getting is just a high tech version of that old waxboard-cellophane thing; if you consider all this, I doubt you'll be disappointed.**Amazon, I am appalled at how ridiculously you have jacked up your prices on many popular items this holiday season - things I've seen at local chain stores for $20 have been listed on Amazon, sold and shipped BY Amazon, for more than twice that! - way to treat your loyal year-round customers, guys.  When most stores are having SALES for the holidays, AMAZON DOES THE OPPOSITE!!

I bought this case not only because it seemed to get overall great reviews but also because I liked the name, since my daughter's nickname is Roo (I know, silly reason to buy something). But the price was right, and it looked like a great solution, with the different ways you could fold it and the magnetic on/off cover.Well, it was the perfect case for a couple of months. I would have given it four stars (minus one for just not being QUITE hard enough to really protect the device from a fall, but if you want that kind of protection, get an Otterbox is what I say).  It folded nearly and was useful for propping the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 at a couple of different angles for sticking movies, playing games, or reading.The problems came after a few months, when the case just became  too floppy to hold the device up. Further, the "spine" of the Roo Case for so soft and floppy that it didn't stay CLOSED and now it constantly slips open when the device is in a bag or something, turning on the Kindle and draining the batteries.So, long story short, great case for short term use (mine lasted about six months in unusable condition) until you can save up for something sturdier, but this won't last a full year. The "pleather" that it is constructed from just gets softer and softer, both on the spine and in the spaces between the firm panels in the front cover (these spaces are sort of like the "dotted lines" that are where you fold the case into its few positions).  Well, once the material that connects the stiff panels gets so soft, it obviously will not hold the weight of the device anymore, stiff panels or no.  This is particularly problematic where any two folds in the "origami-style" cover intersect, and the area of fabric is larger/wider.  Of course, these intersections are where you need the case to be the STRONGEST, not the floppiest, hence, collapse.  Same with the spine, which causes the cover to slip off in about ten student ways and get crinkled up in the purse or backpack in its own special version of "origami", leaving the device on and the screen exposed to damage from keys or whatever else is in the bag.I was surprised, given all the rave reviews, but then, I LOVED mine at first too.  Bottom line:  I would NOT recommend this to a friend (or an enemy even, if I had one) unless they made some serious design changes.  I give two stars simply because it DID work well for a few months, and deserves something for that.

Wow. What a captivating story, told in a unique and beautiful voice!  This book is written in the style of a first-person narrative from a (now grown, and one presumes, old) young girl raised by "Tasmanian tigers", long-extinct marsupial dog-like creatures, after being accidentally separated from her parents in the wilderness of Australia.  (Just FYI, Wikipedia has an absolutely essential companion-article on the "Tasmanian tiger" that will break the heart of any animal lover or environmentalist who hasn't yet heard the story of this poor misunderstood creature.)I read INTO THAT FOREST non-stop.  I just couldn't put it down!  Even now I am hard pressed to believe that this book is NOT actually a true story - so convincingly and skillfully written was it.  The story managed to be savage and beautiful and sad and joyful and very richly textured, all while being told in the voice of someone with supposedly limited English language skills; the "under-educated" dialect takes a few pages to get used to, but it is a big part of what makes the story so REAL.  This kind of writing is not easy to do, but the author pulls it off with tremendous skill.I am very fussy about what I read, and I typically won't even bother finishing (never mind reviewing) a bad book.  This book deserves a place among the great works of modern literature, however.  I will definitely be trying anything else by this author that I can find.  Highly recommend.

The only reason I felt that I had to dock one star is that there were some overly graphic descriptions that I felt were unnecessary and anxiety-inducing to my tender heart.  I don't KNOW if this excellent story could have been written successfully without those descriptions, but I would like to have seen it tried.(That said, however, I wouldn't anticipate most people immersed in the media of our current age will even really know what I am referring to, so, Potential Reader, please don't let the vagaries of THIS reader's sensitivity deter you from this excellent story.)Again, as in my review of "Containment" (Christian Cantrell's superb and unputdownable -- yes, it's a word; I've used it before--  novel), I will not bore the reader of this review with a summary of the story, other than to say that the ending was unexpectedly elegant.  I don't think that gives anything away, do you, Mr. Cantrell?Thank you for another excellent read. Keep writing them and I will keep buying them.  Better yet, publish them in an omnibus collection and I will just buy the whole batch at once!  :-)

SummaryGame is cute and original. Object is to "fix" broken robots that come in after accidents (a still shot silhouette of an "accident" about to happen is shown - no graphic details of friendly robots getting mashed and mangled).  A variety of tools (hammer, pliers, etc) are provided and when selected, an arrow points to the robot "patient" wherever you are supposed to apply the tool. Even includes a roll of paper towels for viewing the robot's "nose".  A clickable checklist shows you how many of the repair tasks you've completed and what's left to go.ConsMusic is TERRIBLY ANNOYING.  Sound effects (mainly what the robots say as you work on them) are even more annoying:  "ELECTRIC!", "what's that, Doc?", "hi, doc!", "OUCH! OW!", "that's much better" and maybe two others.  They say these things over and over again, every robot says the same things in almost the same voice (although pitched differently for the "girl" (I.e. PINK) robot.= Minus one star for annoying sound track.Gender stereotyping promoted:  "girl" robot is pink, and for some reason she is the only one that giggles and acts ticklish.= Minus one star for perpetuating gender stereotypes.Game is very repetitive and provides no real learning or portion item solving opportunities.  Every robot has the exact same "injuries" in the same places.
