I never did but it made me self-conscious since it didn't close securely.- more and better zippers; back pockets are just small little velcro patches (like right cargo pocket) so they're really unusable - you can't trust them - especially in crowds - too easy to pickpocket.Update:OK, I'm changing my review to 5-stars. Despite the room for improvement, at this price I have to call these as 5-stars. I hope they make the improvements and just up the price a few bucks. I would buy these again in a second and highly recommend.

I know they're just inexpensive t-shirts but I want them to fit. And, these fit me perfectly. Love them. I'm going to buy more and keep them in the back of my closet in fact. I've noticed over the past few years that Hanes and FOTL keep making small changes to these lines and so I have to re-evaluate my choice every couple of years. Last time it was Hanes Perfect-T but now the v-necks of those are way too tight and the cotton was scratchy - which is mindblowing since Target could hardly keep them in stock, they were so popular these past few years. I don't get it. Anyway, these, for the moment are my go to t-shirts. The large fits well (I'm 5'10"/170) but I like things a little baggy so went with the x-large.They are not super long in the torso but depending on preference, you may have to cut them and live with the 'roll up' effect - personal choice.I bought a 4-pack of these for a two week vacation in Southeast Asia and they were perfection - exactly what I was looking for.

I know they're just inexpensive t-shirts but I want them to fit. And, these fit me perfectly. Love them. I'm going to buy more and keep them in the back of my closet in fact. I've noticed over the past few years that Hanes and FOTL keep making small changes to these lines and so I have to re-evaluate my choice every couple of years. Last time it was Hanes Perfect-T but now the v-necks of those are way too tight and the cotton was scratchy - which is mindblowing since Target could hardly keep them in stock, they were so popular these past few years. I don't get it. Anyway, these, for the moment are my go to t-shirts. The large fits well (I'm 5'10"/170) but I like things a little baggy so went with the x-large.They are not super long in the torso but depending on preference, you may have to cut them and live with the 'roll up' effect - personal choice.I bought a 4-pack of these for a two week vacation in Southeast Asia and they were perfection - exactly what I was looking for.

Excellent insect repellent - nice little travel friendly container for flying where malaria may be an issue. Look up Picaridin - it seems to be just as effective as Deet but without the nasty chemicals, smell or clothing issues. I'm a new fan and would buy again. I learned about this product researching travel in Asia - a lot of people recommended picaridin as an alternative. 15-20% was the minimum - I think that's what the CDC recommended for Deet comparable effectiveness.

I bought a few pairs of convertible pants to compare before a big trip. These were the best - no question. If you want convertible pants, get these - you will not be disappointed. The sizing was perfect - except for the length - see below:Pros:- Thicker, higher quality material- Better Quality design and workmanship - really excellent- Zippers, pockets everything very cleverly done; quality all aroundCons:- Tailors said the side zipper at the bottom made them very difficult to hem/shorten - insert sad face here.I absolutely loved these but i wasn't going to spend $50 to have them hemmed at the one tailor who would take the job. I really needed a 29" inseam and 30" was the shortest. And, the trip was coming up quickly.So had to return them - hoping one day they'll have more inseam choices in the future - if so, I'll buy these in heartbeat!!Bought the Colombia Silver Ridge Pants instead - they're fine; were easy and quick to shorten; cheaper. But, I would have preferred these Mountain Khakis - I have many pairs of MK pants and shorts - great products.

I have had the 9250 Nexus phone for a few years now - with a similar extended battery. And, it has worked flawlessly. Lately, I've been wondering if the battery was losing some steam so for $15 I picked up this Onite and yeah I needed a new one. Very happy with it - I noticed the improvement in battery life almost immediately - I'm going almost three days without having to charge it. Nice.Regarding the back cover - I saw a few comments on this. I really like it. It's definitely superior to the last one I received two years ago. It has a nice smooth, silky feel to it. And, mine is extremely difficult to get off. So, I'm definitely not having any issues with it coming off.

I like the fit and feel of the Champion long sleeve Double Dry shirt just a little better. But, it's close, and this Powertrain one definitely has the better look going for it. They're both super comfortable also but the double dry feels like silk and this one is just shy of feeling that way - close and very comfortable but just not silky. They're both winners and I'm glad I bought both - they're like $12 so why not. I highly recommend both. I'm 5'10" and 175lbs - the large double dry is a perfect fit; while the Powertrain hangs just slightly longer in the sleeves and below the waist. Again, very close though - buy both.

I ordered a large and I'm 5'10" 175lbs. Sleeves are perfect. It hangs a little lower than I'd like but close enough. Normally I order larges and they hang way too long. And, I like that it's nice and roomy - definitely won't stick to me and feels really silky so should serve its purpose well as an undershirt for hot humid climates and travel.

I've tried them all and this is by far my favorite of the Nature's Path Oatmeals. And, this is the one I buy nearly every week at the grocery store. I like the portions and the taste is right on. I find some of the other flavors a little lacking in ...um... flavor.

Very pleasantly surprised. I've had a few multi-port USB chargers along the way but none felt as solid or frankly looked as good on my desk. I know the look of this thing is hardly the most important feature but it's nicely solid and feels very well built. And, looks like I bought it from Apple to be honest - looks kind of cool next to my MacBook Air. Well done on the look and feel.Performance wise - no issues here. I plug in my phone, drives, etc and it just works. I like that the light is a pleasant color as well - most have a harsh light you wouldn't want to stare at all day - red/blue etc. I only use this for drives and my phone - no iPhones or iPads (yet) so I can't comment on that just yet.I really like the rubber feet on this so it stays put on my desk.

This is one of those 'so small and light - why wouldn't I always have it with me' kind of devices. Throw it in your bag for emergencies, etc.It's very small, thin and light. I wish it had a little more juice - can't quite fully charge my Nexus (3750mAH I think) but it gets awfully close.I'd say the price is about right. Although I generally prefer more juice in my emergency batteries, every one I own is also much much heavier than this - and that's sometimes a consideration. I mean this thing weighs about as much as my glasses.I did receive this for free in exchange for a review. I like it - I have many backup batteries. It's replacing my always with me emergency backup one - it has less juice but probably weighs 20% of the one it's replacing.

My last cheap HP LaserJet lasted forever - or until last month when I bought this one. This was like $20 more than the cartridge on the old one so how could I resist the upgrade after 8 years. So, for like $100 I have another rock solid laser printer that will likely last another 8 years and it's wireless. I hooked this up to an Apple Time Capsule - and the instructions from HP could have been a little bit more helpful but it didn't take that long and, once configured it's been a champ every since. I'm a fan and wouldn't hesitate to buy HP again. I think this is my third printer in 20 years - HPs just don't quit.

That's what my wife tells me. We have migrated over to a lot of silicone stuff in the kitchen these past few years. Everything is light, durable and easy to clean - and healthier to cook with so I'm told. This stuff is brilliant in my opinion - very clever and easy to use. I'm a little biased because I never cared for all the loud metal clanking sounds of metal stuff knocking together in the kitchen. And, washing metal pans was not my favorite either. These are easy to clean - hurray!

We replaced both parts of our food processor - this top and the bowl. Both pieces were getting a little beat. We've had this thing for over 10 years - it's bomb proof. So, with this purchase and the bowl, the whole thing looks fairly brand new but more importantly it's working like it was brand new. My wife puts some serious mileage on this things - I'm kind of surprised the plastic parts lasted this long.

Our old bowl was getting pretty beat up. The yellowing old plastic and many many cracks, chips etc. It was on its last legs. Ordering a replacement was not high on the priority list so of course we put it off. This arrived quickly and it's just what we were looking for. My wife puts some pretty serious mileage on our food processor and it's fairly old. Good to know we can just replace some parts and carry on. I recommend. These KitchenAid food processors seem to be bomb proof - our must be like 10 years old at least.

This must be my week for movies. I see a lot of ok movies but so rarely something I can say I'll watch again. My wife and I both had the same reaction - wow, that's a great movie and I could see it again. The other great one this week was 'Stuck in Love' - I also highly recommend and we both agreed that it's a winner.I felt like The East had elements of some of the later Bourne Identity movies and at times reminded me of The International as well. All favorites of mine. It had all the right ingredients - great acting, great story and the filming had that hard to describe sort of European thriller grittiness - like you believe this is actually happening and you're peering through a window.Brit Marling was awesome - over the top awesome - I saw her on Bill Maher a few months ago plugging the movie and She and Bill were right - yeah, I really liked this movie. And, no they don't make them like this often enough. Also, this one makes for some great after movie conversation. I like that. Usually the after movie conversation at my house is about how awful a movie was - sadly. I wish I was exaggerating.

This is a very good movie. I see a lot of ok movies these days but they're so rarely entertaining along the lines of Family Stone, Blue Jasmine, etc. I'm not a movie critic so this will be short. Stuck in Love has a little bit of everything but it delivers where it's most crucial - we care about the characters. I wouldn't say this is as good as The Family Stone but I will say it reminded me of it and that's one of my favorites. I highly recommend this movie - the actors across the board just deliver. First movie I've seen in months that I can happily say I'll watch again.

Thick cable - seems really solid and well made. I think for me this is most useful in two ways.1) Although I have a thousand cables like this, they are almost all less than a foot long. This can be very inconvenient while traveling - you know when the only available hotel outlet is in a ridiculously inconvenient location. This happens too often. Well, with a 6-foot cable, it makes it a little easier to charge up my stuff.2) The other handy use is with desktop computers. I no longer have one but this would have been handy when the tower is on the floor or under the desk. This cable would have given me some nice reach to the devices on my desk.Disclaimer: I received this as a gift and was asked to evaluate.

Perfect for travel - I'm amazed that I can charge an iPad, Nook and my Nexus phone simultaneously  - and I have an extra port! This is beautiful for travel. It weighs half of the other device I've been carting around for years and it's a third of the size. Sounds like some folks are experiencing issues with it burning out. So far so good on our end. I'll update this review if it fails. In the meantime, it stays in my travel bag.

No complaints here - except for the noise. We put it in the closet when it's time to mix - takes about 20 minutes or less. This thing make some fine ice cream. My wife is really the one having a blast with this. She's having fun making up new vegan recipes and all kinds of 'healthy ice cream'. And, I'm enjoying the fruits of her labor. We've had a couple of experiments that were a little too 'healthy' tasting so those are not to be repeated. But, we've had mostly home runs with this. And, making traditional ice cream recipes is a breeze - just follow the directions. It's really simple and makes some delicious and custom ice cream. Bacon Chocolate ice cream anyone?

I love these Imagine organic soups. I haven't bought a case just yet but it's tempting because of the great price. But, this is definitely one of my current favorites. A little high in sodium but has a unique miso soup taste to it. And, I'm a big fan of quinoa too. I bet the 'spinach' part puts people off - but it's like a potato stew with a nice miso taste. Give it a try - it's good.

Gotta love Pyrex. These are mixing bowls - and storage for left overs. You can heat them, freeze them or make cereal in them. What's not to love. And, most importantly their glass! My wife only uses glass/pyrex stuff - or silicone - healthier alternative I'm told. And, it's important to do as your told sometimes.

First of all, like another reviewer, I'm not using this for cigars. But, it's very well made and perfect for other things like storing folding glasses or anything small. I've seen a friend use this for small vape pens as well as those e-cig devices that can be a little fragile and susceptible to breaking if bent at all. This carrier keeps anything you have inside very safe and completely protected.Sidenote: it's significantly heavier than I expected. But, it does the job perfectly. That might be the trade off in terms of the stainless steel. But, I'll take rugged and built to last over lighter so I'm pleased. But, take note, you could probably use this as a kubaton which leads me to think TSA will never let this through unfortunately. Just a guess. If anyone has tried flying with this, please let me know.Great protection for whatever you can fit inside this tube. And, since it's stainless, it looks very cool as well.

Honestly, I thought the 78 ounce would be bigger for some reason. It's a little short/squat - so perhaps not what you'll expect either. But, we've owned these before and have never had any issue with them. We have a few around here that we've used for years and they're perfectly dishwasher friendly. I know some struggle with the top. Maybe they just need to google the instructions. I never read any instructions on the process. It seems easy to me. Hold down top and twist? What's the issue. I rarely use the 'air tight seal' but when I need it - it works. And, it's absolutely handy to have.I do wish they could improve the ergonomics of the handle. It's a little small and awkward but again, it works and it's ruggedly made so perhaps that's the trade off.I would buy these again. They're very well made.

The fit and finish on mine was perfect. And, the performance is just what I was looking for. I'll be ordering a few more just to keep around the house. These are very compact and seem rugged. I really like the on/off switch at the opposite end. And, the 'clip' seems well done so I think it will hold up to being attached and reattached for the foreseeable future.At this price, I have to highly recommend this to everyone. I'm impressed.

I tried the Armband built for the Nexus and it was just too tight - probably because of the extra few millimeters of the extended batter. But, I love the extended battery so that's a keeper. This Armband fits my phone perfectly with extra room for quick and easy insert and removal after returning from the gym. Very nice. I'm a happy camper. I also wear these above my calf and they're extremely comfortable. I find that these are annoying on my arms - IMHO.Excellent product.

I'm using this to mount my old Nuvi 550 to my vespa's left side mirror. It's perfection. Rock solid construction across the board. And once it's on, the mount is very easy to adjust to your heart's delight.I couldn't be happier. I will be looking at other products by RAM - maybe a holder for my mobile phone is next. I like stuff that is well made.

For the price this is ok. I bought the 47x35 with the lip and wish I'd bought the bigger one. With the bigger one, the constant moving around or drifting of the mat might have been less irritating. I have to constantly adjust this. And, I have a medium pile carpet for sure - I even measured it.So, I would strongly recommend a bigger one and seriously consider this version for thicker carpet so that the spikes are longer and hopefully there would be less drift. I will likely replace this in a few months because I find the constant adjusting kind of annoying.

Like others have said, the on/off switch seems a little flimsy. But, I like the modern look and generally rugged design. For me, the rotating plug is really useful so I tend to look for that feature. So, this is a surge protector home run. I would and likely will buy another one.

I've had to update this review and downgrade it a few stars. While the product seems top notch - I just couldn't get it to work well for me. I was looking for a Phone/GPS/intercom solution. The music feature didn't work out at all - the sound isn't rich enough for it to be pleasurable. But, in the end, I had to return this because I couldn't even hear/understand my phone/gps while riding - even around town and with a full face helmet on. It just wasn't usable for me. Maybe it's my hearing - I don't know. Others seem very happy with this. But, sadly it just didn't work out. I really wanted to like this product. Here's why:I had this working with my GPS and Google Maps on my Samsung Nexus phone in 2-minutes.- Easy to install (Arai Vector 2)- Low profile and very modern/cool looking- GPS / Smartphone / Intercom abilities are a homerun - until I used it while riding.- Impressive battery life- At this price, I think it's an incredible value if it worked for me.You may find different results but I was disappointed.

I didn't expect deerskin to be this soft. These gloves have a really nice feel to them. And, for this price, I'm happy with the purchase. I would say the sizing is right on. I always get large and this was no exception. In fact, if they stretch out, these will be extremely loose fitting. For driving, that wouldn't be a problem. For a scooter/motorcycle, it may be an issue for some folks. I'm hoping the already loose feel will translate into being cooler in the summer - we'll see. I'll update my review once I've had time to test these out on some hot days.The only cons I can think of:- these are double-stitched; some of the stitching looks a little sloppy. But, at this price, I think they're still great.- the wrist is very loose. Take that with a grain of salt - my wrists are small and watches are sometimes a problem. I would have preferred a tighter elastic feel around the wrist.But, they feel great and I'm happy with the purchase. Note the leather is very thin - but at least as thick as the $75 motorcycle gloves I see at the shops. I only hope they're thick enough for a spill.

The rack is very solid - and I believe it should last. I can fit 9 pairs of Men's size 11 shoes on it and there's even room for three sets of low-profile sandles underneath. And, yes, it assembles very quickly - which is just a bonus.

This roomy yarn storage bag is great!  At almost 12 inches tall and a bit over 10 inches in diameter it is able to hold several skeins of yarn, making it perfect for large projects.  The number of skeins it can hold will depend on the yarn weight--up to 8 skeins of worsted weight, fewer for chunky weights.  the bag has opening in its lid for yarn to spool through and there are four small pockets on the outside to hold needles or hooks and accessories such as a gauge, scissors, etc.  It is lightweight and made of a sturdy blue cloth that won't show dirt and lined with cotton fabric.  There are two ways to carry the bag--the built in handle on the top, and a detachable shoulder strap.  Perfect for any knitting or crochet project.

This solar powered light is easy to use.  You need to leave it bottom side up (the solar panel is there) in the sun for 8 hours or so to charge it up.  Then, when you want to use it, press the power button on the bottom.  It has three modes:  press the the power button once to get a flashing light, twice to get a dim light and three times to get a bright light.  The light is good, even on dim.  That said, the light doesn't last very long at all.  On bright you get only  1 - 2 hours of light.  On dim I got about twice that.  The device is very thin and encased in flexible clear vinyl that has a tab that allows you to hang it up.  I wish I could have given this light more stars, but I need one that lasts longer than a couple of hours.  It was given to me in exhange for an honest review.

This USB hub has openings to charge six devices at the same time.  It has a cord that can be plugged into a USB wall plug (not included) for power.  I didn't try plugging it into my computer as I didn't know what kind of drain charging more than one item at the time would put on it.  The hub is very small and light so it can be easily carried when traveling but has a cheap feel to it.  It works very well--I charged several devices at the same time and it did the job.  So why did I give it only 3 stars?  It will not work with my iPhone's lightning cable.  I tried three different lightning cables and couldn't get a charge with any of them using this hub.  It charged my two tablets and my Kindle with no problem at all but was a bust for my iPhone.  I was given this device free in return for an honest review.

These bunion pads are made of soft silicone gel and have a built in toe separator that helps align your toe to the proper position.  They are comfortable to wear and the soft gel provides great protection.  What you get are two of the bunion pads plus two "standalone" toe separators that can be worn at night to align your toes.  No instructions are included, but none are needed as it is obvious how to wear everything.  The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 is that the toe separator on the bunion pad is a bit too wide for me to be able to wear all my shoes with it on.  With my wide toe-box shoes there is no problem, but I can't comfortably wear my narrower shoes with it on.  I was given this product in exchange for an honest review.

Well made brass Y connector for hoses.  This connector is very handy when you need to connect more than one hose.  I use one side for a self-filling water bowl for my dogs and the other for my garden hose. The valve controls turn easily and you can open the flow as little or as much as you want/need.  I've had no leakage problems at all.  All in all, this is a well-made and handy gadget.  I was given this in return for an honest review.

High quality oil which comes in a dark bottle to protect it.  A very small amount in my diffuser is enough to produce a pleasant relaxing effect in the room.  Longer lasting fragrance than other lavender oils I have tried.

I've had similar small chargers before, but this UNU charger is the best one I've gotten.  It comes with a dual micro USB & lightning cord so I can use it to charge both my iPhone 6 and my Kindle--and the same cable can be used to charge the unit itself..  And it charges both devices very quickly with plenty of power left.  LED lights indicate the level of charge left in it, and the unit turns itself off if left unused for more than a minute (you can also turn it off your self by pressing the power button).  It is also pretty lightweight and can be carried easily in my purse.

This is a great zip-up sweatshirt.  Good quality, thicker fabric and well-made.  It was a bit too large, but shrank down to a perfect fit when I put it in the dryer for a short while after the first washing.

First, this is not good quality leather, it is a thin skin of leather on man-made materials, which smell a bit when the belt first comes out of the package.  Letting it air out for a day has gotten rid of most of the odor.  Second, this belt is WIDE--about 1.75 inches--too wide for for the loops on some pants.  Other than that, this does what a belt is supposed to do and looks as if it will be long-lasting.I was given this product in return for an honest review.

This is now my favorite little sewing kit.  It contains everything you need in an emergency.  It comes with twelve little sppols of thread in a variety of colors, a package of 6 needles, scissors, a couple of pins, three buttons, a safety pin and two needle threaders.  It even contains a few things you are less likely to need, but which are handy to have:  a thimble, a tape measure and a seam ripper.  All of this contained in a nice little zippered case that is only 4.5 x 4.75 x .75 inches.  Hard to beat and a good price, too.

This set has nine crochet hooks, sizes A through I.  The colorful handles (a different color for each size) cushion fingers and are clearly labeled with both letter and metric sizes.  I have wanted crochet hooks like these for a while and was happily offered this set in return for an honest review.  I find them very easy to use--in addition to the comfortable handles, the hooks are smooth and don't snag yarn.  I found that I was not gripping the hooks as hard as I usually do, and my hand didn't become sore as it usually does when I crochet.  The hooks come in a handy zippered case.

This is a good rechargeable clip-on light that can be used anywhere.  The neck is extremely flexible so the light can easily be aimed where you need it.  If the light is positioned directly over the base it can also be used with it sitting on a table--though the base is so lightweight that the neck must be exactly positioned for this to work.  The lamp has 3 light settings and simply tapping on the base cycles through them.  About the only "con"  is that the charging USB cord has an irregular plug at the lamp end and, for me, was a little too short.  On the whole, this is an excellent cordless reading lamp.I was given this in return for an honest review.
Extremely comfortable ankle socks, perfect for summer wear.  They fit snugly and are knit in such a way that the arch of the foot is supported.  All around, this sock is just what I was looking for.

This paranormal novel goes nowhere fast.  The first book in the series, "Mr. Hartley," was a short and somewhat interesting introduction but this second book is just plain bad.  There is no character growth at all--the protagonist Zach Hartley and the other characters stay at a boring level all the way through.  Even when it turns out that Zach is a Messiah-like individual there's no change in his character.  In a word, Zach is nothing short of perfect.  He never gets angry or even annoyed with anyone.  He always has a timely and perfect way to resolve conflicts.  Everything comes easily to him. Everyone is always in awe of him.  He's so modest it becomes annoying to the reader though not to the other characters because, well, he's perfect and they're in awe of him.  Yeah, it goes in circles like that.There's a lot of sex.  No, this isn't erotica or porn.  It's too matter of fact for that. There's just a lot of sex.  All the females of whatever species want to have sex with Zach or get sexual relief channeled to them by him.  Even some of the males want it.  A large number of the females even live with him--so many that he has to buy a larger house and is considering buying an even bigger one.  The women have designated nights to have him all to themselves, but in between times they are performing fellatio or giving him hand jobs or massages.  That's when he isn't having to pull the shirts up on various and sundry women, laying on hands and shooting sexual energy into them that way.  This is constant, literally constant, throughout the book.So basically this is an adolescent boy's wet dream with only enough plot line to get you from one sex act to another and sometimes not even that far.  It's a how-to guide on making sex boring.  Also has some editing errors sprinkled throughout.  Since it's obvious that nothing's going to change I won't be going on to the third book.

This is a nice little lantern.  Although it is only about the size of a large soup can, it puts out more light than another lantern I have that is twice the size.  It is lightweight, with two metal handles that fold up and down, and a small compass in the lid.  To turn it on all you have to do is pull up on the handles which can also be used to hang the lantern.  The compass works well, too.  It is powered by 3 AA batteries (not included).  I would be a bit worried, however, about losing this lantern on camping trips due to the camouflage.  This is a great little lantern!So why did I give it 4 stars instead of five?  The SMELL.  When I opened the shipping box I was hit with an incredibly strong petroleum/plastic odor.  I left the lantern outside for several hours and the smell reduced and over the next few days it faded even further.  However, if you put you nose right to it, the smell is still faintly there after 5 days.But all in all, I like this lantern.  It works well and puts out a lot of light.  And face it, I doubt I'll be spending much time with my nose touching it and schnuffling it.

This review is for the Small Bite Lamb and Rice formula.  Finally, a dog food that all my dogs can and will eat.  I have 4 dogs of varying sizes, small to large, and the small size of the kibble means that I don't have to have separate foods for them.  In addition, my large dog has always been a picky eater but he loves this food, cleaning his bowl quickly instead of leaving the food sitting.  His excessive flatulence has also been helped by this food, as has his itchiness. Over the years I have fed my dogs the high priced "premium" foods but I will be sticking with this Purina formula from now on.

Coming-of-age SF.  Set in a future in which an alien civilization has conquered Earth and made it part of their empire.  It's protagonist is orphaned at the start and is adopted by a Tarchein viceroy.  This first book in the series covers his experiences at the military academy to become a star pilot and his first forays into battle.  I enjoyed this book--the author is a great storyteller--but I found that it jumped from one experience to the next without enough detail to any.  Tommy's relationship with his adoptive father isn't gone into at all and we get no sense of internal conflict for him between that and the treatment given by some of the Tarchein to their human compatriots.  There is a "glass ceiling" for humans in the empire that is mentioned a couple of times but nothing is made of that either.  The ending is abrupt but leading toward the second book in the series, which I look forward to reading.  There are a few editing errors, but not enough to detract from the novel overall.

This set includes five measuring spoons & five measuring cups in stainless steel, and a glass measuring cup for liquids.  All are well-made and sure to last me many years.  The spoons include 1/4, 1/2 and 1 teaspoon, and 1/2 and 1 tablespoon.  The cups include 1/4, 1/3, 1/2, 3/4 and 1 cup.  The one thing that gave this set 4 stars instead of 5 is measuring marks on the glass measure for liquids--it is marked with litres, ml, and ounces, but not for cups.  The set came quickly and was well packaged.I was given this set in return for an honest review.

The scent in this oil is incredibly weak.  Yes, it smells good in the bottle, but the odor dissipates so rapidly once dispensed that it is worthless.  I tried it with my diffuser and it was as if I hadn't  used it at all.  Save your money.

I have been looking for a replacement for a very old similar style wallet and am very happy with this one.  I frequently go on outings where carrying a purse is inconvenient and this slim wallet is handy to slip into a pocket.  There is a spot with a clear window for my driver's license on one side, and on the other two slots that can hold two cards each.  There is also a center pocket that can hold cash or more cards if desired.  This is perfect for a man or woman who doesn't like carrying a bulky wallet.  When it first arrived I was a bit concerned because smell of the leather was overwhelmed by that of the inner parts, but that soon faded, I am happy to say.  I would have given the wallet five stars, but the fact that there is no opening in the clear window to allow me to easily push out my license when required is a small drawback.  Also, the wallet is well made but I think the price is a tad high.I was asked to give an honest review by the manufacturer.

Great set of dog hair brushes.  I have four dogs with varying coats and these brushes did the trick for all of them.  The de-matting rake did a fine job on my longer coated dog who has fine fur that seems to mat at the drop of a hat.  The brush is double-sided for use on different types of coat, which worked out well for my other dogs, and the undercoat rake works like a charm.  The only thing I would change on the set would be the handles--I have larger hands and would like the handles to be a bit bigger.
Good moisturizing serum. It is thick, goes on smoothly and absorbs well into the skin.  Does improve skin tone, however for me there was no improvement as claimed for fine lines.

Excellent in-ear headphones for the price.  Good all round sound, handling bass through high range well.  I tried them with all sorts of music, from classical to hard rock and all sounded good, with no hissing in the high range or boomy sound in the bass.  The one drawback might be the thinness of the cords.  No case is included, but they do come with a velcro strap to keep the cords from tangling when not in use.  Also comes with three sizes of silicon tips and an attachable shirt clip.  If you are looking for headphones that won't break your wallet and have great sound, these are it.

I like this brochure holder.  It is well-made and meant for table top use only.  It's base is wide enough for it to be extremely stable, and the pocket is deep enough to hold 25-30 brochures depending on thickness or 50-80  narrow flyers or bookmarks.  The clear acrylic allows people to see the entire front of the contents.

This fantastic  charger is definitely going into my emergency "go bag."  It is the size and weight of a smart phone and has two power sources--solar and electricity.  It comes with a short cable that can either be plugged into a computer or a USB wall plug.  When I received it, I put the Mengo in the sun for an hour to charge it (LED lights indicate how much of a charge is available).  Then I plugged my iPhone in and it was fully charged within two hours.  Doing that used up half the power,  but in an emergency that isn't bad and a bout in the sun remedies it.  At the moment I am using it to charge my Kindle ereader.  There are two USB ports and a built-in flashlight which is turned on & off by clicking the power button twice.  Also included is a caribiner clip that can be used to attach the charger to a backpack or belt if you are out hiking.

Naturalist Sy Montgomery renders the story of her pig, Christopher Hogwood, with love and insight.  The effect he had on her life and those of others who met him and the town that adopted him was as immense as he was.  Christopher embodied joy for life, intelligence, and many of the characteristics we humans like to claim solely for ourselves.  From the time he was adopted as a tiny runt no bigger than a cat to his death at the ripe old age of 14 & 750 pounds, this pig's life was filled with love.  Woven throughout is the story of the author's family and career, which has taken her to far-flung countries.  This book was a joy to read.

Each of these short horror stories are well done, though the third one, "Rail 715," was predictable, and the second one needs more detail about the demon who terrorizes the protagonist.  I wish that they'd all been a bit longer in order to provide more detail because the story lines were so intriguing.  While the Edge is referred to in the first two stories, I wanted more detail about that as well.  The first two stories, "Worst Things Than Death" and "Desert Fun Amusement" are heavier on suspense that the last one, which is a straightforward horror story in a classic vein. On the whole these three stories are well written, though the price point ($2.99) is a bit high for 59 pages.  I look forward to reading more stories by this author.Note:  I was given a free copy in exchange for an honest review.

Where to start?  Atrocious editing and a nearly non-existent plot that is an adolescent boy's wet dream,Our intrepid hero Matt Molter joins a ship fresh out of Fleet Academy and quickly plunges (pun intended) into sex, sex, sex.  Women on this ship outnumber the men, and due to some mysterious effect of high velocity travel they are driven to aggressive sexual appetites--and the faster the ship goes, the more they're driven.  Not to mention that the men develop longer "staying power."  You can see where the wet dreams come into this.  The female crew members are constantly exposing their breasts or getting naked at the drop of a hat.  They are endlessly masturbating, performing fellatio and having group sex.  And all of them have humongous breasts due, we're told, to light gravity, raging hormones, and frequent massaging of said breasts.We see little of the other male crew members as the "plot" mainly consists of Matt constantly being pursed by every female on the ship.  A superior officer orders him to have sex with her and 87% of the way in even the Captain propositions him.  Did I mention that at one point the Captain orders Matt to never become monogamous as it might cause rioting?  Oh the horror. The women frequently cry if Matt refuses to have sex with them.  They are constantly launching themselves at his neck to kiss and hug him.  They ogle and fondle him.  They beg him to "take" them.  He is constantly told how wonderful he is.  Two women who broadcast their desire for him while out on an EVA assignment are "punished" by having to stay naked for the entire day while on duty.  For some reason, given the way women strip off constantly, they are mortified.  So Matt increases their punishment by forbidding anyone to touch them, denying them "release."Now, don't think it is all sexual hijinks.  There is action, too.  This action mostly consists of major accidents.  This has to be the poorest maintained ship in the Navy judging by all the equipment malfunctions.  There are four in the first week and a half Matt is on the ship, and four others over the course of the book.  Matt is, of course, a hero in these accidents and that makes the women all the hotter for him.  It's really no wonder that these equipment failures occur--whenever the women are performing important tasks and repairs, they are so busy getting off talking about sex that they mess up.  The amazing thing is that women are allowed to pilot shuttles and carry dangerous weapons.  They're a danger to the ship's safety.Within 5 days of coming aboard, Matt has earned two silver stars, one bronze star and is made a lieutenant JG.  Due to one of the accidents he has also been made acting commander of his section when his superior dies.  In a few more months he is made a full lieutenant.  At the end of the novel the Captain sends him for advanced command training, telling him that he will only have to take the second half of the course, he's so good.Editing. Editing.  Wherefore art thou editing?  Words and letters are left out in several places.  The author has a real problem with commas (the lack thereof can change a sentence's meaning) and apostrophes.  He uses "were" when he means "we're"  (and this is on almost every page in the book) and "your" when he means "you're."  He never uses apostrophes in possessives--for example, "Captains" when he means "Captain's."  Then there are improper words throughout, such as:  "bear" instead of "bare," "breaking" instead of "braking," "loosing" instead of "losing."  AUTHOR:  if you're going to take the time and trouble to write and publish a book, do yourself a favor and get it edited, because spell check doesn't cut it.Oh, and get a plot.

These are great little scissors.  The only reason I didn't given them five stars is that I wish the handles were a bit bigger for a better grip.  I have a terrier mix and the blades handled his thick wiry fur with absolutely no problems.  I also like the round tips--with a dog that squirms a bit, they insure that the dog's skin isn't poked by a sharp point.  Overall these are marvelous scissors for cutting pet hair!

Due to arthritis opening bottles has become more and more difficult.  This opener has solved the problem, gripping caps firmly and making bottles easy to open with minimal effort.  I was nervous about ordering as some reviews said the device is cheaply made and easily broken.  I'm glad I ignored those reviews because I find it sturdy and very well made. Love it.

This book turned out to be a take-off of John Wayne's movie, "Angel & the Badman." There are a few changes, which allow a lot more romance as well as a couple of understated sex scenes, but it's basically the same story. Even the main character's name is close to the movie's--Colt Evans instead of Quirt Evans. Now, I've always loved the movie (which wasn't based on a book), so this didn't bother me. The book does need a lot of editing, which led me to give it only three stars.  There are words left out here and there and the author has a lot of trouble with idioms, sometimes to the point that the opposite of what was meant is said.  I like this story line enough that, for the most part, I could overlook the poor editing, but I did find myself shaking my head a couple of times.  This author really does need to use a proofreader.

I kept waiting for this story to really get going, but it never did.  Which is too bad since the concept of a human social worker for supernaturals is an interesting one.  The heroine finds herself in a battle between two vampires who are in a battle for control of a substance, the Tears of Christ, that can give vampires the ability to be active during the day amongst other things.  Sounds good as far as it goes.  But that IS as far as it goes.  She stumbles from one attack to another, never willing to bring complaints against her attackers and generally acting like a milquetoast--until she doesn't, suddenly becoming a kick-ass 3/4 of the way into the story.  The Tears never make an appearance in the story and other than a brief mention nothing more is made of their powers.  There is a tiny bit of a romance angle, but nothing comes of that either as the heroine keeps protesting that she likes her job too much to do more than kiss the werewolf who is her supervisor, so why bother including this angle at all.  So the book is essentially a montage of attacks on the heroine by vampires, with a witch and a werewolf running interference and no resolution at the end.  Perhaps the only explanation is that the author is setting up for a series--but it's not a very good explanation.The book also needs some serious editing.  There are missing letters here and there and quite a lot of misusage of words throughout the book.  For example, "close lined" is used when the author means "clotheslined."  this throughout.It's really too bad.  I kept plugging along hoping the story would come together but it never did.  If there is to be a sequel I would think twice about buying it based on this first book.

This novel starts slowly and never really picks up, despite a premise in which the protagonist is dragged into an alternate pocket-world in which Washington D.C. was magically taken over by vampires in the late 1800s.  The magic is breaking down and the vampires need a rare magician to maintain their world (which seems to consist of nothing but Washington).  Cue our heroine.From the point at which Quinn is drawn into that vampire world, the plot devolves to endless scenes of BDSM.  Rape features prominently.  Our heroine is too stupid to live and keeps believing her vampire owner despite his lies and mistreatment.  I wasn't even able to finish this novel--couldn't even get halfway through.  At the point when the vampire who rules all the others wraps a spike-studded strap around his mammoth-proportioned schlong in preparation to raping a human slave, enough was enough.Amazingly, this doesn't even have the excuse of being independently published, and HarperCollins should be ashamed.

This book is one long slog of...stupidity.  Because, according to the author, everyone in it (with the exception of himself and one or two nurses) is stupid.  The prisoners most of all, but also the system he's working within.  Bureaucracies are noted at different points as Nazis and donut-eating ignoramuses.  And he doesn't, we're told, like to take orders in any case.  His interactions with the prisoners he treats are all on the same theme--prisoners make up symptoms, want drugs, and ignore the doctor's diagnosis and advice.  After a while the unending litanies become as boring and dreary as the monochromatic paint adorning every site he works in.  And the author manages to contradict himself.  Despite noting to his wife that he doesn't even ask what his patients are in prison for because that's not what is important, with every single inmate interaction he gives us what the inmate was in for.  He tells us that the job is easy, with lots of down time, then tells of non-stop inmate interactions.  He tells us at the end that inmates are still human and deserve his best care, yet throughout the book, in dealing with inmates, he is off-hand, sarcastic, and gives mental notations that give the opposite message.I wish the author had given more details about himself and less of the history of the Colorado Penitentiary.  And more varied interactions between himself and staff and the prisoners would also have made the book more interesting.  Its really too bad, because this is a topic that is very interesting to me and I was hoping for better.

Don't get me wrong, Electric Moon is a great story.  I wish I could have given it more than three stars. It has good world building, well-rounded characters and an interesting take on shifters.  If the story hadn't been so good, I would have given it two stars due to all the editing mistakes.For this book (I don't recall this problem with the first one), the author decided to dispense with editing and rely solely upon spell-check.  That is the only possible reason for the innumerable errors throughout where a word is spelled correctly but either isn't the correct tense, or is entirely the wrong word (ex: lesson in place of lessen).Please, Ms. Brutger, don't ruin your books by neglecting the all-important editing. I'll stick with you for the third book in your series because I like the story, but if it has the same massive problem I doubt I'd buy the fourth.  Even traditionally published books can have editing errors here or there, but your book has them on almost every page.

This self-published romance is set in the 13th century Highlands.  The protagonist is reminiscent of one of Julie Garwood's heroines, leaving disasters in her wake in her determination to find a home and acceptance when her father makes her marry a neighboring laird to gain an alliance.  The laird in question is fierce, distrustful of women due to a past problem, yet fascinated by his new wife.  Outside of the time period, there isn't much actual history and the story revolves mostly around the struggles involved in the romance.I would have liked to give this a better rating--the story is good and the characters are appealing.  But the editing of this book is atrocious.  Needed punctuation is lacking is many places.  It often seems as if the author changed her mind about the structure of a sentence midstream and never removed the rejected words. Or words are left out entirely and the reader must spend a few seconds parsing the sentence.  And some words are misused--"and" for "but," for example; and throughout the word "cottar" is used to mean a cottage, instead of villein or peasant farmer as is proper.Too bad the author didn't give her book the care it deserved.  The price should be dropped drastically--$5.99 is too much to pay in light of the editing problems.

THIS IS A BOOTLEG!!  It came with a case held closed with a piece of tape.  The disc has a cheap white label that is stuck on and says that it is "published by Mad Phat Enterprises"--when I googled them I found that they sell on eBay and nothing else.  The image quality is so poor that it is almost unwatchable and the sound is garbled.  It has obviously been copied from an old videotape, which was itself probably copied, judging by the incredibly poor quality.  I have reported this to Amazon and will be shipping it back.

I bought this on the strength of being written by Keri Arthur, and wasn't disappointed.  The protagonist is a half-breed elf/siren who has started a PI business with a human friend.  When the only elven relative who will speak to her ask Harri to find out what happened to the siren he loves, she dives head-first into the mystery.  The story is set in Australia and the plot moves swiftly, with a lot of action as Harri deals with elves, dragons, trolls and ogres--not to mention the father who hates her.  The one drawback is the sloppy editing which includes missing words here and there, some misspellings and, a couple of times, using a singular when a plural was in order.  But the story is so good that it is easy to overlook this.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book, which is a science fiction spoof.  Its protagonist is Hank, a 4th degree mutation who lives on a space station at the edge of the Colmarian Confederation.  For the most part, the inhabitants of the station are criminals and Hank is a neutral go-between who alternates as muscle-for-hire and mediator.  He's not particularly smart, but he is street-savvy and holds the respect of all sides.  But life gets sticky when powerful mutants, robots, the space navy and an invading civilization all show up.  In short order Hank finds himself at the center of trouble.  The novel is told in a tongue-in-cheek style and the story is fun.  The one drawback for me was the need for a strong suspension of disbelief I occasionally had to draw upon due to some flaws in logic & physics.  Projectile weapons, including a cannon that can destroy buildings, being used inside a space station is one.  Another is a statement that a 35 ft.-tall being had few bones due to its height & weight (we had dinosaurs--one 56 ft. tall--that had no problem with their bones).  There are a couple others that I more easily overlooked.  But overall, the story is good and fun to read.  I look forward to reading more by this author.

I read this series when it was originally published and was pleased to find it finally available for the Kindle as my paperback copies are worn out.  A.P.B. is the first book in the series and introduces Walt Pynchon, a special investigator for the local DA and despised by the local cops who resent his interference.  Pynchon is a hard-bitten, irascible and suspicious man who longs to for early retirement to a warmer climate but keeps getting pulled into cases.  The case in this book involves a serial killer who murders the wives & girlfriend of police officers.  And it doesn't help that he is attracted to a woman who represents a form of life he hates:  reporters.  A great mystery for fans of hard bitten mysteries.  It is unfortunate that the author died after only six books. But  Crossroads Press has done an outstanding job of bringing the series back for mystery lovers.

I couldn't even come anywhere close to finishing this book it is so bad.  I'm a huge Jane Eyre fan and was looking forward to reading this. What a disappointment.I felt a premonition at the very first sentence of the preface: "Dear Reader, do you remember me?" Then came a recital of the events in Jane Eyre. One of the most famous novels in the world doesn't need a recap. The fact that the author almost injures herself trying to imitate the tone of the novel doesn't help. And it is painful to read it is so awkward.It quickly becomes clear that the Jane in this sequel has a very low opinion of Mr. Rochester and an inflated opinion of herself: "I was pleased to see my generous nature was influencing my companion's tendency towards pettiness, and the marriage ceremony only ten minutes old!"She gets mean on their wedding night, blowing hot and cold for no reason. Then, after 4 months of marriage she becomes a resentful shrew who feels that her husband is selfish and though she has gone out of her way to serve him without his asking her to be a slave (she even tastes his cherries before he does to make sure they're not too tart!) feels put upon, feels that he has nervous fancies and is "not cruel, but merely conjectured my service to him was a pleasure." Then she gets ticked off if he takes any time away from her. Sheesh.Finally after treating the poor man to a series of mood swings and pettiness (she's even upset that marriage doesn't improve England's climate for her) that cause him to withdraw she says: "What his struggle was that took his attention from me I could not ascertain by a survey of his pagan mien."!!!That's it. 12% into the book and I couldn't take this crap anymore. Because the rest is surely as bad or worse.  I wasted 30 minutes of my life that I will never get back.

Here is a good story struggling to get out. The author has some intriguing and different ideas for her vampires' physiology and lifestyles. Unfortunately, after reading a bit more than half of it, I was forced to admit defeat because her writing and editing buried everything else. Poor sentence structure combined with constant misuse of words made reading difficult.  "Seen" is used instead of "seeing" throughout, as is "bolder" for "boulder."  And there are a lot of boulders and lots of seeing in this book.I also felt as if I was reading about a teenybopper slumber party rather than vampires due to the amount of giggling going on.  I'm serious.  There are very few laughs in this book--everyone giggles.  The protagonist, the vampire head honcho, macho soldiers, the stud muffin who wants to bed the protagonist...they are all constantly giggling.  The only ones not giggling were the pitbulls. Yes, there are vicious pitbulls (that's the way the head honcho likes them) who of course drool all over the heroine.  But that's not unusual because everyone else drools all over her too with the exception of the stud muffin's numerous concubines.Speaking of the stud muffin, he acts more like a spoiled, acne-spotted teenager than the commander of the army and Heir of the head honcho. His pouting and juvenile posturing are not attractive. Yet the heroine pants, albeit reluctantly due to her past, after him and you can't help wondering why.The author's two favorite words are "vampire" and "speed."  We quickly learn this because "vampire speed" is used almost constantly.  The characters lift things with vampire speed, they block things with vampire speed, they move with vampire speed.  Well of course they do.  They're vampires after all and the reader is informed about vampire attributes at the beginning of the book so it goes without saying.I really wanted to like this book; there's a good story crying to get out but after being told that the heroine is naked underneath her nightgown I finally gave up. That's noteworthy...why?  The image of someone wearing a nightgown over their clothes immediately sprang to mind and suddenly I just couldn't continue reading.  I wanted to reach through the book, slap the author upside the head, and tell her to a) get an editor and b) get honest criticism before publishing in order to avoid sabotaging her own story.

I am a big fan of the Solar Clipper series and waited eagerly for this book to come out.  Unfortunately "Double Share" does not live up to expectations.  It has major plot holes. 1)If the line owner knew about what the captain was allowing to go on, why didn't he just fire him?  The line that he couldn't do it "without cause" doesn't hold water; at the very least the owner could have run an upfront investigation.  2) What was the captain up to in his cabin & why were a couple of crewman constantly being seen coming out of it looking embarrassed?  3) How does the mere idea of Ishmael having sex with women on the crew protect them?  After all, the First Mate and his henchmen are rotten to the core so that shouldn't stop them & they'd certainly not stand for Ish "hogging" so many without a LOT more retaliation than happens.  4) It takes very little to get the dissolute crew turned around--good coffee,clean passageways and the idea that Ish has a larger harem than the First Mate does soon has most of them singing kumbaya together.  5)Very little comes of all the sexual assault and harassment in the end--for example, one of the biggest perps gets off scot free because "he fell in with bad company."  What?!?All in all, "Double Share" is a big come-down from the earlier books in the series.  And there is an added problem with the Kindle edition: the editing is poor.  There are missing words in a couple of places.  And at least half of all the periods are missing.  This book was held up at the publisher for an entire year--the editing should have been perfect.

I love the Mercy Thompson series and was looking forward to River Marked.  I happily paid the inflated price for it.  What I got was a small taste of a great series & character, but none of the "calories."  The lack of substance had me zipping through it in record time and when it ended I was left with a "this is it?" feeling.Everything is rushed. Subplots are so briefly touched upon that I wondered why they were included at all. Mercy and Adam are dispatched on a mission by the Fae on their honeymoon but the reason is incredibly vague.  Exactly who are the Otterkin?  The river monster is impressive, but her history and and motivation are glossed over. Stephen makes a brief insubstantial appearance. Yo Yo girl is mentioned but nothing comes of that. A toe is dipped in Mercy's Native American heritage, but other than finding out that Coyote both is & isn't her father, she & we don't really learn a lot about it.  Other Native American totems pop onto the scene with no warning to help defeat the river monster and then disappear again.And as for the marriage of Mercy and Adam, it is nice finally see it but other than the sweet affection they evince, it mostly for the purpose of Mercy constantly growling "Mine" at every opportunity whether deserved or not.  And while Adam is an Alpha, a lead bullet conveniently wounds him gravely so that Mercy can do her thing without much interference from a take charge kinda guy.River Marked would have been a great short story or even a novella, but for a novel is is lightweight.

If you are looking for action, action, action, space battles, space marines, hot sex, evil aliens or vast star empires in conflict, this is not the novel--or series--for you.Half Share is the second book (following Quarter Share) in a marvelous series that is reminiscent of Andre Norton, early Heinlein and other great science fiction of the past. It follows the shipboard life of the protagonist, Ishmael, his interaction with fellow crew members and his growing expertise as a trader along the ship's route. This is a good old-fashioned SF coming-of-age story and Nathan Lowell presents it with a masterly hand.  Hopefully the third in the series will be made available for the Kindle in the very near future.

These house socks are thick, incredibly soft, and wonderfully toasty.  Great for wearing around the house or lounging about when you don't want to slip your slippers on.  They are also great for wearing to bed on very cold nights. My tootsies have been jumping with joy since I got these socks--which makes walking about the house a mite difficult, as you can imagine, and frightens the dogs.  But hey...that's the price you pay for warm feet!

OK, I'll be honest--the pattern on my slippers is butt ugly.  The only pattern that was in stock when I purchased was the "Chocolate dots."  But I was desperate for slippers and the reviews were great so I went ahead and bought them.Beauty is only skin deep!  These slippers are wonderfully warm and the memory foam is great for tired feet and there is enough width that your toes have nice wiggle room.  They also have a good sole that allows you to go outside if you need to.The one drawback is that they run a bit big.  I was forewarned about this by previous reviewers and so bought a size smaller than usually for a good fit.

Desperate for a job, any job, spacer Art Gordon hires on as "housekeeper" on an alien ship.  He is the only male on board, as the Tani'Anneray are bound by a vow of celibacy while in space & have segregated ships.  While learning to do his job on his own (his employers don't believe in manuals or training) he becomes disgusted with their pecking order system in which the lowest ranked crew member is made miserable, thereby allowing the rest to "safely" blow off steam.  Gradually, he falls in love with the put upon Choon. Eventually he makes up his own version of a Christian marriage rite and takes her as his wife.  When the ship's captain learns of this, Art is dumped on a planet and left.  Not giving up, he makes his way to Choon's home world to plead his case.The plot plods along. A quarter of the way through the book it was obvious that it wasn't going to get any better but having purchased it (on the strength of the description--a lesson to *always* get the sample first) I was determined to finish it.  I have to say it is great as a soporific: even when the ship is blown through a rip is space into an alternate universe & chances for survival are between slim and none, there is a lack of tension, suspense or excitement.  It is also waterlogged: Art is constantly tearing up or weeping over one thing or another. The plot is further dragged down by the character's continuous prayers and droning on about his faith and his religion.

This version of Jane Eyre is one of my favorites. I excitedly preordered this DVD a month ago when I found out about it.  Unfortunately, I can only give this DVD two stars. That is one star better than the last "remastered" release that I reviewed...the extra star is due to the fact that THIS one is at least not missing an entire scene.Far from being remastered as claimed this release is, if you can believe it, even worse than the other I reviewed.  First, it is dark & muddy--I had to crank up the brightness on my TV up almost all the way in order to see any detail at all.  Second, the picture is almost constantly filled with long scratches (sometimes right through the middle), both white & black "drop-outs," and a hair or fiber that appears at the top of the screen throughout the entire front credits.  Third, the color fluctuates several times throughout the film.  Fourth, in some scenes the sound is a bit scratchy.And to top it all off the release company (VCI Entertainment), not content to lie on their packaging, had the GALL to insert "This Special Edition motion picture has been digitally restored to its present condition" before the film.  There's 'truth in advertising' for you.I can't figure out why it is so impossible to get a GOOD release of this film.  But I am tired of releasing companies lying about remastering it.  Don't piss on my leg and tell me its raining.

I was hesitant to buy this cover mostly due to the pictures in its listing, which seem to show a light that doesn't even extend to the opposite corner. The fact that I have not been impressed with the Amazon's Kindle covers in the past didn't help.  I went ahead and purchased it because the cover I wanted isn't available yet and I don't like to take my Kindle out and about without a cover.  Now I am glad that I went ahead and bought it.PROS:1. The light is much better than I thought it would be. Using it in a darkened room I found that the light did the job very well.  In a pitch black room, it performs even better. While the screen corner opposite the light is a bit dimmer than other areas, there is no problem reading the page at all.2.  The light gets its power from the Kindle itself, through the gold-plated hinges which attach it to the cover, so batteries are a thing of the past. When your Kindle goes to sleep, the light will go out as well.  It will also turn off when you slide it back into the case.3. The cover is slim, well-fitted and very easy to attach and detach using the hinges.  The inside has good padding. The leather outer surface has a nice pebbled texture with the exception of a smooth area along the edge of the front. While stiff enough to protect the reader, the cover is slight flexible and the front easily folds behind when reading so you can hold your Kindle with one hand if you like.4. A great plus is that the cover has an elastic cord that fits into a groove on the front of it.  This holds your cover closed (unlike the original Kindle 2 cover that would flop open in your purse & let things slide into it) and easily distinguishes the front from the back--important as many owners of the Kindle 2 cover accidentally opened it from the back, which could cause cracking along the Kindle's spine.CONS:I haven't found any, really.  The light Is a bit hard (stiff) to pull out of the cover, but then you wouldn't want it to be flopping out when you don't want to use it so that is more of a Pro than a Con.The one concern I do have is about pulling the light in and out--I wonder if whatever wiring or conductor that is used to get the power from the hinges to the light will eventually break.  But that is something to find out down the road.  Right now, the more I use this cover, the more I like it.

I really enjoy murder mysteries and have read quite a few.  A friend who is like minded recommended those by Cora Harrison, so I checked into them.  I had my reservations with the first book I read (My Lady Judge), but gave them a chance and found them quite satisfying.  I subsequently read 10 of them over the course of a little over a week (when I’m in the mood to read, that’s all I do and can read up to a book a day, depending upon the content).I found the characters enjoyable and distinct, especially the children of the Brehon’s school.  For some authors it’s difficult to make children seem individual; they often come out two dimensional stereotypes. Harrison does a great job of individualizing them; one never confuses one with another despite the fact that there are several of them.  They are also age-appropriate and exhibit considerable development over the course of the various books; they essentially grow up and have lives like real children do.  In this way, these books remind me of the Harry Potter series. The author’s biography indicates that she was a teacher, and if the attitude of her central character is anything to go by, she must have been a good one.  The various children are give instruction, support, responsibility, and gentle correction individualized to the personality and needs of each specific child. You couldn’t ask for more.The mysteries themselves are quite methodical; that is to say, they obey the rules of classic mysteries.  I never felt I’d been “cheated” by a heavy handed maneuver introduced to make things come out “unexpected.”  The only literary criticism I have to offer is that the author’s environmental descriptions seem repetitious, mechanical and a little dull.  Once read, they added little to the actual narrative, and I found I tended to skip over them.  Some of the strong points are that one learns a lot about the early culture of Ireland: its history, its relationship with the English, its distinctive laws, colorful language and its monuments.  I looked up some of the sites the author mentions on Wikipedia and found out that they do in fact exist.  Because I'm interested in history, I found the author's attention to authentic detail impressive.The stories harken back to a slower and more intimate time when everyone knew everyone else in a neighborhood, and people’s behavior could and was kept in line through opinion.  Apparently it was also a time when murder was dealt with in more humane ways almost impossible today.  In general I found that the books made me think through my own opinions on a lot of things one takes for granted.  In some ways I think we’ve come a long way, in others that we have lost our way.

Years ago I had to take French in order to finish a BA degree.  It was a miserable experience.  Not that it actually had to be, but at the time the material for reading was pretty limited and mostly “high minded.”  We started, very a propos, with Les Miserables.  I’m not much into “high minded” even in English, so the whole experience was torture.  More recently, and especially on Amazon, many more volumes of French material, high minded and otherwise, are now available.  The Harry Potter series is one of them.  I read this volume in English when everyone else did at the end of the 90’s (see my review of the English and French versions) and then later in French, when I found that I knew a lot more than I thought I did.  Since that time, I’ve read the Kindle version as well and found that the introduction of a French dictionary to it has made it even more approachable for the English speaker to manage—one no longer feels one is trying to wade knee deep in molasses, looking up every word in a separate dictionary!  One further improvement has now arisen:  I can sit with my Kindle version of the book and listen to my audio version at the same time, allowing me to follow the story, identifying individual printed words with the spoken words on the CD, learning vocabulary, pronunciation and rhythm at the same time.  At last, the real hour for learning a foreign language has arrived, and it can actually be fun!

This type of book is a great way to improve your reading French.  When I first took French in college, it felt like pulling teeth.  I can handle grammar lessons—I like to understand how languages function and have taken quite a few, including Egyptian hieroglyphics and Sumerian—but I’m terrible when it comes to vocabulary.  Part of the problem was that the course focused on classic French literature, and I’m not really even an English literature type person.  I couldn’t read French because I didn’t care what it said in the first place!  Other books in French at the time were virtually non-existent, but over the years more have become available, especially through Amazon.  My favorite literary genre is the classic murder mystery, and when I found this book in French, I got it.  I read Mysterious Affair at Styles years ago in English when I was working in Saudi Arabia—there wasn’t much else to do but read—so I already had a handle on what the book should say.  Since the Kindle book comes with a dictionary (albeit in French) it helped to check my understanding of some of the words as needed, just as I would for something I was reading in English. This version also saves the reader the painful process of looking up every word in a separate dictionary which is time consuming and frustrating and often is the primary cause of “giving up” on the project. The definition pops up when you highlight the word.  By the end of the book, I had a clear feeling for the environment, the cast of characters, and the crime; I even had a good idea as to the culprit, just as I did when I read it years ago.  This story is one of Christies’ earlier works—in fact I think it’s her first book—so it’s a good place to start.  The vocabulary and sentence structure are simpler than her more developed style in later books, and the French translation seems to follow closely to the original. If murder mysteries are your guilty secret too and you want to improve your reading French, this is a good way to go.

This type of book is a great way to improve your reading French.  When I first took French in college, it felt like pulling teeth.  I can handle grammar lessons—I like to understand how languages function and have taken quite a few, including Egyptian hieroglyphics and Sumerian—but I’m terrible when it comes to vocabulary.  Part of the problem was that the course focused on classic French literature, and I’m not really even an English literature type person.  Other books in French at the time were virtually non-existent, but over the years more have become available, especially through Amazon.  My favorite literary genre is the classic murder mystery, and when I found this book in French, I got it.  I read Murder in Mesopotamia years ago in English, so I already had a handle on what the book should say.  Since the Kindle book comes with a dictionary (albeit in French) it helped to check my understanding of some of the words as needed, just as I would for something I was reading in English. This version also saves the reader the painful process of looking up every word in a separate dictionary. The definition pops up when you highlight the word.  By the end of the book, I had a clear feeling for the environment, the cast of characters, and the crime; I even had a good idea as to the culprit, just as I did when I read it years ago.  This book is a little more advanced than Christies’ earlier books, like Mysterious Affair at Styles, so I’d start with the latter and work through the author’s books by year.

This is an impressive volume, definitely the most impressive of its kind that I’ve ever read.  Not, to my certain knowledge anyway, has anything like it been published on a single specimen, a single individual.  As far as I know, neither the much studied King Tut nor the famous “Otzi the Ice Man” has received such thorough discussion in a single published work—collections of journal articles maybe, but a single volume, no.That said, however, I would also have to say that the book is not for the average reader on anthropology, archaeology, or paleontology.  You’d certainly have to be an uber-fiend of an amateur to get much out of it.  I’ve a very broad educational background including some of these disciplines, and I had difficulty wading through some of the chapters. (I had to look up anadromous fish, for instance, which I thought might be single gender or alternating single and dual gender animals, but which turned out to be fish migrating between fresh and sea water habitats.)  This is a scientific, multi-disciplinary work.  As such it’s full of details and professional jargon likely to either bore or overwhelm the casually interested reader—expect to keep a dictionary close at hand.  If you want to look at the book and pick out specific interests or at least read the conclusions, I’d recommend a library copy if you live in an area with a large public facility or have access to a university library.  Smaller library systems will probably not carry the book unless someone specifically provides for it by way of a donation.  Because of its expected limited audience, it’s somewhat expensive, about the price of a modest textbook ($60+ on Amazon when last I looked, though the Kindle edition is $40+).  If your budget is like mine, definitely limited, you might prefer to buy other books.This is more a professional’s book, and I suspect that even a professional will pick and choose among the chapters for specific information when he or she reads it.  It’s a book designed to be “referred to”  in pursuit of data (it has incredible end-chapter bibliographies); information about what happened in the discovery and study of the skeleton and about specific aspects of the skeleton itself, information perhaps relevant to a research project being undertaken by that reader.  For such an individual the purchase price may be a steal, especially if they expect to do further work in the field.  It should definitely be in a research facility’s or university’s professional library if they specialize in any of these areas of interest.The book might also make a good addition to a class syllabus for anthropology, archaeology, paleontology, ecology, etc.  It provides such a thorough discussion of each aspect of the study subject, that it becomes a good educational tool for students.  Selected chapters will show what can be learned, what can’t be, what the pitfalls are, the legal issues that arise, etc.  To some extent it also illustrates technique, the importance of documentation, and the effects of changing technology on what can be gleaned from both specimen and site, the importance of good conservation for future research, the significance of collecting specimen and samples in situ by professionals, the importance of comparative data from research and other similar specimen, the use of statistical approaches, and what different specialties have to contribute to the overall project.  Importantly it shows that even specialists within a field may not agree on interpretation or even on what they see in the physical remains and that with time and more information interpretations change.  Archaeology is definitely no longer a lone explorer armed with pick and camel hair brush looking for buried treasure; it’s a very expensive and elaborate collaboration of specialists trying to find answers to clear cut questions.  Used with consideration of course intent and of the abilities of likely students, it would be a very useful and demonstrative tool.  Permission might be obtained to reprint desired portions of the book at a nominal price to limit expense to the student; I’d check with the publisher.More interesting to both the average and the professional reader might be that part of the book which is a history of the pursuit of knowledge, in this case about the Kennewick skeleton, and more especially about the right to pursue such knowledge.  It features the legal processes needed to actually access the skeleton for scientific study and ultimately directs itself to the question of whom, if anyone, has an exclusive right to the past.  This is an ongoing argument, much like the battle between individual and group rights, but one that this particular specimen brought into the public spotlight and the courts possibly for the first time, at least in this country.  It’s certainly been followed with interest throughout the world, probably because there is often a socio-political undercurrent, with significant vested interests involved.  The need to resort to the courts established legal precedents and put the issue on the road to social integration as a concept—one has to recognize a problem exists to solve it equitably.  As with most such arguments fraught with emotional content, one legal battle will not write the outcome in stone.
