It does relate some of the newer data being found in a worldwide investigation of human genetics and history, but it really has been discussed elsewhere in a more interesting manner that may appeal more to the novice.  It's not so much that this book is too detailed, as it is too little too late.The actual implications of what is learned about history from genetics were covered very ably by Bryan Sykes in his books, written much earlier in the process of the investigations, The Seven Daughters of Eve: The Science That Reveals Our Genetic Ancestry(2002), Adam's Curse: A Future without Men(2005), and Saxons, Vikings, and Celts: The Genetic Roots of Britain and Ireland (2007).  These follow the science in a more contemporary manner, and go into considerable detail about the use of the mDNA and the Y chromosome for research, the history of their discoveries and the historical meanings of what is encoded.  They do so, more importantly, in a more engaging narrative style.While Sykes examines primarily the Mediterranean and the Western and Northern European data--since much of his data come from these more easily accessed gene pools--Dr. Wells discusses historical genetics more globally, so it does provide a less biased focus on human history.  More importantly, he presents a great deal on present day hunter gatherers, something that definitely needs to be examined before we damage these people irreparibly. If nothing else perhaps the book will encourage its readership to support the preservation of these ancient cultures in the fragile political environments that are currently destroying them.Both authors also address the question of Neanderthal contributions to our own genetics, and why we might have succeed where they failed.  Personally I'm not sure we will ever know the answer to that question; though I'm inclined to believe it had more to "pure dumb luck" than we are ever likely to admit!

With the recent internet publicity for the last of the Harry Potter films, there appeared an article on the so-called Harry Potter Wannabes and their "failure" to capture public attention.  The author of the article was somewhat rough on these books and films, so I decided I'd do a little research of my own.  I selected some of the DVDs of the movies and the books upon which they had been based to see what I thought of them myself.One of these was City of Ember.  I was really quite impressed with it.  It bore nothing at all that seemed to be in imitation of Harry Potter but was completely its own self.  While it was also a children's book/film and taught truths about society and about growing up, it was not a Harry Potter Wannabe at all.  It simply followed the rules of its genre; I would have considered it inappropriate if it had not done so.  That the film makers were taking advantage of an upsurge in interest in children's literature is hardly strange; money follows public interest in almost any field.  Personally I thought that it was a good thing in this instance.The main characters, as expected for children's films and books, were a young boy and girl--younger in the book than the film--whose lives are defined by the environment into which they had been born.  This is no different from our own experience except that theirs is not quite the environment that we know.  Like ours it is a very fragile, insular and manmade environment and one that, as ours may, is about to collapse. It is, however and unlike ours, entirely underground with all the caveats that that introduces.Since things started out quite comfortably for this community, the gradual slide into decline over some 250 years was ignored by some, denied by others, and ineffectively worried over by the balance.  It is particularly bright and attentive children that notice that the world into which they have been born and raised is tottering on the brink of extinction, but none of the adults want to deal with it.  Some continue with their lives as they are able accepting that they can do nothing else, others form friendship groups that devote themselves to a philosophy that "help will come" from some outside source in the eleventh hour if they just "believe," while some put by hidden goods to sustain at least themselves during the "end-of-days."  In short we have a pretty broad section of human reactions to slow pending disaster.  Ember is a microcosm of our own world.  Furthermore, just as in our world, political entities have a vested interest in keeping everyone in the dark--sometimes literally.  It is therefore the children who are left to save the society of Ember, and they do so at great risk to themselves--which makes for a very good story.The book was well written and engaging.  The opening captured the imagination, and the odd culture of "make-do" was arresting and kept the reader moving from chapter to chapter.  The subtle evidence that all was not right in Ember kept mounting, lending a sense of urgency to the children's discoveries and their will to save the people of Ember from their fate.  None of the adventures the children had was beyond the capacity of young people, though luck played a strong part--as if often does in real life.  It is not so much the happenstance events in life that make or break but how they are used, as Doon's father tells him early on in the story.  More than anything, these are not superheros against the super villains; these are average young people with an above average sense of curiosity and desire to do something profound for their society; Abraham Lincoln would have understood them completely.  Even the villains share the same sense of self preservation that we all recognize in ourselves.  Having more experience, they have a greater sense of the implications of things; some do what they can for others, some think only of themselves.  Most of us have done both in our time.A great tale of survival and courage.

With the recent internet publicity for the last of the Harry Potter films, there appeared an article on the so-called Harry Potter Wannabes and their "failure" to capture public attention.  The author of the article was somewhat rough on these films, so I decided I'd do a little research of my own.  I selected some of the DVDs of the movies and the books upon which they had been based to see what I thought of them myself.One of these was City of Ember.  I was really quite impressed with it.  It bore nothing at all that seemed to be in imitation of Harry Potter but was completely its own self.  While it was also a children's book/film and taught truths about society and about growing up, it was not a Harry Potter Wannabe at all.  It simply followed the rules of its genre; I would have considered it inappropriate if it had not done so.  That the film makers were taking advantage of an upsurge in interest in children's literature is hardly strange; money follows public interest in almost any field.  Personally I thought it was a good thing here.The main characters, as expected for children's films and books, were a young boy and girl--younger in the book than the film--whose lives are defined by the environment into which they had been born.  This is no different from our own experience except that theirs is not quite the environment that we know.  Like ours it is a very fragile, insular and manmade environment.  Again like ours may do, it is one that is about to collapse.  Here however it is underground with all of the caveats that that introduces.Since things started out quite comfortably for this community, the gradual slide into decline over some 250 years was ignored by some, denied by others, and ineffectively worried over by the balance.  It is particularly bright and attentive children that notice that the world into which they have been born and raised is tottering on the brink of extinction, but none of the adults want to deal with it.  Some continue with their lives as they are able accepting that they can do nothing else, others form friendship groups that are devoted to a philosophy that "help will come" from some outside source in the eleventh hour if they just "believe," while some put by hidden goods to sustain at least themselves during the "end-of-days."  In short we have a pretty broad section of human reactions to slow pending disaster.  Ember is a microcosm of our own world.  Furthermore, just as in our world, political entities have a vested interest in keeping everyone in the dark--sometimes literally.  It is therefore the children who are left to save the society of Ember, and they do so at great risk to themselves--which makes for a very good story.The film managed to keep quite close to the format of the book; important--and sometimes difficult--if one is to keep the original audience of the book who will probably know every detail.  There were really only minor changes.  The adult roles were well played by skillful actors who had a capacity to reign in their egos in favor of the young, less experienced actors in the cast.  This shows incredible professionalism.  It also shows a good deal of common sense; my main complaint with Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events was that the central adult actors, Jim Carey and Meryl Streep, overwhelmed the younger actors and even the story itself.  Here the young actors were allowed to shine in their roles and were very competent and comfortable with them; one thought entirely about the character and never about the actor playing it, which suggests either excellent talent or skillful direction--or both.Though many films these days get carried away with computerized graphics--to the point where they might as well be computer games--this one was a nice combination of live action and CGI.  One was never allowed to forget that this was a book about children and about a society at risk.  The city of Ember was a delightful set; a combination of almost medieval society and watered down 20th century, with cultural lacunae designed to get one thinking about what was actually happening here and why.  The set was dark and brooding, almost as much as one of the Alien films where humans made their lives in the midst of unearthly landscapes.  It gave the viewer a distinct sense of "what had been lost," as The Builders had said and why they had prevented knowledge of the outside world from being known.  Costumes were designed to suggest poverty but an ongoing sense of human pride, even in adversity.  The population was poor, but they seemed to have made, not only the "best of a bad situation," but a virtue of making do.  Furthermore, while there were people who were willing to lie and cheat to cushion themselves from difficult times, there were also people who were willing to make sacrifices for others, sharing what little they had.  Even The Builders may well have done so at the very beginning of "time" in Ember.  If there is anything about people that will help us through what may be a very difficult time in our own future, it will be just those psychological assets.It was a wonderful film.

Almost anyone who has read on the topic of human evolution, blood groups, genetic archaeology, etc. over the past 30 years knows something about the work of Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza.  His name looms large in almost all publications on these topics, so it was interesting to actually read something written by the man on the topic.While the book is actually a very general discussion of human migrations throughout the globe and includes material derived from a variety of disciplines beyond the author's own, enough of it is discussed from the point of the author's specialty to make it truly informative.  I enjoyed it for its ability to stimulate my own thinking on the topic of modern humans as living members of a multi-species genus. While I found the topics of genetic and linguistic history and their contributions to the illumination of the human diasporas of interest, I found the author's original work in blood groups, especially on the Rhesus differences, most intriguing.For years there has been a discussion of how speciation occurs and even of what exactly a species is.  In particular the occasional occurrences of successful interbreeding of different species within a genus, confuses the definition usually applied.  Generally speaking a species prefers to mate with its own group, and on occasions when it mates with another species produces non-viable or sterile offspring, if any at all. The archetype of the definition is the mule, which is a horse-donkey cross breed and which is always sterile; the fly in the ointment being the wolf-dog cross breed which is usually viable and fertile.  The author's work in Rhesus differences seems to suggest that a division between species might arise by virtue of something as invisible as a mutation in blood groups.Given that without modern technology, a Rh+/- cross breeding will lead to a drop in productivity of such pairs due to the death of all infants after the first, one might see the Rhesus differences as a genetic event on its way to speciation of modern humans into two biologically incompatible groups with virtually no other visible distinction between them, including mental or cultural characteristics.  The fact that we have not done so may be due largely to our technology.  Interesting book.

"Cro-Magnon" is an interesting book by Brian Fagan, whose primary approach to archaeology and pre-history is generally speaking that of the paleoclimatologist. Here, though he again examines the effects of extreme climate on human populations, he is primarily interested in the question of Neanderthal and early Sapiens and their cultural responses to the environment, especially in respect to the extinction of the former and the spread of the latter.  He paints a rather more different picture of the two than the usual, since he almost sees the Neanderthal as simply moving away from extreme climate while the Cro-Magnon embraces it.  I'm not certain I agree with that, since the earlier species spread and flourished for several thousands of years in a climate of widely swinging temperature domains before the arrival of Cro-Magnon and seemed to exhibit a suite of cultural traits that enhanced that survival.Even though the presence of two populations of humans placing demands on limited resources was bound to produce a differential in survival, I'm more inclined to agree with Clive Finlayson (The Humans Who Went Extinct: Why Neanderthals Died Out and We Survived) who suggests that chance played a greater part in the process.  Both Dr. Fagan and Dr. Finlayson note that both types of human ended up disbursed among various residual domains of habitability during climatic downturns, some with less interconnectivity than others.  Dr. Finlayson, however, places a greater emphasises on the resulting isolation and its pronounced effect on genetic variability and overall decline in species viability. The cul-de-sac into which Neanderthals found themselves during the last glacial maximum may simply have reduced a stressed breeding population beyond its capacity to survive, with or without the pressures of a rival species in the environment.Observations on evolutionary tracks and other phenomena, where events of different magnitudes are possible and can have major effects on outcomes, have been made by a number of researchers in other fields under the rubrics of "self organizing criticality" (Stuart Kaufman and the Sante Fe Institute, The Origins of Order: Self-Organization and Selection in Evolution and Per Bak (how nature works: the science of self-organized criticality) and "complexity or ubiquity theory" (Mark Buchanan (Used & New from: $7.00 Ubiquity: The Science of History . . . or Why the World Is Simpler Than We Think]) and [[ASIN:0609809989 Ubiquity: Why Catastrophes Happen) and the resulting concepts suggest that chance occurrences can indeed have exactly this type of effect on natural systems, including species survival.  When it comes down to which species made it through to modern times, it may have been as much a matter of "shear dumb luck" as it was of increased cultural complexity and changes in mental outlook.  In fact even our understanding of the differences and similarities which may have existed between the cultures and mental realities of the two populations is as much the outcome of a differential in chance survival of artifactual remains as it is of actual quantifiable differences in the two species of human.Our sense of superiority, not only to extinct species of our own genus but to our existing distant cousins the great apes, may only be an illusion in the long run of things.  I think it's very telling that most genera have more than one species, and that genera that don't are usually those that have undergone or are undergoing serious stress of some kind.  Our uniqueness as a species in the world may not be such a good sign.Nature doesn't care about our ego or our technological successes; it only cares about numbers and sustainability.  Our short run of success may ultimately be leading to our final demise as our numbers bring pressure to bear on sustainability and lead to collapse.Interesting book.

This is a charming book that brings the iconic figure of President Lincoln to life as a real human being, the kid next door so-to-speak.  It emphasizes the qualities that led to his success as an adult, a good sense of humor, approachability, an insatiable interest in learning, and a degree of persistence that many so-called average people share. As a first book on Lincoln, the book gives children an accessible portrait of the man as a boy much like other boys.  The illustrations are comical and dear and add to the approachability of the subject.  The overall message is not only "my best friend might grow up to be president" but also "I might grow up to be president."

"Vanished Ocean" is a fairly thorough introduction to the life and death of the Tethys Ocean and how geologists know what they do about something that has not been around for several million years.  I certainly found a biography of the ocean an arresting way of bringing attention to its central feature in both earth history and life history.  Oceans are so much a part of our world that we often overlook them as a primary shaper of that world until they rise up out of their basin and drown some of us or otherwise intrude themselves into our awareness.  That is part of our problem with global warming and species loss.  This book points that out quite neatly when the author describes the Permian and end Cretaceous extinctions.I suspect the book will appeal most to those with at least some college background in earth sciences.  Though the author does a good job of defining terms (in fact he includes a short glossary) and of describing processes, there is still a lot of pretty heavy science here. (I haven't heard the term flysch in years, not since my degree program in geology). If the reader has read extensively in geology as a hobby, they might also feel comfortable with what is described.  It will probably be heavy going for those with no prior knowledge of the field.To some extent the book seems a little disjoint because there are so many digressions into personal history or into what amounts to a travelogue of distant places.  I know this is intended to bring the reader and the author into a sort of vis à vis relationship, but I always find it distracting.  This so interrupts the central narrative that it's sometimes difficult to follow the scientific information the author wants to impart.  For those who enjoy this type of chatty prose style, or those who want to know something about the "glamorous" life of a field geologist, this is the book for you.  I suggest also books by Peter Ward(Gorgon: Paleontology, Obsession, and the Greatest Catastrophe in Earth's History), and in anthropology/paleontology Donald C. Johanson (Lucy's Legacy: The Quest for Human Origins) whose prose styles are very similar.  Certainly young people looking for fields of endeavor in which to find a future career may find these books illuminating for this reason.I was most impressed by the author's more balanced approach to the demise of the dinosaurs.  This debate has been such a media circus that it has been the media and its effect on popular opinion that has had the "final say" on the issue.  Like it was possible to vote on the subject.  I've no doubt that the dramatic character of the theory has made a lot of people a lot of money.  About how much the notice has helped earth science I'm less sure, though the author assures us that real research continues to shed light on the subject.I also found the information on oil and gas production interesting.  While I had known the "how," I had not known that so much of the oil and gas we use today was produced in the Tethys.  I suppose it shouldn't have surprised me, since much of any such product from earlier times would have been destroyed by the same processes that led to both the creation and the demise of the Tethys. The discussion on anoxic bottom conditions is particularly informative because we are seeing this occur in our own times, and Dr. Stow's discussion is therefore very current and very informative; we would do well to pay heed.  Another book on the eutrophication of the oceans is by M. J. Benton When Life Nearly Died: The Greatest Mass Extinction of All Time who tells a similar cautionary tale.An interesting and informative discussion

When I first started the book I wasn't sure I'd enjoy it.  It has a pronounced bardic style common to the genre of children's fantasy fiction that takes a little getting used to for an adult who has been away from it for a while.  This said, however, I loved it.  I think it's almost in the league of Harry Potter in many respects.Unlike the Potter series "The Sword of Darrow" takes place in "deep time" rather than in the present.  The venue has much of the early middle ages about it (though admittedly the presence of castles suggests a later period.)  Certainly the authors seem to know something about life at the time:  their descriptions in the "gong farmer" episode suggests as much.  There are plenty of mythical individuals filling out the cast on both sides of the "good and evil" battle lines, individuals that force the reader to set aside prejudices with respect to those who are different.  Minotaurs, Trolls, a dragon, a Scorpion Man, and other even more imaginative creatures appear as friends and enemies.There are also any number of grey areas that make the reader think from a different frame of reference than his or her own.  The goblins, for instance, do evil things, but they do so out of a mistaken need for revenge that makes them as much victims as are the hapless human citizens of Sonnencrest that they attack.  The spiritual development of two of the characters and the way in which this develops bring the reader to see that often times anger and the need for revenge are more damaging to the individual who feels them than they are to those who elicited the feelings.  I think this is very cogent.  (Being a former nurse I know that these feelings raise the serum cortisol level and the blood pressure, neither of which are good for you!)More than anything the book suggests that the happy, easy life of even the best of kingdoms can always change; it takes vigilance and dedication to keep such an era going; and such times should be valued and recognized for what they are great good fortune and something to be treasured.  In the end the people of Sonnencrest realized that the treasures that had been plundered from them by the Goblins were not nearly as valuable as their freedom, their families, their belief in themselves, and their willingness to come to the aid of their fellows in time of need.The lessons learned by the young protagonists are definitely similar to those of Harry Potter:  self discovery, the worth of good friends, overcoming personal weaknesses and cultivating strengths, learning that bad things sometimes happen to good people, that there can be negative repercussions to taking a stand for even the best of causes but that sometimes it's worth it anyway, that even a good cause can suffer setbacks, that people we love die, etc.  Here the lessons seem to jump out rapidly one after the other, where the labors of the Harry Potter children are dealt with in a more leisurely manner over the course of several books. Here all the lessons are learned by the end of 342 pages.  There is a beginning, a middle and an end that is rather final in The Sword of Darrow, leaving no sense that there is a "next story."  This is rather sad in an era of sequels, prequels and series.  It leaves nothing to look forward to which is too bad.  I think J. K. Rowling's understanding of that need is what made her books so tremendously successful.  She didn't hurry her characters; she let them grow through a series of adventures tailored not only to the emotional level and age of her targeted readers but using their vocabulary and level of sentence structure at each stage.  That takes a great degree of self-control and foresight.The authors are obviously very able spinners of tales with a very literate vocabulary and grammar style, though I doubt it is outside of the reading range of most individuals among the older grade school or middle school or of the average adult.  Even where it might be, it's good to stretch the mind a little.  Younger, preliterate children will probably enjoy having it read to them and will enjoy the many pictures that accompany some of the chapters.Given the mélange of venues, characters, and episodes I think The Sword of Darrow would make a wonderful children's film.  The overall arrangement of the events would certainly provide a good script:  there is an attention capturing beginning, a good flow to each episode that keeps the story moving and an excellant dénouement.  There are a number of good roles for experienced adult actors and very strong roles for younger actors.  The range of mythical characters would give a good field of play to makeup specialists and to model and puppet artists.  The scores of goblins in the goblin army, the attack of the spider army, and the activities of the evil wizard, especially in his human whirlwind form, would provide opportunities for the CGI specialists to show off their particular talents as well.  Hopefully the right people will see that.A lovely story.

"Saxons, Vikings, and Celts" is another of Bryan Sykes ventures into genetic archaeology.  It makes fascinating reading and gives rise to some interesting results.  Some of the material appears in his earlier works, The Seven Daughters of Eve: The Science That Reveals Our Genetic Ancestry and Adam's Curse: A Future without Men, the foundations that explain the nature of genetic research in the area of human evolution and migration and in the history of mitochondrial DNA and the Y chromosome as keepers of human history.The book does not require any great knowledge of biology or genetics to be understood.  Anyone with a standard high school education, especially those given to watching programs on PBS or Discovery Channel, will find the book very accessible.  Those interested in archeology and anthropology will find it an invaluable window onto what the field of genetics has to say about human events.  Often the reasoning from cultural remains is very circular because what the presence of material culture actually means to the human drama is very ambiguous.  As the author also points out, any interpretation of the ambiguous can be heavily biased by personal agendas and beliefs, but genes are incapable of lying or dissimulation.Professor Sykes has a very readable style and a good handle on the history of the United Kingdom and is able to weave both the history and the science of his work together into an interesting tale.  Though some of the discussion on the scientific aspects of his research may lose the reader in details, in general the results are perfectly understandable and very arresting in the human tale they tell.An enjoyable peek into human history from a genetic perspective.

"Elixir" is one of the many books by Brian Fagan, The Long Summer: How Climate Changed Civilization, Floods, Famines, and Emperors: El Nino and the Fate of Civilizations,  that deals with paleoclimate and its effects through history on human societies.  In this instance he looks specifically at water and its uses by human beings, both modern and ancient, of various technological levels.  As in his book The Great Warming: Climate Change and the Rise and Fall of Civilizations, he notes that the more technologically innovative the society and the more wedded to agriculture it is, the more vulnerable it is to sudden, long term and extreme climate changes.  He cites world wide examples, some of them also described in "The Great Warming," to illustrate his point.For the most part it would appear that higher technological societies are a victim of their own success.  By divorcing themselves from the transhumanance of hunter-gather societies and thereby from the natural tendency toward smaller populations, the settled groups became subject to the upwardly spiraling demands of increased population, to diseases arising from crowding and from living close to herd animals, and to episodic malnutrition during climatic downturns.  The author--and others writing on the topic of early agriculture--suggest that far from being a superior lifestyle to that of the hunter-gather, farming as a way of life tended to anchor individuals to a location near water and decent soil, reducing the surrounding abundance of wild plants and animals by a continued need for land.  He also noted that while the benefits of society accrued to a few elite individuals, it was often not the primary producers who benefited from surpluses.  Thus by subjecting land to management, people subjected themselves to management and ultimately to a far less satisfying life; that fact continues into our own times.In gradually worsening climate, those having invested ever more time, energy and materials into a location were loathed to leave it.  Furthermore, the damage that agricultural pursuits wrecked on the natural environment by over exploitation meant that there were fewer emergency food sources during hard times and more people making demands on what there was.  Given that increased population pressure ensured that even the less desirable property was harnessed to feed the increased number of mouths and at further and further distances from the core development, when transhumanance became necessary, there were  often people already in the region where a migratory people might go.  Unless the various groups had participated in some form of reciprocal helping strategie, as they may have done among some of the early societies of the American Southwest,  (David E. Stuart describes some of these strategies and how some may have failed because of drought and water shortage in his book, Anasazi America: Seventeen Centuries on the Road from Center Place) the migrating people may not have been welcome, and war may have ensued.  (My little short story, The Tale of Little Crane: A Fairy Tale for All Ages is a parable based on this idea.)  The history of the Ancient Near East is rife with stories of migratory people living in marginal regions suddenly overwhelming settled society during periods of climate change.  (The author describes this as a "pump" phenomenon in this book and in The Great Warming.)  In some regions like the Maya Yucatan, the drought may have been so widespread that there were no close places to which to migrate. (Richardson Gill describes this in great detail in his book The Great Maya Droughts: Water, Life, and Death).It was interesting, to read the author's take on great droughts, especially that of the Maya penninsula, since he is disinclined to see a "migration" of people and wholesale death of large numbers in a drought ridden region.  (Richardson Gill's work on the subject makes very grim reading, though his work is also very extensive in its discussion on the effects of global climate change.)  Rather he sees individual families as deciding to leave the area, and moving to other locations, probably to relatives or reciprocal help groups, long before the duration of the drought has taken its toll.Along the lines of the "fitness landscape" of the Santa Fe Institute in its very interesting discussion of The Origins of Order: Self-Organization and Selection in Evolution, those with less desirable land--i.e. lower on the peak of fitness--would be the first to abandon it, having less to lose by moving across a possibly bleak landscape to another peak.  Those in a better place to ride out the drought and with a great deal to lose--i.e. those at the peak of the fitness landscape--would remain until the drought proved an agricultural life to be unsustainable irrespective of the human investment.  These people would either leave or die.  In either case, the culture to which their control of resources had given rise would certainly go extinct.  Dr. Fagan discribes a number of these episodes including the Moche and some of the dynasties of China and Southeast Asia.It would appear that the concept of "meme," (The Meme Machine (Popular Science), is very applicable here.  The "idea" of farming spread widely, and while the immediate consequences might have been positive, the ultimate outcomes were often not.  The meme, like the gene however, is oblivious to the wellbeing and happiness of the carrier; it just mindlessly promotes its own replication.  While there is much debate about the usefulness of the meme concept, it certainly seems applicable in this instance.  The lifestyle to which the human dedication to agriculture has given rise is certainly far more convenient--for those at the top of the heap anyway--even if not necessarily happier than living a life of constant movement in search of food.  As the author points out, however, it also leads us further and further out on a limb of unsustainability that may lead to a major disaster in the not too distant future!Just as in his book on the Chaco culture, Chaco Canyon: Archaeologists Explore the Lives of an Ancient Society, Dr. Fagan notes that climate can change abruptly and can leave a high risk population with few alternatives.  He seems to extol the water management skills of the simpler cultures that make use of gravity alone for their needs.  He notes that gradually mechanizing and enlarging society's demands and forcing nature to give up its water supplies beyond its abilities to recharge them, has brought many civilizations to extinction.  The reader is left in no doubt that this applies to the demands of our own world; the entire last chapter, "Mastery?" is dedicated to examples of modern societies blindly pushing nature to its limits.  Like Life's Matrix: A Biography of Water, by  Philip Ball, there are a number of warnings about damage to non-renewable water sources and about the future changes that global warming may bring to even those resources that have not been stretched to the limits by human demands.  As he points out, water may be the next "oil" crisis.  It is undoubtely in our best interests to pay attention to that fact, but given that not everyone is on the same page and that many vested interests have reasons to prevent any changes, it seems unlikely that we will be able to avoid these perils.

I wrote a review shortly after getting the TV and was quite happy with the product.  Lately I've had problems with the TV turning itself off and on indefinitely without ever really staying on for use.  I've been told it's a problem with the capacitor and in doing a little research on the issue have discovered that it is actually a problem known to Samsung and one they're not to really dealing with.  When I called their help number they told me they'd replace the capacitor but would not cover the repair costs.  From other reviews I've seen on Amazon, I see that repair costs range from 300-$400.  I'm on a fixed income these days and the TV was sort of my last splurg.  It's a pain to discover that I was actually one of the lucky ones because my TV lasted almost 3 years; apparently others have had theirs go after mere months.  Not a good long term buy.  Color great, sound good, picture quality wonderful, electrical problems a royal pain!!!

Brian Fagan's "Chaco Canyon," like many of his other works (The Little Ice Age: How Climate Made History, 1300-1850, The Great Warming: Climate Change and the Rise and Fall of Civilizations, Floods, Famines, and Emperors: El Nino and the Fate of Civilizations), deals with climate and its effect on the human condition, here the ancient pueblo societies of the American Southwest.  Chaco Canyon as an archaeological entity is a series of abandoned settlements dating from roughly 800 A.D. to 1100 A.D.  The book is a discussion of its archaeology, culture, history, probable social trajectory, and likely reasons for abandonment.Although the book discusses climate at some length, as readers of other books by the author will notice, it does not go into lengthy detail about the air and ocean currents that bring about these changes.  He does discuss the drought years, where they occurred, how long they lasted and how native people responded to these changes at different times.  He sees the entire phenomenon of the Chaco rise and decline as a human response to climatic changes.  Interestingly he notes that their flexible response to these changes allowed them to endure in the area for a long time despite drought conditions.  He credits their heavy investment in agriculture with an increase in population and a gradual limiting of their options to remain flexible that brought about the final abandonment of the area.  Severe drought contributed, yes, but an inability to rely on former practices because of the destruction of habitat was the prime factor.  If this is true, it definitely has implications for our own society.More than anything this study is a narrative of the archaeological history of the region, beginning in the late 19th century and continuing to the present day.  The author notes the change of focus and techniques of each generation of workers at the numerous canyon sites and what they contributed to our understanding of the region and its people.  I was particularly impressed with his unwillingness to engage in the pointless condemnation of earlier fieldworkers and their motives; not all authors have been this gracious.  I was especially impressed by his admiration for the patience and focus that field researchers exhibit and the minutia that they mine from the data to contribute to a thorough picture of ancient culture.  (I've always been more impressed with their apparent willingness to work in very unpleasant conditions; anthropologists, archaeologists, field geologists and paleontologists all seem to end up working for months on end in barren deserts dealing with heat, dust, snakes, spiders, limited water, etc.!  An online friend, an Austrailian field geologist Roger McEvily positively thrives on it!  That's dedication!)The book discusses some of the research techniques that have developed over the past decades that allow archaeologists to gain a clearer picture of the life of the area, particularly at some of the larger "Great House" sites like Pueblo Bonito.  Building styles, construction techniques, pottery characteristics, and burial modes are all discussed with respect to what they have to say about contemporary society.  Though such discussions in other books can be pretty burdensome to the average reader--I know because I've read some of them--this volume does not carry it to extremes.  The author acknowledges that there is much information out there but that the casual reader is not necessarily going to benefit from an in depth exposé.  Instead he gives short sidebars of information that illuminate the facts he provides in context.  His excellent endnotes give a number of resources for those interested in further information about the various aspects of the material record.The author, who admits to being a "parachutist" in his archaeological approach, puts much of the data in the context of the entire region, addressing such points as whether the Chaco culture had close ties to other areas, whether these associations went beyond kin ties to actual domination of other regions, etc.  I was very impressed with his ability to stay within the limits of what the data can actually tell us about these issues.  Unlike others who make more flamboyant claims for these people, Dr. Fagan points out specific data that lend support to or tend to contradict such claims.  I thought it was a very balanced discussion of these themes.While some authors seem to buy into the fairytale of the southwest, seeing conquest, hierarchies, exotic trade goods travelling on major highways through the desert, and a great collapse, Dr. Fagan sees small, insular populations that cooperated with extended kin groups in important projects and in times of need.  He sees a population that probably shared many of the common beliefs and behaviors of other subsistence farmers around the world and particularly those that still occupy the southwest, behaviors and beliefs shaped by the realitites of nature.  Where others see "collapse and migration," Dr. Fagan sees worsening conditions and a gradual disbursal of individual families from the area to other regions where they shared kin ties and reciprocity obligations.  Those on more marginal land probably moved first and not until there were few to no outside groups around them from whom to draw support did those living in the Great Houses depart as well. They had the most to leave behind having invested greatly in their buildings and agricultural projects.  He--and others--see groups like the Hopi and Zuni as being modern descendants of the Chaco people.  Since these modern heirs to the region share myths of kinship with the ancestors of the abandoned sites and visit them for spiritual input, I suspect he's correct.Interesting and informative book.

Most of Dr. Fagan's books have to with paleoclimatology (The Little Ice Age: How Climate Made History, 1300-1850, The Long Summer: How Climate Changed Civilization, Floods, Famines, and Emperors: El Nino and the Fate of Civilizations) and the effects of sustained types of weather on human society.  This one is no exception.  Having looked at the Little Ice Age in a previous book, he now looks at its opposite, the Medieval Warm Period, a climatic event that has reprocussions for our own future.Studied from proxies for environmental change preserved in ice cores, sea and lake bed sediments, and tree ring data, the history of climate both locally and globally can be illuminated with fair accuracy, revealing the environmental conditions under which contemporary societies lived their lives.  The Little Ice Age brought with it both winners and losers as global climate changed, with wetter, cooler regions in usually dry areas and colder, drier or stormier conditions in other areas.  Populations of people, less numerous at the time, moved into or out of areas as conditions changed, shaping the course of history.  (I was once invited to go on an expedition that was to explore the Katarah Depression in the Western Desert in Egypt looking for evidence of a settled society that lived around the oases during a wetter time in Egypt's climatic pre-history.) It is thus no surprise that the Medieval Warm Period also saw winners and losers with people moving into or out of adversely affected areas, again shaping history at least locally.Dr. Fagan suggests that climate is a history shaper.  He looks at some of the world's most significant historic events, like the migrations of Genghis Khan and his Mongolian people, the collapse of the Maya and the Moche in Central and South America and the migration of the Pueblo people out of the affected areas of the American Southwest, as the outcome of environmental changes that made top heavy, centralized civilizations collapse under their own weight.  When droughts diminished the agricultural output on which they depended, these societies ceased to exist as entities.  Each of the book's illustrations is covered in limited detail and could support a book on its own---in fact some have entire books on the subject well worth the reading (The Great Maya Droughts: Water, Life, and Death, Anasazi America: Seventeen Centuries on the Road from Center Place, The Tiwanaku: Portrait of an Andean Civilization (Peoples of America), etc.).  Certainly he makes a clear case for the instability of agricultural societies in both China and India where populations have historically been very large and consequently climate disasters of staggering proportions.What makes this episode in climate history so significant is that it provides a window into the possible future as our own climate swings into a heat overdrive.  As Dr. Fagan suggests, however, it is grist to the argument mill for both those who believe climate change to be an urgent matter in need of attention and to those who think it's just "business as usual on the old home planet, and we made it through it last time."  The author makes a very cogent point when he writes of winners and losers and of the staggering number of fatalities and human misery that resulted from these changes in the weather of an age.  It's not about "making it through it;" it's about who will and who won't make it through it.  He also points out that much of the globe bares far greater numbers of people than it did during the Great Warming and in many places already far greater than the agricultural carrying capacity of the land.  Climate changes like those of The Great Warming will cause even larger migrations, greater chances of military violence, higher mortality rates, and far greater social disruption if and when they occur.  No one will be able to opt out of the chaos.Far more interesting are the implications in this scenario.  Great civilizations were not immune to the downsides of the climate change of their era.  In fact they were even more susceptible to it, because they encouraged, though indirectly, population growth and an increased use of even marginal land for agriculture.  This put them on a "fitness landscape," to quote the self organizing criticality group at Santa Fe Institute and other institutions, (At Home in the Universe: The Search for the Laws of Self-Organization and Complexity and how nature works: the science of self-organized criticality), that prevented them from morphing easily into something else, and the civilization collapsed.  Modern day First World countries seem to think their technological advances will indemnify them from abrupt change, but they may be in for a big surprise.  They could find themselves unable to respond rapidly enough to changes or to be able to deal with the massive numbers of migrants fleeing the climatic devastation of their former homelands.Interesting are some of the self defeating behaviors that we practice in the US and that put many areas in danger of irreparable long term danger.  My favorite is the massive draw-down of the Ogallala aquifer that supplies eight of the western and southwestern states including Nevada.  I had once read that there had been more water in that aquifer than in Lake Superior, and that it is and was being rapidly consumed, much of it by Las Vegas.  I'm not sure that it is rechargeable, but even if it is, much of the mountain run off from melting snow upon which that process depends may cease to exist if warmer drier conditions overtake the system.  This may well leave Las Vegas a ghost town in the future.  Likewise California, Arizona and Nevada have already had dust-ups, as early as the 1920s and 30's, over the water of the Colorado River upon which their heavily populated cities and the irrigation agriculture of each depend.  While daming the river in the 1930s and routing the water according to legally established guidelines helped stay the violence, the Colorado is a mere shadow of itself these days and the western states are again facing a waterless future.  Just like the Maya and the Moche, we might have poised ourselves for collapse, at least in some regions, by the growing dearth of water in those areas.Still more interesting is what the author says of the collapse of areas where lack of water was often not the problem.  He discusses the Moche of Peru, the Chinese, and India as suffering as much from a superabundance of water and the resulting effects of floods as from droughts.  In the US, where there is abundant water, there is also sometimes major flooding.  Much of the richest agricultural property in the country, land that feeds not only the US population but many countries overseas as well, occupies flood plains that are occasionally devastated by the heavy rains in watershed areas upstream.  These seem to be increasing in frequency--the 100 year crest levels coming almost every other year if not every year--and in quantity of water drained.  Those of this year (2011) are a prime example.  The loss of agricultural production will have serious implications not only for the US but for many of the world's poorer countries.That things are changing is becoming overwhelmingly apparent.  Even if one looks upon the weather statistics as just extreme variations around a norm, there are other indicators that suggest that something unusual is going on in the world.  That climate's effects on human society have already begun is becoming clearer with each decade.  Problems in Africa, the Middle East, Central and South America, and India are already causing social unrest and/or migration.  Some of this is due to the fact that elites have everything they want but that the bulk of the population, never well provided for to begin with, is starting to suffer considerable want in even the basics.  As the author states, many areas in the third world have neither adequate clean drinking water nor decent sanitation.Egypt, actually a very progressive Middle Eastern country with universal education and health care, fed the world during the Roman Empire and during the early Islamic period; now it can barely feed itself.  Population there when I first visited the country in 1979 was 40 million people spread along the thin strips of green land on either side of the Nile and in the fertile and well watered Delta area.  The fellaheen had a difficult go of it even then, with national activists pointing out their plight and the government making efforts to encourage reduced birth rates.  Almost 40 years later, about two generations among the fellaheen or one and a half among the middle and upper classes, Egypt supports 80 million people on the same property and faces the same issues.  Now it shares out what there is among twice the number of mouths.  It's no wonder there was a political revolution; however, it remains to be seen if an appropriate social revolution will follow that can save the country from total disaster.In the US illegal immigration has gone from a trickle to a deluge in the Southwestern part of the country, encouraging some of the affected states to enact laws that will limit the flood.  Violence is not unknown along the borders and citizens in these states are feeling a threat.  That migrating people are escaping very difficult living conditions in their respective countries is obvious in the fact that they are willing to undergo great discomfort, even death, at considerable financial cost to their families just to get into the US to find work, any work.  Even some of the drug wars suffered by Mexico may be in part due to a need to rechannel labor into something that brings in more income for unemployed farmers and urban poor than farming now can.  If that is the case, the war between drug trafficers and the central government will be ongoing, violent, and unwinnable by the government because there are too many people at the bottom of society who have too much to lose if they abandon it.Though history is not a repeatable thing according to historians and scientists of complexity theory (Ubiquity: The Science of History . . . or Why the World Is Simpler Than We Think, Ubiquity: Why Catastrophes Happen), it does tell us one important thing about the world.  As one of my geology texts said, "If it has happened, it CAN happen."  This says nothing, of course about when, where, how or how big, but it definitely tells you that it can and will, and when it does, "this is what it looks like!"  Experience also tells us where it's likely to occur.  It may not, but I'd hedge my bets and plan for it.  Long lives gave our ancestors "elders" who could remember longer and longer periods of events that helped them survive changes.  Over the course of a 50 year life span, a lot of odd things happen at least once--I know they have in mine!  Modern society has recorded memory and scientific enquirey that extends these "memories" even further back in time.  If we don't make use of it, we suffer the consequences.An interesting--though somewhat depressing--book.

I can't help but wonder what personal crises in Professor Sykes' life make him so completely down on his own gender!  While the book contains a wealth of information on genetics, its technology, practices and results, I find it a little difficult to believe that a single gene can have the "ambitions" that he ascribes to it.  I have to admit that he puts the arguments forward logically enough.  Not being a geneticist myself, I certainly find it difficult to argue the point.  All of the research and many of the author's case histories, including his own family history, make the book much more interesting than dry data would be, and a good place for those interested in the subject to start.I had heard of the Genghis Khan data before, the first time as the spread of the famous "blue spot" at the base of the spine among a large modern day population which is apparently a legacy of the Great Khan.  The actual relatedness of the various clans of the MacDonalds was new to me, although the relatedness of the Cohans, which had been discussed in journals some time ago, is very similar to it and much more impressive.The entire history of the discovery and interpretation of the Y-chromosome is well worth the price of the book.  I had no idea how clever the early scientists had had to be to narrow down the entire data set prior to the current technological advances.  There are a lot of very smart people out there.I found the author's discussion of homosexuality particularly interesting.  I have to admit that I've often wondered if it doesn't arise when population density and violence affect the sense of well being and safety of women.  While I could see a chromosomal origin for the characteristic, it seems much more likely to me that it would be a hormonal thing, perhaps methalation or demethalation of segments of DNA to take them off-line or activate them.  It's not that homosexual males can't be violent, but their stereotype is for greater compassion, a nurturing behavior, and less aggressiveness; I can't believe that that stereotype has absolutely no reality to it.  If certain hormones, such as cortasol or other chemicals involved in stress, reach a critical level in the mother's blood perhaps the fetus, while its gender is already determined chromosomally, may have its behavior altered in such a way that it is less likely to lead to increased violence in the mother's vicinity.  Alternatively--or additionally--it may lead to a greater likelihood of the survival of that child in an environment that is frought with violent male behavior.The whole discussion of mitochondrial DNA sabotage of the Y-chromosome was also very interesting, because I have recently met a person whose daughter seems unable to carry a male child to term.  The possibilty that it is similar to the rH problem might give researchers a handle on the problem so couples are able to have the children they want without so much heart ache.I had already read the author's book, The Seven Daughters of Eve: The Science That Reveals Our Genetic Ancestry, and was amazed at the degree to which human travels and disbursal times could be determined from genetic studies of mDNA.  This book does for the Y-chromosome and the male line what that one did for women.  It was interesting to see the data on migrations during the Norse invasions.  Having studied the period from historic and archeological points of view, seeing the degree to which genetics could clarify it even more was amazing.  I had taken a course on archaeology of the Anglo-Saxon era in England and was amazed at what the data suggested of the period.  More than a "take-over" of the land from the inhabitants, it would appear that much of the land had been emptied by the withdrawal of military personal--and presumably their families--back to Italy to protect Rome from invasion.  Furthermore the Anglo-Saxon cemetaries yielded burials that suggested that while the men may have been from Europe, many of their wives were drawn from the local population.  It would be interesting to see if the genetics also suggested this, as it sometimes did according to Dr. Sykes for the Norse population movements.Fascinating discussion.

I had read the Jared Diamond's books Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies and Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed: Revised Edition quite some while ago and was thoroughly impressed with the author's incisive look at humans in the natural world, particularly their effect on the other members of Earth's biota and on one another.  The former book is an absolute classic and makes such thorough sense of what occurred in and after the 15th century that it should be required reading in most history courses.  These and the present book are often cited in works by other authors, and since I had not read The Third Chimpanzee, I thought it was about time.There is a lot of very interesting information in the book.  Though some of it I had read before in other contexts, here what are fragments of data in other books are arranged in a way that their importance to the whole picture of human history can be more easily understood and appreciated.  The author definitely has a handle on the wider perspective.  As a naturalist and professor of physiology, he sees humanity as "Homo sapiens," and animal much like other animals.I had read about the concept and content of "Indo-European" languages years ago when studying ancient history.  It was known even in the late 19th and early 20th century that the shared words of various languages probably belonged to the parent, but I was still very intrigued by the more recent ideas about the primary homeland of the speakers of the early language, their lifestyle and their degree of connectedness with modern languages and people.  Diamond is quite honest, however, about what professional researchers in the field of linguistics think about these efforts, which is not much.What surprised me the most about language, however, was the degree to which other animals also "speak" in their own way.  I suspect anyone with a pet comes to realize their capacity to communicate with their owners on subjects of interest to them! Animal art is also something I'd heard of before--I knew that the Phoenix Zoo had an elephant that painted--but as the author states, the artists in this case live in captivity, are subject to human contact, and have very little else to do.  I worked as a volunteer at the Minnesota Zoo for a year and often wondered how the animals kept from going completely insane in such a small fragment of what would have been their ranges in the wild.  Perhaps participating in "art therapy," especially for the brighter inmates was a good outlet for a mental life no longer devoted to the rigorous activity necessary to ensuring safety and nutrition.  As the author points out, observations in the wild have yet to observe these same animals participating in art projects---though he indicates elephants in the wild do make designs in the dust with their trunks.The book is also a little depressing.  Unlike Clive Finlayson's book The Humans Who Went Extinct: Why Neanderthals Died Out and We Survived, which suggested simple chance put paid to the Neanderthals rather than aggression from our own species, Diamond--and many others--seems inclined to lay the whole affair at our doorstep.  Similarly he convicts us of destroying the megafauna of North America.  In fact, he, like Bryan Sykes, Adam's Curse: A Future without Men, seems to see humans as thoroughly destructive animals.  From the evidence of our current world, I'd have to agree.  In The Sixth Extinction: Patterns of Life and the Future of Humankind Roger Lewin and Richard Leakey liken the spread of humans throughout the world as a cancerous, terminal disease of the biosphere and opine as to whether the rise of intelligent life isn't the end stage of the disease.  While Dr. Diamond does not seem quite this negative, I suspect he might agree to some extent.

They so have Great Danes down in this movie.  It was a delight.  Having had three of them at one time or another, I can definitely guarantee it.  Seeing Marmaduke sit on the couch, like a human would do, reminded me so much of my first Dane, Courageous who used to sit side by side with me watching TV.  Even the fictional character's unwillingness to engage in a fight with another dog was so like my dogs.  It was sort of "let's discuss this" with Courageous.  Even the dominant dog in the park scene was familiar.  I took my dog Tempo to a dog park starting as a puppy.  A cane corso mounted him every time to prove he was dominant over Tempo.  Then one day he walked up to Tempo, saw that his butt was actually too high up off the ground to actually even attempt it, and just walked away.  After that it never came up again.  Taking the human for a walk, even the complaints about hearing the comments about "where's the saddle?" all the time are also familiar!  For anyone who has never had the blessing of being loved by one of these wonderful animals, this is a perfect introduction.  I adored my Danes and loved the movie.

Although I'm not sure I go along with the Multi-regional Theory of human evolution, I do think that Clive Finleyson's book "The Human's Who Went Extinct" touches on some very cogent points that often get overlooked or glossed over by those with their eyes on the Out of Africa Hypothesis.  I certainly found them enlightening and have tried to incorporate them into my own way of thinking about the human species.More than anything, while authors often give lip service to the fact that people are animals too, they often neglect what that actually entails especially for early humans.  Many of the patterns of behavior among early people, regardless of their genus and species, were dictated by necessity and what was possible--even by sheer luck.  These writers also seem to ignore the fact that most genera have more than one species in it and that those few that don't are usually under some degree of distress.  I think this is something we should pay more attention to than we do when we look at our Neanderthal cousins as "failures," since it has ramifications for our own kind. In this context the author points out that this means that, far from one species "succeeding" another and winning the sweepstakes, there may have been many types of humans alive at any one time, each occupying their own little niche, much as other species in other genera do.  That our co-genera species are no longer with us may have something important to tell us about our own contract with Mother Nature.  One does not usually blame most extinct species for being "too dumb to live," as we are prone to do with our own ancient ancestors and their peers.  All species are suited to the environment in which they evolved; it's only when nature changes the game plan that they may find themselves in trouble.  The author makes this evident in his work on human species as well.  I found that refreshing.From the point of view of the archeologist, dealing with material remains from such a long time ago, the author notes that there isn't much by way of fossil evidence.  He notes that many grand theories that massage the hubris of modern man's notion of himself have been built on next to no evidence.  What there is of cultural material is biased toward what lasts in the record, stone and pottery--what there is of it.  As he points out, this gives a much skewed perspective of what happened and who brought it about.  His most interesting contribution is a discussion of just what technology is useful in what environment.  Here he notes that it is probably the habitat in which any given human found himself that dictated the materials employed, what shapes were created and how the resulting tools were used; and not the intellect or the species of the individual user.  He makes a number of references to modern, non-human animals who perform many of the feats of hunting and even trans-marine travel without nearly the mental ability of our distant ancestors and their contemporaries.  I think this is very important.  It is perhaps uncomfortable for us to believe that Neanderthal or Heidelberg men could become extinct, at least without our help, unless they were somehow mentally or physically defective.  (This attitude brings to mind the old biases regarding races other than "our own.")  To do otherwise puts us in the awkward position of having to admit that our success has as much to do with dumb luck as it does with our much vaunted "brain."  It also makes it more evident that our luck could just "run out" one of these days just as it did for other species of human in the past.  Here the author refers often to Jarod Diamond's Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies which makes similar points about the European contact with the inhabitants of the Americas.I found the author's reference to the ranges of some modern animals, particularly the collared dove, very interesting and grounding.  One tends to forget that the "great migrations" of our distant ancestors took place as they did and do with other animals and not as some grand manifest destiny.  As population density increases, part of the group moves over a bit to have space and resources with which to raise their own "kids."  Over generations, the range of the species expands until it hits some obstacle it can't go over or around.  If major change occurs pockets of species may remain in refugia waiting for better times.  If better times fail to come along, these populations may become extinct.  With humans one tends to get the impression of a great "mission" or "destiny" with the expansion of ancient human populations that just isn't there anymore than it is for other animals.  Even in more recent times, most people left their homes to find new ones so that they could promote their own interests.  While a Genghis Khan might bring about a major migration for the purpose of conquest in the post agricultural world, in the pre-agricultural world this is most unlikely to have been a motivator.  For one thing, "conquest" or "exploration," even "migration" would have to have been concepts that could even have arisen, and I'm not sure they could or did at the time.  It's very unlikely that the ancestors of the Native Americans suddenly decided to mass migrate from Siberia to North America one day.One of the issues that the author brings up with respect to which individuals survive hard times to populate the environment was particularly interesting and relevant.  As he notes, it was those who lived marginal existences around a settled and conservative population that managed to navigate through whatever bottleneck occurred.  This seems to have been the case with most plants and animals.  He also suggests that the modern individual is essentially as "domesticated" as are the plants and animals upon which and with which he or she lives.  The "wild form" of our own species is rapidly being crowded out of existence.  While no human is less "modern" than another, some live closer to the "wild" existence than most of us do.  In the event that a catastrophe occurs that brings about the collapse of society as we know it, it would be this "wild" population that would probably repeople the world--that is if we've allowed them to continue to exist--because they have the greatest experience with "making do" with almost nothing. I know I couldn't; I'm not sure I'd even want to. We might remember that destroying the dissenters of the world--like those living in the mountains of Afghanistan, the forests of South America and other marginal areas--may well put paid to the human experiment if and when Mother Nature decides she's had about enough.

"The First Human" by Ann Gibbons was a bit of an eye opener for me.  Although I have studied anthropology at the college level and have followed it in the popular literature since then, I had not realized how much ego went into the research.  I guess I'd expected disagreements and arguments; that's what science is all about, thrashing out the "true" story of how nature works.  But I'd expected respectful discourse.  After the book though, I ended up thinking that not many of the key researchers in the field were really very nice people and that I'm glad I didn't/don't know any of them!In general Ms Gibbons' account suggests individuals who are vain, selfish, horrendously competitive, cut throat, and sometimes not entirely ethical.  It's a wonder that anything actually gets done in the field.  I suspect there are those who feel it doesn't.  More than anything this not terribly flattering account of anthropology suggests just how much resilience science as a field actually has, since it manages to make progress DESPITE rather than BECAUSE of the motives and agendas of individual scientists.  This has been pointed out by other scientists in other fields before, most notably physics, but "The First Human" makes a definite statement of the fact:  The "SYSTEM of science" is what corrects and redirects what is known about the natural world.  Medical research is another case in point.  It has been suggested that science makes a leap forward whenever a given generation of researchers passes away, relaxing their grip on their field of interest.What makes anthropology and the origin of humankind a difficult field is that the specimens from which composite concepts and developmental phylogenies must be drawn are few and far between.  Even their exact relationship to one another is a matter of disagreement.  Clive Finlayson takes up this issue in The Humans Who Went Extinct: Why Neanderthals Died Out and We Survived and does a brilliant job of approaching the problem from an ecologist's point of view.  When the fact that careers are made and fortunes and grants acquired on the basis of having the "right" fossil specimen and the "right" understanding of human evolution, one wonders that the disputes aren't more lethal than they are!  There certainly seems to be a "survival of the fittest" among academics that is a component in research activities.  I agree with the late Steven Haines, the anthropology corriculum needs to add a combat 101 course!

This is a nice little book of holiday patterns.  Essentially many of the designs are combinations of patterns that have been used in more complex doilies, but here they have been rearranged to create lovely angels, trees, stars, and snowflakes.  Anyone who has actually mastered the mechanics of tatting--pulling the right thread to make a slip knot rather than the wrong one and creating a plain old knot--can perform these patterns.  Interestingly, there is a nice pattern using half of the tattting knot, something one doesn't often see.  For those beginners who find the simpler diagrams a difficult way to learn, you might try Beginning Tatting:  A Lesson Book: Arts and Crafts Collection.

I'd never tried adding beads to my tatting before and was surprised at how easy it actually is to do.  Although I didn't add as many beads to my projects for my own book on tatting, Beginning Tatting:  A Lesson Book: Arts and Crafts Collection, I actually learned a lot by actually trying it after seeing this book.

I have this little book and love some of the patterns in it.  I've tatted for over 45 years and have also written a "learn how" book on the subject, Beginning Tatting:  A Lesson Book: Arts and Crafts Collection, yet I still collect pattern books like this one and have a large collection of them.  (In my opinion you can't have too many!) Even if you're an accomplished lace maker, there are new ideas, especially those for the use of tatting, that can add to your repertoire of patterns and techniques.

I wasn't sure if I'd enjoy these stories or not, but I decided to give them a try.  I was concerned that they would all be "tear jerkers," capitalizing on the viewer's love of animals by dealing with sick and dying animals in a maudlin manner.  While to some extent this is true, it was more of a natural mix of real stories.  Based as it is on the semi-autobiographical novels of James Herriot, a veterinarian who practiced in Northern England during the early part of the 20th century, the stories are a delightful concatenation of animal stories and the lives of some of the eccentric people in the area--my favorites being Mrs. Pumphry and her pekinese Tricky Woo.  (At one point after James tells the wealthy lady that the dog must get more exercise, she has her gardiner carry the dog around the garden three times a day).  The interactions among the central characters, the brothers Siegfried and Tristan Farnan, the "new" vet James and his wife Helen Harriot, and the marvelous housekeeper Mrs. Hall are wonderfully balanced.  The acting is exceptional, creating a sense of real people, people one would like to know.  There are disagreements, as there are in any family, pranks and jokes, and a loving support in hard times. (When a dog owner takes his own life after his pet must be put down, James feels responsible for the man's death and is supported by his wife and friends, subsequently able to rise to the occasion when another pet owner threatens suicide in a similar incident).  In the background is the rising threat of WWII; knowning as the viewer does that the charming world of these people will be irrevocably altered once the storm breaks, makes each episode a treasure to be remembered, and one can empathize with Siegfried when he sits on a hillside trying to remember every nuance of the landscape as it is before it is lost forever.  By the end of the series, when the two senior vets go off to take part in the war, the viewer feels all the emotional tugs of seeing close friends leave without any assurance that they will ever return again, and sharing a clear knowledge that even if and when they do, things will never be quite the same again.  I think in part that intensity comes from our own experience with the world as it passes from the "once upon a time" into the vague and distant future.

The King's Speech was probably one of the best films I've seen in a long time.  While I can't say that the central character was a "true" likeness of the future king of England during World War II, I think as a dramatic creation he certainly "rings true."  Colin Firth did a fantastic job of portraying him.  The sense of frustration, anxiety, sadness, and isolation he created for his character was amazing.Most surprising I think, though it probably shouldn't have been, is the degree to which the prince was subject to what would be considered patent child abuse today.  It probably shouldn't have been, since the power that came to individuals favored by the king since childhood was often formidable, and the Prince of Wales was to have become king, not his younger brother.  The wonder isn't that he stuttered but that he wasn't considerably more impaired than he was by his experiences.  The fact that he could overcome his more overt signs of that oppressive upbringing with the help of the individual he consulted reveals his considerable determination as a person and the great emotional support he received as an adult from others in doing so.  His personal conflict over becoming the king was very poignant.  One is generally led to believe that individuals would--and did--kill to become king; watching someone try everything he could not to be was enlightening.  It also puts into perspective the desperate circumstances of former usurpers; the threats to them and to the country had to have been major, not only for one to undertake treason but for one to undertake the headaches of rule.The character of Wallis Simpson, while she did not appear often in the movie, was one that was pivotal to history.  She was well portrayed in the film; part real person, part public perception.  While I have not read her own history, I have read books in which she featured, and it would appear that she was part of the 19th century phenomenon usually practiced by wealthy 500 families in America, that of marrying a daughter to a financially strapped noble family, sort of  "aristocrat" by proxy.  I strongly suspect that Mrs. Simpson, who was definitely not of the 500, expected to "make the big time" in terms of American social climbing by becoming a reigning queen; in that she definitely misread the British people of the time--and when it came to the monarchy, everyone below the king was "the British people!"  Morganatic marriages are not something that is well accepted even today, as questions of Kate Middleton's "commoner" status suggest.  The divorced status of Camilla Bowles brought her future as "queen" into question for a long time.One of the things I found most intriguing was the king's status under parliamentary government.  It would appear that whereas the kings of earlier times were themselves often guilty of abusing the "people," their function in more recent times has been as a focus of power that moderates the abuses of the people's own elected government.  Elected parliament members might have short term personal agendas, but the hereditary monarch can and does take the long term point of view; England is more-or-less his "estate," and he doesn't want to go "out of business!"  I'm not sure if this impression is true or not, but it certainly seemed to be in the film.

I've been reading this type of book since the 1970s, and there were still things that had confused me about some of the common topics.  I found this one made many of them much clearer.  I found the author's approach to his subject rather clever, because so few authors look at such topics from the point of view of limits.  The mode is usually to imagine the possibilities as though there were no limits.  Some of the topics upon which the author expounds have to do with the inherent limits of the human mind/brain to comprehend and some are bounded by what can be known or more than inferred.  In this frame it is almost a philosophy of what is knowable.While the book is probably a little oversimplified for anyone who has read on this topic for any length of time, it is a good place to start.  The similes are clear and are rarely taken to extremes.  It also reveals how physicists approach their subject and how, when and why breakthroughs occur.

I felt that this book was written and published a little too soon, possibly so that its information could be put to use for financial reasons before a lot of it was publically up for grabs.
