It was a beautifully painful and real romance full of clandestine meetings, illicit touches, and stolen kisses. I was hooked from the very first chapter. Miz Raeder has a wonderful way with the written word, making it both poetic and visual. She created two characters I was immediately drawn to and had me hanging on every word. And then there is the way that she writes the sex scenes--filling them with so much tension and passion and emotion. You can feel every touch, every breath. It will knock your darn socks off! You do not want to miss this salacious and evocative romance.

Rating: B+ ... Heat: SizzlingOh, these two crazy kids. Cela and Foster, what am I going to do with you? When we last left them, Foster went uber-dominant and, though coming from a loving place, wanted to basically LoJack Cela. Used to being smothered by her dad, there was no way that shit was going to fly. So, Cela flew--away from Dallas and Foster.After a lot of time apart and experiencing the not-so-wonderful joys of working for her dad, Cela's missing Foster. All of him. Still not understanding her submissive needs, she can't help but fantasize nightly about what Foster would do to her. And she might even be imagining naughtier, rougher scenarios than they'd experienced together--craving things Foster didn't have a chance to show her. For Foster's part, he's been doing a lot of self-loving too. Plus sleepless nights spent consumed by Cela. When he realizes just what she means to him, off he goes to see her. See if she's happy or if she misses him like he misses her.This installment may be my favorite, as both characters had a good amount of growth. Hopefully the time apart made them reevaluate things and truly figure out exactly what they want. No more wishy-washiness. I don't think my heart or nerves can take more backpedaling--especially from Cela. I can cut her some slack, as she's a 23 year old former virgin and Foster is.... well, a whole lot of man... but, dang girl. Make up your mind. (And, really, it's Foster! No hard choice there, even if he is almost crazily protective.) With only one installment left, this one has left me clamoring for more. I need to read their HEA!

Like most of the reviews I was originally very happy with Roomba, and give it a very positive 5 star review, but the robot broke after less than a year. I learned not only is it very cheaply built, but its bad design leaves it vulnerable to the dust it is supposed to be designed to pick up.It turns out its parts are very vulnerable to dust which is a major issue for a vacuum cleaner. None of the gears, barings, or moving components are sealed so dust gets into them and they start to grind until they fail. Even the gears and bearings that drive the bushes are unsealed leaving them vulnerable to the dust and dirt they are designed to pick up.Eventually the brushes on the bottom stopped working. The tech support person confirmed that it was still under warranty, and that the problem was a documented know fault with the design. They how ever refused to replace it. The only thing they would offer was to send me new parts that I would have to replace my self. I explained I am not a tech of any kind and did not feel I was qualified to replace small gears that need to be precisely installed. They said sending me the parts was all they would do for me.

Seems focused on shock value not science.Like the first book there are some interesting ideas that can cause you step back and examen new ways of looking at things. Unlike the first book this one is much much less throw, and gives very little attention to ideas or data that do not support his concussions. Some of the theories are not based on any data at all, but instead uses assumptions that no evidence is provided to support. It gives the feel that the focus on this book was coming up with wild shocking conclusions to get attention and sell books rather than trying to get to accurate answers.As an example of the use of un-supported assumptions the "It is more dangers to walk drunk than drive drunk" conclusion is based on the assumption that people walk and drive the same number of miles drunk. Which seems unlikely. People are only likely to opt for walking if it is a short distance. If there is a long way to travel they are probably driving, getting a ride, or calling a cab.An example of poorly supported ideas. One of the arguments used against global warming is that both cars and cows produce green house gases. While true it ignores that cars produce much larger volumes of green house gases, making them much more damaging.

I have the blue version of these end caps they are beautiful and unique, and durable.  Lots of people ask about them, and where they can get them.  After four years there is no sign of aging, or damage.  They are holding up really well, and will likely outlast the wooden posts they are on.

I have the blue version of these end caps they are beautiful and unique, and durable.  Lots of people ask about them, and where they can get them.  After four years there is no sign of aging, or damage.  They are holding up really well, and will likely outlast the wooden posts they are on.

Despite the high price point this product is badly designed and poorly made.Problems:  1.  It does NOT effectively increase the humidity in the air.  2.  It is extremely loud.  3.  If you tap it and it tilts, even a small amount water will spill out of it.  4.  The opening to add water is on the bottom of the tank which gaurenties it will eventually start leaking.  5.  When you pull out the tank to re-fill it it drips a lot.Details  1.  It does NOT effectively increase the humidity in the air.  After running on it's maximum setting for three days it's own humidity sensor showed no increase in humidity.  2.  Makes a lot of fan noise, so if you are a lite sleeper you can not use it in bedrooms.  3.  It holds water in an open tray.  If you bump the unit and it tilts even a small amount water will spill out of it.  If it stays tilted or falls over the entire tank will pour out of it.  4.  The opening to add water is on the bottom of the tank.  There is a cap with a rubber seal to prevent leaking, but it is only a matter of time before the seal starts to wear out.  When that happens it will start to slowly leak.  The opening should be on the top to prevent this from ever being an issue.  5.  When you pull out the tank to re-fill it it drips a lot.

I have the 50 pint version of this model.  It started having problems freezing up after 4 - 6 months, and completely died after about a year.  Whirlpool will not honor the the 5 year warranty.  They require a bill of sale before they will even consider a warranty repair.  Even then you have to pay a service fee, and only some of the parts are covered.  So even if you have the receipt years later you will likely still have pay part if not all of the cost of repairs.

I have the 50 pint version of this model.  It started having problems freezing up after 4 - 6 months, and completly died after about a year.  Whirlpool will not honor the the 5 year warranty.  They require a bill of sale before they will even consider a warranty repair.  Even then you have to pay a service fee, and only some of the parts are covered.  So even if you have the receipt years later you will likely still have pay part if not all of the cost of repairs.

Like most of the reviews I was originally very happy with Roomba, and give it a very positive 5 star review, but the robot broke after less than a year.  I learned not only is it very cheaply built, but its bad design leaves it vulnerable to the dust it is supposed to be designed to pick up.It turns out its parts are very vulnerable to dust which is a major issue for a vacuum cleaner.  None of the gears, barings, or moving components are sealed so dust gets into them and they start to grind until they fail.  Even the gears and bearings that drive the bushes are unsealed leaving them vulnerable to the dust and dirt they are designed to pick up.Eventually the brushes on the bottom stopped working.  The tech support person confirmed that it was still under warranty, and that the problem was a documented know fault with the design.  They how ever refused to replace it.  The only thing they would offer was to send me new parts that I would have to replace my self.  I explained I am not a tech of any kind and did not feel I was qualified to replace small gears that need to be precisely installed.  They said sending me the parts was all they would do for me.

I was not expecting much from this product.  I have a very small yard, and just needed to do light weekly trimming.  So this seemed like a good option for me.  The convenience of cordless electric vs. gas.  With the trade off of less power and limited time.  Given that my needs where not very demanding I did not think it would matter.  I was wrong.  My low expectations still turned out to be too high.The product is:  1.  Under powered  2.  The batteries drain quickly  3.  Batteries need half a day to charge  4.  The batteries start to lose their charge as soon as they are un-plugged.1.  Under poweredEven the 18 volt model is lacking in power.  Just cutting grass can not be done in a single pass unless you move very slowly.  It will eventually get the job done, but it takes a log longer than with other products.2.  Batteries drain quicklyMy yard is very small.  It takes about 15 min to mow.  Even fully charge BOTH batteries will only last about 30min.  This is in part due to the second battery never being more than 1/2 charged.(See #4)  30min is just barely enough for my small yard given how slowly you have to go.  (See #1)  So I am always rushing to get done before both batteries go dead.3.  Batteries need half a day to chargeThe batteries realistically have to be plugged in over night to charge completely. After 3hr of charging they will only last about 5 - 10min.  Fully charged they only last about 20 min.  My other cordless power tools, not Black & Decker, only need around 2hr to charge, and last 1hr. - 6hr.4.  Batteries start to lose their charge as soon as they are un-plugged.I was originally impressed that they included two batteries.  I quickly realized that you really only have one and a half batteries at best.  You can only charge one battery at a time.  As soon as you un-plug the batteries they start to lose their charge.  So while you are charging one the other is always draining.  After a full day of being un-plugged the batteries will lose about half of their charge.  So even if you plan ahead and switch the charging batteries the night before the best you can expect are one and a half batteries.

I am an artsy type, but also lazy. I loved art class in school because I had a whole room full of supplies, though I hated cleaning up. I was really looking forward to using this software because it simulates all of that messy stuff which is fun to use but not convenient. Fun times ahead!It's mostly a fairly straightforward painting/editing program, but it has a whole ton of "brushes", both simulated real art tools (paint brushes, pens, spatulas, airbrushing, etc) and some wacky fun stuff like the "image hose" which lays down a trail of objects. If you're a skilled hand artist, or planning to become one, many of the brush types will be very useful in creating digital images which do look very much like they were created with brush, pen, or sponge strokes.However, for what I expected to be a pretty high-end piece of software, I was disappointed with some quirks.To avoid using the word "tool" (often used to refer to editing tools) and also avoid calling everything a "brush", I will refer to all simulated things as implements.Some of the implements are too perfect and constant, and obvious patterns show. The "loaded palette knife 2" strokes with a pattern you might expect from a scraping painter's knife, but it NEVER CHANGES, down to the pixel. And unlike some of the other implements, there's no rounding or smoothing of the stroke to make it look convincing. It's exactly what you would get by copying and dragging a row of pixels in a paint program on an old DOS box. See the uploaded image, it's loaded with patterned artifacts. Utterly useless. Some others had similar problems, but I remembered this knife as the worst.Some implements which rotate to match the stroke direction have a similar problem. They are completely 2-dimensional, and while they make delightful swirls of texture, they ALWAYS start and end with a completely flat row of pixels, just as no object in the univers would if used to draw. Again, it looks like the obvious result of a paint program.One feature I was initially happy to see is the ability to zoom in with the mouse's scroll wheel. Why that isn't universal I have no idea, and being a detail hawk I am constantly zooming in and out at various points. Great! But it's silly, because using your scroll wheel will only zoom in to the exact center of your screen. The program doesn't care where your cursor is! So you have to first drag over to center whatever area you want to zoom in on. How did they not think to make it zoom in on the area I am pointing at? Yes, I can drag to the area first, but zooming in & out is something I might do literally hundreds of times while working on one image.I was not able to figure out why trying to pick the crop tool sometimes jumps my focus down to the canvass layer, which is surely the last layer anyone would want to crop and move. Unlike some other things, there was no popup telling me why it didn't want to let me crop the paint layer.Here's another silly thing. The escape key does not un-select things. If you use the select tool, and have the dotted box around an area then either perform some action or change your mind, you want to un-select the area. In every other program I have used, either ESC or ENTER will unselect the area and let you move on with your life, which is handy because you can draw with your right hand and hit keys like that with your left. In Corel, you have to use the "reset tool" on the menu bar. Again, it might not seem like a big deal but it interrupts the flow of an action you might do hundreds of times while working on a serious project. And it's not like the ESC key does anything else.And finally, though the number of tools is impressive at first, it's all about buying upgrades. Want more brushes? Hand over a chunk of cash. It looks like the "image hose" is the same, and you can only use leaves and tires so many times before your work looks like a child got on your computer when you weren't there.  When the program first started, this really convenient learning interface popped up. Oh good, something to get me started! Not really, they're all "30 lecture" bundles you have to buy. No free 5-minute intro to using Corel's mediocre interface.Overall, it's got some good stuff. But don't think you're buying into some great thing. They think they're selling you a bare-bones system, some of which can be addressed with upgrades and some maybe not.
Cave men with dinosaurs? No.

The volume goes to 16, which is way too loud. A normal volume level is obtained by setting it around 6.  However, there is a constant hiss sound (not reception static), even when the volume is at 0. If you set the volume to 4 or 5, the hiss is about as loud as the music.It takes a couple seconds for the power to come on, which is annoying because it is not immediately clear if you pressed the button fully.While scanning, each step makes a bit of a click sound which is kind of annoying.The pocket clip is a thin piece of plastic.

Pro:Cheap alternative to the no-longer-made black Casio databank (they still make a nearly-identical chrome or gold).Con:Poor quality LCD. Some of the older Casio models had a dark brownish background for the display, but this is different. The LCD itself has a very narrow viewable angle. All of the segments of the LCD turn dark at an angle which is still visible on a real Casio.All right-side buttons are flush with the watch body, the same way the setting button is. This makes many basic features very difficult to use because you really need a finger nail to press them.The segments of the numeric digits have more space between them than a real Casio, making the numbers slightly odd to look at.When setting the time, the seconds don't skip to 00 when pressing the adjustment button. They increase 1 second with each button press. This was very confusing at first, since my intuitive behavior is to press a button and wait a second to see what happened. It took me a while to figure out that it was actually working.The display has a slow refresh response when switching modes or data pages. Not enough to interfere with use, but just enough to notice it seems kind of slow.Overall, it's pretty loaded with features for a cheap generic watch. It's interesting to see a knockoff product made with a full set of features like this. The top row (for day and name display) is a true pixeled/matrix display (many knockoff watches simulate it with dotted segments which are actually figure-8 displays). If you really don't want to spend more, I guess it's an option. It does everything it claims to do. But you'll probably be a lot happier with the real thing.

I used to be overweight, but I slimmed down about a year ago. I am now quite normal, but I still prefer to wear pants sightly larger than my exact measurements. I was offered this in a size slightly larger than a tailor would prescribe, which should have been perfect.However, despite the overall size being what I expected, everything else is cramped. If I bend over a bit, I can feel the inseam riding up my rear. The pockets are all at least half an inch shorter than would normally feel like the minimum size. I can't imagine what it would feel like for someone larger than me who would supposedly be a proper fit.The material feels nice. The elastic sides of the waist band are normally a nice feature on pants, but only useful if one can wear a perfectly-fit size and enjoy added comfort of elasticity around the waist. As these pants are, the shape is only just barely acceptable at a size which makes a stretchable waist unnecessary.

The handle has somewhat sharp edges, more like a generic Chinese knife. It's not like Boker's real Solingen-made models. Either get a higher-end Boker, or get a cheaper generic knife of roughly the same quality.

The outside of the package says no programming required, which seemed like an odd claim. The inside of the package tells you how to program it, or tries to.It says to press either the power or the setup (S) button, (and hold it down for up to NINE MINUTES until the TV powers off). That's kind of weird, and turns out not to be true because both buttons do not do the same thing. Holding the power button causes the light to blink for a few seconds and then go off. Holding the S button does nothing for several seconds, and then makes the light come on for as long as you hold it.  Here's an oddity I discovered: if you hold the S, then also press Power, then release both, the light comes on solid forever until you press S.I was not able to get a new LG TV to respond by any method. This same TV is compatible with a 1980s Casio TV remote watch which only has 40 different codes.The flashlight function is not very good. A dim red light with a slightly darker center. Not up to par even with the lowliest keychain LED flashlights from junk stores.

It's hard to see in the stock photo, but if you get one in your hands and look at it head-on it is clear that they chopped down the struts(?) which connect the solar panels to the cockpit. They're too short, and they weren't just reduced in total. It's like they cut off a chunk at the end before attaching the panels. The whole thing is too narrow. Why they would do this and ruin the model I can't be sure. Perhaps they wanted it to fit within some existing manufacturing equipment. Regardless, this is not an accurate TIE fighter and looks silly if you are familiar with them. It doesn't match the picture on the package, which appears to be accurate.

Now that the new batch of Star Wars Micro Machines is coming out, I am reminded of the sad fact that the Star Wars models were generally not among the better-made Micro Machines. This set in particular, having 3 of the more desired ships, is a perfect example. The Star Destroyer, the ultimate in sharp lines among sci-fi vehicles, is bent. Every single unit I have seen is bent, and doesn't straighten well with the hair dryer trick. It's like the upper and lower halves are not the same size.  The Millennium Falcon's tips don't line up and the details are blobby. The X-wing has misaligned cannons, but it can be fixed with the hair dryer and some careful work.Unlike the old Micro Machines, most or all of the Star Wars models have a good portion of rubber rather than hard plastic.
Just another one of these boring running games, overlaid with Sonic graphics.

I don't know what all of the current designations mean, but I bought this card and it's slow as an analogy related to something which is very slow. Need to copy 30mb? Find something to do while that happens.

I'm in a valid ZIP code. I have the app installed (because that's the only way to use this service). I have Prime. I even have the normal Amazon app installed, and it works.I added items to the Prime Now cart. When I go to check out, I have to log in. But the login screen doesn't work. I can't type in the password box. I can't click the button. The password recovery link doesn't work either.How can the login screen be the thing they can't make work? Is this all new to them?UPDATE: Also, if an item is out of stock, it vanishes! No saved-for-later or anything. If it's not in the cart and ready to buy, it's gone.

This is not the same as other penlights, so I'll start with the emitter setup.It's a 5mm LED set in a reflector.  Some 5mm LEDs are set into a reflector (like a regular LED or bulb would be), but most are not.  It's also not the tightly-focused kind of 5MM LED, such as the Nichia LED used in the basic Energizer penlight. This one is a dome-shape which emits light mostly equal in all directions, similar to the LEDs used in Bayco flood flashlights.  Since the LED is somewhat large, and the reflector relatively small in comparison, it produces a wider reflected beam. It's even wider than the 4Sevens Preon, so wide that the reflected light, which would normally form the "spot" beam, is as large as the direct flood area.So what we have is a flood beam (about 45 degrees wide total). But it's much more efficient than the flashlights with magnifier lenses, a system which leaves almost zero peripheral light and lets most of the side-emitted light die inside the flashlight body.  The resulting beam is mostly smooth over an area almost as wide as the stereo vision area of your field of view, with soft edges and diminishing light trailing off at the far edges. The color is less blue-tinted than flashlights such as the Coast G20 with a lens.If you're one of the many whose main goal for a flashlight is a super-narrow spotlight, this is not for you. But if you want illumination of an area, not just a narrow spot, this is useful for checking breaker boards or the inside of computer cases with enough light at close range without a blinding narrow spot beam in the middle. It's also good for wandering around in the dark, covering just the right area to see ahead a bit while simultaneously seeing where you are stepping. I'm glad that such a thing is available.The body is also of fairly good quality. The button is too tight in my opinion, but it's about the same as the Streamlight Stylus Pro. It screws together smoothly with well-machines threads and a properly-fit O-ring keeps it watertight (some flashlights have a super-thin ring which barely works).A warning, this flashlight is not black like the stock photo. It's a medium-gray with a very slight bluish-green tint, similar to a lot of other aluminum products which are not-really-black. A lot of new Dorcy products are also this odd color, I'm not sure why.

They are using their Chinese patterns, which are obvious if you are familiar with the actual German Bokers, but sticking a German shield on them. They're a little more chunky in overall design than the true German models. Notice that the blades don't say Germany or Solingen, only the shield which is assembled after the Chinese parts (of unknown assembly progress) are sent to Germany.This is the 4th model of similar marking I have gotten my hands on, and so far every one of them has had one issue or another. If Boker is assembling any of the parts in Germany, they aren't doing a very careful job. Sometimes handle slabs don't fit. Small bumps or notches in the tangs make opening/closing inconsistent.Also lacking is the steel quality. It's not quite as hard as Bokers basic stainless German steel (not even compared to 440c, even the nameless mystery German stainless is better than the Chinese stuff). But also annoying is either an inconsistent formula or sloppy heat treating (both of which can cause similar symptoms) makes the edge wear down in a chunky way as it is used. Steels with good grain structure wear down leaving a finer edge, while inferior steel, like this stuff, leaves a more random edge which does not continue to cut through stuff well (e.g., chunks of the target material are more likely to clog on the edge and rip rather than cut cleanly, such as when cutting tape or envelopes). Even at equal hardness and wear-resistance, a steel with a better grain structure is going to remain useable longer.I've seen equal or better quality from Frost's Steel Warrior line. Collectors sometimes praise this quality level from Frost because their knives are literally 1/2 or 1/3 the price of these Red-Shield Bokers.  Don't put too much in the "Germany" shield on this mostly-Chinese knife. Boker is only putting as much German effort into a Chinese-quality knife as they need to in order to justify adding a "Germany" shield. Give that due consideration before buying a Boker not clearly labeled "Solingen" on the blade.

I was suspicious when I first saw it, but then a quick mechanism test revealed the brilliance of the design. Very elegant and effective, it rocks forward and the door swings closed and latches.It won't work as well on soft carpet, so leave it on a flat floor or a sheet of paper.The main drawback is it is very small. It's definitely for mice only (definitely NOT a true rat, which is larger than the trap). It's only about 1.25 inch wide, but more important is that the forward half is only about 3.5 inches after the pivot point. If the mouse can reach the bait without fully crossing the pivot point, it might not rock and close the door.

I reported this many months ago. Case used to sell this simple model for a price which makes sense for this being a 2-pack, so I ordered it without much thought. What you get is a single knife in a normal box with an inventory sticker which says 2-pack. You will not get 2 knives. It looks like Case has upped the MSRP for this model from the old days.

First of all, it doesn't taste like lobster. Very bland, slightly gross. Tastes vaguely like squash maybe.Second, there's bits of hard lobster shell in it!  Little hard shards.  Apparently the shell is the only part of the lobster you can identify in this soup.

The stock photo must be an older version. The one I received has a narrower blade and a different shield (round with "mustang" in it, not the classic shield-shaped shield). It does have the same model number on the box.The awl and the small blade have an extremely weak spring. You can push them closed easily with a pinky.The awl is also extremely thin and soft, and bends back and forth like a paper clip. It would not survive punching a hole in a belt.

I overpaid for this thing at a local store, and I'm still glad I bought it.  It doesn't do much but lick and fidget its arms, but that's all it takes. It's real cat size, and the appearance is just wacky enough to be somewhat creepy. Just hold it in your arms and move the head a bit, people go nuts.

For some reason my local stores don't have this. It's silly, but I forgot that this was the perfect mustard. I felt disappointed with the regular stuff I was routinely settling for recently, and tried all kinds trying to find whatever I was missing. I got this in a sausage/cracker gift set, and instantly realized that this was the good old perfect mustard I wanted. Sandwiches, cheese&crackers, grilled cheese, whatever.

It's not like the stock photo. The color is listed as brown, but the actual knife they are now shipping is more like a weak orange/yellow color.The fit of the parts is definitely not like the picture. The bone scales are not flat on the inside. The curl back away from the liner and bolsters at the ends and stick out.This probably varies, but on mine the large blade does not hold in place well. When opened, it does stay in place but is very easy to move up and down about 1.8 of an inch before it feels like it hits a strong spring resistance. The inner surface around the tang is crude and lumpy, so one of the lumps in just the wrong spot much be sticking out just enough to ruin the mechanics of it.This is one of Boker's German-assembled buckets of Chinese-made parts, and it's not even on the upper end of Chinese parts. Chinese-made Schrades for half the price are of better quality.

I literally would not use pencils regularly if not for this lead. I have a collection of pens, and ended up with an old Cross pencil a while back. I decided to load it up just for the heck of it, but I'm the obsessive type and I quickly ran into a whole world of different lead types. I settled on this stuff (in 0.9mm 2B).This is definitely worth buying. It's both smoother and darker than the normal cheap lead in pencils. It's almost as smooth as a ballpoint. Something more like a super-fine crayon rather than a scratchy pencil. And, despite reading warnings about soft/dark lead being weak, it seems to be fairly durable with no particular problems with breaking while being used.I tried some store brand leads just to be thorough, and they definitely don't hold up. Pencil lead technology has improved over the decades and the new generic leads are better than antique lead I have in 90-year-old pencils, but still not as good as Pentel's fancy new stuff here.

My favorite part of this thing is how both the in and out holes are self-closing.  The spout has a little flap which opens and closes on its own to pour water out, and the filling hole on the top has a spring-mounted window so you just fill it from the faucet and it pushes in as you fill, and springs shut when you're done.Other than that, all of these things are fairly similar.  The drawback to this one is that the capacity is a little low, but I like the narrow profile because it's easier to fit in between other junk in the fridge. But the contradiction here is that it's good for squeezing into a loaded fridge, but not good for serving multiple people.  The ideal use is for a single person sharing a refrigerator with others.As for the filter function itself, the water certainly loses the funny smell and taste of tap water.

I always wanted one of these, but they were kind of expensive way back when I was a kid browsing through a knife catalog. For whatever reason, I recently decided I would finally get one.Unfortunately, Hen & Rooster has gone downhill. Not just compared to the original Bertram manufacturing (the "Bertram cutlery" which now appears on them is just a lie, as there is no Bertram Cutlery any more; Frost owns the H&R name and has the knives manufactured in the mystery factories), but even compared to the Hen & Rooster knives from the earlier Frost ownership. Some are still OK, but this is not one of them. The modern Hen&Rooster manufacturing strategy is to do a quick sloppy job grinding out the blades, then over-buff the whole thing to blur the edges and hide the sloppy work. The result is a blobby appearance.Despite the excessive buffing, the internal surfaces are pretty rough. It does not feel smooth when opening. And not only is the rear of the tang not smooth, it has that little flat area you can feel just before it snaps open (a pretty common flaw in cheap knives).The H&R logo on the tang isn't stamped in, it looks like it is either printed or an extremely pale and shallow etch. That's lame enough, but the "german stainless" on the back is stamped in deeply and the inconsistency looks silly.The shield on mine is not level with the handle. It's sunken in extra deep on one side and sticks out a tad on the other.And then there's one last thing... it had some chunks of buffing compound all over, so I washed it off in PLAIN WATER and this thing keeps dripping red dye. So be careful about carrying this in your pocket if it's raining.The whole thing has the appearance, in all ways, of a crummy imported knife with an extra shine job on the outside.

EDIT: I always leave my mistakes visible for the sake of honesty. I was wrong. The new version of this knife isn't even assembled in Germany with Chinese parts. The new box does just straight up say MADE IN CHINA. The sticker seal also now labels it as a Boker Plus (always made in China or Taiwan).Old review...Boker has a line of classic-style folders made entirely (?) in Germany, and a bunch of similar knives assembled in Germany of Chinese parts.The Chinese versions have slight differences in the shapes, some relevant and some not. One thing you will notice if you see a current version of this knife is that the Chinese Boker stockman with "round" ends on the handle actually have a slightly cornered shape (as if they started square and didn't finish rounding them) while the German version is more rounded. The current production does not look like the stock photo here. The Chinese models also have slightly thicker and sloppier blade bevels. The Chinese models are still OK knives, but they are a definitely lower-end.  Another thing to note is that the location stamped on the knife is either absent or less specific (eg, removing Solingen, or removing both Solingen and Germany).Boker pulled a bit of a sleazeball move by switching the brown bone Cinch stockman from the good version to the cheaper version. SO the super-deep discount you now see isn't really a huge discount, it's reflecting what is probably a lower manufacturing cost.

The bolsters are ugly. They don't have as much of a nice curved surface as you might expect from the stock photos. They are more flat, and actually get slightly thicker at the ends. The edges at the ends of the bolsters have a slightly chunky small bevel.The blades wiggle left-right a little.  Not a whole lot, but it's there.The blades are OK, but the tang and bevel do not have a well-defined shape. It looks like a blade which was not manufactured precisely and was over-buffed to cover it up.The scales are made of good stag.By the way, nowhere on the knife or box does it say where the knife is made. The box says "German" under the Buck Creek name (odd grammar, most German brands say "Germany" as their location). The blade tang says "German Stainless Hand Made" which is the sort of thing often stamped on Chinese or Pakistani knives made from cheap steel they imported from a German steel mill.  Just to be clear, the manufacturer absolutely does not clearly state anywhere that this knife meets a local standard for being made in Germany.My best guess is that this knife was made by having parts stamped out in China or Pakistan using German steel, then having someone in Germany do the final assembly (at something less than their absolute best effort). That way they wouldn't have to say where the parts were made, but couldn't specifically say it was made in Germany while still getting away with mentioning the HQ country. And that result appears to be what we have here.  It may be an efficient way of making a medium-quality knife, but consider whether or not the price of these reflects that quality level, and whether or not you want to buy a product which makes efforts to hype what might be a half-true origin (if anyone at Buck Creek/Frost thinks this is not accurate, they are free to provide a clear statement about their manufacturing processing, which they seem to prefer not to do).

UPDATEI'm upping this from 2 to 3.5 stars because apparently all of these cases are pretty bad. However, this one is slightly easier to trim and manually finish up to fit better. Basically, either sand the hard plastic part (smoother on this brand, so sanding makes a nice finished product vs. those with lumpy textures) or put a rubber sticker on the center rear, then assemble with one side aligned and cut down the extra rubber sticking out on the other side. Sounds ghetto, but all of them require some mod and this one is easier.Optionally, you can make the power button easier to press by cutting a slit along both long sides of the button area with a razor, extending past the ends while leaving the end sides attached. The volume buttons already work OK on this case, and the cutting process is better on this case because there is a more defined button protrusion.ORIGINAL REVIEWThe hard shell does not fit correctly over the rubber part. It's very close, but whichever side you snap over first will fit perfectly and the other side will be just barely short of reaching around into the correct position.The whole thing is slippery as heck. Both the rubber and plastic portions are exactly the worst kind of super-fine texture to give no grip at all (a shiny finish would actually grip better than the soft matted finish). The rubber portion is very hard rubber, so it doesn't have the grippy benefit you would normally get even with smooth rubber.  Regardless, unlike the otterbox for my old p[hone, the hard shell doesn't just grab on to certain locations, it's pretty much a full wrap around both sides. So you are gripping the slippery plastic when you hold it, not the rubber.The buttons work OK, which is the only thing this case gets right.The corners of the cutout around the charging port are sharp. This could easily have been designed with a rounded or beveled edge if they bothered to think about it, but they didn't.It was shipped inside a hard plastic retail-ish case to protect it during shipping, and yet the back of the case was scratched up as if it were used.

Nice and shiny. The handle looks smooth, though it needed a little soap to remove buffing compound from the scales. Once cleaned, it looks great.The Philips screwdriver is absurdly small, about half the size of the Philips on a Victorinox, but the point isn't any sharper so it's not like a precision driver. There is a cutout in the handle to make room for the screwdriver, but it doesn't close down into that cutout. It hovers above the handle over that cutout and looks like the wrong parts were used.The main blade has a very weak spring. The sort of weak slipjoint which flops halfway closed if you cut a box and pull it out wrong. I can push it closed easily with my pinky. It's just not a serious useable pocket knife, and for that it gets no use and no good rating.The other tools have a normal spring strength.
Mostly dull jokes and rehashed gag moments from the first movie.  Slow, not funny.

I'm a fool. I forgot that I bought a similar Clauss knife years ago and returned it because it was lame. I ran into this, apparently on sale for an extremely low price, and added it to my cart without thinking much.At full price, it's as much as a Victorinox gardener, and almost identical in size and shape, but just not made as well. The last one I had didn't snap open well. This one doesn't want to close well.  The edge is almost good, but a little thicker and steeper than the Victorinox and not consistently sharp (one area blunt, one flaking metal, one OK). It's a little too blunt and sloppy for cutting flowers. The blade feels rough when opening.  The blade also has a slight left/right wiggle when open.  It looks OK at first glance, with the parts all fitting together well, but the finer points are all a bit sub-par.The main design difference is the Clauss' having a main bevel on both sides (but the final edge bevel is one-sided), while the Victorinox is completely flat on the back side. This is ideal for cutting stems, as the one-sided blade profile pulls the cut stump away from the stem of the flower, and there is no crushing against the stem end you want to pot.  The Clauss would probably still be OK if not for the blunt edge angle.

It's a bad movie with no bad-movie-quirkiness or corniness to make it amusing.Dolph Lundgren is evil, with some random lame attempts at forming an evil philosophy of life (including the incorrect claim that only humans lie). Scott Adkins is the typical monster movie idiot who doesn't want to kill the beast (with the ridiculous assertion that they have no reason to kill it, after it has killed several people).The monster is nothing but a medium-quality giant CGI lizard. Very boring monster.Of course the good guys end up killing the monster to protect themselves, even though they didn't mind dragging their feet as it killed several locals.  Kind of morally hazy.  In the end, the argument between the good guys and bad guy is whether or not killing the monster was awesome, though there was obviously no disagreement at that point that it had to be done.  This is like an Internet flame war over a functionless distinction.  Lame.

I use can openers, so it's disappointing that the one on this is not useable (it's the really old style, which requires a good sharp internal edge and a very pointy tip). On the other hand, it's cool that they made this with the super-retro style can opener, given that it is hard to put a functional one on a knife this size anyway.The bottle opener would be slightly awkward to use, with its short size requiring a few pry-ups along the edge rather than a single motion, but it would still work.  But of course this is kind of a novelty item, so I'm not subtracting anything for low useability.The blade is actually sharpened well, and is both fairly well-sharpened and done at a low enough angle that it will be easy to touch up.Rough Rider did not add an awl to this knife, which is a good thing.  A common scout knife pattern has a poorly-shaped awl which requires a nasty bent blade and the whole thing still doesn't fit.  For a full-size knife, I prefer many of the German scout-style knives which skip it.  This knife has a nice straight main blade which doesn't jam up against an awl or unnecessary second blade and get scratched up.The overall quality is very good. The blades snap well but the springs are not too stiff to use, a problem many cheap knives have.  The bone and bolsters are polished well on the sides (the edges are left brushed). The shield is fit nicely into the bone. The whole thing is very well done, as well as you might expect for a larger knife.
Maybe if anyone else ever makes canned German tater salad, I will be able to say this is less than the best. For now, Read is the only game in town and I like it.

First, the blunder: you can't turn off the vibration for the navigation keys. I find keypress vibrations to be extremely annoying, and it is just silly that a phone manufacturer would not offer this feature. I googled, and Microsoft says the OS supports an option to disable nav key vibration but the manufacturer has to choose to enable it or something like that. The option is not in the menu where MS says it should be, and the only mention of vibration in the settings only affects keypresses on the screen (the nav keys here are actually not part of the display).The only saving grace with the vibration is that it is weaker than average (hardly a good selling point), so the constant vibration from the home button is not as audible as most phones would be.The navigation keys also do not light up. A lot of phones skip this, and you can get used to their positions (only 3 of them), but it just seems ridiculous that Blu thought that it was so necessary for these same keys to vibrate (an entirely functionless behavior) that they have made it mandatory, but don't care if you can see them.The screen quality is pretty good. Unlike some of Blu's early products, the resolution is high enough that it doesn't assault your eyes with chunkiness. The color and brightness are also roughly in line with most modern phones as well. The viewing angle is not extremely wide, but is good enough that you don't get an unsettling holographic effect.Processing power is definitely where this phone has some issues. This is a complex aspect of a computing device, so I won't pretend to diagnose the exact problem. It can run Angry Birds mostly OK for a long time (with an occasional freeze fixed by locking and unlocking the screen). Another problem, more notable, is that it doesn't scroll smoothly. Whether it be web browsers, file manager, Twitter, or even the phone's own menu system, it moves at a rougher motion than any other phones I have (including an older Nokia Windows phone). Oddly, if you "toss" the page and let it scroll under its own simulated inertia, it goes smoothly. But tap-and-drag makes it jump in continuous chunks as if maybe the touch display doesn't have a good sensor resolution. I guess? Whatever the cause, it's good enough to use but not reliably smooth.The body of the phone has a very nice matted finish and the whole thing feels as solid as a phone should.Sound quality is somewhat weak (as is the vibration). Useable, but not a good choice if you want to use your loudspeaker a lot of talk outdoors. Note that, in my opinion, hardly any phones are very good here, so this only makes it average.The camera quality isn't like a high-end Nokia, but is actually a little better than I expected. It's squarely medium among speed and quality.Overall it's an "OK" Windows phone, plus the added feature of having a larger display than you normally get in this range. But that might only be true if you absolutely need the Windows OS. This runs about the same price as my 1st generation Moto G Android which doesn't have the scrolling issues, no fascist key vibration, and somewhat better sound. And now the 2nd generation Moto G is adding a larger screen. So the Blu is just a reasonable imperfect mid-range phone, though the Windows OS' lacking as much hardware variety probably makes the Blu a good choice.

They don't seem any stronger than the store-branded bags I normally get (which are above average). I can poke my finger through just as easily and ditto for the corners of boxes if I try to.The texture pressed into the plastic is a silly gimmick.The elastic drawstring is very handy. I gave it a good strong pull and it didn't break like others have reported. I suspect this problem was silently fixed and then Hefty tosses out a bunch of free samples of the new bags. It works well holding the bag in place in my garbage can. Other bags actually fit very closely, but do eventually tend to start slipping while these have not.

I don't normally buy stuff like this, so keep in mind that I have little to compare it to.I sometimes get dry skin, in part because I never wear gloves in cold weather and also because I clean tools with harsh cleaners (soaps, WD40, etc) without gloves. I don't bother with hand lotion because all of the stuff people have previously offered to me seems like it just makes your hands goopy, but otherwise doesn't help much.This year I was doing especially bad. My knuckles were so dry that my skin literally cracked in a few places, which causes painful little nearly-invisible wounds resembling paper cuts which hurt when I flex my fingers because all of the motion is concentrated on the ripped-open flesh. Yuck!  I was desperate and randomly grabbed this stuff at the 7-Eleven (the only thing they had) without researching as I normally would.I can't believe how well this works. After something like an hour or less (I didn't push things too quick, so I'm not sure exactly when it got better), my skin is back to being flexible, and the lotion has dried or absorbed or whatever and I am simultaneously not dry or cracking, AND not dripping with goo.  I have a little bit of a rubbery grippy feel on my skin, but it's not rubbing off on clothing or anything. And it remains that way for several hours (24 might be overstated, but twice a day seems to do the trick).The active ingredient listed is dimethicone, which Wikipedia says is a polymer with both liquid and elastic properties. Thank you, technology. You have saved me when Mother Nature wanted my freaking skin to fall off.

The blade has a fairly weak spring. For a knife which is larger and heftier than a typical Swiss Army knife, the blade closes with about half as much force.The multi-purpose blade has what appears to be a saw on the bottom, but it is poorly made. The teeth on one side are sharp, but flat and blunt on the other.If you want something similar, get a used Bundeswehr knife for half the price.

1. Scan is run.2. POPUP: Threat Detected! No fix attempted, we recommend you remove this threat!3. [opens main control panel...] BIG GREEN CHECK MARK: Secure!I also looked at the full scan results, it clearly says 4 threats, only 3 resolved. So why does it say "No threats/Secure" on the console? This is not new behavior for Norton. They have always been quick to slap a nice big green mark on the front of the console declaring that everything is OK. On first installation of a previous version, I noticed that Norton would declare my computer protected even though the virus definitions had not been updated yet.By the way, the supposedly infected file is a Firefox install file from more than a year ago (not modified or accessed since then), so the good news is this is probably just another BS fake Norton virus alert. In testing multiple antivirus brands, it seems like Norton will ALWAYS find a virus in some random file, even if you have run multiple scans from other brands already.

In the stock photo, the can opener is clearly a sharp tool which is intended to work. The one I got is not, it's one of the bluntest can openers I have seen on a knife.As is common in poorly-designed scout/camper knives, the large blade and the awl rub against each other. The awl is tapered as it should be, as if to avoid pushing against the blade too much, but not enough. The blade does not snap closed all the way by itself because it is wedging against the awl.If you open the awl, leaving the blade closed of course, the blade moves over blocking the awl's return path. The tip of the blade is very close to the edge of the awl's tang, and depending on exactly how you hold the knife, the tang of the awl can jam against the tip of the blade when closing.This is definitely not a good alternative to a Victorinox.

Adjustable height, awesome, right? You can make it exactly the position you want!Except the LOWEST height you can adjust it to is HIGHER than nearly every other monitor. The lowest position is almost 4.5" above the desk.  Mine looks slightly different from the stock photo shown here, but the menu has this model number.

Nothing too complicated here, some field peas and a few little jalapeno bits (not very hot, just enough to make it interesting) with some mild mystery seasoning.  It's a nice change from the standard veggies.

I could swear I already reviewed this, and I'm too lazy to write it all again so I will be short.I largely agree with the other review, it's a pretty good knife for the price and the design is a very nice slightly-French style.  It's nice to be able to get something which doesn't look exactly like every other knife out there.The blade snap is just right, not too stiff or too loose.I dropped a star because the edge angle from the factory is a little too wide and not the same on both sides (it's sharp enough to use, just not done perfectly). There were also some typical leftover brass splinters from the factory wedged between the liners, though not the worst I have seen by a long shot.

I first noticed this line of Maserin folders because some of them look similar to some Puma models (this one looks like the Puma Pocket Friend, plus a cap lifter).It's hard to pick out any one detail, but the Maserin is just a little rougher all around, and costs more than the Puma (not as much as it appears with this more tool-loaded model vs. the Puma, but even with more similar comparisons the Maserins cost a little more).

Thanks to the combination of Lamy's needlessly silly ballpoint mechanism (in which they moved half of the mechanism to the front of the pen) and Monteverde's sub-par manufacturing, these refills are not good at remaining extended in the 2000 model. The CP1 seems to mostly work OK.Lamy's ballpoint cartridges are held in the forward position by 3 little house-shaped bumps on the plastic piece at the front, which has to go forward and sit atop 3 flat tabs in the nose of the pen. Nothing keeps the cartridge from rotation in either direction and slipping back into the retracted position, and unfortunately Monteverde's little retaining bumps are not as sharp and squared off as a real Lamy refill.  About every 3rd or 4th time I click the button forward to use the pen, the cartridge will hold in place for a fraction of a second and then slip off and spring back into the pen.I have two Lamy 2000 ballpoints (one fresh and new, one older production), and the same thing happens in both.

It's a nice functional pen, using a Parker-type refill.I wasn't sure how I would like the rubber bumps, as some pens go overboard with grip texture. They are not like that, they only stick out just enough to add a slight grip and are a non-aggressive dome shape.  The clip isn't too bad either, being more of an internal spring-mounted type (the visible portion does not bend, it hinges on some internal mount) though a slightly mushy one.The only problem is that it does look a little cheap, especially for the price. The "silver" surface is just that cheap frosty gray stuff you see all over.  The part between the barrel and the button is unfinished, just unfinished gray plastic with an extreme mold line on one side. If you have an eye for this sort of thing, the plastic is also that nearly-translucent stuff where it isn't covered by the frosty coat. Then there's the mold line where the triangular barrel meets the cone-shaped front end. It's a little sharp and is clearly a molding intersection with imperfect alignment (not just where the shape changes).None of that is absolutely horrible, and this might very well be your favorite pen for long note-taking sessions, but for the price it really ought to be a little better all around. It only looks slightly above the sort of pen you can refill but typically don't, but for about 5 times the price.  Consider that this is in the range of a Parker IM with a brass (if somewhat thin brass) body with a lacquer coating.A final bit of info, this is a non-clicking button.  It moves up and down with no feelable or audible click. I have actually come to prefer this since getting several Caran d'Ache 849's which are also fairly silent, but some people like the feel of a good solid click.

None of the stock photos are accurate. It's not just another sparkle-gray color as so many ugly products have.  It looks like old beat-up corroded metal. The color is a very dark gray. Then it has a smooth clear coating over that.The pocket clip and button don't make any sense. They are a matted/bead-blasted finish as you find on a lot of very cheap products (not the simple smooth finish on other versions of this pen).  I hate the cheap look I expect on junk, and regardless of one's like or dislike of matte gray it doesn't make any sense to have an extreme antiqued finish on the body, but then have a button and clip which are done in the style of a new modern low-cost item.  I buffed down the surface to get a shiny but darker color.

"Citrus punch" apparently means very low quality grapefruit juice.  The ingredients list has orange juice first, but grapefruit is stronger and this stuff doesn't taste much like orange at all.Grapefruit is a very volatile flavor. If it's not high quality fresh juice, it's nasty.  And who would expect "citrus punch" to taste mainly like grapefruit anyway?I'd rather drink sugar-free Red Bull.  If you want fruity, I think Rockstar actually has a vague fruity taste.

Rhodium looks like clean silver. It's a whiter color than cheap chrome plating.I have an older Ecridor model and a new one from Amazon. Both say they are plated with rhodium.  Unfortunately, while the older unit looks like exactly that, the new one is darker and doesn't look much different from any cheap chrome plating.  I will upload a picture (if amazon is in the mood to let users upload pictures at the moment).

Ranga is awesome. They make a nice classic-style pen from ebonite for not too much money (very cool for those who collect older pens). On top of that, they will make your pen to fit pretty much any common ink refill. I opted for Parker's rollerball, which is unique in having a true fluid reservoir with a fountain-pen-like feed system for consistent ink flow to the last drop.  They are made carefully in India, so it takes a little while to arrive in a very safely-packed box.

Read this whole thing to understand just how shady this is.Many pen manufacturers have their own shape for ballpoint refills.  This is annoying, but can usually be overcome because the main difference is usually just the length.  I have a lot of pens with alternative refills installed, if I want a different color or ink type than is available from the pen manufacturer.There's no way to do that with a Lamy ballpoint. They have done the most absurdly unnecessary thing you MIGHT be able to imagine. Most people wouldn't come up with something this nutty.Imagine a Parker refill. It has alternating high and low surfaces on the back of the cartridge, and some teeth built into the pen's button which alternatively line up with the high or low positions as you click it in and out (note that many pens which user Parker refills, even many of Parker's own pens, don't actually rely on this any more, but rather have a complete retraction mechanism in the pen).Lamy still uses a similar concept for their clicker ballpoint, but they have the entire system at the FRONT of the pen.  If you look at a picture of a Lamy refill, that black piece near the front isn't just a block for the spring to rest against. It has 3 angled teeth sticking out, which fit into a mechanism built into the nose of the pen. The teeth on the refill go past the teeth inside the nose of the pen and rest against the front of those.There is basically no way to fit any alternative refills into this pen, and it's because Lamy went out of their way to make their pens ridiculously complex for no conceivable reason other than to make you buy their stuff. You can get a Monteverde refill made for it, but Monteverde makes a lot of junk.  There's zero hope of fitting a Parker gel or Uniball ballpoint into this thing.It's one thing if, for example, Sheaffer has their own cartridge shape because they don't want to change from the one they invented 60+ years ago. Or Waterman, which had the brilliant idea of making their ballpoint refills compatible with their rollerball pens if you want to switch (try it, almost any Waterman rollerball can take a Waterman ballpoint cartridge).  But Lamy is doing this for no reason I can imagine other than to require you to buy OEM refills.  And oh boy did they go out of their way, what with this odd reach-around system up at the front.

I have used other washes like this..primarily Summer's Eve...but I like this one much better.  It as more of a silky feel to it, is colorless, almost odorless, and quite effective for odor control.  I have very sensitive skin and I have absolutely no irritation from this formula.  I use it by applying with a wipe and don't rinse it off, so if there were irritants in this product, I would experience it.I wanted to take a star away but did not, though, for the thoughtless bottle design.  It cannot sit upright, on either end, and I have to lay it on it's side.  The dispensing end is too narrow to hold the bottle up, and the bottom has a small ridge which prevents you from standing it upright.  Now *that* is irritating...although the product inside is not.

Smooth wood & no rough metal connections for scarves to snag on, and good-sized rings that will rotate up or down...perfect!  At 1st I thought that the rings didn't rotate on the hanger as advertised, but I found that if you grasp a ring and then firmly push it a 1/4 turn, it will stay in that position....or any position between straight up and lying parallel to the floor. The wood is very soft and twisting the ring will cause the hole to widen. I put my scarves on it with the rings turned just slightly for ease of getting them on and off.  This is a functional and attractive addition to my closet...love it!

This is a really nice quality item that is really invaluable if you use paper napkins outside, to keep them from blowing away.  It's easy for adults and children to use and to refill, with just two pieces.  The base is nicely weighted for stability, and the metal bar fits into a groove and on top of napkins, allowing them to be easily pulled out, one at a time.  The design is such that lots of napkins can fill the unit to the brim and the bar will stay nicely in the groove and rolls as each napkin is pulled out.  It can only be removed by slanting it slightly when pulling it up.  With this design, I'm sure there other creative ways to use it...possibly as a place to keep receipts or the like.

This is my 1st taste of the famous Lindt chocolates, and I must admit that I am more a dark chocolate fan.  However, I do like milk chocolate and love caramel, but I was disappointed in this product.  It is extremely sweet, rather oily, and it didn't taste to me like a 1st rate chocolate candy, which I expected.  The milk chocolate shell is about a 1/4 inch thick, and is very creamy and smooth, but didn't give me a real chocolate taste...kinda bland.  The center is semi-solid caramel that is too sweet and oily. On the positive side, the chocolate doesn't taste waxy or artificial.When I received the chocolates, they were slightly melted from the heat in the mailbox, so I had to let them re-harden before eating.  I would have appreciated mention from Amazon about ordering chocolates anytime other than winter, unless they come in packaging protected from heat.

I very much enjoyed this book, as I love science and biology as well as a good involved mystery.  I realized at the beginning that this book was going to be filled with information about and around the research on comparing birds and dinosaurs that the main character Anna was doing, and that biology was going to figure prominently in the book...and I didn't mind at all.  I became quickly involved with all the vastly different characters as Gazan developed them for us, but being such a lengthy book, I had to go back and re-read on more than one occasion if I had to put the book down for more than a couple of days.  I will be interested in seeing what future books will be published by this writer.

This kit contains lots of really pretty, colorful duct tape, all kinds of "notions" to make jewelry and bags, and has complete instructions and illustrations for 14 projects.  I was surprised and how many different items can be made from this kit/from duct tape, and it is really packed full.  The age range says 7-14, but I think this is mostly suited for elementary age kids, and especially several friends getting together to do something "crafty."  The tape is easy to tear, and is not the really thick type of duct tape.

It was a great idea to come up with a combination coffee brewer and blender, and it's not only fun to use, but a serious appliance.  Coffee is brewed one cup at a time into a travel mug (included), and I have several of them so I'm not limited to only making coffee for myself....would have been nice if the machine came with two mugs.  The hot coffee can be poured right into the blender, but care is needed to not overfill so that hot coffee spews out when blending..need to use towel or oven mitt on top of blender for safety.  One drawback is that you have to use small ice in the small blender (they mention crescent-shaped ice cubes, but I don't have an icemaker) so you have to smash ice up some before putting into blender.  The enclosed drink recipes for coffee and fruit smoothies are quite good and I was impressed with the several I tried.

I get tired of replacing hoses when they wear or kink, but this hose is really excellent and I feel it will last for years and years.  It is a heavy hose and has quality hardware at each end.  I trust the Scotts brand, as well.  This is a 50 foot hose, and I anticipate that I will also be buying the longer hose to reach all corners of my yard.  Good job, Scotts!

I can't say enough about the quality and design of this slow cooker!  It is a heavy-duty, quality piece of kitchenware.  It consists of a base made of metal with two handle/latches on the side.  Into this base fits the crock---unusual that it is rectangular, but that makes it perfect for slow cooking casseroles.  Being more shallow than other round, deep slow cookers, it seems that food should cook a little quicker on high, and I found that to be the case.  The crock is even oven-safe!  The lid to the unit is exceptional, as it has a silicone seal around it's edge that allows it to make a complete, leak free seal for the crock.  (I've had so much trouble in the past with slow cookers having ill-fitted lids.)  The lid then attaches to the metal base with nice quality plastic and metal locks...this is for transport only, and not to be used during cooking.  When not in use, the locks on the lids fold into little "nooks" and out of the way.  This unit has a dial with 3 settings--low, high, and keep warm---and of course "off."I often give cookware away to friends and family when I find something better, but not this one!

This little thing is pretty amazing when you see how quickly it unfolds and refolds.  I had a 7 year old try it out and she mastered it right away.  Right out of the box, the easel legs will unfold in moments and then you slide the two support pieces to the desired height for what you want to display.  You then just spread the legs out to the back and then bring one to the front to make a tripod.  After working with the legs a little bit, you see where a good balance point is where all 3 legs will be securely on the floor and the easel won't tip over.  In taking it down, the key is to utilize the elasticity of the bands in the legs and firmly pull the leg sections apart when refolding...they will then collapse quickly into a small, portable bundle.  Pretty genius, really.  Now, this is not designed to hold a large, heavy item, but will easily support several poster boards, a small framed print/painting, or other lightweight object.

As I don't have a big screen TV, I wanted to get this projector to use with my TV and with my computer to enlarge the picture.  I had no idea how incredibly clear and sharp the picture would be with this Epson!!  I project onto a wall in my living room, close the curtains, and it is like being in a movie theater for me.  I actually enlisted a more tech savvy younger relative to help set it up, but instructions were very clear and complete...I'm a stickler for that.  Now my brother wants to borrow it for business meetings!  Very happy with this projector, and I seem to be having more visitors lately.....

With all the game options out there, I wanted to make sure and introduce my granddaughter to a classic game like Yahtzee.  I loved this game as a child, and, sure enough, she loves it too.  So many skills are used for this game to help kids....counting, decision-making (how many dice should I roll again?), writing/tallying (keeping score on your card), taking turns, and even learning to spell a fun word like "Yahtzee!"  As others have stated, it would be nice to have the leather cup back again...the sound of rattling the dice inside that cup is different than any other sound!...but that's no biggie.  This really is a game that every family should have!

I already had these on both my front doors when I got these new ones, so it was just a matter of replacement--they had gotten a little bit worn and dirty over the years.  I had previously used all kinds of towel and fabric contraptions to seal off the draft under my doors, but every time I would have to move whatever I constructed.  So these little things are brilliiant!  You end up with a foam roller on the inside and on the outside of the bottom of the door..the entire length of the door...and they are held in place by the velvety material that encloses them and then passes under the door.  When you open the door, the whole thing just slides along with the door, and back when it shuts.  You have to be aware of what you have at the bottom of the door, as too high carpet will not let it slide.  I just have a small, low rug that is no problem.  I love these, and need to get more for my back door,,,,great invention by Duck!

Well, I don't think you can go wrong with Arrow products, and this stapler is an example of their good quality products.  This is not an industrial-type stapler, as there are a number of plastic parts, but it is certainly a sturdy little thing.  There is a nice cushiony handle at the top where the heel of your hand & thumb  grip when using, as well as cushioning for where your other fingers rest,  It is very easy to load, by simply pushing up a tab and sliding out the top of the staple chamber.  I noticed that it is well-balanced in order to put the weight of the stapler closer to the front where you are going to be applying all the force.  With this stapler, you must make certain that the area where the staple will be ejected is placed completely flush with the surface where the staple will come out, an apply a great deal of force, as the staple will not go all the way in otherwise.  I would suspect that more industrial staplers would be heavier and help steady the stapler to get good contact.This is a stapler that I think is excellent for around-the-house projects and repairs, and will last for years with occasional use.

This Vornado Small Room Tower Heater is aptly named, and is a good choice for very small rooms.  Unlike other small heaters I own, it does not fan/blow heat directly out the front, but rather circulates it out.  You can get very, very close to it, even when on the "high" setting, and not be uncomfortable.  This feature is good and bad, in that it is a nice heater to put very close to you when you're sitting watching TV to warm your feet, but is not really effective in spreading heat quickly out into a room that you want to heat.  My small dog likes to lie inches away from this heater, so it is perfect for older pets who need extra warmth, and it's not dangerous for them to do so.  There are two settings...high and low...and a red light indicator to let you know it is on.  One great feature is the very sensitive "tip-over" safety feature:  if you pick up the heater (which you can do easily to move it, because it does not get hot on the outside), it immediately cycles into a sort of standby mode, and a warning light comes on..  When you place it back down, it resumes it's heating...much better than if it completely cut off every time you adjusted it's position.  There is an overheat function that has not kicked in since I have had the heater and I have used it for hours and hours at a time.  There is also a timer feature, which I would never use because I stay in the room with the heater and cut it off when I get ready to leave the room for an extended amount of time.  Another good feature is the 5-year warranty.This is a good heater for quick heat in a very small area, but I disagree with the write-up about the product that states that the heater has a "wide circulating area."  The heater is only 12 inches tall, and the heat comes straight out from the wavy-lined vents on the front of it, and it only radiates maybe one foot or so directly in front of it.

Being a c-pap user at night for sleep apnea, I began to have congestion as well as a dry nose now that I'm using heat in my home....wasn't such an issue in the summer.  Instead of using the humidifier feature on the c-pap, I wanted to try a humidifier for the whole bedroom.  I have been using the Vornado for a few days now, and it's made a big difference for me.  I feel that it is a good quality humidifier that will last for years, with good maintenance.  It was quite easy to set up, with good instructions in the booklet.  I have well water, so I will be cleaning the filters periodically in a solution of vinegar and water, as recommended, so that I don't have to buy filters frequently.  It will be a chore keeping up with when the filters need to be cleaned/changed, but time will tell if the good, humid air is worth the trouble.I do have a couple of things I don't like about this unit.  First, there is no light to signal that the water in the tank is low.  You can see through the tank, but it is at the back of the unit so that I have to turn it to see the tank clearly.  A light on the front would make things much easier.  Secondly,  is the noise of the unit.  It operates pretty quietly on low, but the water gurgling into the base from time to time can be pretty loud.  If on "high", the fan is noisy enough that I can't sleep, and if on "auto," the changing from low to high is even worse.  On "low" it is actually quite restful.

A very powerful frother!  I like the balance and weight of the unit.  When inserted in a half glass of milk, I got nice foam within 2-3 seconds!  The frother wand is easy to clean, but I wouldn't want to let it dry with milk on it, as the coils would be hard to clean with dried food on them.  Hopefully the batteries will last a while in this unit...I haven't used this item long enough to know at this point.

We have used several different types of sleepers for the newborn in the family, but this is definitely her favorite.  She likes the hammock/snuggle position that she is in when in the sleeper, especially when it is inclined.  The fabric is soft and plush, and she seems to feel all "snuggled up" when placed in it.  It rocks slowly and steadily when pushed, and doesn't have jerky movements.  The height of this sleeper is a plus, in that when placed beside a bed, the baby is at eye level.  It is portable, and folds up easily and compactly, fitting up against a wall in a very small space.  The baby is too young to pay attention to the "clackers" but these are a nice feature for when she gets a little older.This is a very convenient and well-designed sleeper that we anticipate using until she outgrows it!

I'm a person who loves nice pillows, and I love this one!  It is soft, although somewhat lumpy, and keeps its volume no matter how much I plump it and re-arrange it.  The pillow is not so hard that you strain your neck trying to sleep on it, but is not so soft that your head sinks almost down to the bed...it's just right.  I have lots of pain in my neck and the right pillow is essential for me to sleep well.  I also like that there are 2 sections to this pillow...one large and one smaller...that are separated by a small strip of fabric, and the 2 parts can be adjusted many different ways.  (The picture shows the strip of fabric as being thick and stuffed, but it is actually just material that separates the two distinct pillows.)  One nice thing is that I didn't notice a chemical odor when opening the plastic zippered pouch the pillow comes in, like you do with some pillows and bed linens.  The label states that the cover can be removed and laundered, but I have not tried to do this yet.  The zipper is covered and not visible at all, which means that it is not going to scratch your face or arms.  This is the only pillow I use now!

I have tried many way to keep produce fresh in the frig...some worked, some didn't work at all, and some were frankly just too hard to mess with.  I bought these little disks a few months back, and they are doing an excellent job in the veggie crisper! Truly, my grapes, lettuce, peppers, fruits are all lasting 3 times longer than they would without the disks.  You simply peel off the top and place one down in a crisper drawer and nothing more to do. I am thrilled and coming back to buy more!!

This monitor has fortunately proven to be quite excellent, as our family has a newborn, and we want all the best equipment to take care of her.  It is sensitive and picks up virtually all noise nearby when set on the highest setting..almost as if you were in the room with the baby.  There  are 5 soothing songs (with volume control), a nightlight, and a room temperature monitor...all great features when you are looking at monitors. The lanyard for the receiver is another handy feature when you are moving room to room.  We also love the ability to talk to the baby from another room, as well as allowing one person to talk to another...good safety feature in case of emergency or needing assistance quickly.Other reviews have covered all the features in detail, and I just truly don't have any negatives to state about the item.  I anticipate this will be passed on in the family when the baby no longer needs it.

This is a fairly good quality child's telescope with one exception:  both included eyepieces would not stay on during use.  Aggravating to say the least, but still this is obviously not a "toy."  I have to say that we were unable to get a clear night to test out the ultimate power of the scope, but we were able to see very far into the landscape/distance with much more power than binoculars.  The stand helps keep the scope steady during use, but it is not tall enough to be placed on the ground, even for a child...must be placed up on a table for ease of use.  Workbook is really nice and provides supplemental education for a child about what she is viewing in space.  Our 7 year old needed help in setting up the telescope and with adjusting it, but was able to use and adjust independently.  This is definitely something we will keep and take out on clear nights to enjoy.

This is a pretty simple grill/griddle combination with nonstick surface, but I'm not sure how sturdy and long-lasting it will be over the long term.  The base is made of plastic that is more flimsy than other griddles like this that I have owned, which concerns me.  The grill/griddle plate seems pretty sturdy, but being a person who has seen many nonstick surfaces, I don't feel that this one will wear very long unless much care is taken to keep from scratching it with metal cooking utensils.  I always use a good amount of oil on nonstick anyway so that would help maintain the surface on this unit.The cord needs more length and could use another foot before it would be deemed too long for safety purposes.  I don't mind the temp control having settings instead of graduated temperatures, as you know you need it medium high for pancakes and then medium for most other cooking.Another feature that is missing is a drip pan/tray.  Yes, there are holes on both sides for excess oil/drippings to flow into, but then the hot juices fall down directly into the plastic base..?
