The Battle of Westerplatte was the first battle of World War II during the Nazi invasion of Poland. Though doomed from the start, the 200 soldiers garrisoned at Westerplatte held out for seven days, thus serving to inspire a nation as a symbol of resistance. In the process of enduring a naval bombardment, assault troops and dive bombers, the defenders of Westerplatte kept well over 3,000 German troops busy, buying time for other parts of Poland to prepare their defenses. The fact they didn’t stand a chance only served to reinforce, in the eyes of Poland and the rest of the free world, how vital it was to stand up to Hitler.It’s great subject matter for a film, and writer/director Pawel Chochelew has come up with a winner for the most part, even managing to inject some truly artful moments into what could easily have been just another World War II film. The problem is the special effects mostly, and the staging of the battle scenes, in part. Let’s face it, audiences are more sophisticated about CGI effects these days , so if you’re going to use them, they have to be well done. The above-mentioned dive bombers are a particularly good example of bad special effects.In Poland, the title of the film is slightly different, translating as THE SECRET OF WESTERPLATTE. Apparently the secret is that the men defending Westerplatte were actually commanded by Second in Command Capt Dabrowski, and not by Major Sucharski. While this is of only passing interest to audiences simply looking for a good war movie, it does aid the human interaction during the siege.Apparently Major Sucharski had some sort of mental breakdown during the battle, which paved the way for Capt Dabrowski’s taking over command. The scenes depicting Sucharski’s breakdown (here interpreted as epilepsy) are very well done and the director manages to find a way to bring something fresh to the war movie genre. Interesting as this is, the poor special effects and sometimes ineptly shot battle scenes (the German soldiers’ frontal beach assault looks ridiculous) undermine these efforts at originality.In the end, one’s enjoyment of 1939 BATTLE OF WESTERPLATTE will be determined by what is more valued: interesting human interaction or battle scenes.

Professor James Shapiro has done the seemingly impossible and found a new light to shed on the life of William Shakespeare and his later plays. Although he makes a few assumptions here and there, (as when he says, most convincingly, that Shakespeare did such and such a thing at such and such a place), his opinion is nonetheless well-informed and his theories, for the most part, are impressively believable. We must remember though that Shakespeare’s actual life and career is very poorly documented, and while it is tempting to place the world’s greatest playwright in any number of circumstances, there is nothing to actually prove these imaginings.I’m willing to concede many of Shapiro’s major surmises, however, such as how events of the day may have impacted Shakespeare’s writings, for they mostly make perfect sense; but one must view this program with just a pinch of salt, at least when it comes to Shakespeare’s biography.But the play’s the thing, is it not? And Shapiro’s knowledge of the time and key events in the reign of King James I is the real meat of the story, drawing us in with a fresh perspective on Shakespeare’s works that has rarely, if ever, (to my knowledge) been considered before.And that consideration is Shakespeare as Jacobean playwright (meaning he wrote during the reign of King James) as opposed to being solely a product of the Elizabethan era, which many people assume. As Shapiro delves deep into the events and changes of the time, the significance of this “discovery” becomes fascinatingly apparent.This is the ultimate value of this outstanding three episode series: how it provides new insight into some of the most important plays in world literature. Not an easy task.While he isn’t the most absorbing on-camera host in an Athena-released documentary (Shapiro’s readings tend to over-emphasize key words which has the effect of sounding like Captain Kirk got an education), this is truly a fine example of content over style carrying the program. Many of Shapiro’s conclusions and observations are truly ground-breaking. And even with some mediocre performances of scenes from Shakespeare’s later plays (was the RSC slumming – especially their horribly-performed bits from King Lear?), the layer upon layer of significant observations about Shakespeare as a Jacobean author pile up so high that the cumulative effect is that of a significant contribution to Shakespearean scholarship. (Bits from Ralph Fiennes’ recent film of Coriolanus make up for some of the shoddy stage excerpts, so that helps, too).As a very special bonus feature is an outstanding (for the most part) production of Macbeth from 1983, part of the BBC Shakespeare series that ambitiously presented all of Shakespeare’s plays produced for television from the late seventies to the early nineteen-eighties. Nicol Williamson is in fine form as Macbeth and the shamefully little-known (in North America) Jane Lapotaire explodes in a technically astounding performance as Lady Macbeth. Note how she ascends several staircases without looking down, as one small example of her powerhouse technique.This two disc set from Athena is a keeper, something every fan of Shakespeare simply must own. Despite a few false notes, it is truly impressive and bound to set you thinking about some of Shakespeare’s late masterpieces in a new way.

The title of this excellent documentary series released by Athena, a subsidiary of Acorn Media, specialists in quality programming, is somewhat misleading. The problem with using “narrow escapes” in the title is that it implies POWs and escapes from concentration camps. The series is so much more than that. Coupled with the informative learning guide that comes with this four DVD set, the viewer or “student” will come away enriched and even fascinated by some of the powerful stories recounted here. Athena presents many documentaries and has a particular focus on educational material. This is arguably one of their best.As a person reasonably well-educated on matters pertaining to World War II, I was delighted to discover a number of stories I’d never heard before in this at times riveting, always interesting series chronicling close calls (A better description than “narrow escapes”) in World War II.And lest one assume that all the stories focus on Allied protagonists, there is a very broad range of situations covered here, with a few Axis “escapes” thrown in the mix. There was a time when this might not sit well with a U.S./British/Canadian audience, but enough time has passed since the Second World War that people can be a little more objective about such things. Each episode is compelling and utilizes archival footage extremely well. In fact, the actual war-time footage is so good it makes the re-enactments look mostly weak by comparison.On the other hand some of the interviews that the producers have secured are fascinating. One episode, number 11,  called “Moore’s March” includes an interview with one of the four survivors of one of the most incredible close calls you’ll ever hear about, a 300 mile trek across the desert with no food and almost no water–and barefoot. The ordeal left the interviewee severely traumatized and while time has helped heal his stress, there are still hints of it on hand. Another excellent episode, number 3, “Wingate & The Chindits” includes a number of survivors’ interviews. This event, set in the Burmese jungle against the Japanese, movingly recounts the strong bond between the desperate men and their donkeys, who served them so well and had to be slaughtered for food towards the end of the campaign. One interviewee reads a poem about one donkey’s last moments and provides a fitting reminder of how animals serve and sacrifice for humans during times of war. I wouldn’t go so far as to call this “War Donkey”, and I’m sure Spielberg will never make a film about it, but it is very moving nonetheless.A number of recent historical documentaries have tried to jazz things up by using shaky camera work and rapid cutting techniques. Fortunately, NARROW ESCAPES OF WORLD WAR II is of a more traditional style and eschews this sometimes annoying approach. It recognizes that a strong story is the focal point of any documentary and the visuals are there simply to back up and illuminate, not distract.This series will be of considerable interest to military history buffs, but educators should also take note. This is an excellent resource for helping to teach young people about the pivotal historical event of the 20th-Century.NARROW ESCAPES OF WORLD WAR II is a worthwhile investment of both time and money.

Recently I had occasion to teach a class to some university age students. During this class I brought up the name Winston Churchill. The students knew virtually nothing about this great politician and World War II leader. It reminded me that historical events like World War II –  arguably the single most important event of the 20th-Century — are little-known to many generations of young people today.That is precisely why DVD releases like the one under consideration here are so important.MISSIONS THAT CHANGED THE WAR: THE DOOLITTLE RAID is as good as any WWII-era documentary I’ve ever seen and superior to most. It has the perfect blend of narrative, archival footage, interviews both vintage and contemporary, and well-placed and unobtrusive re-enactments. I knew the basics of the story, but the details! Everything from the close calls so many of the 80 volunteers airmen faced to the eccentric touches such as painting a couple of broomsticks black and setting them up to look like a tail gun (the real tail gun having been removed due to issues of weight).This four episode documentary has no pretensions about its purpose. This is to-the-point, well-balanced, dramatically interesting storytelling of one of the most important U.S. military operations of the Second World War.There is sufficient examination of Jimmy Doolittle the man to understand what drove him to be the only person considered capable of planning and executing this crucial mission. Doolittle was a great American hero, though not without flaws: he praised the Apartheid system of government in South Africa in the 1960s, for example. Nonetheless it is the portrayal of Doolittle as a real human being that makes his story so compelling. Convinced the mission had failed because all the planes were lost after the raid, Doolittle had no idea what was in store for him or the other raiders if and when they returned home safely.The program’s sense of authenticity and solid research is anchored in Gary Sinise’s superb narration. Sinise is a worthy contributor to this program. He started The Gary Sinise Foundation several years ago, a charity that supports the work of America’s “defenders, veterans, first responders, their families, and those in need.” ([...]) His narration is a text book example of how to do documentary narration right.Also of great interest is the contribution of the handful of surviving Doolittle raiders who, now all in their nineties, give that important first-hand account that benefit all historical documentaries.THE DOOLITTLE RAID’s four episodes are titled “The Call To War”; “Special Aviation Project Number One”; “The Target Of This Task Force Is Tokyo”; and “The Legacy”. There are surprises in every episode that help make this program one of those rare gems you just can’t turn off.For those of you who, like me, were familiar with the bombing raid only from the excellent Spencer Tracy film “30 Seconds Over Tokyo”, you’ll be immediately drawn into MISSIONS THAT CHANGED THE WAR: THE DOOLITTLE RAID. It’s war documentary as it should be: informative, enlightening, entertaining and thrilling.

Previously, Acorn Media released The Doolittle Raid, the first documentary in the MISSIONS THAT CHANGED THE WAR series. It was truly outstanding and the review can be found here [...]High hopes, then, for subsequent documentaries in this series.Alas, Germany’s Last Ace, despite some excellent attributes, is a disappointment.Germany’s Last Ace is the story of three men who played decisive roles in the aerial battles over Germany. Most interesting of these is Luftwaffe squadron commander Gunther Rall. Had the film stuck with Rall it may have succeeded in achieving the same standard as The Doolittle Raid. Rall’s interviews are riveting, a real window into the past. In the accompanying 16-page booklet that comes with this 2 DVD set, Jon Tennyson, writer and producer of the program, describes Rall as “complex and unforgettable”.A truly heroic figure, despite having fought for Germany, Rall was never a Nazi and distinguished himself after the war as well as during the conflict.In stark contrast, the son of one of the American pilots featured in the story drones on and on in his interview segments, dry as bones and without much to say.This curious mixture of brilliant and mediocre material undermines any possibility of this documentary measuring up to the standards set by its illustrious predecessor.In addition to the unevenness, the structure of this four part film is maddeningly repetitive. Many such shows made for the History/Military/Discovery etc. channels utilizes the “re-cap” after every break (where commercials would be inserted). The needless repetition is particularly annoying when the narrative crisscrosses between the American and German story threads. The opening of each episode also includes a lengthy re-cap which is especially excruciating when you’re watching back to back episodes. This structure assumes a lack of attention, perhaps even intelligence, on the part of the audience. It seriously undermines the program’s effectiveness.Gary Sinese’s Foundation, which actively promotes the work of service personnel, needs to pay a little more attention to just how easy it is for a documentary with great subject matter to slip under the radar of excellence into mediocrity.It also needs to be pointed out, yet again, that the Canadians were step by step with the U.S. and Great Britain in most of the war in Europe. There are endless places where Canada is simply left out of the narrative. This is poor, even offensive, scholarship.While I was disappointed in many ways with this DVD set, the fact remains that the story of Germany’s Last Ace–Gunther Rall–is a compelling one. If the program focused exclusively on him, it would be vastly improved. Not every war documentary has to have the United States front and centre. Otherwise call it Germany’s Last Ace… and Others.

I’ve always entertained a certain fascination with the American Civil War. I’m not alone in that regard, which explains the ongoing output of documentaries, books and memorabilia associated with that terrible conflict.Let’s face it. There have been great achievements (Ken Burns’ “The Civil War”) and dozens of imitators. Finding a new angle to present this compelling subject matter is a challenge that is seldom successfully met.As Civil War documentaries go, Lee & Grant isn’t bad, but is so caught up in style that it overshadows the content. This is really too bad, because a detailed examination of the two most well-known generals from that war is a compelling topic.Perhaps the most-often speculated theory about the American Civil War is the idea “what if Robert E. Lee had chosen to remain loyal to the Union?” Would the war have been shortened? Would it have taken as great a toll as it did?Lee was arguably the greatest American general of the period. It’s a pretty safe bet to say his decision to put State over Country resulted in more death and destruction than many people are comfortable to admit.OK, so how could this subject not fail to measure up as a great documentary?Because Ken Burns’ comprehensive exploration of the subject matter has made it virtually impossible for any subsequent film about the Civil War to be as highly regarded, director/producers are tempted, I think, to try to find a totally different approach to presenting this subject matter.Fair enough, but the result, in LEE & GRANT, is overkill; style over substance.For example, when filming an historian, I don’t want to see a gigantic close-up of an oak tree in the foreground taking up two-thirds of the screen, with the dwarfed speaker sitting in the distant background. Such visual tricks are meaningless and distracting.Similarly, when explaining Grant’s aversion to blood, the filmmakers tell how, as a boy, Grant was exposed to the slaughter of animals as part of the family business. This is accompanied by repeated shots of a little boy’s bare foot stepping in a pool of blood as he runs along. Surely this is (excuse the pun) overkill?There is a wealth of information about Generals Lee and Grant that will be of value and interest to students and historians alike, but I, for one, don’t like my facts overshadowed by attention-grabbing camera work and direction. Subject matter this good simply doesn’t need it.

Standing in stark contrast to the visual and stylistic excesses of “Lee & Grant”, executive producers Ridley and Tony Scott (and others) have put together an utterly fascinating film about one of the most tragic military engagements ever involving North Americans – the battle of Gettysburg.GETTYSBURG is full of rich visuals, but the film manages to match them with a compelling story that focuses on a number of individuals who were either directly or indirectly involved in the battle.The most heartrending of these stories involves Amos Humiston, a Union sergeant who has the distinction of being the only enlisted man to have his own monument at Gettysburg. The reason for this will really tug at your heart strings.It seems that Humiston knew he was mortally wounded. He crawled off to die and as he slowly bled to death, he retrieved from his pocket an ambrotype—an early type of photograph—of his three children.His wife had sent it to Humiston after he had gone to war, never imagining the impact it would have in helping to immortalize her husband’s memory.After the battle, Humiston was found, holding the picture of his children in his death grip. Since this was the age before dog tags, rendering dead soldiers unidentifiable unless they carried something that explained who they were, the picture was the only clue as to who this soldier was.The picture came into the possession of a volunteer physician, who, some months after the battle, decided to try to solve the mystery. Eventually newspapers published detailed descriptions of the ambrotype, since at that time they had no means of reproducing pictures.Eventually the description reached Humiston’s widow, who hadn’t heard of her husband’s fate. She made inquiries, eventually saw the picture, and was able to confirm her husband’s identity.This is but one episode that serves to put the tragedy of the battle of Gettysburg into perspective for the modern viewer. Most people know there was great loss of life and that it changed the tide of the war. But it is the human aspect of all such stories that is the difference between an outstanding film (which this is) and just another documentary.If you couple this GETTYSBURG documentary with watching the brilliant 1993 feature film of the same name, your experience of the tragedy of Gettysburg will surely be complete.

Even today, new stories about the Holocaust rise up out of the ashes and demand to be told. Each voice is worthy, every story worth telling. And some are more interesting than others.THE FLAT is certainly interesting, even important. But it falls short of being the compelling experience the filmmaker hoped it to be. The reason for this, in this reviewer’s opinion, is that there is no pay off. Granted, this is a documentary, where there are no guarantees as to the outcome of the story. One simply jumps in and hopes for the best. Arnon Goldfinger must’ve made a hasty decision to pursue his grandparents relationship with a high ranking Nazi and his wife when he discovered evidence of their friendship while going through his recently deceased grandmother’s belongings in her flat. (If it wasn’t a hasty decision, then that would mean the footage of his family going through his grandmother’s belongings was staged).It is difficult to understand the myriad of emotions he and his family must have felt at this revelation, but clearly, at least for Goldfinger, the stakes are high, even if his family members’ reactions to various memorabilia are, for the most part, subdued.One can’t help suspect that as events unfold the filmmaker was hoping for some catharsis to take place: either his mother breaking down and screaming “how could they?” or the daughter of the grandparents’ Nazi friend shrieking “it can’t be true!” This is a reasonable hope, for therein lies the stuff of good drama.Sadly, for the sake of the documentary, this does not occur. Goldfinger voices his disappointment with his mother’s guarded reaction (she knew nothing about this relationship), but the rest of the time he looks dazed, as if he cannot believe no one is expressing outrage.Perhaps a more objective perspective on the part of the filmmaker might’ve served the story better; something the best documentaries seem to have in common.THE FLAT is, to be frank, a little flat, dramatically. It still deserves to be seen, however, as yet another valid documentation of an unusual offshoot of the Holocaust.

Very light weight. Handle is indeed very comfortable. Adjustments are quick and solid. Unscrew the locking nut at the bottom of the top section, push the button to slide lower section up and down to suit, and re-tighten the locking nut. I weith 240 and this cane feels very solid under me.

This thing is built like a tank. Welds are as beefy as the steel they used to costruct this tool, so it's very heavy. Clamping and release functions work efortlessly without using your hands so you can control the work, though you do have to slide the lock/unlock tab by hand. Takes a little getting used to but when sliding the lock/unlock tab, the work is always in a clamped state. The tool is shown being pulled by a handle but while the tools does have rubber wheels, they are relatively close together so the tool is tippy with being pulled. Doesn't have a flat top surface like a Workmate but with the wide front legs, it is inherently more stable when working close in next to the clamping surfaces.

Great stuff. Very rigid and not easy to bend for the diy'er, unless you have the tools it. Will mar if you use pliers...but then it's brass so that's to be expected. I was happy to find the right diameter and just the right amout without having to buy huge quantities elsewhere. I will definitely keep this in mind when I need it for another project.

This 'Create Your Own' cover was a present for my wife. I uploaded a picture of her favorite dog for application to both sides and she is very happy, so I am happy...well, sort of. Had I bought it for myself, I'd be sending it back. The transfer process did not center the picture on the back side of the cover as I had done on the order page, (front page ok), the colors are washed out and have a decidedly blue cast, and the surface is tacky. It is so tacky that when you fold the front over onto the back, the sides sound like they are stuck together when you peel them apart to close. I'd give it one star but it wasn't for me and the recipient was very pleased. So when you average our responses, it gets three stars. I'm not sure I can send it back (custom item and all), but I'm looking into re-doing it. I just submitted a 'request for return authorization'. I'll let you all know how it goes.

Considered buying a retractable awning but already had the base for an umbrella. Pushed the long edge of this umbrella against the house in front of a bank of windows on an upper deck and it does the job for less than half the price of the manual awning (Considering the price for the hunter green color. Other colors more expensive). Brass pulleys work smoothly, Sunbrella fabric is top quality as are the support arms and brass pivot pins. The spider joints to which the arms attach including the one that slides up and down the pole are plastic vs an older umbrella I had in which they were wood. This is an Improvement! The older wood spider joints cracked and fell apart after a few years. Several issues of note, the pin used to secure the sliding spider joint in the 'up' configuration is bright brass coated zinc. If you manage to pull down on the hook instead of out to release the mechanism and close the umbrella, you'll break it like I did during a brain f _ _ _. So I bought a 24" piece of 3/16" REAL brass rod and made another pin. Even put a nice curve in it from which to hang the extra cord. This one won't break! Another issue is that you'll need a heavy base that accepts the large diameter pole (see description) and this could be costly. My recommendation is don't skimp on the base. Get the heaviest you can find. Finally, the wood is not teak but stained a nice 'teak' color. Oh, and the finial? It's plastic, big deal. Screw it in and forget its there. I'm very happy overall with the quality of this umbrella and would purchase it again over less expensive alternatives.

This is a Small Hose rack, not a small Hose Rack. It might hold 25' of 5/8" hose ok....that's it. I bought it to hold 50' of 12ga power cord and it works great for this. 50' of air hose would probably work on this rack as well. Mounting bracket is 3.5" wide. Overall Height is 6.5" and the hook extends out 5.5". I found this rack for $25 elsewhere but they added about $13 for s/h. If you'd rather go there, search on Dura Loop. As for the Rack, it's built tough. The hook itself is mounted to a two piece bracket and seems to be a lot more complicated than it needs to be (meaning they should simply weld the wire to a thick back plate and call it done), but nothing flexes, bends or otherwise 'gives'. Very solid. Mounting holes will take 1/4" screws very nicely, 5/16" screws would be a struggle.

Interesting weave, it's almost like a very fine knit. So if you are looking for a shiny, silky, smooth shirt, this isn't it. But it is soft and might even breath better do to the more even weave. I'm keeping it, but I haven't found my perfect, 'Inexpensive' shirt.

As designed, it was a no-brainer choice for my new elevated deck and should have been an easy set up, but......Please read the reviews regarding the packaging, they are dead on. Sitting on my front stoop, it looked like it had been poured into the bottom of a fairly large sized box. I held my breath and began to unpack. It comes packed in essentially three distinct parts. On top is the copper plated bowl that is 'secured' to the upper black iron ring assembly to which is attached the gas valve. Next are the legs that are stacked together in a couple of bundles and wrapped in thin foam, and finally there is the bottom larger iron ring.Sure enough, the lava rock bowl (and attached burner) had dislodged from the upper black, iron rim and gas valve. Ok, I'm handy, I can put it back together.  Which I began to do until I realized that the copper thermal coupling tube had been badly kinked and even cracked in the middle. The black 'striker assembly' electrical wire was disconnected from the back of the gas valve and the venturi tube had pulled away from the gas valve....darn.So I called Camp Chef. Wow! I explained the issues and Cassidy sent parts Immediately. I received a new copper thermal coupling tube AND a new gas valve! An hour later I had the new parts assembled and it works beautifully. It's everything I expected in terms of charm, warmth, and good clean fun.Cassidy also sent an email with a very good pictorial instruction guide on how to reassemble the unit should it come apart during shipping, (I had to laugh as I read it). And of special note, please be careful to leave the thermal coupling and igniter housing Uncovered in use! Covering it up to hide it Could compromise the igniter function resulting in an unintended collection of gas in the bottom of the bowl. The next time you try to light it....well you get it. The instructions are very clear about leaving this assembly uncovered and for good reason. FYI, the company listened to those who experienced the lava rock problem and included a metal screen designed to cover the fire pit the first time you use it to keep exploding rocks from flying out. They say it's only needed for the first 15 minutes of use and can then be discarded. My lava rocks did not explode/pop, or otherwise make noise.Hope that helps. When it's working it's wonderful. The tinkering required to get it to that state might be too much for some individuals resulting in a very disappointing experience. (And forget about trying to send it back! You'll have to find a brand new box and plenty of packing material :)Because of what a great idea it is, for how it performs when operational, and because it should last and work for a very long time (once assembled :),  I give it five stars.
easy to set, nice ring tone, works. (doesn't have clock face that I know of, it has a digital readout. you should test drive it)

Bah...Humbug. The price is ok, (downright cheap)  but clearly you get what you pay for. I can flex the outboard bolt extensions with my hands. Not robust enough for my use. So, please don't let the "1200 pound capacity when properly installed as a pair" statement mislead you as it did me. Also, I've heard that the diagonal support braces fail at the welds. Looking at them,I can see how this is true. The welds were tacked at only one spot at each attachment point. I would not trust a couple of these to support any load over a couple of hundred pounds. I recommend you stay clear of these unless your loads are appropriate and evenly distributed.

I am 100% satisfied with this jacket. Sizes are true, material is medium thick soft wool. Sleeves are perfect length, for me. I consider it more like a light coat rather than a jacket. Wool has excellent wind resistance so there's no problem there. It does not have a lining so if worn with a long sleeve shirt can be very warm on cool to cold days. I have worn this on 30 degree days with short sleeve shirts and it's at it's maximum usability as a standalone. Cooler than that, I recommend a long sleeve shirt with thin vest and if desired a scarf. Another nice feature of wool is that it 'breathes' and I seldom if ever take this jacket off when inside. It is comfortable and I don't overheat in it.Pockets are ample but not overlarge. Hand warmer pockets are convenient and don't close but don't 'communicate' to the interior of the jacket.I'm very happy with this jacket and wear it everywhere, layering it if necessary.

This is a quality ceramic extender that put my light buld right in the middle of the lantern where I wanted it. The components are solid and the construction is robust. I use it in a protected outdoor location and have had no problems with it. I only wish it would come in something other than white.

I have an all Gigaset phone system with the DX800A as the base to which are registered 3 various model Gigaset remote handpieces. I have enjoyed using the Gigaset products very much. They function well as remote telephone  handsets and intercoms registered to the base and they are all excellent hands free devices with great sound quality. We never lose contivity and enjoy the  picture library I uploaded from my personal photo files which serves to identify the caller (as well as using one of many distinctive rings) and as a screen saver/photo viewer (though small). There are too many features available with Gigaset phones to mention here.This handset, the S810H was supposed to register to my DX800A base but did not. I upgraded the DX800A  firmware but this did not solve the problem. I'm not sure why the unit did not register to the base other than to suspect that 1) the unit was devective or 2) this is a European unit and somehow did not interface with the DX800A base purchased here in the US but available worldwide. After several calls to various resellers in the UK and the EU, I was assured there would be no compatability problems so I purchaed the handset. Alas, no joy. Yes, it might have been defective but I'll never know for sure. I would have enjoyed the functionality of this handpiece, identical in every respect to my other handsets (which are no longer made or available).

Where to start.....I'm on my third one. First one, bought for a friend worked flawlessly. Preliminary set-up in my house was a breeze and it's now working great in her house. 2nd one would not recognize itself unless plugged into the same outlet. 3rd one had outlet issues too but I was determined to beat it into submission. Here's what I discovered: I couldn't plug either piece into power strips, or power conditioners. I've got them both plugged straight into wall outlets. Doesn't seem to matter if they are on different circuits or even across different service boxes, (I have two 200 amp services).I also have the router part connected downstream through two switches and then into the router. The first is a Cisco product, the other a Netgear product. But the software finds the powerline access point without problems....**UPDATE**, at least it used to. Can't seem to find the access point anymore but I am still getting a WiFi hotspot. Given it was behind two swithces and not conected directly to the router, I was never able to get an IP address for it.  But it still seems to work!Last, the WiFi range doesn't seem to be that great, like about 20 feet through a wall or two and it drops from 4 bars to 3, even down to 2 bars but this isn't a problem for me. The added value is the wired port that I prefer to use for a remote printer. Now I don't have to run a 100 feet of Cat 5 cable!So for set-up I give it a 3.5, and for convenience a 4.5; Average 4.**UPDATE** My friends unit has stopped working...the two pieces no longer recognize each other through the homes AC wires. She had the router part plugged into an A/V power strip so I told her to try using the empty socket of the receptacle and go back through the set up process. Resolution pending......

Had an older one of these that did not say it was rated for dimable CFL/LED lights and it buzzed like the dickens. This unit works exactly as advertised, dimming my new LED lights very nicely without noise throughout the travel of the switch 'slider'.

Fits over practically any type of Rx eye glasses. Arm lengths are adjustable and angle of attachment to the protective sheilding is also adjustable, (from the descriptione),  "Features adjustable lens inclination and adjustable temple length for close-to-the-face fit." When you get them, you'll discover they are really made by Honeywell.  Inside the package you'll find a number to call, to speak to someone about sending little rubber bumpers that you add to the inside of the sheild to prevent contact with your glasses. They are very light weight and stay put when properly adjusted.

Everything about this Bible exudes attention to detail, finish, and usability. This is my fourth Fireside Catholic Publishing product after those I've purchased for my wife, daughter and friend. All are consistently well made and flawless in every detail.With the deeply embossed Crucifix on the front and decade Rosary on the back, this Bible is easily identifed as a Catholic edition.NABRE is one of only two complete bible translations approved by the US Conference of Catholic Bishops. Pls see the USCCB.org website and type 'approved translations' in the search box. (the other approved verision is the New Revised Standard Version, Catholic Edition, National Council of Churches).Note; It is not leather covered. I've called the Fireside company and asked about their design philisophy regarding the use of the realistically leather like material they use and I'm told it wears much better than real leather. The material is very soft to the touch, supple, and has never pulled away from the backing.

Just got this yesterday to put in an outdoor hanging fixture whose sides are made out of clear textured 'seedy' or 'water beaded' glass. So to make the glass sparkle, I went with a clear bulb. Wow, this thing can be bright if you want it to be, (I have mine on a dimmer).  I am trying different kinds of clear bulbs and also bought something similar to this: Philips 222042 - 69A21/TS 130V Traffic Signal Light Bulb.  While this bulb is rated at 116 watts (at 130v), the two have entirely different personalities but are seemingly identical in output! Whereas the Halogen, (subject of this review) is white, more full spectrum even though rated at 2900K, the Traffic signal bulb, at 2850K, is almost yellow by comparison. It's got to have something to do with the type of filament used.This Halogen is rated for 1000 hours of use. The Traffic Signal bulb is rated for 8000 hours of use.Im my application, I picked the Traffic Signal bulb....purely personal preference. I love this Halogen and give it five stars for lumen output and full spectrum appearance. But for a front door application, it's almost too stark. I can dim it but it doesn't have the warm inviting cast of the Traffic Signal bulb.

Very nice strap with superior padding. The design is woven, intricate and sophisticated. Stitching is thoroughly completed on all edges; there are no loose threads, or misdirected sewing lines. The 1/4" thick, dense, and full width padding really only extends about 16 inches and is placed squarely in the middle of the strap.  I consider this a good thing as it helps limit bulk and aids in flexibility from the end of the padding to the camera attachment points. The wide chromed metal buckles that transition from the neck strap to the camera straps are smooth with nicely rounded corners. The rivets are extremely flat and have no raised edges. The attachment to the camera is via narrow nylon webbed straps that fit perfectly in the eyelets on the camera. Excess can be trimmed but additional plastic loops are included to secure the floopy tails, (same idea as what is used on the tail of a belt).The strap gives every indication that it is strong enough for the heaviest of camaras and nothing about this strap will harm your camera's finish  We are very happy with this product and highly recommend it.

Very well made, has a quality feel. Remove the back cover of the remote and slide the base into the remote's rear cover slot. Really only goes on one way with the 'on' side oriented up, (May not look it from the picture, but the base has an incline built into the remote attachment plate...more on this below). I bought two and the remote on one base fits nice and snug. The remote on the other fits more loosely but nothing that can't be fixed with a shim. (Pls note, the fit issue is not with the base...I have two very different MRF2-600 remotes and it's the different remotes that fit differently. pls see below for more info on this) The base is nicely weighted and prevents any kind of tipping when the remote buttons are pushed. It also sits on a full surface rubber pad to keep it from slipping.I have three remotes, two in different locations within our home, and a third in my wifes car so she can turn on the front porch and an interior light remotely. These new remotes are much smaller than those that came with the previous MRF-600 and are very light. They don't come with their own rubber feet like the MRF-600s did so they really need something to help stabilize them and this base is the ideal solution, so I gave it 5 stars.Lastly, you may have noticed that the MRF2 remotes don't all have the same graphical appearance. Two of my remotes are solid white without the darker half indicating the 'off' side. You had to stop and read the fine print on the all white remote to know which end to tap. This base solves that problem by permanently orienting the remote with the 'on' side up.....yeah! It's worth $10...but the s/h pushes the price to the edge of reason....And Now!- It's offered as an Amazon Prime item bringing the price down substantially for Prime patrons. (Should have waited :)

Replacing an old plastic Water-Pik showerhead, this item delivers in spades. My variant in stainless finish Delta Faucet  58471-SS-PK Universal Showering Components, Round Traditional 4 Function In2ition Hand Shower/Shower Head Combo, Stainless has a metal shell, plastic inerds, a stainless flexible hose and substantial stainless screw on fittings. There is a three position diverter at the juncture where the wand hose attaches to the main body; 1) halo, 2) halo and wand head 3) wand head only. The wand head has a push button on the wand handle which allows me to select 1) hard pulse from the center of the wand, 2 ) soft pulse from the center and spray from the wands ring around the center, 3) slow drible from both the center and the ring on the wand, (not sure whether this is defective yet or what. I'll update later. UPDATE: all I can figure is for you to use this setting to turn off the wand rather than to change the diverter).The thing that sets this shower head apart is when the diverter is set to head(halo) and wand, and the wand is set to both spray and soft pulse....you feel like you're in a hard rain....you are engulfed in water....Fantastic. And the wand head rests magnetically and snaps into the center of the larger stationary ring. This provides a frim attachment of the wand to the head(halo) but will take me a little getting used to. The ONLY thing the old Water-Pik had going for it was the ease with which you returned the wand to its' attachment point.My wife suggested this type of 'large ringed showerhead' when she used one in a hotel on a trip we took together. I don't remember that showerhead but this one is wonderful and she's elated, (we're older...it doesn't take much :) )**UPDATE** 19 June 2013: We've had it about 6 months now and have had no problems with this shower head. The stainless shell cleans up nicely with Scrubbing Bubbles and a soft non-abrasive sponge.

I've been using the stock handle for a couple of years, the one with the battery that makes it vibrate. It stopped working a couple of years ago :) and when it recently started to come apart, I figured it was time to customize. I read all the reviews of practically every offering and picked this one. Objectively this handle is larger in every dimension and slightly larger in diameter. Additionally it weighs A Lot more.....so much more it'll take some getting used to.  The knurling could be a bit deeper or more 'grippy' but it is satisfactory.This thing really is heavy and you'll have to figure out the balance. The finish is highly polished and all edges are smooth. The blade locks up nice and tight and releases smoothly.
Clip and terminal ends are tight. Jacket is silver gray and flat in shape. Length is as advertised. What's not to like? I would purchase this product again without hesitation.

This is a nicely made all metal laser pointer that takes 2 AAA batteries. The casing is brass to which is permanently bonded the front end from which the laser emanates. The clip end unscrews providing access to the battery compartment. I looked for a pointer whose clip was not crimped into the side of the body. If the clip bends, then you sort of have to deal with a bent clip that doesn't do its job. The clip on this pointer is part of the tail cap and can be re-bent if necessary.This pointer does not have a strobe function or a constant on mode and I did not need these features. Dot size and output are right in line with all the other pointers I've used. So in general, it's a single function laser pointer that I think is well made. Cannot attest to longevity but will update.

Protective glass for lower, large LCD screen only. Fits like it was made for the D7100 as well as for its intended use on the D600. Would help to do this in a ZEro dust environment but otherwise goes on without any problems. (If you do get a spec under the new glass, expect what looks like a small bubble that won't come out). Highly recommended. Look elsewhere for a protector for the upper screen...it's not included in this kit. This is my second purchase of a screen protector for the D7100; the first not suitable but which happily did provide a perfect 'stick on' window for the upper screen. Look here, GGS III Generation DSLR LCD Screen Protector for Nikon D7100, for my review of my first purchase, an alternative to this protector.

Used on my gas dryer, this product replaces an old 'disintegrating' plastic vent hose, (which should never have been used on a hot exhaust appliance in the first place). If you have to cut it, be advised that it will helically tear if you're not careful. I was concerned about its' crush factor, but the sidewalls hold up well and it will bend around tight corners without crimping. I use high temp HVAC aluminum foil tape rather than hose clamps to secure the ends. I would not hesitate to purchase this again and recommend it as a safer way to vent hot dryer exhaust.
These excellent ties snug down tight and don't inadvertently release. Tie after tie, same positive lock-up. Quality control, or manufacturing tolerances, appear to be spot on.

This review is a mixed bag of functionalily and mis-representation. I wanted an adhesive tie mount that was predrilled for support screws, if needed. I do not like the kind with the hole in the center since in use, the tie tends to catch on the screw head if just the right kind of screw is not used. And if tightened down too tightly, even ever so slightly, they tend to cup. So I saw these with what looked like holes on the four sides....Great! But that's not what I got. I received the correct quantity but of the kind with the a single screw hole drilled in the center. I'll keep them but it's not what I thought I was going to get and they won't work as well for my needs.

Nothing to write home about here...two ply, full size sheet...so what. It doesn't hang together long enough to use it. Maybe because the two plys are so very thin and separate easily. So what you wind up with is two very thin, unsubstantial layers that together don't provide the strength to do the job. Try one roll, or buy a package of four...Maximum, and try it. Please don't buy a case like I did.

Not much to this brief and that's perfect for me.  From front to back: A couple of zipped front pockets; a shallow outer and large inner that is compartmentalized for phone etc. which has yet another inner zippered pouch, in front of an unsecured fullsize slip pocket to which the front handle attaches. Next, the zipped inner main section is lined on the front side and bottom with a 1/4" layer of neoprene that protects a slightly padded slip pouch for either a full size Kindle Fire HD (with Amazon cover) or a full size iPad. Then comes the inner main section that is about 2 1/2" inches wide. You can drop a compacted umbrella in it whithout it stretching the brief. Another zipped inner slip case follows, that barely accomodates a document folder depth wise. Next, outside the main compartment is an unsecured slip for full size documents but still within the confines of the two handles. Finally we have the main outer wall of the brief, not padded with neoprene, to which the rear handle attaches.  One more full size zip secured slip case outside the rear wall completes the brief. Through this rear outer slip case, a roll around luggage handle can be inserted (through a zippered opening in the middle at the bottom) to secure the brief to the top of your luggage carrier. I know what you are thinking and I agree, there are lots of zippered and un-zippered openings and all within a relatively slim brief.Yes, a laptop can be inserted into the main zipped compartment but it'll need to be protected in its' own slip case, and then you run out of room for anything else except for a few relatively thin file folders. And if you carry a laptop inside, forget the umbrella.Supplied shoulder strap is excellent but I tend not to use one.Finally, and reason enough (for me) to buy Tumi, is that it is very well made out of supperior materials; Zippers are strong, clips for the shoulder strap are robust, nylon material is thick, and the leather handles are smooth and well finished. It'll last another 10 or more years of daliy use.One last nice touch, inside the front zippered large pocket is a Tumi barcode that links this piece of luggage to your Tumi account once registered. A phone number is supplied that will assist the 'finder' in conjunction with a snapshot of the barcode in returning the lost brief to its' owner.

I prefer the anvil pruner over the F2, F7, or the F8 bypass cutters, (I have the F8). Though the side cutters are robust, I've actually sprung the blades apart with some tuff material. That said, the pointy bottom blade of the bypass pruner is great for getting into tight spots. See these links for more info on the bypass pruners:Felco F-2 Classic Manual Hand Pruner Felco F-7 Gardening Hand Pruner with Rotating Handle Felco F-8 Classic Pruner with Comfortable Ergonomic DesignI have an Old (!) generic anvil pruner whose bearings were getting sloppy but loved it so I replaced it with the best. Felco pruners are built so well they should last forever...and the blades are replaceable.If you are a purist, then here are a couple of professional recomendations to help sway your decision:"Anvils provide one blade that is pushed up against a flat surface. These are less expensive and are good on dried wood. Some experts also believe evergreens also prefer this type of cut. Bypass pruners allow you to cut larger branches." (I'm not entirely sure I agree that Bypass pruners allow you to cut larger branches and Felco anvil's are Not less expensive!)According to the Master Gardener Foundation of Washington State University, anvil pruners "have a tendency to crush rather than make a smooth cut" when cutting back branches."If still undecided, buy one of each from a less expensive manufacturer and try them out for a year......I have a professional carpenter background and appreciate specialized tools for different needs so, I like having both for different applications.

Wish we could upload pictures but Amazon removed this feature from the product pages (or is about to).  I'd give this garden sculpture 5 stars except for the fact that the supplied picture doesn't quite tell the story.  Looks like the animals are nose to nose doesn't it? They're not.  The noses are offset as if they were touching the sides of their noses.  This is not a deal breaker for me and my wife (for whom I bought it) thinks it's very realistic much the same way our two huskies touch noses.The fawn is painted realistically though I'm not sure where you find a rabbit the color they've painted this one. Two brown criters, though realistic, wouldn't provide the contrast in colors these two do so maybe that's why the rabbit is a sort of a verdegris/taupe. Though the description talks about using it outdoors, I'm sceptical. I just don't think the finish or colors will look as crisp after a year in the weather but this is only an opinion, not an observation.Construction is very curious in the sense that the animals are assembled from pieces, and 'welded' together. Ex; the fawn's right front leg is 'tacked' on and gaps are filled to help preserve the anatomical flow of the limb. This is most evident when you lift the piece and look at the bottom surface. I was somewhat surprised when I took it out of the box and discovered it weighs all of a pound, nothing more.In summary, it has a nice presentation. You'd swear it's larger than the size as listed in the description. We have ours inside on the floor where it'll stay protected.

I had some trouble (see UPDATE below) but ultimately I got it to work; For 1st time setup, follow the instructions to the letter, ex: plug the Gateway into the router THEN connect the power, and you 'should' not have any problems connecting to the internet (solid green light). The wireless connection setup to the thermostat is the same as for all the other accessories and is flawless. Once all the electronic/wireless connections are up and running, you'll have to register the thermostat and gateway via various websites then authorize emails for alerts. This is cumbersome but doable. I've set up a host of email addresses to which the gateway will send customizable alerts and all the settings are adjustable. Ok, but so what? Why do I need this? I set the cool back during the day while away, (but not too far as I have Huskies), and I suppose I could crank it back down (summer) or up (winter) if I went home sick or left early from work. It's a great idea, and it works, but I don't really need it.Somewhat unrelated but I've been trying to upload new thermostat 'Home Screen Icons'. You've seen pictures of the Prestige thermostat with clouds in the backgroung? That is a pre-loaded 'home screen icon'.  I thought this Gateway might offer an upload to the thermostat's 'options' screen but now I don't believe it's designed to provide this functionality.  Rather, info must be uploaded to the thermostat through the USB port on the bottom of the thermostat. I have uploaded an Installer logo but it doesn't transfer to the thermostats home screen. If anyone has any ideas on how to do this, please let me know.UPDATE: I still love this thing EVEN THOUGH I just had a negative experience. I had my HVAC duct work guy over to make some modifications for a new electrostatic air cleaner and he turned off the power to the HVAC system. His work done, he flipped the switch and Everything started back up without a hiccup, the new Prestige thermostat, the Equipment Interface Module, all the peripherals, including a remote control, outdoor and indoor sensors, and, seemingly the Gateway. But then I started to get emails that my Gateway was no longer able to communicate with the system. A quick inspection revealed that all was right with the Gateway, all greens, (power, internet, and Red Link to thermostat). But the emails kept coming and I could no longer control the thermostat remotely. Removal of the Gateway (through the Wireless devices screen) and reconnecting to the thermostat did not fix the problem.  Finally, I entered the thermostat website, DELETED the Gateway account, and re-registered it. This Worked. Remote access is restored. Maybe there's an easier way to restore functionality but I'm not aware of it. Do I have to do this every time the power goes out? Hmmmmmm.........

OEM part numbers don't lie. This was the exact part as specified by the manufacturer and bolted right in. We started this project because of a broken belt (see my review for General Electric WE12X10014 Drum Belt), and upon inspection, while exposed, we discovered the left glide pad had worn through the nylon slide. The drum turns a whole lot easier now with the new glides in place and we just might get another 10 years out of a 25 year old gas dryer. Planned obsolescence take a hike :)

OEM part numbers don't lie. It's exactly what we needed and is in 'fresh' condition. Meaning, it's a 25 year old dryer for heavens sake, how new can the replacement parts be? Well this one gave every appearance of being freshly made. We also replaced the front glide pads; GE WE25X60 Dryer Support & Drum Glide Kit. Good thing too, the left one was through the nylon glide surface and was into the felt under-pad. Rear bearing did not appear to be in need of replacement and was a lot harder to get to so we left it alone. Drum rotates a lot freer. Maybe we'll get another 10 years out of it. Planned obsolescence take a hike :)

As someone else has said this app should be standard equipment on every tablet. Works perfectly on Kindle Fire HD. I use it when I get a slowdown and the problem goes away. My title is relatively acurate but the program will take a minute to scan through all the memory, (32gb).

Just wanted to drop a note about the 'care and feeding' of this excellent dehumidifier.  When it works it puts out a prodigious amount of condensate. But mine only worked about 3 - 4 yrs before I began to notice a drop-off in output. Both Sylvane and Therma-Stor have been wonderful to work with....but finding someone to work on it has been a chore, and its not over yet.Turns out I was on the Last day of the 5 yr sealed system warranty but Therma-Stor had no problems honoring the 5 yr warranty.  Given this thing weighs a goodly amount, I can envision a host of problems packing it up securly not to mention the cost of sending it to Therma-Stor for repair. And Therma-Stor agrees. They told me to take it to any local appliance repair facility (none of theirs in my area) and they would send them the parts, making me responsible for labor only. After all it is quite simply a standard refrigiration unit that works really well at collecting condensate. Easier said than done. The first place I took it was highly rated but I called ahead just in case and they said "bring it in, we'll take a look at it". They had it over two weeks before they decided there wasn't any profit in it for them and told me to come pick it up. The thing is, they apparently make their profit on parts, and mine were covered by the warranty.I have other repair options (brother in law in HVAC business) and will pursue these, but Therma-Stor is proudly a business that puts the customer first. I emailed the repair recomendations to my contact at Therma-Stor and here is the response I received from him this morning;"Mark, Thank you for the kind words. It was my pleasure to help out in any way that I can. That is why we are here. I will process the order to have an evaporator coil sent out to you so that a repair can be made."Several days later and I have a brand new evaporator coil.Thank you Therma-Stor.But if yours ever starts to go bad on you, don't hesitate (like I did) to let them know.UPDATE: Brother-In-Law has the unit and the new evaporator coil. He actually seemed delighted for the opportunity to tinker on something in the workshop. But from another review I read whose evaporator also went bad, it seems some repair facilities just don't want to burden themselves with this kind of work. I'll write again after the unit has been repaired.

Good size for even x/xx-large t-shirts...and it's Hinged! The hinges alone should prolong it's useful life vs those whose folds are just creases in the plastic. Note, it will take some assembly to add the bottom extensions and once assembled, does not lend itself well to disassembly. It will fold back up, though longer than other models whose side panels have a horizontal crease. Still, it fits nicely behind a door or in a broom closet. For assembled and folded up size, please see the additional pictures I've posted above.**Update 25 March 2013**It is being used 2 or 3 times a week. No signs of wear or fatigue at the hinges."

I'm kind of a Titanium 'fan boy' but with good reason. Titanium is truly a wonder metal and excels in lots of applications. It's light, strong and corrosion resistant/proof. Bing/Google/ it or look it up on Wikipedia and I think you will be amazed at its' qualities.Titanium products are also more expensive but with normal use you'll never need to replace them.About the design of this product, the spoon side is a little wide and deep but ok. The fork side is perfect with the tines slightly rounded at the tip. One edge of the fork side is slightly serrated and does not work well as a knife but I get through pizza crust without any trouble, (yes, I eat pizza with a fork, sometimes). You may find the curve a bit of an issue to hold on to but I got used to it. Finally, given titanium is so strong, they didn't need to make this thing very thick so there's not a lot of volume to hold onto. This is kind of hard to describe but it's very thin; not at all like holding on to a piece of stainless flatware.So it has limitations, but given it's one utensil trying to do the job of two if not three and to everyone's satisfaction, I think it's a perfect compromise.Finally I'm never without a utensil at work.  While others scramble for extra plastic utensils, I'm set.  I even have many of the women I work with admiring this spork so I began to buy them as 'gifts' to say thanks for all the food others have bought for me, (and to keep them from borrowing mine :)

I rate this five stars because of how well it does what it's designed to do. Please don't expect it to cut tall grass or even cut very evenly. But, for quick touch ups on mostly level or evenly graded slopes, it does exceptionally well. The blades are 'perfectly' aligned and the cutting action is smooth. Sounds kind of like continuously closing a large pair of shears.I haven't tried to adjust the depth of cut yet, but it's set at about 2 and 1/2 inches which is fine for me. And being so narrow, I'm not recommending it for anything larger than postage stamp size lawns.It's solidly built and should last many years if it's kept out of the weather. Note, the handles must be assembled and attached to the base but this only takes about 15 minutes, and your off.

I didn't do too much shopping around but this shirt seemed to fill all my prerequisites, so I took a chance. Here's what I like:Fit is right on.This color, the Blue Note is dark but striking, hope it doesn't fade.Pattern is very subtle and not visible across a room unless you're in direct sunlight.Very soft to the touchNor would I hesitate to buy from this seller again. Shipping estimate was right on and it came well protected in its own sturdy box.

(Pls Note, I've posted pictures to help illustrate the following review):I wasn't quite sure what to expect but wanted something fast. As a result, and as a first offering, this product may not ultimately be the best choice of a screen protector for the D7100.  Some have argued "Who needs one? It already has a Reinforced Glass screen."  But I have also read how the traditional 'stick on' protectors have cracked, taking the brunt of a mis-directed blow, saving the oem screen below. And the oem Reinforced Glass on the LCD screen is not scratch proof. So I say scratch the protector, (if you can), and change it later at a fraction of the cost.The protector comes with main screen and eye piece protector in one unit (stock photo). To install, you have to remove the oem rubber viewfinder eye pad and slide the new 'unit' down over the viewfinder, (there are grooves down the sides of the viewfinder to line it all up). This centers everything up really well and sort of locks it all in place though there is no satisfying 'snap'.  However, the main LCD screen protector is a frame-like appliance that has no grooves to hold it in place.....it just sorts of sits on top of the main screen, or rather on the flocked edges of the integral frame. The frame holds the new screen protector off the oem Reinforced Glass by about a sixteenth of an inch. This creates the shadow box effect I referred to in the title. So while it all seems to sit in the right position, the new protector's frame doesn't completely seal over the oem Reinforced Glass.  One bottom corner does (right), the other does not (left). Disappointing.  To complete the installation, the oem rubber viewfinder eye pad, slides down over the new viewfinder cover in a sort of stacked assembly.  This actually seems to work quite well Except for the fact that the oem eye pad doesn't seem to slide down far enough...leaving the top edge of the rubber pad exposed and not at all flush with the top edge of the new protector.And last, the little piece of Optical Glass that covers the top window really is a stick on piece, is cut well for the location, and fills the recessed cavity perfectly. No complaints here.This item is not nearly close enough to perfect and I will continue to look for better D7100 screen protectors.

OEM product that stays put, sheilds from aberrant light, and protects the bottom edge of my Nikon 18-200mm f/3.5-5.6G AF-S ED VR II Nikkor Telephoto Zoom Lens for Nikon DX-Format Digital SLR Cameras with B+W filter: B+W 72mm XS-Pro Clear with Multi-Resistant Nano Coating (007M). It was a no-brainer for me.

This filter does its' job well in use on my Nikon 18-200mm f/3.5-5.6G AF-S ED VR II Nikkor Telephoto Zoom Lens for Nikon DX-Format Digital SLR Cameras. I guess my most helpful comment would be that I have purchased 4 B+W filters of varying sizes and all have been flawless in construction and use.  They screw down tight and don't bind all the way to fully seated.  I haven't had an opportunity to compare this to other high priced filters but the B+W reviews were (consitently among) the best so my confidence level is high. These things just get completely out of the way and let the camera do its' job, of course with the added bonus of the much touted Multi-Resistant Nano Coating (MRC).

We love the color and the pattern variations. We wished the color was more consistent from piece to piece. The bottem is flat and the piece oozes stability.The mouth is large for dunking, (primary consideration), and the lip does not drip.We like these very much and will consider the other pieces in the setting.

After 5 or 6 paper towel holders, most recently the ZACK 20702 ADEO kitchen roll holder that just didn't suit my needs (explination below), and before that the Lifetime Brands 4536AS Stainless Steel Perfect Tear Paper Towel Holder that lasted Maybe a year, I'd begun to loose hope that MY perfect paper towel holder existed. First a word about Zack products.  If you are mechanically inclined, you can tell simply by examing their products that they use only the best materials and put a lot of thought into how the products are constructed.  Case in point, the Zack paper towel holder mentioned above is, I think, a marvel of engineering. It assembles simply, ingeniously, and is built to last forever (all components are solid stainless). However, it is way too tippy for me, requiring two handed operation and is not suited for use with the larger rolls of paper towels.So with some trepidation, I ordered this paper towel holder. I suppose you're asking; Who in their right mind would spend over $100 on a paper towel holder? A couple of points prompted me to at least look at 'cost no object' products; 1) I'm ired of replacing things that are planned to wear out...that's just not right. 2) Nothing out there seemed to work well, or had some sort of limitation.In my opinion, this product is not worth the asking price. Having said that, I am once again, amazed at the degree of engineering design that went into this Zack product. The parts fit together like hand in glove, The function is flawless, and with care it will last forever. The product from start to finish was designed to be adjustable to whatever size of paper towel you are using. It accommodates anything smaller than and up to an 11" tall roll and the flapper arm adjusts in and out 'automatically' to the shrinking size of the roll as it is being used. The foot print is essentially no bigger than a large paper towel roll and in my smallish kitchen that's perfect.  And it Doesn't Move! You can can yank paper towels out of it all day and this thing stays glued to the counter. Under the SS base is a vacum mechanism that is unique.  The rubber gasket it sits on is made out of some sort of material (neoprene?) that feels slightly tacky to the touch, though it is not sticky....it just molds well to any non porous surface. Once in place (cause it's not going to go anywhere), grab hold of the base with both hands and rotate it until you get a satisfying snap. While the whole unit is relatively light in weight compared to holders with 'weighted bases' this thing is welded to the the counter.Yes, I'm glad I bought and tried it if only to write this review for you. And yes, I'm keeping it. No I don't work or Zack or any of its' affliates :)

There are a lot of new 'High Tech' kitchen knives out that sell for $hundreds$. Even Henckels offers a variation on this theme. But for my wife's money,(the chef in the family), why mess with a good thing. We've had Henkels Twin Four Star knives for probably 20 years and to her they just feel right, hold and edge, and are effortlessly sharpened. So why did I buy her a Twin Star II instead of the older Twin Star? I liked the SS end cap.Upon inspection, the blade has been reshaped a little to be a bit broader toward the tip but otherwise it's a wonderful SLICING knife. It's the one knife she goes to more than any other; kind of a cross between a paring knife and a chef's knife, (so expect some fexability in the blade). The only thing I'd improve on is the length. 6" can be a bit short for some applications. So guess what I did, I bought her an 8" Twin Four Star II as well. Turns out she loves this one just as much :)The 8" is more to my liking. I thnk the extra 2 inches are handy when trying to slice through a boneless ham for instance. But here again, the blade is flexible at 6" and even more so at 8". Not a chefs knife, but it does 99% of what we need it for in our kitchen.

for the price, this is super. spring clip is Tight! wire clip doesn't line up with notch in hook but so what, for this price i'll bend it to work...or leave it alone. It's for my NG daughter who likes the darker color and who doesn't care if the 'black' chips off a little.

I like this product. It's simple and extremely well made; all solid stainless steel and very evenly and softly brushed.  It just doesn't lend itself to the larger rolls of paper towels.  The roll pictured is probably one of the smaller (fewer sheet) type rolls and certainly isn't 11" tall.  So getting the wider rolls on presents a real challenge. And at 5" the base is really quite small in diameter. An 'oversized' Bounty roll is just under 6" and so would hang off at first, (if you could even get it on). And yes, it's tippy making two handed operation a must.So, Very well made of High quality materials to be used with small or medium size rolls only.It's hard to rate this product. I would give it a 5 on materials used and engineering alone but it's advertised on the ZACK website to work with All sizes of rolls, which it doesn't.

With multiple POVs, Tiny Pretty Things makes us see ballet in a whole different way. With girls having such high hopes for a lead position, non-stop training, and backstabing at every corner, this is definitely an intense novel that's filled with drama. The only problem that I had with it is that it was a little too immature for me.You have Gigi, Bette, and June who are completely 3 different girls going to a prestige and exclusive ballet school with dreams of becoming the lead for some of the largest pieces that are put on stage. But with the weight ins, family issues, and trying to keep your head up high at the same time, it is not as easy as it seems. When girls get hurt, they have come back up and show that they are worth being on stage because of their dreams and their family's dreams.I was shocked at the pave in which this book was written. The characters made me wish that the society wouldn't be so hard on them but having them fight with their inner self and having all the confidence they could get was actually motivational. But the moments where those "teenage love" came out weren't for me. And I am not sure if it was the way it was presented or just me but I did not find them interesting. Overall, the book itself was a great read and I will read more from this author.

Graduating just in couple of months, this book has been an eye opener for me. Although I already have a job and pretty stable on where I am, I know that when I graduate, my life will change. Max Lucado truly is a great author and made believe that my path will be exciting and although I will face challenges, it's a part of life and I should take it as it comes.

Believe Student Edition is a great guide for anyone who is trying to get closer to God and revalue their morals to be more stronger. It is divided into 3 sections for easy formatting and really does a great job of making sure that the teen is good in studying scriptures and understanding more of their meaning. Highly recommended, I agree with the format and think it's a great addition to any household.I received this book free from the publisher through the BookLook Bloggers book review bloggers program.
