We live in an age where most passionate political activists have limited vision, the right being passionate about the horrors of government income redistribution and need to avoid budget deficits, and the left being passionately alarmed about increasing income inequality favoring the ultra-rich, and the need to counter the austerity policies that protect the big banks against losses brought about by their reckless lending practices. I must admit that I am not much concerned with either of these threats, but rather with the growing cultural rift between the intelligent, motivated, and talented upper middle class and the increasingly dysfunctional lower middle class, and especially its male integument, which seems to have lost its way in a society that increasingly values drive, creativity, and capacity for abstract thought over pure upper body strength and physical stamina.It is interesting that the phenomena is increasing recognized as a serious problem by conservative writers, such as Charles Murray and the author of this fine book, Brian Lindsey, whereas the liberal pundits cannot cease for a moment from wringing their hands about the excesses of the ultra-rich. Lindsey is a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, which is a very, very conservative institution, although one whose analyses of society are usually worth paying attention to. The title of this book, Human Capitalism, refers to the fact that increasingly the goodies go to those who have "human capital," which is the result of investing in the development of individual skills and ability to address and solve social and technical problems. This development has long been anticipated, most eloquently in Michael Young's 1958 book The Rise of the Meritocracy.Of course, conservatives love meritocracy (except when it interferes with the inheritance of wealth), while liberals hate the idea (having no faith in the abilities of the `lower classes' and an exalted estimation of labor unions). However, as Lindsey shows, the current meritocratic dynamic is destroying the working class family and leading to a generation of hard-working white collar women with loafing and indolent lovers and husbands. The situation is well described statistically with a minimum of tables and graphs, based on the brilliant research of David Autor, Susan Mayer, and others. This book can be read with pleasure by those who do not care to go into great statistical detail, and the references lead those who do to the proper sources.Certainly this situation, especially the differential effects of modern business organization and technology on men versus women, was not foreseen by Michael Young and the early students of the meritocracy revolution, bit Lindsey shows that it is quite real, and he presents thoughtful suggestions as to how to deal with this situation through social policy.

Decriminalizing recreational drugs for adults may be the most important improvement in life for Americans and the honest people in countries that supply the US drug habit. Most recreational drug users never become addicts, but the 10% or so who do ruin the lives of themselves, their families, and those that they prey upon for drug money. Our prisons are full of people who are otherwise ordinary citizens who have only the high price of a drug habit to blame for their plight.The problem with decriminalization is that it will be effective only if it radically reduces the price of recreational drugs, which means, by a simple and almost inevitable economic logic, the amount of drug use will increase significantly (perhaps double, according to some reliable estimates, based on the long-run elasticity of demand). It is not clear that this will increase the number of drug addicts in the USA, though. Probably the most important test case is Portugal, which abolished penalties for possession of drugs in 2001. According to an authoritative report by the Cato Institute, between 2001 and 2006, recreational drug use among teens actually declined. "Judging by every metric, decriminalization in Portugal has been a resounding success," write the report's author. "It has enabled the Portuguese government to manage and control the drug problem far better than virtually every other Western country does."Nevertheless, it is important to accompany decriminalization with therapy for the unfortunates whose psychological and genetic makeup renders them susceptible to addiction, because excessive use of some recreational drugs is bad for one's health and social functioning (alcohol is of course probably the worst in this regard). That is why I picked up this book.In fact, this book debunks lots of myths and has sage advice based on scientific evidence, but it does not offer a reliable way out of addiction. Its suggestions are mostly completely obvious, such as "addiction is a disease." The best part of the books is his relating the experiences of addicts and their families. Heartbreaking but fascinating. The author is an accomplished writer, so virtually every sentence and episode is expertly crafted. Read this book to avoid some mistakes if there is a loved one who is an addict, but don't expect easy answers.

I have no idea why the eminent biologist Robert Trivers wrote this book. There is lots of interesting material for the uninitiated, but very little on self-deception, and certainly nothing like a proof of his assertion that self-deception serves the evolutionary purpose of being better at deceiving others.

William Hamilton was one of your ordinary brilliant scientists, grappling with fundamental questions in sociobiology all his life. His claim to fame is a single article that he published in the Journal of Theoretical Biology in 1964, "The Genetical Evolution of Social Behavior I." This article gave rise to the terms "inclusive fitness," "kin selection," and "Hamilton's rule," three terms that are explained in every sociobiology article and book. He of course did other things of interest, but in everything else, he was just another brilliant scientist, of whom you might not be inclined to read a long biography. Segerstrale claims correctly that many consider Hamilton the Darwin of the Twentieth Century. Indeed, Hamilton is like Darwin in having shown the world a simple idea that explains an immense amount of biological dynamics. Unlike Darwin, however, Hamilton did not write a Great Book, his simple idea is in fact extremely subtle and not available to the critique of such dimwits as Creationists and Intelligent Design blowhards. This book will not appeal to the casual reader, as might a Life of Charles Darwin.Ullica Segerstrale is a talented and insightful historian of biological thought. Her 2001 book "Defenders of the Truth: The Sociobiology Debate," covering early clashes between sociobiologists, especially Edward O. Wilson, and their critics, especially Stephen Jay Gould, Marshall Sahlins, and Richard Lewontin, is a well written and exciting documentary of this fascinating period. There is no question concerning her sympathies in this book: she gives a rather manachean account where the sociobiologists are Good and their critics are Pathetic.This book is well worth reading, but it is not up to the standards of "Defenders of the Faith." Part of the problem may be with me: I really don't care about Hamilton's childhood, or where he sends his kids to school, or how he behaves at dinner parties. Moreover, his recurrent disputes with journal editors and his dismay at his treatment by article reviewers, stressed repeatedly in this book, is supremely uninteresting. Every academic has such experiences, and they are so common that they are not even worth mentioning.Hamilton is not the sort of Lovable Creature that we associate with the likes of an Einstein or a Freud. He's just your typical brilliant scientist. Moreover, Segerstrale spends only a small portion of the book dealing with Hamilton's substantive contribution, inclusive fitness, and a much larger portion deal with how his other ideas fared---which was about average for a big thinker like Hamilton. She should have elaborated on the development of his ideas in the larger field of population biology and sociobiology. More important, Segerstrale does not appear to understand inclusive fitness theory that well, never deals with the substantive intellectual debates surrounding this theory (most of which are misunderstandings, not by Hamilton), and just acts as a rah-rah booster for William Hamilton. One might describe this book as a Readers Guide to the Narrow Roads of Gene Land (Hamilton's book about his own work).Hamilton's 1964 article is a masterpiece. Indeed, in my study of inclusive fitness theory, have never seen anything in print with the analytical power and depth of Hamilton's original article (I explain this in my paper "Inclusive Fitness and the Sociobiology of the Genome, which is on my web site). Before I read Hamilton's 1964 article, I could not even make sense of standard expositions of his theory, because they misstate and overinterpret it. His article, on the other hand, is extremely opaque, despite that fact that he uses only simple algebra. I arrived at an understanding of his model only by starting with the basic equations, and working backward to determine the underlying model. This model is a paradigm of rigor and clarity.Karl Marx once said, after hearing some of the claims made on his behalf by so-called supporters, "Je ne suis pas Marxiste" (I am not a Marxist). William Hamilton could say the same thing when encountering the bizarre claims of some of his supporters: "I am not a Hamiltonian." By God, he'd better not be!

This is a first rate book in every way. It is short, to the point, the points are all correct, and it is very affordable. It is also quite unbiased (lefties think it is right-wing and righties think it is left-wing---always a very good sign). It central message is that the budget crisis is caused by the voting public, who want all sorts of perks, but don't want to pay for them. Thus we borrow to pay for them, and this is unsustainable in the medium to long run.There are legitimate reasons for the government to borrow, just as there are good reasons for firms and households to borrow. For the government, investments in social infrastructure, education, and other projects that have high up-front costs and whose payoffs lie in the future should be financed by debt. There is no burden involved because these productive projects generate the income to repay the debt. But borrowing for current account purposes, such as paying for social services and recurrent military operations is a no-no. The voting public hasn't figured this out. As Leonhardt puts it, "The problem is us-- the voters. We have not managed to figure out what kind of government, and what kind of economy, we want...The seemingly irrational politicians in Washington are, to some extent, responding rationally to their own confused constituents."The answer to the chronic deficit situation is some combination of raising taxes, lower expenditures, especially the entitlements Medicare and Social Security, and eliminating waste from government expenditure. No one really wants to tackle waste and corruption, although recent health care policies instituted by the current Administration are making serious headway into dealing with health care costs. Republicans have followed the losing strategy of holding the line on tax increases (we owe a debt of gratitude to them for this), while Democrats have embraced heady vision of solving the problem by "taxing the rich." Taxing the rich in the name of "fairness" may be acceptable, but as a means of solving the deficit problem, it is a pipe dream.Why, you ask, is this a pipe dream? Here Leonhardt does not really answer this question. Here it is.The US government does not tax to get money. The government can simply print money. It taxes to reduce the purchases of taxpayers so it can increase its own purchases or transfer the purchasing power to others. The rich predominantly save, and taxing them does not much reduce their consumption spending. Moreover, when it does, the items involved are mostly high-priced non-producibles, such as gems and valuable property. If taxing the rich does transfer purchasing power to the government, it is through the reduction of business investment. This is because the savings of the rich go into banks, and the money is for the most part lent out to investors. Thus "tax the rich" really means "lower investment so we can consume more now." This is a really, really, stupid strategy. Leonhardt should have made this clear."Ask Americans if they are willing to accept higher taxes on themselves," says Leonhardt, "and most say no. Ask if they favor cuts to Medicare and Social Security, and most again say no.'The United States faces a fundamental disconnect between the services that people expect the government to provide, particularly in the form of benefits for older Americans,' Doug Elmendorf, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, said in 2010, "and the tax revenues that people are willing to send to the government to finance those services.' " This is the central message of this little volume."From a purely economic perspective," says Leonhardt, "the deficit remains a manageable problem. Relatively modest changes to Social Security would eliminate its shortfall. Military spending could be cut significantly and still be much greater than in the past and much greater than in any other country. Some domestic government programs truly are wasteful and could stand to be cut. Even Medicare and Medicaid, the heart of the problem, are not intractable." This is a wise suggestion indeed.
The title of my review says it all. The insects are in perfect condition and nicely mounted. The package smelled of formaldehyde upon unpacking, but that comes with the territory.

If you want a rigourous and fairly thorough introduction to the ideas of Tarski, Goedel, Skolem, et al., and you never really understood the Loewenheim-Skolem theorem or Tarski theory of truth, this is the book for you.Do you understand why a logical system that proves its own consistency must be inconsistent? If not, and you think this is an interesting question, this is the book for you.

Behavioral contributions to public policy have become a growth industry. Eldar Shafir is a great experimentalist, but this collection is rather uneven, with lots of dry, government report-style writing. The references will point you in the right direction, though.
The series is an extended cameo for Kenneth Branagh, and he lives up to our expectations. This series is worth looking at---it retains its Swedish aire.

This is a set of facial care products that are not only luxurious, but work well. They have a delightfully light, fresh scent - usually fragrance is a deal breaker for me - I'm annoyingly sensitive to perfumes, but these products don't cause my sinuses to so much as twitch.The wash is gentle and wonderfully foamy and the moisturizer is very nice and seems to work as well as my favorite moisturizer, Eucerine Co-Q10 Cream. It's nice and thick and a little dab will do you. It goes a long way.My favorite thing is the Incredi-Peel. I will be buying a larger pack of these. Only five come with this set but they're so big that you can cut them in half. (I store the other half in a zip-lock bag.) The peel is effective and gentle and feels great coming off.This set makes me  - and my skin - feel pampered and healthy. it would make a great gift, too.

I am very disappointed with this charge and sync dock from Belkin. It claims to be case compatible and since I like a slender case, I expected it would work. First I tried it with my OtterBox MYSYMMETRY iPhone 6/6s Case - Retail Packaging - SCARLET CRYSTAL / FAN RED INSERT. Sure, it's an Otterbox, but it's as slender as that brand gets. It didn't come close to connecting.But no worries, I thought as I slipped on my very favorite (and by far the least expensive) case.Omaker Slim Bumper Case with Soft Flexible TPU Material for iPhone 6/iPhone 6S (4.7 Inch). It almost connected. Not quite. The Omaker is easy to remove, and when I did, my iPhone 6 slipped right in and began charging. (I tried it with a third case - a very slim one - and that worked, but I had to give it a good shove. No point to that though: I don't use that case since it doesn't give the front of the phone any protection.I will use this when I really need to surf while charging - using the built-in cord will keep me from wiggling the cord until too much - but removing a case - when it claims to be case-compatible really irritates me. All Belkin had to do was bring the charging port a little higher in the holder. Sure, I could modify my case, but I really don't want to. Know what I mean? I'm usually a fan of Belkin, but not this time.

My husband is up on the roof this very chilly (for SoCal) morning installing a new layer of roll roofing on our patio in preparation for the El Nino storms. Without these warm gloves, he would be waiting until afternoon to do the work since the cold makes his hands ache.He's pleased with these Dickies. The fleecy lining is perfect. The pigskin leather is soft and supple and covers the entire palm and fingers. On the back of the hand, it's brown canvas and leather. They have ribbed cuffs that keep the warmth in - and grit or grass or whatever you're working in - out. He really likes that.These gloves will be especially great for working with wood and bricks - particularly during cold weather.My husband has always worn large and these fit like ... gloves. They're slightly tight (due to the warm lining) but are loosening up as he uses them.  The little finger, as at least one other reviewer has mentioned, is extremely long and the thumbs are a little long on his very average large hands. (I only mention the thumb because that's never happened before - it doesn't affect how well they work. - and if you have long thumbs, you'll really appreciate those extra couple of millimeters.If the gloves were a tiny bit roomier and the little finger more proportional, they'd rate a five.

This big (to babies, at least) soft fuzzy ball is a delight when it comes to tactile fun and learning. My grandson is only four months old and, of course, can't possibly push on the top to make the monkey pop up, but he loves to see his mother do it. It makes him giggle madly. (As a child, I was terrified of jack in the boxes and somehow I think this little monkey to will help the grandbaby avoid that.)There are different sides to the ball, each with different colors and textures. One has a "mirror" - that's a big hit. It's set into colorful (blues, yellows, and whites) zigzags. There are short colorful ribbons to touch, too.  Another side squeaks, though our boy is too young to master that yet. There are parts that have ridges that are horizontal and vertical. The monkey on top pops out of leaves that make fun crinkly leaves.He's very young right now and his favorite thing to do is push it around in his crib and watch it move. I'm certain he will enjoy it more and more throughout his first year or two.

Ammex gloves never feel cheap and that's one of the reasons my husband and I like them so much. We're both very fond of their nitrile gloves and he wanted to find out if these powderless latex gloves help up as well. They do.He uses these for everything from changing the oil to scrubbing the kitchen sink and dedicates a pair for changing the cat boxes.  While these are not heavy duty by Ammex standards, they certainly are heavy duty when compared with some brands in Home Depot.With textured fingertips to keep a strong grip on whatever you're handling, these durable gloves can be used several times, at least.

I wanted this porcelain angel bell to call everyone to the table at Thanksgiving and Christmas. While the ring is rather soft - not like a metal bell - it's quite charming. This piece comes with a red ribbon so you can hang it on your tree, and it would work well with a large strong-limbed tree. Even if I didn't have cats who consider our 6-7 foot tree their personal Mt. Everest, I wouldn't hang it - it's rather large at about 6" tall.She stands upright on any surface easily. The angel has a beatific face and is detailed discreetly with 24K gold and green holly with red berries. The angel itself is glazed but the graceful wings are not - they're are like a confection, reminding me of spun sugar. She holds a small gold star in her hands. All in all, this angel bell is very attractive and will grace our holiday table for years to come.The piece comes in a nice red box with the image of the angel on top. It would make a great hostess gift.

This is a gorgeous little ring. The band is silver coated in rhodium which makes it very shiny. It's studded with clear and very pale green cubic zirconia and the stones go all the way around the band, which means you never have the back of the ring showing if it shifts.The green stones are obviously green in daylight and good interior light, but in the shadows, they're almost indistinguishable from the clear stones. That's not a criticism, just an observation.My ring is very sparkly and just a spritz of glass cleaner will bring the stones back to full shine if you get them dirty. The ring would make a great gift for someone with an August birthday since the pale green stones look like peridots. Also, it's priced right and  would be fun to wear in several colors at once.

It's purple - I love purple! It's grippy - I love a grippy case! It slips on easily and plays nicely with the buttons and camera. And I almost gave it two stars because the front "bevel" will only protect your iPhone if you drop it on a perfectly flat surface. Asphalt parking lots are often bumpy. My driveway is bumpy brick cobblestone. If I drop it in either place - and I will - my phone's glass has a good chance of cracking.If you like using safety glass and you adore purple and grippiness - this slender case could rate four stars, maybe even five - for you. But a lack of a good front bumper makes it foolish for me, a safety-glass hater, to even consider using.

This book attracted me because it includes ADHD as another name for "brain fog." While I call ADHD another name for "creativity," it is true that the fog is a frequent and less aspect of it. If I - or my equally ADHD husband - don't get VERY interested in something, we forget about it - and that can be annoying.This simple book offers answers to this that are definitely helpful. For ADHD, it's no cure - nor would I want it to be! -  but we find that following Dr. Dow's instructions is quite helpful.The book is about changing your lifestyle over three weeks, starting with sugar consumption. You begin by cutting out all sugar for a week - which is very difficult at first. But the main focus is on paying attention to all the forms of sugar that are added to processed food and trying to eat more naturally. We've been doing this for a while - since well before receiving the book - and I can honestly say that these days an apple or orange is more of a treat than a cookie. (Maybe not a cupcake, but you won't crave it so much.) Go for less-processed foods, get rid of the excess glucose added to those products, the chemicals and additives, says Dow. It's true. It helps.Dow says that this, along with a reasonable amount of exercise and some form of meditation - whatever works for you - will help rebalance your  your brain’s serotonin, dopamine, and cortisol. It does work and you won't suffer that lack of added sugar for long. If you are ADHD like we are, don't worry - it will only improve your creativity and lessen the less-welcome aspects of your busy brain.If you're not ADHD, I have absolutely no doubt that following Dr. Dow's methods will improve that fog and make you healthier, too.  My husband, who fights depression, has found he's fighting far less of it since getting rid of the sugar-caused blues, and now that he's meditating (he already exercised enough) he's feeling lots better, too. I can attest to that: he's far more pleasant to be around.

Viva Labs' glucosamine-chondroitin-MSM supplements are the best anti-inflamatory I've found. The future is finally here, ever since I saw Back to the Future II I’ve been dreaming of owning my own hover board and going on adventures. This isn’t quite the hover board, but the closet thing we can get to it. The hottest holiday gift item of 2015! With this bad boy you can reach speeds of 7 in a half mile an hour on this balance board.The design is very sleek and comes in 2 colors. I purchased the black one as the Blue LED lights that light up under the board looks AMAZING! Comes with a very nice travel bag. Great way to take your self-balancing scooter and impress your friends or use to get around in the mall or parks, etc. The royal blue carry bag is durable and stylish.PROS:☢▱▱☢ The future is here, your own equivalent hover board.☢▱▱☢ LG Lithium Battery, excellent brand and long lasting.☢▱▱☢ Fast Speeds☢▱▱☢ Easy to maneuver and control☢▱▱☢ Comes with bumper guards and carry bag as well as battery charger and manual.☢▱▱☢ Looks Fantastic!!!CONS:☢▱▱☢ NONEThe best feature of this balancing scooter compared to others is the battery life. This uses a LG Lithium 18650 battery, so it charges really fast and lasts for longer periods than other balancing boards. Just takes one hour to fully charge so you can hit the road with your personal transporter.Very easy to use, at first you’d think it’d take a long time to get used to it. It’s nothing like riding a skateboard, this is very easy to use, ages 13+. Once you have it fully charged, which I recommend doing when you first get it, to expand the battery life. You just turn the power switch on. 2nd, step on with one foot and activate the magical self-balancing system, then step on the other foot. Try to stand straight when first getting on. Then shift your weight forward to move front and backwards to slow down and reverse. It’s like using the balance board on the Nintendo Wii, except this is thing is actually moving!The motors are very intelligent in that if you apply pressure on only one foot, it starts to rattle abruptly. This is an indication that you can’t move forward in this situation. Pressure needs to be balanced on both motors in order to move. Both motors have a blue LED light in the front which gives it a cool look and gives you some light as you navigate at night. The lights turn blue as soon as the balance sensor is set to green when you stand on the pads. The lights also act as an indicator light, so if you are turning, the turning side light starts to blinks and automatically turns back to solid once the turn is complete.This is very well packaged. The weight is pretty heavy which makes it feel like you have the real deal. The balance board is roughly 28 pounds. Comes with free bumper guard adhesive that you can attach to the hover board. I highly recommend this for anyone thinking of purchasing for themselves or a nice gift. They will thank you for it. I received this product at a discount rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

The quality of this pillowcase enhances any kind of pillow you own from down feather, standard fill, to memory foam, or bamboo pillows. I love sleeping with this pillow cover. This is high-quality standards and the best pillowcase I’ve ever owned. This comes in 19 momme silk, as it’s measured in weight. The higher the number of momme the heavier and better quality of silk. Industry standards range from 10 to 15 mm of pure silk but this brand by OOSILK is 19 momme. I have yet to find a product over 19 so this is one of the highest out there and should be strong enough to last for years. Mulberry silk is super soft and feels wonderful when resting your head. Mulberry silk is usually cultivated by silk worms that fed on mulberry leaves and the chameuse silk refers to the final product. *I received this product for free in exchange for a review*DESIGN - Like other Willnorn products I've tested, the design is sleek and minimalist. The 6s case (also compatible with a 6) is one piece that snaps snugly and carefully around the phone. The thinness means that it works with any charging cable and the button cutouts are aligned perfectly.PROTECTIVENESS - Here's why it gets 4 stars instead of 5. I'm just not convinced something that thin and firm can cushion any impact onto a hard surface. Most protective cases are built to absorb impact, but the hard edges and backing of this case will deflect impact, meaning that you're fine unless the impact shatters the case...and at 0.7mm thick, the case's most impressive feature becomes less so.Overall, this is a good phone case, but not the best I've seen. If you're looking for something minimalist though, this is the one to check out.

*I received this product for free in exchange for a review*PROTECTIVENESS - This case from Willnorn boasts that it is a "thin armor." I hesitate to test that theory because it is incredibly thin and is simply a hard plastic. Usually, hard plastic cases are MORE prone to breaks because they don't absorb impacts well. I really like the sleek look, but I'm not convinced I trust it on protectiveness.DESIGN - This is a lightweight, minimalist style that looks sleek and stylish. It comes in two pieces (back and front plate) that snap together. Others have said they felt the case was too tight, but this case is meant to wrap snug and seem like it's part of the phone. Beautiful design! However, one discrepancy from the product photos and the actual product is that the brand name Willnorn is painted in white on the back of the base, not etched or branded in like the promo pictures show.COST - Given that this comes with a tempered glass screen protector, this is a good deal for a basic phone case. Buy this if you want something sleek and minimalist, and you don't think you'll drop your phone much.

This is a upgraded model of the old QY8, though the upgrades and updates seem to be minor at most. That's not a dig on the product, as both the old and new models are quality products. If you already have the old model, you probably don't need an upgrade.DESIGN: This model is simple in its design: just one about 2 foot long cable connecting two ear pieces. Easy enough. The cable itself can be adjusted with an included hook. The only downside is that all the volume and other control options are located on the ear piece, which makes it difficult to use easily.SOUND QUALITY: No problems whatsoever here. Very good sound quality.FIT: This is critical. It's awful to have earbuds that look nice and function well, only to not fit. The average sized ones that come attached worked well for me, but if they don't, then this set comes with several different sized extra earbuds to choose from.Overall, there's really no doubt about this. This is quite a good product. It's a little bit on the expensive side for earbuds, but the extra cost is worth the quality - something reflected in everything from the design to the packaging.

I get a lot of products to review (this product was provided for free for in exchange for review), but only a select few replace whatever it is I used before. My old wallet is about 10 years old and due to be replaced. I was dubious that this wallet, which is so much smaller, would be able to fit everything my old wallet did...but I was wrong.CARD SLOTS - This wallet has two outside card slots with vertical inserts and six inside card slots with horizontal inserts. The outside card slots hold firmly, which is very important, yet were wide enough that I could fit two cards in each slot. The inside card slots are made a bit tighter and will fit one card.ID WINDOW - The driver's license/ID card slot is exterior. That can either be a good thing or a bad thing based on your preferences. I haven't decided how I feel about it yet.MONEY CLIP - This is what I was most concerned about, but in the days I've had it, it's proven to be an invalid concern. This clip is flexible enough to hold a decent amount of cash, yet will securely hold even a single bill.OVERALL - If you want a wallet that has a space for pictures of your kids, to carry receipts, change, or anything else, this is not for you. This is a minimalist wallet, meant just for cards and cash. But it does exactly what it's supposed to do: be a slim, streamlined wallet. In the picture below, you can see that this wallet FULL is thinner than my old wallet EMPTY and flattened as much as possible. I have a new wallet!

Children need to know about private parts. That’s how Justin and Lindsay Holcomb’s book God Made All of Me begins. On the surface, that seems obvious, but past parents really do a poor job of talking with their children about the private areas of their body.All too often, private parts are treated as dirty or shameful. When a young boy touches himself in public, a parent might slap the child’s hand and say “No, that’s dirty.” I’m all for “don’t touch your penis in public,” but the message you’ve just sent to the child is that there is a part of him that is dirty and shameful. Parents need to know how to balance the message that God Made All of Me with the message that not all of me is to be shared and that not every touch is good.This is especially important because, as the authors state in their parental preface, One in four women and one in six men will be sexually abused in their lifetime. Go to a park with your kid. Watch the children there playing and let that statistic sink in. It’s absolutely horrifying.Education is important in preventing inappropriate sexual behavior or contact. Teaching your child to say NO! to unwanted touch (even if it’s just overly-huggy Auntie) is imperative to your child’s safety.What I loved about this book is that it is positive. The message is “God made all of me and all of me is good.” Another refrain is “Some parts of your body are for sharing and some parts are not for sharing.” Then, one of the most powerful statements in the book: “If OK to say no because we don’t always want to be touched even if it’s by someone you love.”God Made All of Me teaches the correct anatomical terms for “private parts” and defines them as “the parts covered by your underwear or bathing suit.” This is important because there are so many parents afraid to teach these terms, which just lends a vague uncertainty to an already confusing part of the body.God Made All of Me teaches children that they are in charge of their bodies. They have the authority to say stop, all done, or no more. It very clearly advocates that children tell their parents of any such times they have felt uncomfortable by a touch. The book ends with a discussion of the difference between secrets and surprises. Secrets are not good. Surprises are. You shouldn’t keep a secret that makes you feel confused or sad.As a parental addendum, there is a couple pages detailing nine ways to protect children from sexual abuse. It’s complete, comprehensive, and serves as the underlying structure that forms the book. This is perhaps my only concern about the book - not that this part is poorly done, but that it isn't intended for children. There's a kid-friendly meat of the book, but the beginning and ending content that is addressed to parents is just that, addressed to parents. I feel that the beginning and end material should have been detachable or come with the book in such a way that children could focus on the child-centric parts without being exposed to the beginning and end.In all, this is a must-read for your children. It puts big, confusing, and even scary concepts in terms that are easily understood. Perhaps more importantly, it serves as a great example to parents on how to speak to their children on the topic outside the book. Let me be clear: you cannot just read this book to your children and call the job done. This book is a powerful tool in raising safe and healthy kids, but it just the beginning of what should be many conversations about their bodies and about sexuality over their childhood. As a pastor and counselor, God Made All of Me receives my full recommendation.

*I received this product in exchange for an honest review.*The first thing that's kinda odd about this is that, of the 12 designs in the product photo, you will randomly get 6 pair. If I had to write a one-word review of this case, the simple answer would be this: posh.This phone case is undeniably elegant. The PU leather backing brings to mind the stylings of a fancy handbag. The gold trim adds a bit of flair, with the whole thing creating a sort of retro-stylish look on what is otherwise a modern-stylish device. It's an interesting mix of cold, sleek, and modern with bling and frills, and Arezio pulls it off flawlessly.Since this case was built with looks in mind, you shouldn't expect too much from it in terms of safety. But you can. The edges are firm and unbending, sure to prevent any damage to your phone's most sensitive areas. The PU leather backing also provides some amount of support from the back of it, and the edge's lip will keep the face of the phone off the ground. The leather backing will also dampen the vibrate sound when left on a table or counter.Button placement is a bit awkward and doesn't work as well as it should, which is why I knock off one star. I'm not sure it'd stand up to heavy-duty use, but if you're looking for a case with flair and style, this is the way to go.*I received this product for free in exchange for a review*

First things first, I'm sorry and I feel your pain. If you're reading this review, you are going through a rough time. No one buys these things for fun and whatever reason has you considering this purchase, I know it's a painful one. I pray that the need for this product is temporary and that your story has a healthy and happy ending.I can't do much to help, really all I can do is leave the best review I know how to leave. So, let me help where I can:SIZEThe mattress is 36" wide, 78" long, and approximately 3" thick (when inflated). The standard hospital bed is 36" x 80", meaning that this product is intended for, and therefore is a perfect fit for, an in-home hospital bed. However, all too often, hospital beds are not available or not desired. A twin mattress is 38" x 75", which provides a fairly good fit. In the pictures below, the mattress is on a king size bed (76"x80").STABILITYIf you use this product in something that is not a hospital bed with sides, you may need something to secure this mattress to the bed to keep it from sliding. It does not come with straps to tie it down as it is intended for use in a bed that would not have any chance for slippage. (However, the instructions manual does seem to indicate it should come with straps). An appropriately sized yoga mat underneath or twin mattress topper on top will help.SHEETSEven if being used on a larger bed, cover this in a twin sized sheet to help with comfort.MATTRESS PRESSUREAs seen in the pictures below, the pressure is adjustable in a range from 1 to 5. The box indicates a pressure range from 70-130mmHg, but the instructions manual indicates a range from 35-130mmHg (0.75-2.5psi, roughly). Though I have no scientific method of testing, I believe the range on the instructions manual to be the correct one. I have submitted this question to the company for clarification and will update my review when they reply. (As a sidenote mmHG is the medical unit of pressure, the same unit blood pressure is measured in.)CYCLE TIMEThe bed alternates pressure every six minutes. Pleas note this does NOT serve as a substitute for manual movement of the patient. This product will aid in the prevention of bedsores when used alongside standard medical practice for preventing bedsores, it will NOT prevent bedsores on its own.INSTALLATIONSetup was easy and took just a few minutes. Very intuitive.RANDOM THOUGHTSThis took about 4 minutes to fully inflate.It's very quiet for a running motor.The rubber tubing is high quality.The electrical cord requires a 3-prong outlet. Unless you have an outlet at the foot of your bed, you may need an extension cord. However, the tubing length combined with the cord length allowed me to wrap it back around the side of the bed to an outlet about 6 feet away.CONCLUSIONSThis product works wonderfully at a very good price. I highly recommend it for any temporary need. For a long-term solution, I would seek the recommendation of a doctor or medical supplies professional.

*I received this product for free in exchange for a review*Ever worried that you'll drop your Go Pro and it'll sink to the depths of the ocean? If so, this is for you. It's one step above a regular wrist strap in that, should it ever come off, it'll float right to the surface. The product works exactly as intended (it's a small flotation device...hard to screw that up) and easily attaches to your Go Pro or other similar device.WRIST SIZE - This is my only concern about the product, as another reviewer notes. I have an average sized wrist that's 7" in diameter and this was tight on me. If you unsnap it, it is still held together with a smaller band, adjustable from 12-14". That's a rather large difference, making it more of a forearm band, which doesn't work for use with the Go-Pro. I give it 4 stars because it works, but take a star away because of it potentially being uncomfortable.

If you're an athlete or weightlifter, you know the importance of wrist support. I'm a former gymnast (current coach) and, after two broken wrists, any intense floor, pommel horse, or parallel bars training required wrist support. I played around with a bunch of different wrist supports and found a pair that I love. Used it my entire competitive career and still keep them in the closet (ya know, just in case). So, I have a LOT of experience and high expectations with wrist supports.These mostly met my expectations. Easy to put on, easy to adjust tightness, good velcro straps, and allows for support with flexibility.If you have a severe wrist injury, or are recovering from one, you might need more support. Flexible, cloth wrist wraps can only do so much. If you're recovering from a wrist injury, a hard brace always beats a soft support to start out.The only thing I didn't like about these was the thumb strap. It's fine for most uses, but not for gymnastics purposes. No worries, just tuck it in or cut if off if you don't need it. It's there to serve to align and stabilize the brace, but you can manage that just by putting it on well.I'm difficult to please, but these meet my standards!

*I received this product in exchange for an honest review*SIZING: This is one size fits most and will be a little loose on those with smaller hands and little tight on those with larger hands. I'm average sized. Hand measurement from wrist to tip of middle finger is 7.5" with 4" width and these fit rather perfectly. The gloves themselves are 5" wide. If your hand is wider than 5", it will not fit you.HEAT RESISTANCE: Placed my hands in a 400 degree oven and you could definitely feel the heat, but it didn't hurt. You could just tell it was warm. These are not recommended for temperature lower than -40 or higher than 425 Fahrenheit. These would also be great for working with dry ice.DEXTERITY: You're not going to be able to play the piano with these on, but it certainly gives you more dexterity than an oven mitt. You can also pluck hard boiled eggs straight from the pot with these on.Overall, these are really good quality and if you need something a step up from an oven mitt and your hands aren't too big, they'll work!
