This is poorly made and will not stand up to any stress whatsoever.It's laughable that the company believes that this would restrain a 60lb (or is it 70lb? The product description and title disagree) dog. Maybe a tiny lap dog. Maybe. The leash diameter is tiny and the plastic housing is flimsy. Frankly, you get what you pay for, I guess.Simply put, this is a waste of your money. It will not work.

QUICK HIT – Intersect is a five-week short film resource for small groups to help engage others in spiritual conversations. The storytelling element is wonderfully done, the discussion questions and study guide a bit lacking. It’s a good resource, but be prepared to put in some legwork to use it in your small group.Intersect hits my heart in a very important place: it absolutely loves Story. The series is subtitled Where Your Story and God’s Story Converge. That’s right in my wheelhouse, it’s the same kind of worldview I have. (Hint, hint…just read the name of this website.)The series was made by the Awaken Movement, headed by Rob Peabody and Cris Rogers. I first met Rob a while back when I read his book Citizen and later interviewed him here. It was a wonderful conversation about the kingdom and about storytelling. They were in the middle of working on Intersect then, so I’m especially happy to be able to see the final product now.Intersect is five short films of about 5-7 minutes each. The five topics are:ExpectationsRestDisappointmentTrustControlThe story begins with different individuals telling their stories. For instance, in the film on disappointment, a man discusses his unexpected and unwanted divorce just before his second anniversary. The story ends with a discussion of wider application. Where was God here? How does this story apply to your own? Where does God’s story converge with ours?The goal of the film series is to start conversation s. These five areas are universal areas of struggle. Learning how Jesus can come into these universal areas opens others up to the practical realities of the Gospel: that Jesus isn’t just for heaven and on your deathbed, but has real power, now power, I like to call it.The cinematography is quality and the stories and video discussion are thought provoking and conversation starting. My one complaint is that there’s just not really enough to follow it up. Intersect comes with a discussion guide that divides each section into five questions. In general, the questions are divided as follows:Topical question about the video’s theme.Deeper question about the root of that theme.Question for the specific story in the video.A Bible passage with a question about how it relates to the themeA challenge to seek God’s truth in relation to the theme.That’s a wonderful and thorough structure, but one question per section is not enough. Unless you already have a very open and talkative small group or a very short small group time, it’s going to be hard to fill the time and keep conversation flowing.I don’t mean that Intersect should throw in questions just for busywork, but based on my experience, it’d be tough to fill more than 30 minutes with the material provided. These themes aren’t so narrow that only one discussion question can be raised from them and more could have been done to develop the Bible study side of things.With that said, you can always develop these yourself, just be aware of that ahead of time. For what it’s worth, I think the video content is worth the extra prep time, but based on the video alone…this one gets 3 stars.

Before I actually get into the review, I want to address something I've seen happening a lot recently. If you look at the different "colors" for this product in the product page, what you actually get is totally different products: a $25 aluminum watch-only stand, a $10 bamboo watch and phone stand, a $17 metal watch only stand, a $25 rose wood 3-in-1 stand, and the $17 3-in-1 bamboo stand that is actually listed. You could buy any of these five products and a review for any of them would be placed alongside this review of the bamboo stand. This just doesn't make sense to me. Different colors, yes; but different prices and products, no.With that said, I was initially excited about this 3-in-1 stand because I thought my app developer of a father-in-law would like it to store/display his Apple devices. Unfortunately, this fell short.APPLE WATCH STAND - The Apple Watch stand is detachable from the baseplate and secured by magnets. The reason to detach it is to be able to run the Apple Watch charger down the side and underneath, effectively getting the cable out of the way. It's a great idea and decently implemented, although the cuts for the cable are shoddily done and the 90 degree bend you're asking the cable to make will eventually wear it down. Overall, a 3.5/5.IPHONE/IPAD STAND - If you use a case on your phone/ipad (and you should) this will fit awkwardly or not at all. Further, there's absolutely zero cable management, meaning that you can't effectively charge either the iPhone or iPad while in the charger. Lastly, the weight/height of the iPad causes the base to be a little less than sturdy. I can't recommend this. A 1/5.AESTHETICS - Just to give it a plus side, the bamboo wood is pretty and provides a nice aesthetic contrast to the cold, tech look of iDevices. The three pen holder holes in the back is a nice touch.Overall, though, it's just not a good enough product for me to like it or gift it to my father-in-law.*This product was provided in exchange for an honest review*

Our devices need charged. Always. This car charger/power bank is a good way of making sure they stay that way. This 2 port charger is a two-for-one special. By day, it charges your device as you drive your car. By night, it charges your device from the external power bank. Okay, forget the night and day metaphor. The big perk of this device is that, if you need to charge your phone in your car but your car is off, you can use the power bank and not drain your car battery.POWER BANK SIZE - At 2800 mAh it holds a charge equivalent to the battery life of a Samsung Galazy S5. The iPhone 6+ is a bit larger at 2,915, while the iPhone 6 weighs in at 1,910. Basically, this will get you 1-1.5 full battery charges if it begins at full capacity.TWO USB PORTS - As it should be, because I most need to charge my phone on road trips, which is when EVERYONE needs to charge their phone. Just plug this in the front seat cigarette lighter and your front seat passengers are good to go. Grab a couple of cheap 3 foot charging cables to keep in your car so you'll never be without a cable.PRICE - At $10, it's a price that really cannot be beat. I highly recommend it.*I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review*

So you've got a brand new iPhone 6S Plus. The newest and biggest out there. Only stands to reason you'd want to make sure that you're protecting your mini-computer/phone the best you can. This 2 Pack is an good product for its purchase price, just be sure to apply it correctly. Some other reviewers have complained about alignment, but I had no issues.My one complaint is that the protector doesn't extend to the bottom of the iPhone, instead cutting off near the bottom part of the home button. Corners and edges are the most likely places a phone can break and are in need of protection. It also makes the phone feel weird, as it now has a slight lip right at the home button.This gets an A on protection and price, but a D on aesthetics. 3.5 stars overall. Amazon rating says 3 stars is "it's okay" and that's what this product it. Not terrible, not awful. Just okay.

I work in a small Christian preschool/early elementary that's been on an organizational kick, updating the signage in classrooms and labeling every area. They needed a cute way to do it, so when I was offered these labels in exchange for review, I jumped at the chance. I must say, they have been A HIT.DURABILITY - I was worried that, at such a low price point, the quality of these wouldn't be so great. You do have to be careful when peeling off the backing, but other than that, if you're careful, these are quite durable and suitable for a number of uses. You can unstick/restick these, but I'd limit the number of times you do so.ERASABILITY - These labels can be erased, which is both a high point and potential trouble area. Like any liquid chalk, it does tend to smear a bit after a while, but that's hardly a problem. It's difficult for them to get "accidentally" erased, but it does happen.PRICE - Really, at this price point, it's worth the price even if it's not reusable. I could see this being especially valuable if you can or preserve your own fruits/vegetables.
Just like the ones sold in stores, except a bit bigger. Perfect for late night cravings.

QUICK HIT – Gideon is a goat herder in first century Israel…and he keeps finding himself in the middle of some pretty strange and important events. At the center of it all is this guy named Jesus. The Big Pig Stampede is a wonderful amalgam of stories riffing off of one of the greatest stories ever told.Want to engage your child in Scripture in a way he or she might find more fun than just straight-up reading the Bible? (Though encourage that too!) The Big Pig Stampede is your answer. Bob Hartman’s series of short stories tells some of the craziest moments of the Gospels from the eyes of Gideon, aka Goat Boy.The story progresses in a somewhat linear fashion as Hartman tells the story first person narrative from Gideon’s perspective. Some of the stories lie on the periphery; others he gets put smack dab into the middle. Hartman really captures the voice of an eleven-year-old well and makes the story relatable and fun for kids right around (or just a bit younger than) that age.The Big Pig Stampede doesn’t preach and isn’t a Bible story book. It’s just the fun tale of Goat Boy and his adventures…adventures that sometimes cross paths with some pretty wild circumstances. But it does always, always, always point toward the True Story. This is the type of story that will leave kids going “Wait. That’s real?” and scrambling to the Scriptures to read the real deal.The Big Pig Stampede is an entertaining teaching tool, one that teaches without your kids even realizing it. (Shh! Don’t tell them they’re learning!) Encourage them to tell you the story in their own words and seek out the True Story together. At about twelve pages per chapter, a child could easily read one story a night. It’s just the perfect length for a short attention span and a budding reader.I really can’t say enough good things about this book. It’s fun, quick, and clever. Oh, and Amerigo Pinelli’s illustrations are wonderful as well. This book is the total package. Put it on your kid’s shelf (or in their hands) today!

Thom Rainer has made a name for himself with what I like to call “blog books”. These types of books are either derived from a blog post gone viral or written as an expanded sort of list article. I Will identifies nine traits of the outwardly focused Christian—i.e. a Christian who is missionaly focused on the world around them—and deftly lays them out point by point.Weighing in at just over a hundred pages in 5x7” page format, this is light and quick read that, frankly, needs a little more depth. I expect blog posts to be list-based, quick to the point, and segmented. Books can follow a same structure, but with more substance. Rainer’s book reads, to me, more like a printed out blog post series than a book. I think that’s a calculated decision on his part, so I’ll let you as the reader decide whether this is a strength or a weakness.Rainer’s nine points are as follows:  I will move from “I am” to “I will.”  I will worship with others.  I will grow together with others.  I will serve.  I will go.  I will give generously.  I will not be a church dropout.  I will avoid the traps of Christianity.  I will make a difference.Rainer moves through them steadily, at about twelve pages per chapter. His advice and his anecdotes are solid and force you to focus on the question of how outwardly focused we are. At the core of Rainer’s nine points is a commitment to community. Community is such an important part of going from going to church to being the church. He also talks strongly about the need to give generously.This is a hard book to review because, although I’m in agreement with pretty much everything that he says, there’s not really anything here that…you know…makes it worthy of being put in a book. Rainer doesn’t say anything new or profound or even substantive. I’d like this on Facebook if it was a link to a blog post, but as a book it just simply needs more meat. Rainer doesn’t feel like he’s very invested in this one.

Thanksgiving is the season for getting together, fixing a big meal, and enjoying family. There’s something about table fellowship that really brings people together and Thanksgiving fellowship especially.That’s begun to get lost in this era of Black Friday chaos and even Thanksgiving Day sales as the season to be grateful for what we have is overshadowed by the season of wanting what we don’t. McElmurry and Miller take us back to a simpler time to a simple story of a family coming together to prepare a special dinner.Each page of the book details a family member’s special contribution to the meal. Mama gets the cooking pot, Daddy makes the fire hot, Sister kneads the dough, Brother bastes the turkey…you get the idea. Though it’s never explicit, the central theme of the story is the idea of family and community. Each family member works together and therein lies the success of the meal. Heady stuff for a children’s book, but it’s couched in a simple and catchy rhyme perfect for reading aloud.Sharing the Bread is an old-fashioned Thanksgiving story that deserves to be read aloud the year round. The simple rhyme scheme—A-A-A-A-B-B-B-B—creates a lyrical pattern that relies on the syllable structure of each line to carry the rhyme’s flow forward. That makes it a unique sounding read and one that will stay in your head once it’s been read aloud.But strong mechanics only work with an underlying theme and there are a number of factors that pull the theme together. Community, family, table fellowship…all of these things make the book more than just rhyming words on a page and into a quaint little book that’ll warm your heart.

I absolutely love the concept of the HeartSmart series. It is never too early to get children into the Word and never too early for them to commit it to memory.The book begins with a child named Emma calling you in for a playdate. You visit her room, you meet her teddy bear, you eat lunch, and then, finally, you learn about the Lord’s Prayer. Emma then takes you line by line through the prayer, explaining it as it goes. You then retreat to Emma’s room to teach the prayer to her teddy bear.I felt like the book was a little slow to start. It’s not until halfway through the book that the Lord’s Prayer is actually introduced. The purpose, I’m sure was to build the context for the prayer and to insert Emma as a Dora-the-Explorer-esque interactive character. Emma talks directly to the reader/listener and asks questions. This is all well and good, but, in my humble opinion, could have been condensed some.I do very much appreciate that the prayer is broken down line by line with an explanation of each concept. The goal of Scripture memorization should never be rote recitation but active understanding of the text. I wish that it would have gone further with this, taking time to explain the “big words” of the prayer. What does “hallowed” mean? Or a “debtor”? Or “temptation”? Be sure to your child understands what he or she is saying. That’s much more important than getting the exact words right.The book (and presumably the series) utilizes the English Standard Version (ESV), which is an “essentially literal” translation of Scripture. The ESV, on average, reads at an 8th grade level, which is why you see some of the “big” words in the prayer. For those unfamiliar (or take issue with) the ESV, the Lord’s Prayer is essentially the same in the more popular NIV. The only difference is the use of “this day” instead of “today” and “deliver us from evil” instead of “deliver us from the evil one.”Let’s Learn about the Lord’s Prayer also chose to include the addendum “For yours is the Kingdom, the power…etc.” This closing phrase has been removed from more recent translations (including the ESV and NIV) because it is not found in the earliest Greek manuscripts. Of course, this does not make the book unscriptural or wrong by including the phrase. I only make note of it in case you, as a parent, are following along in your own Bible—that phrase is not likely to be there.Overall, I get excited about teaching kids the Bible and I get excited about kids reading books and I get excited about Scripture. That makes me triply excited about this book. The key to memorization is repetition, repetition, repetition. Use this book as a launching pad to develop a system of teaching memory verses to your children. Train them up in the way they should go and, when they get old, it will not depart from them!

Full disclosure here: I like Rand Paul. I am wary of politics. I am sure that he has political motivations for releasing this book now, even as I am sure that he does have an honest interest in the faith lives of our past presidents. So while the cynic in me wants to call this a pandering gift to the Religious Right, I’ll refrain from taking that stance in this review.The book is coauthored by James Randall Robison, which is a fact worth noting, since it’s specifically mentioned that he compiled and edited the quotes in the book. To me, that’s not a good thing because it already distances Rand Paul from the actual spiritual content of the book. What’s left for Paul to do? Comment on the quotes set before him and not-so-subtly lay down some of his own political opinions.The fact that Paul has ulterior motives comes just a few pages in on page 6 with the word “Obamacare.” Didn’t take you long to get sidetracked from presidential prayers, Rand! And that, to me, is what really detracts from this book. Rand Paul inserts his own stories, political positions, and current events commentary into a narrative that should be focused on Our Presidents and Their Prayers.Paul, to his credit, does go through all 44 Presidents, though the book lacks a uniform structure. The key leaders—Washington, Lincoln, and the like—all get extended treatments complete with artwork and an excursus by Rand Paul on something somewhat related. Other Presidents barely get a page. Millard Fillmore, for example, barely warrants two paragraphs. Of course, some Presidents give more material than others and that’s okay, but Paul seems hesitant to say that.Moreover, Paul very rarely engages with the Presidential prayers—or should I say, Presidential quotes, as many aren’t prayers but just references to God. Sometimes, Paul seems to forget that there are any Presidential quotes there at all. A discussion of Jefferson leads to his thoughts on warfare. The section of Madison leads to a discussion of his Spring 2015 filibuster. And so on.Instead of a deep look at the personally profound faith of some of our nation’s greatest leaders, we instead get a politically sanitized taste of American civil religion interspersed with Rand Paul talking about…whatever. It takes what could have been a very powerful book and turns it into a shallow regurgitation of a faith I don’t recognize.I’m a Republican. I’m a pastor. I’m supposed to eat this up. And, undoubtedly, many of my colleagues in the pulpits and pews will do just that. But I can’t. There is a difference between my country and my God. And there is a clear delineation in between the two in which one has my primary allegiance. I do not mix the two.What I wanted and hoped for from Rand Paul’s book was an honest reflection of an honest look at the prayer lives of our Presidents. I wanted Paul to interact with their statements. To agree, disagree, wrestle with, and expound upon. What I got was a book that lacks any sort of cohesive structure or message meant to sell Rand Paul’s name to the Christian Right and fundraise for his political campaign.Oops, I guess my cynicism won out.

0:51 MinsI received this product in exchange for an honest review. Here are my thoughts.When you're juicing a lemon or lime (or anything else, for that matter), you want to get the most out of it. No other juicer I've tried has done such a good job as this Superjuicer from One Life Improvements. First of all, it's sturdy. Made from stainless steel, there's no worry that this is going to fall apart. Second, it's easy to use. Just insert a half lemon/lime open-end down and compress. The bowl shaped squeezer inverts the rind and guarantees that every last bit of juice gets out.It does exactly what it says it'll do, just as it says it'll do it. Watch the video for a demonstration.

A while back, I reviewed iPhone 6 Case, GMYLE Snap Cover Glossy for iPhone 6 (4.7 inch Display) - White Marble Pattern Slim Fit Snap On Protective Hard Shell Back Case. I mentioned that I loved the design, but was afraid it was not protective enough. In response to that, the company kindly sent me out this case, very similar in design and structure, but a but more reinforced. Here are my thoughts:DESIGN - Love, love, love the design. The marble background is just beautiful and brings out the stylish tech-beauty of the iPhone. Cutouts for the camera are perfectly aligned, as are the cutouts for side buttons and bottom inputs.PROTECTIVENESS - Look, it's still not a LifeProof, but it's not meant to be. What I like about this one is that the case's sidewalls go up and around the buttons, rather than just being a backplate. That provides a lot of added and needed protection. That design also reinforces the edges, holding your phone more secure and providing greater shock absorption. It also has a bigger lip around the top. Altogether, I'd trust this with my phone.COST - Excellent price point! Couldn't ask for better.Overall, it's as if GMYLE took my critique of the previous case and custom made me a new case to my specifications. Love it! And you will too.

This is a BIG container of coconut oil. 54 ounces big. Now, the seller mentions that quite clearly but I don't think it registered to me until I saw it. At first, I was afraid this would make the oil to be of poor quality, because it's a GREAT price for the size.I've tried a couple other brands of coconut oil and this hold up well. Since I don't use very much all the time, I used what I needed and gave the rest to a friend who incorporates coconut oil in her hair and skin care regimen and she's been pleased as well.One criticism to note, though this is Amazon's fault, and not the manufacturer's. At some point in transit, the jar came slightly unscrewed and spilled out. Luckily, it was just a small amount, or else the entire block's mail would be been covered in coconut oil. I suggest that Amazon pack it more securely, so that it cannot tip over in transit.This item was provided in exchange for an honest review.

This is a pretty straightforward product that has a number of decorative uses, especially for the holiday season. The remote control feature is great, as well. Easy to set up, easy to use.QUALITY - At first, I was afraid that the copper wiring wouldn't be sturdy enough. The wiring is very thin and seems flimsy at first, but is quite durable and maneuverable. The lights are bright and streamlined into the wiring, which gives it a very good aesthetic.REMOTE CONTROL - Most remote control lights I've used are difficult to set up, but this one was almost plug-and-play in its simplicity.I'll be using this to accentuate my Christmas decorations this year ;)

I just became an adult. You know how your parents (or you, if you're the adult) just had a thermometer somewhere. Yeah, I didn't. So I went out and bought a cheap one I didn't like. When the opportunity came to review this ear thermometer by VIVE, I jumped at it.ACCURACY - The normal average human temperature is 98.6. I say "normal average" because some people's resting temp is higher or lower than others. The true test of accuracy is repeated tests at a similar temperature. After about a dozen tries in a few days, the temp was always within 0.2 degrees, between 98.4-98.6.SPEED - As a kid, I HATED having to hold the thermometer in my mouth for a minute or more. With this one, it's just a few seconds and it's done. This is great option for kids and adults alike, but especially useful for those with young children.MEMORY FUNCTION - This is a great way for tracking a person's temperature over time. Easy to access as well.I'm perfectly happy with this. Works just as advertised.

QUALITY - As some other reviews have mentioned, this underpad is not quite up to the standard of quality I've come to expect from VIVE. The stitching is substandard and may not hold up with repeated washing and use. This is doubly true if you intend on using this for house training puppies or kittens.FUNCTION - A water test showed that it absorbed nearly 500mL, which should be enough for most overnight use. Of course, the purpose of this mat is to absorb as much as possible to keep urine out of the hard to wash mattress covering. It will feel damp and not comfortable or smart to continue to lay in.SIZE - At 24"-36," this isn't an entire bed covering, but does cover a good portion of the bed.COMFORT - When dry, the underpad is fairly comfortable but not completely unnoticeable.Overall, this underpad works well, but I do have some quality concerns. Time will tell if it holds up.

Three years have passed since Maviah the slave became Maviah the Bedu Queen—Queen of the Outcasts, Daughter of Yeshua. Those three years have not been easy. Her lover lies in prison in Dumah. She is the leader of all those cast out by the Thamud. Life is harsh, yes, but life is real and worth living as a daughter of the King. And now the time is come. It is time to set the captives free.From page one, A.D. 33 throws readers back into the carefully crafted Beduoin world of the first century, a world strangely foreign to even scholars of the Gospels. Dekker wastes no time getting readers up to speed, meaning that while A.D. 33 can be read by itself, you most certainly will not want to do that. Instead, take some time to travel through A.D. 30. It’ll give you much needed insight into the characters and their motivations.The story is a surprise a minute, peppered with thoughts that make you slow down and think. The A.D. series has been some of Dekker’s most personal work and, as such, let me be frank, the message is not very subtle. Many times I heard Ted speaking, rather than his characters. Take that as a flaw, take that as a highlight, your choice.But the message is wrapped around an incredible story of war and intrigue as Maviah seeks to hold true to identity as a daughter of Yeshua while yet dealing with those who would come against her to destroy her. Though I doubt Ted would forthrightly claim such, I definitely saw shades of Thomas Hunter in Maviah’s character.I shan’t say much about the plot, lest I spoil the surprise. Dekker handles the characterization of Yeshua very well. Usually, “Jesus characters” either come off as less-than-Jesus or incredibly forced and stilted. Dekker manages the balance well, holding true to the teachings of Jesus (for evidence, just see the appendix) while yet making this Jesus seem real to the story rather than a cardboard cut-and-paste from Scripture.Dekker’s historical background is immaculate, a skill he learned, I’m sure, from the great Tosca Lee. He opens up the reader’s eyes to an ancient world we thought we knew, but one just beyond the borders of our experience. By making Maviah an outsider to the Jewish culture, he portrays the story of Jesus in a way not often thought about. How did Messiah affect those outside the Roman Empire?The storyline and pacing flow well, though it’s a bit slow at points. Dekker’s writing is a bit fuller and deeper and makes you slow down to really immerse yourself. That’s not a bad thing, but it, along with many other things, makes the A.D. series much different than his other works.A.D. 33 is the book Ted’s wanted to write for a decade and, coupled with his new spiritual awakening, the passion and power from a story held in so long just pours out on the page. Take a wild camel ride through the desert and join Maviah, Queen of the Outcasts, in her pursuit to follow the man called Yeshua.

Whether wearing your child is, to you, a matter of attachment and bonding or just a convenient way to keep your baby close to you, this ultralight baby carrier is the answer to your problems.SECURITY - The first question that must be asked is "Is this safe?" The last thing you want is for the baby to fall out or for the straps to come undone. Of course, you must always make sure that you have safely secured the straps, but, if secured, there is no way that your baby will come loose without you noticing first. The straps are easily adjustable to fit all sizes, up to about 25 lbs. The strap structure also minimizes the strain on your back, making it relatively easy to carry around your child.FUNCTIONALITY - I personally prefer the front-carrying method, just because you can see your baby that way. However, it can just as easily be turned around backpack style. It comes with a detachable (via a zipper) neck support, meaning that it can support the head/neck of very young children, yet be removed once the child has control of the head/neck. With the neck support removed, the baby could also be faced forward, giving him or her access to view the world.DESIGN - I love that there is a little velcro pouch included in the front. It's just big enough to be useful but not so big as to get in the way. The various pieces fit together well. Like I mentioned in the previous paragraphs, the design really is ergonomic and flexible to the needs of your child. The color tone makes it fit with either gender.DURABILITY - I've not had this for a long time, but from my observation, the material is strong and durable, of good quality. This should certainly, barring abuse, last for the duration of your child needing it and even on to a second child.Overall, I really could not ask for a better product!

*I received this product in exchange for an honest review. Here are my thoughts.*I had been looking around for a replacement laptop bag, so when this handbag/briefcase was offered for review, I thought I'd try it out. Unfortunately, it didn't quite live up to my hopes.SIZE - One of the first things I noticed about the bag I received was that it looked different than the one in the product description. Product description estimates a size of 15.1" x 12.2" x 4.3.". Mine is approx. 14.5" x 14.0" x 4.0." As such, the bag looks more like a square than a rectangle and really messes with the aesthetics of the bag. The decreased width did not affect the bag's ability to handle a 14" laptop (as specified).AESTHETICS - I have seen good PU leather and bad PU leather and this is not up to snuff for the price of the bag. The leather looks and feels fake. It's marketed as a men's handbag/briefcase, but the squareishness of the one I received definitely makes it look more like a purse.FUNCTIONALITY - This bag lacks any sort of clear pockets or dividers inside the bag. There are two small pouches on one side and a small zippered pouch on the other. There are no outside pockets. The inside offers no padded protection, meaning I would not trust it with electronics. As you can see in the included pictures, the main zipper has an extended flap that made the bag very difficult to zip. It took me about 3 minutes and both hands to get the thing closed.PRICE - As you've gathered, I don't exactly recommend this bag. But especially not at this price point. The MSRP, per the tag on the bag, is $98. The $44 price tag here on Amazon isn't even a good buy. There are a lot better bags for a lot less money.

Dare socks have proven themselves to be a quality brand, so when they offered their low-cut socks to me in exchange for a review, I happily cleared out my sock drawer and made room for six more pairs of Dare socks. Unfortunately, my happiness was short-lived. I've loved their ankle-length socks (it's all I wear anymore), but these below the ankle socks are simply just too small.Now, I wouldn't have a problem with that if it didn't clearly state on the product description that "one size fits most" means men's size 6-12. I wear a men's 10.5, which is about the national average. The socks were clearly too tight, and after about five minutes, caused numbness and tingling in my feet.From a quality perspective, they are well-made with a great color pattern that makes them usable for either casual or formal use. I leave my review at 3 stars because, for someone with smaller feet, they'd be a great fit. But for larger feet, they simply aren't comfortable.

QUICK HIT – In this surprise ebook short, Ted Dekker takes readers on a personal journey through his life and how he found his faith again by losing it.I’ve known Ted for a long time and I’ve heard his story and been there as he’s worked through trying to word exactly what this experience actually is. I’ve seen a total revitalization of Ted, both in his person and in his writings and, if you’ve read any of his recent works, the content of this 25 page self-reflection shouldn’t much surprise you.Waking Up: How I Found My Faith By Losing It is an ebook exclusive meant to pair with the release of A.D. 33.My experience wasn’t lining up with what I thought I believed. That’s how Ted begins his story. At the height of his NYT bestselling career. A successful CBA novelist now with a “secular” publisher and writing like a madman. It should have been the pinnacle of success, but it was there he had a crisis of faith.I mean, I believed all the right things about God, but could I really let go of everything…? And this begins a very personal and very honest journey of faith. This is Dekker’s soul laid out, not because it’s easy for him but because it’s necessary for him to share this story. Does Christianity actually change anything?Ted strikes right at the heart, underlining the Christian journey of more than just himself, telling the story of a person who knew and believed all the right things, so why was it not all working out? In the end, what Dekker discovers is that “What matters isn’t our stated belief and doctrine but how we live and what we experience in the story of our lives.”The second quarter of the book is a summary of Dekker’s upbringing. If you’re familiar with The Slumber of Christianity—his first non-fiction book—then you’ll be familiar with most of the information here. All of this leads to his new awakening.This new awakening, as any who have read the A.D. series knows, is all about finding identity, purpose, and destiny in the person of Jesus Christ. We are united with Christ. We don’t have to do good deeds to please the Father, the Father is pleased by our existence in Him. For Ted, he found the meaning of life in being loved by the Father.The last half is a manifesto of sorts, a clarion call for others to jump the divide, to dive deep, to drown in Elyon’s waters, one might say. Go on. Take it. Dive deep. See what love the Father has lavished upon his children.

Compression sleeves are meant to help both athletes and non-athletes with a variety of circulatory, lymphatic, and vascular problem. Compression helps relieve soreness, cramping, and fatigue. It promotes blood flow and supports the surrounding muscles. You have seen some of your favorite basketball players wear one on their shooting arms for this reason. However, these types of sleeves can also be good for the non-athlete dealing with bad circulation or neuropathy.Please note that compression sleeves should never be overworn, lest the body become dependent on them.SIZING - Like with the leg compression sleeves, I take one star away for the lack of definite sizing options. Neither the product description nor the drop down sizing bar tells you exactly what a small, a medium, or a large actually is. That obviously leads to some problems. I ordered a medium, but definitely should have gotten a large. According to the box, sizing is as follows:Measure circumference right below elbowSmall: 8-9.5"Medium: 9.5-11"Large: 11-13"FIT - Can't comment too much on this, as mine was way too tight given it was the wrong size. I will comment that the sleeve length should extend from the bicep to the wrist and, unless you have freakishly long arms, it should do so easily. I was able to comfortably stretch this to 21".QUALITY - VIVE has a history of producing nothing but quality products and this is no different. The material is high quality, firm, yet breathable. It's made to last and made to withstand impacts and scratches. It is a bit pricey, so if cost is a concern or you don't think you'll use a compression sleeve much, you may want to go with a cheaper option. But if you want durability and quality, this is the way to go.I received this product for free in exchange for a review. [...]

VIVE Health has proven themselves to me with a variety of healthcare products and these compression sleeves are another notch in their belt when it comes to a quality product.Compression sleeves help the lymphatic and vascular systems, as well as promote circulation, which makes it perfect for post-workout recovery for athletes or non-athletes with circulatory problems. As an athlete, I'm always looking for ways to stay healthy and, for feet-heavy sports (think basketball especially) these compression sleeves can really help.SIZING - This is where I take off a star. With the current sizing chart, you're left to basically guess whether you're a small, medium, or large. According to the package, sizing is as follows:Measure circumference right below knee.Small: 12-14 inchesMedium: 14-16 inchesLarge: 16-18 inchesIt'd be very easy to add this information to the sizing options box and would help individuals make a sizing selection. I received this product free for review and figured that a medium would work for me (I'm 5'8"), but I'm more a large.FIT - Provided you get the right fit, the compression sleeves fit perfectly. They should (as the image indicates) begin a couple inches above the knee and extend to the ankle. When stretched, these went comfortably to a length of 21," which, unless you have abnormally long legs, means it should work for anyone under 6'6".QUALITY - The rubber lining at top ensures a secure fit that won't droop. The material itself is breathable and thin, yet strong. It's really a high-quality product. It is a bit pricey, but you get what you pay for. If price is a concern or you won't be using these often, then maybe opt for a less expensive pair. For heavy use and good quality, these will do the job.I received this product in exchange for a review. If you have benefited from this review, please consider voting my review as helpful. Thanks!

I really wish the company would be clear whether or not this is MFi certified. A couple other reviews (one five star and one two star) both assume that it is not and nothing in the product description says that it is. I prefer to only use MFi certified cables due to some bad experiences, so I'm not sure I'll actually end up using this cable.I received this for free in exchange for a review, so for testing purposes, I took it on a business trip over the weekend to serve as a car charger. It did it's job well and, most importantly for me, fit in my lifeproof case.Since it hasn't thrown any errors yet, I feel I can give it a solid 4 star review, but if I get a "this is an unlicensed device" error, then I'll adjust my review accordingly. In my opinion, you should only buy MFi certified devices and it was just my assumption that this device was until I read other reviews.

The Psalms are filled with one man’s longing heart-cry for his God. But it is also filled with God’s longing heart-cry for his children. Shouldn’t we be listening? Speak, Lord is all about hearing the Psalms in the first person. Not as written four thousand years ago and not as spoken to a different time, culture, and person. But now. Hearing God speak to you in Scripture directly.Let me give you an example from the book. Psalm 1:11-2 says:  Blessed is the one  who does not walk in step with the wicked  or stand in the way that sinners take  or sit in the company of mockers,  2 but whose delight is in the law of the Lord,  and who meditates on his law day and night.Here is how Black paraphrases it:The company you keep is very critical to me and your overall success. I really want to bless you. I want you to be happy and prosperous. I want others to look at you and be envious of my goodness evidenced in your life.I will bless you if you do not walk so close as to hear and consider the counsel of the wicked. Why should you consider their advice?I will bless you if you do not stop, stand, and lean against the wall where sinners normally travel, down the path they regularly take.I will bless you if you do not pull up a chair and join the environments where the ungodly scoff and laugh at all that is good and righteous.And this here is the essence of the book: learning to take the Psalms and make them yours, taking them from words said to others to words said to yourself. Now there’s no way for Black to give examples of all 150, but he does cover 19 of the most significant and important. After each paraphrase is a section on writing prompts and a section on devotional thoughts, each about a page long.This isn’t a book you can just read, it’s a book you have to commit to and make part of your life. Paraphrasing Scripture is a powerful way of seeing it in a brand new light and discovering the applicational value to your own life. But, the pastor in me also says to be cautious: don’t read into the text what you want to hear from it. Be open and honest with God and pray over the process. Write down what it says, even when—especially when—you don’t like what it says.I really wish that Black had included more interaction and less his own thoughts. A few full length examples are necessary, but after those first few, I think he should have broken it down more verse-by-verse. I say this because, since every example in the book is preceded by Black’s own persona full-length “answer,” there can be a temptation to merely write again what he wrote. After the first two or three chapters, I would have appreciated a more thorough breakdown. Taking things in small chunks makes the task seem more manageable and keeps readers engaged. I know the thought was that there are a 131 other Psalms to sample, but people are most likely to get engaged with what is in the book.But overall, this is a valuable resource and teaching tool, not just for the Psalms but for Scripture as a whole.

Best known for his eponymous biography of German theologian and thinker Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Eric Metaxas has become the go-to person for Christian biography. After seeing his work perform well in a full-length version, Metaxas decided to try shorter anthology-type biographies in Seven Men. With that experiment of success, Seven Women was an anticipated and expected follow-up.A good biography requires two things: an interesting subject and an interesting writer. Maybe I’m just a cynic, but while the biographies are good, there’s nothing in there that makes them great. Bonhoeffer was a massive work of academic precision that shed new light on an before under-appreciated historical figure.Because of the length of these biographies—about 25 pages each, average—Metaxas can really only give a bare bones summary of their stories and thus, at least for me, not really tell me much I didn’t already know. Further, the subtitle—And the Secret of their Greatness—implies that there’s going to be some evaluation, some discussion, about the qualities that made their lives great. I expected Metaxas to spend his space focusing on the singular area for which they were great, not giving a general life biography.Life is Story. I understand that. And when you write a long story, you can tell the whole thing. But as any good short story writer will tell you, in a short story you must be focused, directed, and condensed, The applicational value of the story must lie more on the forefront. I think Metaxas missed the point of a short-form bio when he assembled them as a collection of facts rather than a dynamic interpretation and discussion of those facts.I also question at least one of his choices. He begins with Joan of Arc, which is a gutsy move considering that he writes to a primarily evangelical audience while holding up an individual who allegedly had supernatural revelations from Saint Margaret, Saint Catherine, and the archangel Michael. He discusses none of the theological problems with Joan’s visions or whether or not the visions were a good thing. The secret of her greatness was…listening to the voices in her head? Metaxas seems like he just wants to have included an enigmatic and popular choice without offering any real discussion about her.Perhaps I came into Seven Women with my expectations set too high, but they were certainly not met. A lot of people seem to love Metaxas, but I’m just not seeing it. However, if you liked Seven Men, you’ll enjoy this one as well.

“He will be the preacher.” Whether this was just an offhand remark or the woman leaning over his crib was speaking under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, either way, her prediction cam e to pass.I’ve always been fascinated by the lives of great pastors. What series of circumstances led to their success? How was the guiding hand of God behind them? What mentors and leaders and teachers did they have along the way? Success is driven by God, of course, something Erwin Lutzer acknowledges in his subtitle The Story of God’s Providence in My Life.I am fascinated because, frankly, that’s where I want to be. Whether I get there is totally up to the grace of God, but I also firmly believe that God has called me to make the most of my calling, and that includes standing on the shoulders of giants and learning from their lives. Erwin Lutzer is one such giant.Beginning with his school days in Saskatchewan and his family’s history, Lutzer weaves a story of unlikelihood—one controlled by the providence of God. The most prominent one comes on April 3, 1977, when with about ten minutes before the start of Sunday service, he was asked to preach at the historic Moody Church. Simply this: Dr. Warren Wiersbe, the pastor at the time, had gotten sick and was going home. A staff member was going to preach a message based off of Wiersbe’s notes. Lutzer had never attended Moody Church before but decided so this week because he had just resigned a pastorate in order to complete his Ph.D. dissertation . A “chance” meeting in the hallway. An off-the-wall request from Dr. Wiersbe. And a last-second sermon that built a relationship that led to his succession of Dr. Wiersbe some years later.As the pages go by, there can be no doubt of the providence of God in Erwin Lutzer’s life. It would have been easy to call his success due to his own connections or own competence. But in everything Lutzer gives praise to the God that opened up those opportunities.I especially connected with the stories about the influence of Dr. Elmer Towns on his life. It was a young Dr. Towns who recommended Erwin Lutzer to Dallas Theological Seminary and an older Dr. Towns that encouraged Lutzer to write books. Many years later, a much older Dr. Towns is still influencing lives at Liberty University, my alma mater.Fans of biography, especially Christian biography, will love this book. Pastors need to read this book. Its insights, observations, and experience teach much more than a didactic book of facts ever could. Thank you, Dr. Lutzer, for a life well lived.

Only 35-40% of engaged couples seek out and receive quality premarital counseling. This despite that fact that such counseling makes divorce 30% less likely and results in a 30% increase in marital satisfaction. In other words, counseling makes your marriage last and it makes your marriage better.There are thousands of books out there on marriage and many of them are solid books coming from a Christian worldview. Ready to Wed stands above many of these and becomes a must-read by bringing in a whole host of counselors to talk about what they know best. With fourteen chapters of about 20 pages each, the book’s format easily lends itself to counseling purposes. In fact, I’d love to see a small group DVD series to come from this! (ed. Note: There is! Fall 2015).Part one covers proactively investing in your marriage and begins with the all-important chapter on leaving and cleaving. Chapter author Ted Cunningham lovingly and tactfully covers how to separate from one’s parents while still maintaining a relationship with them. Other chapters cover communication (Joshua Straub), sexual intimacy (Juli Slattery), and an intense focus on commitment (Scott Stanley, Gary Smalley) and spiritual intimacy (Joe White).Part two focuses on conflict management and covers topics like personal differences (John Trent), expectations (Bill and Pam Farrel), chores (Susan and Dale Mathis), money (Scott and Bethany Palmer), and dealing with crises (Greg and Erin Smalley). One thing you’ve probably noticed is that most of these chapters are written by a couple. That means you don’t just get a profession opinion, you’re getting a professional opinion that’s also based on real-life experience.The only chapter I have any criticism on is Greg and Erin Smalley’s chapter on fighting well. While I agree with their suggestions for conflict resolution, I do not agree with the premise that fighting is necessary. Marriage sometimes means differences and conflict, but I don’t believe that those things must lead to a fight. They write that out of these fights comes growth, but can’t such growth also come from dealing with the situation before it escalates to a fight?Perhaps the Smalley’s are defining fight differently than I am. And I do think that’s partially the case. They certainly aren’t advocating having knock-down-drag-out shouting matches. To them, “fighting” means to learn to positively deal with conflict. But I still don’t like the terminology. Fighting pits two people on opposite sides and must have a winner and a loser. That’s the opposite of what conflict resolution in marriage should look like!But, given that my only criticism is quite literally mostly semantics, I’ll let it slide. Ready to Wed is a fountain of needed advice that will start your marriage off right. Stop planning for the wedding and start planning for the marriage.

Anger gets a bad rap. It’s often pictured as wild, out of control, and consuming. Think about the latest Disney movie, Inside Out. Anger is depicted as short (denoting little patience), red (a fiery, bold color), gruff, and easily knocked out of control. But if anger could be a good thing? With that bold premise, Gary Chapman, best known for his Five Love Languages books, tackles the topic of anger and how to control it.Gary Chapman’s first couple of chapters builds the argument that anger is not inherently negative, but can be controlled and tamed and released positively. Anger, he writes, is something that we experience because we are made in the image of God and God experiences anger as well. However, God’s anger is wholly positive and just, an appropriate reaction to sin or injustice. We, as fallen creatures, have perverted anger to make it something negative and petty.Anger, therefore, should stem from our sense of moral concern. It should arise in us when our sense of morality is shaken. He talks about the righteous anger of Jesus, the anger against drunk driving that led to the creation of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, the anger against slavery that led to its abolition, and more. Anger, properly controlled, is a powerful force for good.The following chapters deal with difference aspects of anger, from how to control and release good anger to how to control and restrain bad anger. Chapman also discusses specific relationships: anger against God, anger against a spouse, even anger against oneself. He covers both quick-tempered anger that builds quickly and festering grudges that slowly poison. One of my favorite chapters his chapter on teaching children how to handle anger (it applies to us older ones too!). The closing chapter also does a great job in explaining best practices for dealing with angry people (an excellent resource for anyone in the service industry!).Each chapter (after the first two) ends with a Quick Take recap that summarizes and distills the content down into its bare bones structure. For example his quick take on handling anger:  Consciously acknowledge to yourself that you are angry.  Restrain your immediate response.  Locate the focus of your anger.  Analyze your options.  Take constructive action.Anger: Taming a Powerful Emotion is an important and vital read that redeems a much-maligned God-given part of our identity as images of God. This book is a paradigm shifter that will completely change how to react toward your own anger and the anger of others.

Timothy Dailey’s The Paranormal Conspiracy begins with an intriguing premise: Humankind’s fascination with the paranormal is a Satanic attempt to draw people away from God. Okaaaay…I’m not saying he’s incorrect, but how? Dailey writes that the paranormal conspiracy is a “diabolical plot [meant] to overthrow the Judeo-Christian worldview and plunge the world into darkness and chaos not unlike that of the cinematic zombie apocalypse.” Seriously? That’s not just poor writing, he never actually explains any of this in words that mean anything.Instead, Dailey contents himself to merely talk about alleged paranormal phenomena and alternately say it either doesn’t exist or is evidence of demons. Nothing else. In his chapter, “Beings of High Strangeness,” he begins by talking about Bigfoot sightings and following it with several pages criticizing Bigfoot believers. He then concludes that discussion with a single page basically saying “But there is a lot of eyewitness evidence.He then jarringly switches to a discussion of UFOs and, in the span of two pages, goes through the same formula as Bigfoot: while there’s no solid evidence, lots of people believe. He then concludes the chapter with this bizarre question: “Could these ‘inhumanoid’ entities [Bigfoot and UFOs] be preparing the way for a techno-occult variation appearing in the heavens as fantastically advanced spaceships—proclaiming a New Age formulation of the primordial lie ‘You will be like God’?” Again….what???The next two chapters focus on UFOs almost exclusively, detailing in very boring manner a number of alleged sightings and how they can be debunked. Dailey focuses on alien abductions and draws the conclusion that they are demonic and meant to draw people away from God. But he does this just after talking about how it’s unlikely that UFO sightings and abductions are real! Throughout the book, Dailey tries to both discredit the reality of the paranormal while also claiming it as the work of demons. Furthermore, Dailey fails to realize that very, very few people who claim to be abductees look on the experience as a positive one. Thus, the argument that demons are doing it to…draw people away from God?…he’s not real clear on specifics, so I don’t quite know what he’s going for, is just absurd.The four chapters that follow detail the “extent to which individuals will go to answer the siren call of psychic forces.” The first story is Percy Fawcett’s search for the Lost City of Z. Fawcett was convinced—Dailey tells us in a long and uninteresting fashion—that the lost city was a city of the gods. Long story short, he went and never came back and was never found. Dailey offers this in conclusion: “Misled deep into a jungle trap, beguiled by deceitful spirits, was Fawcett the not-quite-full Colonel.” Again…what??? Poor writing and no real conclusion.The second story, that of Joe Fisher’s descent into spiritism, is probably the highlight of the book. Dailey outlines Fisher’s involvement with séances and communicating with the dead. Fisher ultimately committed suicide, which Dailey attributes to demons or people, he isn’t quite sure which.There’s more to the book, but it’s really just more of the same. Dailey never draws any conclusions, makes any connections, or even fully commits to his own premises. The book lacks any sort of cohesive structure, the writing lacks clarity, and Dailey himself seems to not know the point he’s trying to make. Incredibly disappointing.

The field of apologetics is in need of good translators. In a field filled with jargon from science, philosophy, and theology, it’s often difficult to make a connection with the average person. There is a distinct lack of lay-level apologetics books that find the balance between dumbed-down simplicity and over-your-head-and-boring academics.J. Warner Wallace has proved himself to be a top-notch translator with Cold Case Christianity and the trend continues magnificently in God’s Crime Scene. In the book, Wallace posits the Universe as a crime scene and asks the all-important question: Has anyone been in the room?Chapter one cleverly asks if the universe was an inside job. That is, did the universe come into being on its own? Through the chapter’s twenty pages, he builds a diverse, cumulative case for a universe that has a beginning (and therefore, a universe that has a cause). Philosophical evidence, residual evidence, quantitative evidence, thermal evidence, observational evidence, theoretical evidence: it all compiles together into a solid case for a Creator. But like all good detectives, Wallace considers alternate theories as well. The chapter is filled with sidebar summaries and key witnesses (primary experts on the topic of discussion, both Christian and non) and well-crafted informative charts and illustrations.This primary chapter sets the style and tone for every chapter to follow. The first four chapters deal with origin and design; the last four deal with the mind, morality, and evil. After this, Wallace has compiled a 70 page chapter of secondary investigation, that is, an evaluation and explanation of naturalistic claims. In these chapters, Wallace goes deeper, giving a more academic approach, but still retains the same style and tone.To me, it’s this chapter that makes the book. It’s not necessary reading, but it shows a dual realization on Wallace’s behalf that this material would have bogged down the main points of the book but that it is also a discussion required to make a strong case.Overall, God’s Crime Scene is one of the best lay-level apologetics books of our age. I’d call J. Warner Wallace the Lee Strobel of this generation but Lee is still writing excellent books too! I’m sure Lee welcomes the company at the top of the apologetics game. An excellent read!

For the few of you who don’t know, Dave Ramsey is the host of the eponymous Dave Ramsey Show, the #3 talk radio show in the country. Dave’s no-nonsense guide to getting out of debt has helped millions and, while he’s not without his detractors, the evidence overwhelms them. At the foundational core of Ramsey’s philosophy is the Seven Baby Steps.  Save $1,000 in a beginner emergency fund ($500 if your income is <$20k).  Pay off all debts beginning with the smallest.  Save 3-6 months of expenses as a full emergency fund.  Invest 15% of your income into Roth IRAs and pretax retirement plans.  Begin college funding for your children.  Pay off your mortgage.  Build wealth and give.It’s under that paradigm that all Dave Ramsey advice flows. Disagree with any of the above and you’ll not be agreeing with much else he has to say. The first couple of chapters deal with your relationship to money: both in terms of dealing with budgeting and working with your spouse to create that budget. That’s quickly followed by a chapter on getting rid of debt, which is, of course, the foundation of Dave Ramsey philosophy.I was excited that a lot of the book focused on what to do in steps 4-7. Listening to his radio show, the majority of people calling in are in the process of getting out of debt. I love hearing their stories and his answers, but I personally find myself past that process. I’m interested in understanding investments, real estate, insurance, how to buy a bargain, and things along that line. (Sidenote: Although it didn’t play to me and hopefully never will, the chapter on dealing with credit bureaus and collections agencies was super informative.) This is where I hadn’t heard Dave talk as much and it was great to see his philosophy on paper and fleshed out.I wish that the chapter on investing had more meat to it, although I do realize that Dave has a pretty bare bones investing philosophy. It’s definitely my own personal weak point and where I’m most interesting in learning more.The appendices in the back of the book include all the budgeting forms put out by Financial Peace, which is, in itself, an invaluable resource. Overall, Dave Ramsey’s Complete Guide to Money is Dave Ramsey philosophy to a T. Same conversational style, same humor, same tried-and-true philosophy.

If you've bought a new laptop recently, you've probably discovered an interesting problem. USB ports aren't what they used to be. No, literally. The newest generation of USB ports are smaller, to account for thinner and thinner laptops. So how are you to plug in all your bulky old USB ports? This adapter!It's small, unobtrusive, and relatively inexpensive (Apple's brand adapter is $19). It's a bit of a pain in the butt, but such is the inevitable progress of technology. This is the best adapter I've found.

I'm always looking for a cheap way to illuminate the outside of my house during the night. Not looking for anything too bright, just enough to dissuade any wannabe intruders. I've got a few different systems set out at my front door, but thought this setup would be perfect for the side gate.There is a "dim" setting that stays continuously on that flashes to "bright" when motion is detected. It's a great way to provide security lighting and notify others that people are in the area. It's great for me because now I can pop out the side door to take the trash out without needing a flashlight.Make sure you install this in a place that will get sun. No sun, no light. But with light, this is all you could ask for in a solar charged LED. Perfect!
